**The Profound Virtue Commentary on the Dao De Jing (True Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue)**

**Title of the Scripture:** *The Dao De Jing (True Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue) with Profound Virtue Commentary*.

**Strong Contemplation and Profound Reverence**—twenty volumes. The original source: *The Zhengtong Daozang (Orthodox Daoist Canon)* under the *Dongshen (Cavernous Spirits)* section, *Yujue (Jade Precepts)* category.

---

**Preface to the Profound Virtue Commentary on the Dao De Jing**

The Dao is supreme and without form, yet it gives rise to wondrous existence.
It governs the boundless Dao, fulfilling the marvelous function of existence—
who else but the **Most High Sage-Laozi, the Primordial Emperor**?

Emerging from the **Symbolic Age** (象先), revered as the **Origin of Transformation** (化本),
He was the first to fuse the divine essence at the dawn of countless kalpas,
His spirit divided to permeate the heavens and earth, nurturing all beings,
Molding myriad forms, and refining all things.
Thus, the **Three Sovereigns** received their mandate,
Still adhering to the **Pure Unity** (淳一) of ancient virtue,
And the **Five Emperors** held the **Sacred Maps** (图),
Gradually dispersing the **Uncarved Simplicity** (无为之朴) of the Dao.

Though **Sage-Laozi** descended through the ages,
Adapting to each era’s needs—
Sometimes as a **national preceptor** (国师),
Sometimes as a **guest of honor** (宾友),
Teaching scriptures and transmitting the Dao,
To instruct the rulers of his time—
At the outset of the **Tang and Yu’s abdication** (唐虞禅让),
When the **Way of the world was in decline** (世道交丧),
He raised the **Primordial Virtue** (元凯) in the wilderness,
And practiced the **Four Offenses** (四罪) in court,
The **Veneration of Worthies** (尚贤) was manifest,
Yet the **Age of Corruption** (瘴恶) also emerged.
Though inner harmony was upheld,
Outer strife persisted—
Human hearts grew cold,
The **Uncarved Simplicity** of the Dao faded like mist.

**Sage-Laozi**, named **Yin Shouzi** (尹寿子),
Dwelling in **Helyang** (河阳),
Pitying the **erring nature of beings** (物性之迁讹),
Fearful that the **true teaching would be abandoned** (真宗之陵替),
Deemed that the **Great Scriptures of the Three Sovereigns** (三皇大字) were insufficient
To guide the **future kings** (后王),
And the **constant Way of the Five Emperors** (五帝常道) could not
Instruct the **later generations** (末俗).
Thus, he condensed the **profound and mysterious essence** (玄奥义),
Composing the *Dao De* in **two chapters**.
He sought to elucidate the **Dao’s non-action** (无为),
Using **virtue** (德) to reveal it—
**Virtue** has practical application,
The **Dao** clarifies its meaning.

He employed **spoken words** (立言) to express the **ineffable** (无言),
Using **principle** (理本) to expound the **mysterious origin** (妙本),
Establishing the **foundation for governance and self-cultivation** (理身理国之要),
As the **ultimate and most refined teaching** (至精至极之宗),
And bestowed it upon **Shun**.
Not that he rejected **benevolence, righteousness, sagely wisdom, and intelligence** (仁义圣智),
But rather, he tempered **excessive passion, deceit, and sharp cleverness** (浇诈聪明),
To guide the **sovereign to rule, ministers to serve, fathers to lead, and children to obey** (君君臣臣父父子子),
So they might **embrace the Uncarved and return to simplicity** (见素抱朴),
Merge with the **Great Harmony** (太和),
And thus naturally attain **loyalty and filial piety** (忠孝).

The **common scholars** (世儒) do not comprehend,
Assuming that **Sage-Laozi’s Dao** (老君之道) abandons
**Benevolence and righteousness** (仁义),
And **overthrows ritual and wisdom** (隳礼智),
This is not the **great principle of his teaching** (立教之大方).

Moreover, **supreme benevolence** (至仁) aligns with the **harmonious virtue of heaven and earth** (天地之德),
**Supreme righteousness** (至义) conforms to the **natural order of heaven and earth** (天地之宜),
**Supreme joy** (至乐) resonates with the **harmony of heaven and earth** (天地之和),
**Supreme propriety** (至礼) follows the **rhythms of heaven and earth** (天地之节),
**Supreme wisdom** (至智) discerns the **distinctions of heaven and earth** (天地之辨),
**Supreme trust** (至信) attunes to the **timing of heaven and earth** (天地之时).
It broadens the **source of Pure Unity** (淳一之源),
Achieves the **transformation of Great Unity** (大同之化),
Blends with the **supreme Dao** (混合至道),
And returns to the **Land of Benevolent Longevity** (归仁寿之乡).
It is not merely about **affected gestures or hollow rhetoric** (踶跂雍容，噢咻蹩趸),
But rather, it is **true benevolence and righteousness** (仁义等).

Thus, the **Sages Zhongni and Ya** (仲尼亚圣) all attained it in silence,
Discarding **cleverness** (黜聪) and **bodily form** (遗形),
Transcending the **material realm** (超乎物表),
And becoming **true immortals** (永为真人).
This is beyond the understanding of **petty scholars and minor literati** (末学小儒).

From the **Xia, Shang, Zhou, and Han dynasties** (绵夏商周汉),
Spanning thousands of years,
Its brilliance rivaled the **sun and moon** (与日月齐光),
Its majesty matched the **heavens and earth** (与乾坤并运).
Though **a hundred schools** (百家) have interpreted and annotated it,
And **numerous scholars** (群彦) have refined and elucidated it,
The more one draws from it, the deeper it becomes,
The more one tastes of it, the inexhaustible it is.
When applied to **governance**, punishments are set aside,
And **Great Peace** (太平) prevails.
When practiced in **self-cultivation**, the **spirit is preserved** (神全),
And **longevity is attained** (久视).

**Patting the table and brandishing the brush** (拊几挥柄),
There have always been those who embody its truth.

**Strong Contemplation (Strong Thinking)**, **Montang’s Qi Muyue** (强思齐，字默越),
A native of **Montang** (蒙阳),
From youth grasped the **Mysterious Passages** (玄关),
Early explored the **profound meanings** (妙旨),
Attending the **Golden Immortal Observatory** (京金仙观) each year,
Discussing the **Great Virtue** (大德) with his master,
Honored as a **Purple-Clad True Immortal** (赐紫全真),
Residing in the **Middle Palace of the Ge Immortal** (葛仙中宫),
After reciting scriptures, he **diligently served** (服勤不息),
His reputation flourishing,
Praised by his contemporaries.

When **Emperor Lizong** (僖宗皇帝) **responded to the auspicious signs** (顺动六飞),
And **halted his journey in the Three Shu regions** (驻跸三蜀),
In the **fifth month**, observing the **Celestial Festival** (应天节),
**Qi Muyue** composed a **prayer of longevity** (祝寿行殿),
And was **granted purple robes** (宠赐紫衣).

When **Emperor Gaozu** (高祖神武皇帝) **responded to the Heavenly Mandate** (应历开图),
And **aligned with the Celestial Pole** (配天立极),
In the **second month**, celebrating the **Spring Festival of Longevity** (寿春节),
He **received the clear command** (允承明命),
And bestowed the title **Profound Virtue Grandmaster** (玄德大师) upon him.
For generations, his **mind dwelled in the Dao** (栖心),
All were **granted radiant favor** (洽光宠),
His **feathered robes symbolized simplicity** (羽衣象简),
And his **virtue was unparalleled** (其何盛欤).

Whenever he **delved into the profound mysteries** (探讨幽玄),
And **expounded upon common understanding** (发挥流俗),
He aimed to **repay the sage’s grace** (报圣明之恩)
With the **power of his lectures** (谭讲之力).

In his **lectures on the *Dao De* in two chapters**,
He selected the **best interpretations of all schools** (采诸家之善者),
Taking **Emperor Xuanzong’s Imperial Commentary** (皇《御注》) as the foundation,
Choosing **concise yet comprehensive expressions** (文约而义该),
**Swift yet logically sound words** (词捷而理当),
Compiling them into **twenty volumes** (勒成二十卷),
So that it might be **easily grasped** (揽之易晓),
And **endlessly transmitted** (传之无穷).
Thus, future scholars may **know the profound intent of this master** (知强君之深意).

Therefore, he titled it: *The Dao De Jing (True Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue) with Profound Virtue Commentary by Sage-Laozi*.

On the **5th day of the 5th month, in the 2nd year of the Qian De era** (乾德二年庚辰降圣节戊申日),
**Master Guangcheng Du Guangting** (广成先生光禄大夫尚书户部侍郎上柱国蔡国公杜光庭),
**Grandee of the Purple Robes, Minister of the Household Department, and Duke of Cai** (光禄大夫尚书户部侍郎上柱国蔡国公),
Composed this preface.

**Volume One of the Profound Virtue Commentary on the Dao De Jing**

**Commentaries by Emperor Xuanzong of the Tang (唐玄宗御注) and others**,
**Master Ge Shanggong’s and Yan Junping’s annotations (河上公严君平李荣注)**,
**Master Xihua’s and Cheng Xuanjing’s exegesis (西华法师成玄英疏)**,
**Montang’s Qi Muyue’s compilation (蒙阳强思齐纂)**.

This scripture is the **crown of the Three Teachings** (三教之冠冕),
The **leader of all scriptures** (众经之领袖),
Encompassing the **great without exclusion** (大无不包),
And the **small without omission** (细无不入),
Exhausting **principle** (穷理) and **essence** (尽性),
Beyond all **conceptual limits** (不可思议).
Thus, it is titled *The Dao De Jing (True Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue)*.

The **Dao** is the **boundless realm of emptiness and flow** (虚通之理境),
**Virtue** is the **forgetful wisdom of profound insight** (志忘之妙智).
The **realm** can **awaken wisdom** (发智),
And **wisdom** can **subdue the realm** (克境).
When **realm and wisdom converge** (境智相会),
It is called *The Dao De Jing*.

Its **intricate and profound meanings** (委曲玄旨) are fully explained in the **opening preface** (开题义).
Now, examining the **upper chapter’s thirty-seven sections** (上卷三十七章),
They are divided into **three major categories**:
The first **one chapter** (第一一章) marks the **Dao’s fundamental essence** (标道宗致),
The second **thirty-five chapters** (第二三十五章) broadly expound the **Dao’s methods** (广明道法),
The third **one chapter** (第三一章) summarizes the **ultimate teaching** (总结指归).

Within this chapter, there are **four further distinctions**:
The first **briefly establishes principle and teaching** (略标理教),
The second **widely clarifies the original source** (泛明本边),
The third **contrasts the two perspectives** (显二观不同),
The fourth **unifies the profound essence of the Dao** (会重玄之致).

**Chapter One: "The Dao That Can Be Spoken" (道可道)**

**Chapter One: "The Dao That Can Be Spoken"**

---

**First Distinction: Briefly Establishing Principle and Teaching**

The Great Dao is a boundless, mysterious principle beyond all forms. Its essence surpasses the grasp of symbols, and its operations arise from the unfathomable. It is not something that can be known by ordinary names, nor is it something that can be fully explored by mere speech. It encompasses all without exclusion, and it penetrates even the finest details—when it manifests, it rides upon the *Palm Boat* (慈舟) of compassion, and when it withdraws, it returns to the *Silent Obscurity* (杜默) of the unspoken. The Yellow Emperor fasted for three months before seeking it, yet Emperor Jing of the Former Han exhausted years without receiving an answer.

Its substance is serene, its name is subtle. Some ascend with the *Dragon Chariot* (龙轩) to wander the *Jade Capital* (玉京), while others harness the *Luan* (鸾) and *Zhī* (骖) to float at the *Golden Gates* (金阙). The Western Sovereign Mother obtained it and sat in the *Minor Broad* (少广), while Dongfang Shuo encountered it and played in the Han Court. Heaven and Earth obtained it and thus were able to bring forth creation, while the myriad beings blew with the ten thousand breaths and gave birth to life. Ah! The profound and boundless Dao—how vast it is!

The Dao that can be spoken is not the Dao beyond speech.

**Commentary by Yu** (御疏):
*"The Dao"* is a strong designation for the boundless, mysterious origin. *"By"* (训由) refers to the path of its operations, *"Law"* (训法) refers to its methods, and *"Constant"* (训常) refers to its enduring nature. The first character marks its essence, saying that this mysterious origin is the universal path through which all things arise, and thus it may be called *Dao*—hence, *"The Dao That Can Be Spoken."*

It can be called *Dao* because the scripture says: *"I do not know its name; I call it Dao."* This is to guide students in attaining clarity of nature and cultivating the mind, thus naming it *Dao*.

Seeking its mysterious origin, one finds that its principle is utterly clear and void, its nature is beyond comprehension—neither luminous nor obscure.

Again, referring to the following passage in the scripture: *"When seen, it is not seen—called *Yī* (夷); when heard, it is not heard—called *Xī* (希); when grasped, it is not obtained—called *Wēi* (微)."* The passage before it—*"When seen, it is not seen"*—refers to seeking the Dao through color, *"When heard, it is not heard"*—through sound, *"When grasped, it is not obtained"*—through form. Yet the mysterious Dao is too subtle and profound to be attained by worldly means of sound, color, or form.

Referring to the *"Scripture of the Nine Heavens Giving Birth to Spirits"* (九天生神经), it says: *"The Sage uses the Three Primordials of Mysterious Origin—*Sān Xī* (三熙)—as his substance, speaking of the Three Mysterious Primordials of the Three Heavens—*Sān Miào Xī* (三妙熙)."* Master Zang Zongdao further uses *"Three One"* (三一) as the Sage’s manifested body. The *"Three One"* refers to: one *Jīng* (精), two *Shén* (神), and three *Qì* (氣).

*Jīng* is the heart of luminous wisdom and intuitive intelligence. *Shén* is the faculty of boundless, unfathomable operation. *Qì* is the method of colors and forms.

The scripture says: *"When seen, it is not seen—called *Yī* (夷), the *Jīng*; when heard, it is not heard—called *Xī* (希), the *Shén*; when grasped, it is not obtained—called *Wēi* (微), the *Qì*."* These three methods are unified into one Sage, and the Sage embodies these three aspects without any contradiction—thus, they are merged into one.

But the *Dao*’s methods and substance are expressed through *"Three One"* (三一), which has distinctions between true and manifested. The interpretations of this vary among three schools:
The first says: *"Dissolving the One into Three"*—meaning the Sage’s manifested body merges the Three into One, which is the Sage’s true substance.
The second says: *"The Three and the One are both manifested; neither the Three nor the One is true. The Three and the One are merely names and numbers."*
The third asks: *"Is there a true substance beyond names and numbers, separate from the Three and the One?"*

It is said that *"Three One"* is not Three nor One—this is the true substance. *"Three One"* is neither Three nor One—this is the manifested body. The manifested body that is not *"Three One"* is the true manifested body, while the true substance that is *"Three One"* is the manifested true substance. The true substance of the manifested body cannot be definitively called true, nor can the manifested body of the true substance be definitively called manifested. Thus, it is neither true nor manifested, yet it is both manifested and true.

The Sage responds to stimuli and adapts to circumstances, manifesting in myriad forms—sometimes appearing in human guise, sometimes as a celestial being. He reveals himself according to the situation, and his transformations follow the times. His subtle essence is beyond *Yī* (夷) and *Xī* (希), yet it remains difficult to fully comprehend.

**Rong** (荣) says:
*The Dao* is the principle of boundless voidness, and its symbols cannot be divided by existence or nonexistence. Its true substance cannot be confined by the extremes of high or low. It is said to be mysterious yet beyond thought, profound yet beyond recognition.

The Sage lays bare this path of the mysterious, opening it as a teaching. He borrows the term *"Round and Pass Through"* (圆通) to designate the boundless voidness, calling it the principle that can be named, and thus the *Dao* that can be spoken. *"I do not know its name"*—the Sage achieves the Dao through boundless voidness, and its constant nature is attained through serene stillness. This is called the *"Boundless Great Dao"* (无极大道), which is the original nature of all beings.

What is the *Heavenly Dao*? It is the system of voidness, the root of transformation, the origin of divine illumination, and the source of Heaven and Earth. It is boundless without exclusion, subtle without interiority, vast without end, and profound without measure. Though it is the most hidden and obscure, its great light shines forth. Though it is utterly still without heart, the myriad things have their fixed places. It is mixed and indistinct without form, silent and empty without sound. Yet from it arise all phenomena, and from it are formed the five tones. That which is born has limits, that which is formed has deficiencies. Birth and formation, birth and formation—eternal and unchanging, from ancient times to the present. This is what is called *Dao*.

Before the *Primordial Qi* (元气) and the boundless voidness, there was serene stillness—what was there? When the most refined essence was stirred, the *True One* (真一) was born.

The *True One* moves with divine illumination, and thus the *Primordial Qi* transforms naturally. The *Primordial Qi* is the existence within nonexistence, the nonexistence within existence—vast beyond measure, subtle beyond detection. It gradually condenses and solidifies, becoming indistinct and formless, yet from it emerge the origins of all phenomena. Thus, the clear and luminous *Qi* (氣) ascends to form Heaven, while the turbid and obscured *Qi* gathers to form Earth. The harmonious and gentle *Qi* coalesces into human beings and their roles, while the chaotic and rigid *Qi* disperses into various other types.

From the single *Qi*’s nurturing, myriad differences are spread and classified. Once the mechanism of transformation is engaged, change is endless without limit. Yet the forms of Heaven, Earth, and all beings arise from the *Primordial Qi* (元氣). That which grants Heaven, Earth, and all beings their spirit is divine illumination. Thus, *Lián* (乾) and *Kūn* (坤) govern Heaven and Earth, while *Jīng* (精) and *Hún* (魂) oversee all beings.

*Qi* undergoes the revolutions of *Yīn* and *Yáng*, while divine illumination is unaffected by cold or heat. Though all things move in confusion beyond count, they perish only to be reborn, end only to begin anew. Yet the body of *Dao* and *Virtue* (德), the divine illumination of the mind, respond to stimuli endlessly without ever being exhausted by the realm of motion and operation.

「The Dao/Way is profound yet encompasses the ten millionfold Heaven without making it vast, penetrates the finest autumn hair without making it small. It precedes the void and formlessness yet is not the beginning, succeeds Heaven and Earth yet is not their end. It ascends to the accumulation of Yang without becoming luminous, descends into the depths of Yin without becoming obscure.

Originally, there is no *spirit* (神). At the utmost void, spirit emerges. Originally, there is no *Qi* (炁). Through the movement of spirit, Qi transforms. Without foundation or substance, it condenses and coalesces to form shape; shape, originally without *emotion* (情), is diminished by motion and operation.

As form takes shape and nature moves, the Dao/Way grows ever more distant. Thus, one is lost in birth and death, shifting between Yin and Yang, unable to halt oneself—this is not because the Dao/Way is forgotten while existing, but because it can cause the existent to return to the nonexistent.

Hence, the Dao/Way is able to generate existence from nonexistence; how much more can it make the existent conform to the nonexistent! If the existent conforms to the nonexistent, then existence will not perish. Therefore, the Dao/Way gives birth to me, yet passion destroys me. If one forgets passion, then nature is preserved intact. When nature is whole, form is whole; when form is whole, Qi is whole; when Qi is refined, spirit is whole; when spirit is whole, the Dao/Way is whole. Thus, when the Dao/Way is complete, spirit reigns supreme; when spirit reigns, Qi becomes responsive; when Qi is responsive, form transcends; when form transcends, nature is fully realized. Those who fully realize nature return and circulate endlessly, merging with the Dao/Way.

It can make the existent nonexistent, can make the void substantial. I shall align myself with the Creator and let birth and death fail to burden me.

The Dao/Way can be spoken of as *substance* (體), and named as *function* (用). That which can be spoken of is but the Dao/Way’s manifestation. Though it may be called "speakable," things adapt to their circumstances, giving rise to sound and speech—this is not the Dao/Way of eternal stillness and repose.

○ **Yán** (嚴) says: When *Dao/Virtue* (道德) is manifest, it is not natural. When fame and achievement are displayed, it is not true essence.
○ **Hé Shànggōng** (河上公) says: That which can be spoken of is not the Dao/Way of natural longevity.

The Dao/Way of constancy should cultivate the nonexistent to nourish the spirit, remain without affairs to settle the people, contain light and conceal brilliance, erase traces and obscure origins—it cannot be named.

○ **Róng** (榮) says: This is not the Dao/Way of humans honoring through rites and propriety, elevating through superficial splendor, losing themselves to gain fame, forgetting themselves to serve profit. They abandon the Dao/Way and follow Virtue (德) thereafter; this teaching now prevails. But having stripped away the trappings of benevolence and righteousness, taking the essence of Dao/Virtue, and returning to the source of purity and simplicity, one reverses their constant passions. Hence, it is called the Dao/Way of constancy.

○ **Chéng’s Commentary** (成疏): The Dao/Way of constancy cannot be defined by words or reasoned through the mind; it transcends subtlety and eludes the grasp of logic. Thus, knowing beyond words and symbols, one may then conform to the eternal stillness—what can be spoken of and named is not the Dao/Way of constancy.

That which can be named is not the Dao/Way’s true name.
○ **Yù Zhù** (御注): Names are the Dao/Way’s designations. I forcefully name it the *Great* (大).

Names do not stand alone; they arise from substance. Words do not exist in isolation; they are established by Virtue (德). The operation of principles and substance flows without obstruction, encompassing all to reach the boundless. Thus, I name the Dao/Way’s *Great* (大) designation to the Dao/Way’s substance, so that things may recognize it—hence, "that which can be named is named."

○ **Yù’s Commentary** (御疏): Names are teachings. Earlier, it was said that what can be spoken of is manifest in principle; now, it is said that what can be named is secondary in teaching. True principle transcends words and symbols, and even teachings surpass verbal articulation.

Since principle is the Dao/Way of constancy yet cannot be spoken of, and teaching is that which can be named yet not the Dao/Way’s true name, one who seeks to clarify principle and teaching finds they are neither one nor different.

Yet the supreme Dao/Way is profound and mysterious, beyond measure or limit. It is neither nonexistent nor existent, neither fixed nor constant—though it is not constant, there is still uplift and subsidence. Teaching exists in gradual and sudden stages; thus, constancy is established to break the speakable, hence the statement that the speakable Dao/Way is not the Dao/Way of constancy.

At the extreme of discourse, there is neither "can" nor "cannot," nor is it the Dao/Way of constancy and non-constancy. Hence, the *Jùjīng Jīng* (玉京经) says: *"Without can or cannot, ponder with the subtle and minute."* That which can be named is not the vulgar honor of transient fame, so it is rejected as "not the Dao/Way of constancy," desiring one to abandon the impermanent and return to the eternal constancy.

There are causes of transcendence and stages of gradual and sudden enlightenment. Opening with the square, one picks up the impermanent; to grasp the eternal constancy, one must go beyond the square. Presenting it to its ultimate, there is no impermanent to be picked up, nor any eternal constancy to be taken—how much more so is the Dao/Way neither the impermanent nor the eternal constancy, nor is it the Dao/Way of the non-eternal constancy nor the Dao/Way of the eternal constancy!

○ **Hé Shànggōng** (河上公) says: It is not the name of the Dao/Way that is naturally ever-present.

The name of constancy should be like an infant before speech, a chicken egg before division, a bright pearl within the shell, or a fine jade hidden in stone—internally luminous, externally dull. The Dao/Way that can be spoken of is not the Dao/Way of constancy; that which can be named is not the Dao/Way’s true name.

The second passage clarifies the original traces.
The nonexistent is the beginning of Heaven and Earth. The existent is the mother of all things.

○ **Yù Zhù** (御注): The nonexistent is the mysterious origin. The mysterious origin reveals itself in Qi, temporarily manifesting as Heaven and Earth. Heaven and Earth derive their beginning, so the nonexistent is called the beginning. The existent is the response to application.

○ **Róng** (榮) says: The Dao/Way is profound, its Virtue (德) subtle. Principle transcends existence and nonexistence. Since existence and nonexistence are transcended, names are discarded. Yet the function of void and emptiness is limitless—how can it not be nonexistent while being nonexistent? Thus, the nonexistent is the beginning of the two principles (兩儀). The existent, though not truly existent, is the mother of all things.

Hence, the Dao/Way generates and accumulates Virtue (德)—this is what is meant.

○ **Chéng’s Commentary** (成疏): This nonexistent is the origin of all things. The Dao/Way originally has no name, thus it is known that it cannot be spoken of or explained. The existent is the mother of all things, as it is described. The Dao/Way of *Double Mystery* (重玄) originally has no name; descending from the origin to traces, names and designations arise. Thus, the sage establishes the existent from the nonexistent, entrusting the existent to elucidate the nonexistent, desiring to nurture all beings and lead them back to their origin. With compassion and mercy, they cultivate and nourish, akin to a mother’s care.

○ **Hé Shànggōng** (河上公) says: The nonexistent is the beginning of Heaven and Earth. The nonexistent is the Dao/Way, for the Dao/Way has no form and thus cannot be named.»

「The origin is where the Dao/Way emits *qi* and spreads its transformations, arising from the void and nonexistent, marking the beginning of Heaven and Earth. The existent, named as the mother of all things, refers to Heaven and Earth—Heaven and Earth possess form and position, and *yin* and *yang* exhibit softness and rigidity; thus, they are called by name.

The mother of all things is Heaven and Earth, which combine in harmony to generate all things, nurturing them to growth, maturity, and fulfillment, as a mother raises her children. The third realm manifests two distinct perspectives.

To observe its subtlety, one must habitually be without desire; to perceive its intricacies, one must habitually indulge desire.

○ **御注** (Imperial Annotation): When a person is born and remains tranquil, it reflects the nature of Heaven. When they respond to things and move, it is the stirrings of their innate desires. If one can perpetually uphold purity and stillness, free the mind and release the spirit, and return to reflect upon their original nature, then they can observe the wondrous origin. If one does not still their emotions, but instead pursues desires and moves with them, their nature is lost to desire, and they become bewildered at the source of the Dao/Way. If they then seek to observe the wondrous origin, they will only perceive its marginal subtleties.

○ **御疏** (Imperial Commentary): To habitually be without desire means to uphold the law-nature of purity and stillness, detached from speech and thought, with no lingering attachments—thus, one perceives the Dao/Way’s most subtle and wondrous essence. To habitually indulge desire is to rise from the origin and act, establishing teachings through speech, adapting to things and achieving harmony, transforming the world—thus, one perceives the convergence of all beings.

○ **缴** (return) is to **归** (return).

○ **严** (Yan) says: To be without desire is to gaze beyond all gazing. To observe its subtlety is to peer into the *Taiqing* (Great Clarity).

○ **荣** (Rong) illuminates the distinction between desire and non-desire: When a person receives life, all are endowed with their beginning by virtue and the Dao/Way, sharing the same breath of *qi* from *yin* and *yang*, yet differing in their luminous and obscure spirits, their tranquil and restless natures. To walk without desire is to smooth the heart and traverse the silent path, to purify the will and ford the mysterious depths—when desires are insufficient to disturb the spirit, and distractions cannot slip the mind, the luminous platform is serene and cold, the mysterious mirror deep and clear. Then one can perceive the marginal subtleties and grasp the wondrous essence; this is the way of non-desire.

The way of desire, if one cannot yet abandon recognition, when emotions are bound within form and roam through the body, is not merely agitation over sounds and colors, but to adhere to the affairs of the existent—how does one recognize the principles of the nonexistent? This is the way of desire.

○ **河上公** (Hé Shànggōng) says: To habitually be without desire and observe its subtlety, for subtlety is the essence. When a person habitually remains without desire, they can observe the Dao/Way’s essence. The essence is oneness—from this oneness, names and transformations are emitted, and the Dao/Way is praised. This is the Master who discerns right and wrong.

○ **成疏** (Chéng’s Commentary): **缴** (return) is to **归** (return). Desire is the entanglement of emotions. **所** (that which) is the realm.»

「Though one cannot act without *for* [事], nor remain tranquil and unadorned, yet observing the Dao/Way’s subtlety and upholding its truth—when false stirrings arise in hunger and seeking, when emotions run wild and cling to stagnation—this is but the sight of the world’s *for* [有], failing to grasp that *for* [有] is empty. Thus, one cannot perceive the Dao/Way’s profound principles, seeing only the fate of life and death. This earlier distinction of nameless and named *virtue/power* [名] now reveals the triumph of desireless over desireful conduct.

The Fourth Assembly expounds the *Dao/Way’s* ultimate subtlety. These two—though sharing the same origin, differing only in name—
○ **御注** [Imperial Commentary]: As with the two above, both arise from the Dao/Way, hence they are called the same.
From movement comes application; names are established according to use, hence their difference.

○ **御疏** [Imperial Exegesis]: Both derive from the same subtle source, thus they are identical in origin. Names differ as they are applied to distinct uses.

○ **河上公** (Hé Shànggōng) says: Desireful and desireless conduct both originate from the human heart. Desireless conduct endures, while desireful conduct consumes the self—thus their difference.

○ **荣** (Róng) says: In close terms, these two—desireful and desireless—refer to humanity. All share the five constant essences [五常], all possess the same *innate mind* [方寸之心], hence their sameness.
To reject clarity and remain tranquil, penetrating the Dao/Way’s source, is to attain the *subtle* [妙]. To be ensnared by perceptions before understanding, lost in mundane affairs, is to fall into *entanglement* [缴]. This is their divergence in name.

In broader terms, the Sage seeks to fulfill the Dao/Way’s clear and empty principles, thus taking *virtue/power* [道德] as their core. Hence, this chapter emphasizes their duality—*virtue/power* [道德] and *virtue/power* [道德]—while the Dao/Way’s essence remains unified. Thus, they are called the same.
The *Dao/Way’s* essence, arising from stillness, is hence termed *out* [出]. Its transformative function is the Dao/Way itself; its nurturing principle is the manifestation of *virtue/power* [德]. Thus, the Dao/Way’s names differ.

○ **成疏** (Chéng’s Commentary): Though these two share the same origin, differing only in name—*entanglement* [缴] and *subtle* [妙]—the observed realm is singular, yet the capacity to observe varies. Since the two modes of observation differ, *entanglement* [缴] and *subtle* [妙] are named distinctively.
This is called the *Dao/Way’s* ultimate subtlety [玄].

○ **御注** [Imperial Commentary]: When spoken of as *out* [出], their names differ; when spoken of as the same, it is called the *Dao/Way’s* ultimate subtlety [玄], which is profound and subtle.

○ **河上公** (Hé Shànggōng) says: *Ultimate subtlety* [玄] is the heavens. It states that those with desireful or desireless conduct all receive *qi* [气] from the heavens.

○ **荣** (Róng) says: The Dao/Way of emptiness and stillness, the *virtue/power* [德] of profound subtlety—its elusive nature is not easily grasped, its silent mystery not easily spoken of. No name can suffice.
The term *ultimate subtlety* [玄] is borrowed to signify the same, for the Dao/Way’s subtlety is ineffable. Only the Dao/Way and *virtue/power* [德] can convey *ultimate subtlety* [玄], hence it is said: *Ultimate subtlety* [玄] is profound and distant, the Dao/Way is supremely subtle and still.

○ **御疏** [Imperial Exegesis]: When spoken of as *out* [出], their names differ—this is the progression from origin to application.
When spoken of as the same, it signifies profound subtlety—this is the return to the source, transcending all dualities.
To return to the source is to attain profound subtlety, hence it is called *ultimate subtlety* [玄].

○ **成疏** (Chéng’s Commentary): *Ultimate subtlety* [玄] means profound and distant, also the name for non-stagnation. The twofold heart of desireful and desireless conduct, both modes of observing *entanglement* [缴] and *subtle* [妙], originate from the same Dao/Way, differing only in name.
The Dao/Way, though named differently, is profound and distant. Its principle returns to non-stagnation.
Neither stagnating in existence nor in non-existence, both are transcended—hence it is called *ultimate subtlety* [玄].
*Ultimate subtlety* [玄] beyond *ultimate subtlety* [玄], is the gateway to all subtleties.

○ **御注** [Imperial Commentary]: Since the mind does not generate, it aligns with the profound subtlety. Yet fearing that *ultimate subtlety* [玄] might be taken as stagnation, it further dismisses the notion of attachment, demonstrating that desireless conduct transcends desire. Those who attain this understand all *dharma* [法], hence it is called the gateway to all subtleties.

○ **河上公** (Hé Shànggōng) says: *Ultimate subtlety* [玄] beyond *ultimate subtlety* [玄] is the heavens within the heavens. Those who receive *qi* [气] with varying depths—if they attain the harmony of *central equilibrium* [中和] and pure nourishment, they become sages and worthy. If they fall into disorder and impurity, they become nobles of licentiousness.
The gateway to all subtleties is to know that the heavens contain another heavens, that *qi* [气] has varying depths, and to eliminate emotions and desires while guarding *central equilibrium* [中和]. This is the gateway to understanding the Dao/Way’s essence.

○ **荣** (Róng) says: *Virtue/power* [道德] is elusive and profound, its principles surpassing all speech and forms. Its true essence is tranquil and vast, its affairs transcending existence and non-existence. Borrowing terms beyond speech and forms, beyond existence and non-existence, to illuminate the Dao/Way’s hidden path—hence it is called *ultimate subtlety* [玄].
Yet one might fear that those lost in duality cling to the pillar, or those who abandon principle guard the stump. Thus, to fix *ultimate subtlety* [玄] as the true Dao/Way is incorrect. Therefore, it is further stated: it is not the fixed name of existence or non-existence.
Using *ultimate subtlety* [玄] to dismiss existence and non-existence, once existence and non-existence are dismissed, *ultimate subtlety* [玄] itself is lost—hence it is said: *ultimate subtlety* [玄] beyond *ultimate subtlety* [玄].
*Ultimate subtlety* [玄] beyond *ultimate subtlety* [玄] is beyond threefold reversal and fourfold phrasing. It is boundless and open, unimpeded by emptiness, encompassing all phenomena’s pivotal essence and unlocking the hundredfold gates of wisdom. Those who reach this state—all subtleties’ gateway.

○ **御疏** [Imperial Exegesis]: The *Scripture of Western Ascension* [西升经] states: "Same origin, differing names, each generates its own *emotional causes* [意因]."
Now, without generating *emotional causes* [意因], it is identical with profound subtlety.
Desireless conduct in desirelessness—desirelessness is the *emotional cause* [意因] for desire. Hence, one seeks desirelessness.
To seek desirelessness while still clinging to desire is not yet free. Now, having no desire, there is no gateway either.
○ **成疏** (Chéng’s Commentary): *Ultimate subtlety* [玄] beyond *ultimate subtlety* [玄]—for those with desire, desirelessness is the dismissal of attachment again and again, until all is forgotten.
True observation, such as this, is the attainment of all subtleties.
Though subtleties are many, they all originate from this—yet one stagnates in existence, while the desireless person stagnates in non-existence. Hence, it speaks of *ultimate subtlety* [玄] to dismiss both attachments.
Again, fearing that scholars might stagnate in this *ultimate subtlety* [玄], it further speaks of *ultimate subtlety* [玄] beyond *ultimate subtlety* [玄], to further alleviate the lingering affliction.
Not only does it not stagnate, but it also transcends non-stagnation—this is the dismissal of attachment again and again, hence it is called *ultimate subtlety* [玄] beyond *ultimate subtlety* [玄].
The gateway to all subtleties—*subtlety* [妙] refers to the essential subtlety, *gateway* [门] is the *dharma gate* [法门].
Earlier, the profound subtlety of central unity dismissed the duality of both categories. Once the dual afflictions are removed, the profound subtlety’s medicine is further dismissed. Thus, medicine and affliction vanish simultaneously—this is the ultimate subtlety, the pinnacle of profound principles, exhausting all reason and nature. It is not merely the door to sages, but also the gateway to all subtleties.»

「**The World All Knows Beauty as Beauty, the Second Chapter**
This chapter follows the previous one because the earlier chapter elucidates the two views of existence and non-existence [有无二观], with their coarse and subtle distinctions. Therefore, this chapter reveals the efficacy of the *non-action* [无为] and the perils of *action* [有为], dividing its meaning into two parts: the first clarifies the common attachments and stagnations that give rise to confusion and delusion, while the second demonstrates the *sage’s wisdom* [圣智] in its emptiness and clarity, as it forgets merit and aids beings without self-interest.

**First: Clarifying the Common Attachments and Stagnations That Give Rise to Delusion**
Within this chapter, two further distinctions are made: the first two sentences broadly refute the illusory nature of beauty and goodness [美善], while the remaining six sentences, in three pairs, illuminate the emptiness of all phenomena [诸法无实].

**First: Broadly Refuting the Illusory Nature of Beauty and Goodness**
The ordinary folk of the world are ensnared by sounds and colors, bound by *action* [有为], never finding true repose. They chase fame and profit like monkeys leaping from branch to branch, indulge in love and desire like moths drawn to flame. They confuse evil for good, regard ease as difficulty, and dwell in the nameless void of ignorance, clinging stubbornly to their fragile, perilous selves. How could they comprehend the *subtle Dao* [妙道] in its emptiness and fluidity, the true words and rational sequence, when its brilliance and obscurity defy explanation, and its acceptance is blind? The Seven Sages [七圣] lost their way at Xiangcheng, and Xizi spoke in vain at Hengshan. Sounds and colors fade into nothingness, and the distinction between self and other dissolves into emptiness. Only by abandoning the flawed body of *existence with defilements* [有漏] can one align with the *non-action Dao* [无为之道].

The world all knows beauty as beauty—then evil arises.
The world all knows goodness as goodness—then what is not good arises.

**Commentary by the Master:**
Beauty and goodness arise from desire [欲心]. When desire dictates what is beautiful or good, even what is evil becomes beautiful or good—hence, "the world all knows." One takes what pleases their own desires as beautiful or good, but beauty and goodness have no inherent master; they are merely deluded emotions, born from clinging to distinctions of existence and non-existence, ease and difficulty, the wondrous and the foul—each falsely usurping the other.

The Great Sage discerns this emptiness and delusion, thus declaring, "Then evil arises."

**Commentary from the *Riverbank Master* [河上公]:**
When the world all knows beauty as beauty, it is merely self-praise, making it appear radiant.

"Then evil arises"—this means peril and ruin are imminent.
When the world all knows goodness as goodness, it implies a demand for merit and reward—then what is not good arises, and people vie for it.

**Commentary by Yan [严]:**
Human cleverness can be cut off but not dispersed; human desires can be resisted but not reversed. Adorning one’s appearance harms one’s nature, and gratifying desire shortens one’s life. The world’s so-called "beauty and goodness" are not the utmost beauty or goodness.

True beauty is not what the world can see, and true goodness is not what the world can know.

**Commentary by Rong [荣]:**
Beauty is pleasure.
All people, by their inherent nature, cannot find joy in the Dao but instead take glory as pleasure. Pleasure cannot be boundless—when pushed to extremes, sorrow follows. Desire cannot be indulged recklessly—when unrestrained, it leads to ruin. Hence, people take sounds, colors, flavors, and tastes as supreme pleasure, unaware of how these very things bring great calamity.

When simplicity [朴] becomes a curse, when simplicity is lost, sorrow arises. When the root is extinguished, nature is harmed, and the body falls into ruin.

The world all knows goodness as goodness—then what is not good arises.

From the highest to the lowest, the noble and the vulgar, none can truly empty their minds and selves, yet all indulge their desires and emotions. Though their affections differ, each follows their nature and shares the same attachments.

Those who love fame regard fame as goodness; those who love profit regard profit as goodness. If one pursues profit without the proper means, or clings to fame to the point of self-destruction, then goodness becomes ruinous.

Though conforming to desire may seem good, it leads to self-destruction—this is true evil. Hence, Boyi perished for fame atop Mount Shouyang, while Zhi the Thief died for profit beneath the Eastern Ling. This is what is not good.

*The world* [世问] is a general term for the worldly realm.
*The world* [世问] refers to all beings between the heavens and the earth, those who are immersed in dusty illusions and falsely cling to beauty and evil. Those who oppose their true nature stir hatred—this is called evil. Those who follow their deluded intentions breed attachment—this is called beauty.

Not knowing that all phenomena are both *existent* [有] and *empty* [空], when beauty and evil are seen as empty, why cling to hatred or love?

Thus, the *Zhuangzi* says:
*"Maoqiang and Xishi are what people call beautiful, but fish see them as deep and dark, and birds see them as high and lofty."*

It also says:
*"The beautiful praise themselves as beautiful—I do not know their beauty.*
*The evil condemn themselves as evil—I do not know their evil."*

By this, it is proven that beauty and evil are mere illusions. Hence, one who clings to worldly beauty as true beauty knows only evil, and one who clings to worldly goodness as true goodness knows only what is not good.

The vulgar masses, lost in delusion, do not merely indulge in sounds and colors but also fixate on reputation, seeking fame even at the cost of their lives, harming others for personal gain. They do not realize that goodness is an empty, delusive notion—hence, the following passage asks: *Which is closer to one’s self, fame or the body?*

The *Zhuangzi* says:
*"To do good without seeking fame is near,"*
and also:
*"What they prize and cherish are none other than fame and goodness."*

Thus, it is clear that clinging to fame and goodness contradicts true principle. Only by forgetting goodness and evil and attaining the *central equilibrium* [居中] can one truly embody the *non-action Dao* [无为之致].

**Second: Illuminating the Emptiness of All Phenomena**
Thus, *existence* [有] and *non-existence* [无] give rise to each other.

**Commentary from the *Riverbank Master*:**
To perceive *existence* [有] as *non-existence* [无]—this is the nature of emptiness.

**Commentary by Rong:**
All things arise from *existence* [有], and *existence* [有] arises from *non-existence* [无]. From *non-existence* [无] comes *existence* [有], and from *existence* [有] returns *non-existence* [无]—hence, they give rise to each other.

Difficulty and ease [难易] complete one another...»

Thus, the *Riverbank Master*’s commentary states: *"The dharma is empty; the potter finds ease in shaping clay but struggles with wood, while the artisan finds ease in carving wood but struggles with clay."* ○ **Yán** says: *"Difficulty is revealed through ease, and ease is illuminated by difficulty; without skill, one cannot discern ease, and without ease, one cannot grasp difficulty. If one can skillfully abandon both, then the names of difficulty and ease both cease."* ○ The *Riverbank Master* says: *"To perceive difficulty as ease."* ○ **Róng** says: *"All things under heaven arise from difficulty as ease, difficulty springs from ease, and ease fulfills difficulty. Ease emerges from difficulty, and difficulty becomes ease."*

The *Master Cheng*’s commentary states: *"The mind of emptiness and the view of harmony—without ease or difficulty, distinctions arise from attachment. With attachment to difficulty or ease, then difficulty and ease both manifest. Thus, it is known that the two dharmas of difficulty and ease interdependently arise."*

Length and shortness mutually define each other. The *Riverbank Master*’s commentary states: *"They are empty in nature."* ○ **Yán** says: *"An inch is short when measured by a foot, a foot is long when measured by an inch. Without length, one cannot clarify shortness; without shortness, one cannot discern length. Length and shortness are empty—they have no inherent reality—hence, they are called empty."*

○ The *Riverbank Master* says: *"To perceive shortness as length."* ○ **Róng** says: *"When separated, there is neither great nor small; when gathered, there is short and long. The Great Mountain and the autumn hair differ in magnitude, the White Crane and the Green Hare diverge in span—thus, it is known that forgetting them yields neither great nor small, while retaining them reveals short and long."*

○ The *Master Cheng*’s commentary states: *"Measuring length by length, there is no length; comparing shortness with shortness, there is no shortness—thus, it is known that length and shortness mutually define each other and differ."*

Height and lowliness mutually incline. The *Riverbank Master*’s commentary states: *"They are empty in name."* ○ **Yán** says: *"Mountains are diminished by valleys, valleys are tilted by mountains. Without mountains, one cannot know valleys; without valleys, one cannot know mountains. Like worldly status shifting between master and servant, there is no fixed position."* ○ The *Riverbank Master* says: *"To perceive height as lowliness."* ○ **Róng** says: *"Incline, means peril. Water sustains boats yet also capsizes them; the scriptures say: 'The high becomes the foundation for the low, the low becomes perilous to the high.' The lowliness of the low is still perilous to the high, and the nobility of the high is indeed capable of extinguishing the low. Losing the Dao, height and lowliness become perilous; attaining the Dao, ruler and subject both flourish. Incline, means to topple and seize—where there is height, there is lowliness; without lowliness, there is no height. For instance, a foot measured against an inch is high, while the same foot measured against a yard is low. What was once high becomes now low—thus, it is known that height and lowliness have no fixed reality, only mutual incline and seizure, hence all are empty."*

Sound and voice harmonize together. The *Riverbank Master*’s commentary states: *"This illustrates the emptiness of harmony and unity."*

Who shapes the harmony of the five tones? The *Riverbank Master* says: *"The tones are distinguished by voice, and voice is measured by tone. Without tone, there is no way to know voice; without voice, there is no way to know tone."*

The *Master of Strictness* responds: *"The high sings, the low responds with harmony."*

**Daoist Classic of the Mysterious Virtue: *Zhenjing* (True Scripture) – Imperial Commentary and Exegesis by Emperor Xuanzong of the Tang, with annotations by Master Riverbank, Master Yan, Master Li, and Master Cheng**

**Chapter 5: "Heaven and Earth Are Not Benevolent"**
This chapter follows the previous one because the prior chapter expounded the Dao of emptiness and mystery, transcending all phenomena before their manifestation. Thus, this chapter reveals the principle of forgetting merit, where the Sage aligns with the two primal forces (*Yin* and *Yang*) in virtue.

Within this chapter, three themes unfold:
1. The Sage and Heaven and Earth, acting without attachment to merit,
2. The analogy of the uncarved block (*su* – raw) and the empty vessel (*qiao* – hollow), illustrating the subtle efficacy of the Dao,
3. The critique of excessive knowledge and learning, which pale in comparison to attaining the Dao’s truth.

**1. The Sage and Heaven and Earth, acting without attachment to merit.**
From the single breath of *Qi*, the two primal forces are shaped—*Yin* and *Yang* divide and settle: Heaven, round and clear, covers above; Earth, square and turbid, condenses below. Both owe their existence to the great Dao, sharing the same observation of *Yin-Yang Qi*. Why does *Nuwa* speak of refining stone to prop up Heaven? Why does *Kuafu* die at the banks of the River? Why does *Zhuiyi* walk endlessly without reaching the end? Why does *Qinmi* gaze without limit? Heaven and Earth show no favor, treating all things as mere *chúdǒu*—sacrificial straw-dogs. The vast *Tianhan* (Heavenly River) flows without regard for distance; the distant *Héyuán* (River’s Source) vanishes without measure. *Zhang Qian* could not fathom its length—compared to the uncarved block, only material form is seen; likened to the empty vessel, no sound of exhaustion is heard. The Dao of Heaven turns in its cycles—how could it be called benevolent?

Heaven and Earth are not benevolent; they treat all things as *chúdǒu*.
The Sage is not benevolent; he treats the people as *chúdǒu*.
**Imperial Commentary:** *"Not benevolent"* means they do not act with benevolent favor.
*"Chúdǒu"* refers to straw bound into the shape of a dog, used in sacrifices. Dogs, by nature, guard and bark—thus, they receive the protection of a roof. But the *chúdǒu* is merely a dog in form, lacking the true function of barking and guarding. Hence, it is said to have no genuine connection to benevolence or love. It is as if Heaven and Earth regard humanity no differently than they regard straw-dogs—expecting no gratitude in return.

**Reflection:** If supreme benevolence has no favorites, who then embodies universal love? Love that is not supreme is merely partial. If one does not love only their own kin, then all under Heaven are kin. If one does not consider only their own children, then all under Heaven are children. Thus, supreme benevolence’s lack of partiality is in truth the most inclusive love.

**Imperial Exegesis:** *"Benevolence"* is the name given to universal love. *Chú* means straw; the straw-dog is formed by binding straw into a dog’s shape for sacrificial use. *Zhuangzi* states: *"Before the straw-dog is offered in sacrifice, it is adorned with fine embroidery. Once the ritual is complete, it is discarded, and even its ashes are used for fuel."* Heaven and Earth, in their supreme benevolence, give rise to all beings, just as humans bind straw into a dog’s form—expecting no barking or guarding in return. They do not regard the act of creation as benevolent favor, hence they are called *"not benevolent."*

The Sage, in pardoning the world, views the people likewise—no expectations, no demands.

**Annotation by Master Yan:** *"Heaven, by its height, is clear and bright; Earth, by its depth, is moist and tranquil. *Yin* and *Yang* interact, and harmonious *Qi* flows. Thus, all things arise naturally without contrivance—Heaven and Earth do not labor with their hearts to show benevolence. The Sage upholds the Dao and harmonizes with it, remaining serene and unchanging, adapting to all transformations with divine insight. Aligned with the Dao’s ways, the world responds, and all things transform spontaneously. Does this not free one from anxious deliberation, revealing the true nature of benevolence?"*

**Annotation by Master Li:** *"Heaven and Earth are not benevolent; they treat all things as *chúdǒu*. Long and short, right and wrong—all are natural distinctions. Benevolence is love. Where there is love, there is also hatred. Heaven and Earth act without intent, transcending love and hatred. Because they are without love, they are called ‘not benevolent.’ The straw-dog is merely straw shaped like a dog; in ancient rituals, it was used in offerings, then discarded. It is said that the straw-dog is not loved when used, nor hated when discarded—an analogy for Heaven and Earth’s warmth like spring *Qi* naturally flowing, where creation is not seen as benevolence, nor destruction as righteousness. The Sage is not benevolent; he treats the people as *chúdǒu*. The Sage acts without intent, aligning with Heaven and Earth’s virtue. The meaning of ‘not benevolent’ and ‘straw-dog’ is now clear.*

Though their grace extends to grass and trees, their blessings reach even the *zhūyú* (fish and turtles), their winds and teachings precede humanity—yet still, they are called ‘people’ in this context."

**Exegesis by Master Cheng:** *"Heaven and Earth are not benevolent; they treat all things as *chúdǒu*. Benevolence is favor; the straw-dog is a hollow imitation of a dog. *Zhuangzi* says: ‘The discarded straw-dog is still round and domed above, square and firm below—just as *Yin* and *Yang* cover and load all beings, nurturing them with care. Yet, it is said they have no benevolence because they regard all things as one straw-dog.’ What is the straw-dog? It is merely a dog in name, not in reality. How much more so for all phenomena, which are equally hollow and empty—none deserving the expectation of gratitude or return!"*

The Sage is not benevolent,
treating the people as a straw-dog.
The Sage, in harmony with Heaven and Earth,
shares their virtue and aligns with the Sun and Moon in luminosity,
thus able to empty the heart for the benefit of all,
whose deeds rival the creative transformation.
Hence, first the *Yin* and *Yang* are raised,
then the Sage is revealed;
the Sage, though detached, rescues the teeming masses,
yet still, no transformation is seen—
what is transformed is but a straw-dog,
hollow and empty, without substance.
The *Yin* and *Yang* encompass all sentient beings,
so all things are called ‘the people’;
the Sage’s intent lies in the *rúqì* (compassionate beings),
thus the term ‘people’ is used.

It is not that the Sage fails to transform the unknowing,
but rather that the knowing can perceive and follow the teachings.

**Secondly, the analogy of the *tǔqiào* (leather bellows and reed pipe) is given,
to illustrate the subtle efficacy.**

Between Heaven and Earth—
is it not like the *tǔqiào*?
**Master Yu’s annotation:** *Tǔ*, like *wǎ* (leather pouch), *qiào*, like *dí* (reed pipe).
The bellows’ wind and the pipe’s breath,
both rely on emptiness and lack of intention,
thus motion yields response.

So too, between Heaven and Earth,
the nurturing of all beings without partiality
arises from their emptiness and lack of intention.

**Master Yu’s exegesis:** Between Heaven and Earth—
is it not like the *tǔqiào*?
Empty yet unyielding, moved yet ever responsive.
**Annotation:** *Tǔ* (leather pouch) refers to a skin bellows,
used to fan wind and ignite fire.
*Qiào* (reed pipe) is the *dí* (reed pipe),
meaning Heaven and Earth regard all things as straw-dogs
because of their boundless void,
thus generating all without favor or expectation—
just as the discarded bellows fans wind,
and the reed pipe breathes air.
Ever responsive to demand,
yet without regard for me,
they empty themselves without yielding,
and motion brings forth ever more breath and sound.

This likens the ruler’s empty-hearted silence,
pure transformation and uniform harmony,
so there is no yielding or constraint,
and daily use remains unknowing—
motion brings forth ever more teaching and efficacy.

**Master Héshànggōng said:** Between Heaven and Earth, the void is boundless,
and harmonious *qi* flows freely,
thus all things arise spontaneously.
If a person can eliminate emotions and desires,
restrain indulgence in flavors,
purify the five *zàng* (viscera),
then divine clarity will dwell within them.

Like the *tǔqiào*, within it is empty and void,
thus it can produce sound and breath.

**Master Róng said:** Between Heaven and Earth—
it is like the *tǔqiào*.
Empty yet unyielding,
moved yet ever responsive.
**Annotation:** *Tǔ* (leather pouch) refers to the bellows;
*qiào* (reed pipe) refers to the *suō* (mouth organ’s pipe).
**Explanation:** *Qiāo* (yielding) means exhaustion;
*jiān* (void) means the interior.
The bellows, being hollow within,
can endlessly produce all things.
If a person can empty the heart and body,
deploy wisdom and virtue without limit,
then their efficacy is boundless.

**Master Cheng’s exegesis:** *Tǔ* is the leather pouch;
*qiào* is the reed pipe.
Heaven, Earth, and the Sage empty the heart for benefit—
like the *shēngguǎn* (mouth organ),
when the leather pouch is inflated,
the meaning of emptiness continues in the following passage.
Empty yet unyielding,
moved yet ever responsive.

**Master Yu’s exegesis:** The *tǔqiào* empties the heart without yielding,
and motion brings forth ever more breath and sound.

**Master Héshànggōng said:** If the *tǔqiào* were to abandon emptiness for attachment,
then its inner and outer would be blocked,
and breath would not follow.

**Master Yán said:** Heaven and Earth, though empty,
act with love—
then transformation falters,
and things do not arise fully.
The Sage, though empty,
acts with love—
then virtue does not spread universally,
the realm does not ascend,
grace does not reach deeply,
and deeds are not fully accomplished.
The *tǔqiào*, though empty,
acts with love—
then its interior and exterior are sealed,
and breath does not flow.
Why so?
Because love brings obstruction.

**Master Cheng’s exegesis:** *Qiāo* (yielding) means exhaustion.
The *tǔqiào* is hollow within,
thus breath and sound emerge.
If it were not exhausted,
it would be like Heaven and Earth’s lack of intention,
thus their creative transformation is boundless.
Motion brings forth ever more—
the *tǔqiào* moves, and breath and sound arise;
the Sage responds, and teachings emerge.

**Thirdly, it rejects excessive knowledge and broad learning,
preferring instead to grasp the True.
Excessive speech, though many,
does not surpass holding to the Center.
**Master Yu’s annotation:** Excessive speech without practice
brings only constraint and exhaustion.
Universal love is hard to fulfill,
leading to resentment and hatred,
thus it is better to embrace the *chōnghé* (unifying harmony),
and all will be naturally sufficient.

**Master Yu’s exegesis:** Excessive speech—
that is, much talk of universal love.
Much talk of universal love,
yet in action, it is hard to fulfill,
thus constraint and exhaustion arise without completion.
This shows that it is better to forget and respond in emptiness,
embracing the *chōnghé* (unifying harmony),
then all will naturally suffice.
**Annotation:** ‘Without practice’ means *xùn* (to answer/fulfill),
referring to mere empty words
that do not align with action.

**Master Héshànggōng said:** Excessive speech brings exhaustion,
excessive deeds harm the spirit,
excessive speech harms the body.
With tongue and lips moving,
disaster and calamity are sure to follow.
Better to hold to the Center,
better to hold to virtue within,
nurturing the spirit and guarding the breath,
loving few words.

**Master Yán said:** Heaven and Earth do not speak,
yet through their emptiness,
they attain the Center of all things,
and the generation of beings is boundless.
The Sage does not speak,
yet laws and decrees are empty and in accord with all—
then the celestial prisons are void without prohibition,
the spirits and gods are tranquil without action,
and the realm is vast and orderly,
unaware and unknowing,
yet in great harmony.

**Master Róng said:** *Qióng* (exhaustion) means *kùn* (constraint).
If speech is just and true,
it fills the world without error.
If speech is not just and true,
then calamity enters through the mouth—
this is constraint and exhaustion.
Yet calamity and fortune lie in correctness and error,
not in quantity or lack.
Now, excessive speech brings exhaustion,
warning against the loss of excessive speech,
urging instead the gain of holding to the Center,
so there is no obstruction in teaching,
and inner accord with the forgotten word.

**Master Cheng’s exegesis:** Excessive knowledge—
that is, broad and all-embracing learning.
Exhaustion—
that is, excessive speech.
Broad learning and excessive speech
only increase worldly wisdom,
yet they do not grasp the Dao,
and their essence returns to the *qióngzhōng yīdào* (one path of emptiness and constraint).
Excessive knowledge is but a means for action,
while holding to the Center leads to longevity and eternal vision—
thus they are measured against each other,
and holding to the Center is superior.
Hence, *Zhuangzi* says:
*"When the superficial is destroyed, the essential remains;
when the broad is drowned, the heart is preserved."*

Yang Zhu further remarked:
*"A neighbor loses his sheep through many branching paths,
while a scholar loses the Dao through many methods."*

**Chapter Six: The Unending Valley Spirit**
This chapter follows the previous one because the prior passage emphasized that extensive learning and broad knowledge are inferior to holding to the Center, and thus this chapter clarifies that only by holding to the Center can one attain the Unending Valley Spirit.

Within this chapter, the meaning is divided into two parts:
First, it reveals the profound and mysterious Dao, capable of generating and sustaining the Two Principles.
Second, it illustrates the ceaseless and unchanging, yet effortless operation.

**First Part: Revealing the Profound and Mysterious Dao, Capable of Generating and Sustaining the Two Principles**
Indeed, both Heaven and humanity receive life through the wondrous *qi*. If one cultivates and nourishes it, they attain perfect wholeness. Thus, the Yellow Emperor rode dragons and ascended to the clouds, while Master Shu Qing attached himself to a deer and visited the Han Dynasty—both achieving millennial longevity. They laughed at the countless burial mounds, returning in the eighth month to inspect their homes, seeing the prancing steeds of immortals. The primal *xiānmǎn* (dark, nurturing) *qì* endures, the Valley Spirit preserves life, subtly and enduringly.

By adhering to the singular principle, one achieves eternal solidity;
By consuming the five *yá* (tooth-like, refined essences), one attains the True.

White hair returns to youthful vitality,
Tortoise-like years extend to great longevity.
Seeing the morning fungus and not sighing,
Embracing the great *chūn* (thousand-year) tree with certainty.

To the left, I pat the shoulder of Hongya,
To the right, I draw upon the spirit of Gaoqiu.
How does one reach this?
The subtle principles of nurturing and guarding are profound indeed.

**The Unending Valley Spirit**
**Master Guo’s Annotation:**
*Gǔ* (Valley) is empty yet responsive.
*Shén* (Spirit) is wondrous and unfathomable.
*Sǐ* (Death) signifies rest.
The Valley’s response to sound is unknown—
Yet when there is sensation, it responds,
And its response is as divine,
As divine as its response, yet it never rests.
To illuminate the supreme Dao—
Empty yet generating all things,
Its wondrous operation defies naming,
Thus the Valley Spirit is used as an analogy.

**Master Guo’s Exegesis:**
The Unending Valley Spirit refers to the *xiānmǎn* (dark, nurturing).
The Valley Spirit clarifies how the Valley responds to sound,
Like the Dao responding to things—
When there is sensation, it responds,
And its response is divine.
*Shén* (Spirit) is the name for the unfathomable.
*Death* signifies rest,
Yet the unfathomable response never rests,
Hence, the Valley Spirit does not die.

*Xiān* (Profound) means deep.
*Mǎn* (Taem) means mother.
The Valley Spirit’s response is profoundly mysterious and beyond naming,
Nurturing all things to flourish,
Thus it is called the *xiānmǎn* (dark, nurturing).

The gate of the *xiānmǎn* is called the root of Heaven and Earth.
The operation of the *xiānmǎn* is such that
When there is sensation, it responds,
And its response arises from things,
Thus it is called a gate.

A gate signifies entry and exit.
Heaven and Earth, the greatest of formed things,
Without the operation of the *xiānmǎn*,
Would fragment and disperse.
Thus, they rely on the singular principle as their root,
Hence, it is called the root of Heaven and Earth.

*Gēn* (Root) means origin.

**Master Hé Shànggōng said:**
*Gǔ* (Valley) means nourishment.
If one can nourish the spirit, they will not die.
The spirit refers to the spirits of the five *zàng* (viscera).
The liver houses the *hún* (ethereal soul),
The lungs house the *pò* (corporeal soul),
The heart houses the spirit,
The kidneys house the *jīng* (essence),
The spleen houses the *zhì* (willpower).
When the five *zàng* are all injured,
The five spirits depart.

**Master Yán said:**
The supreme harmony of wondrous *qi*,
Like a wondrous thing as divine,
Emptiness as its dwelling,
Silence as its constant state,
Entering and exiting without openings,
Coming and going without hindrance,
In motion, nothing fails,
In stillness, nothing is incomplete,
Transforming yet not transforming,
Generating yet not generating.

**Master Róng said:**
The Unending Valley Spirit is the *xiānmǎn* (dark, nurturing).
Master Hé Shànggōng spoke of it as nourishing the spirit,
Which is the method of *sǐcún* (thoughtful preservation).
Master Fǔsì spoke of the emptiness within the Valley,
This is metaphorical language.
Though the insights of the true and virtuous are lofty,
They are all explanations of particulars.

Now, I shall speak of this in terms of principle.
*Gǔ* (Valley) is emptiness,
*Xiān* (Profound) is the Dao,
*Mǎn* (Taem) is stillness.

If one has form and spirit,
Then there is life and death.
If there is life and death,
One cannot speak of the Dao,
For it flows and shifts without constancy—
How could it be called still?

If one can empty form and spirit,
Abandoning the self and objects,
Exiting without root,
Gathering *qi* yet not claiming life,
Entering without openings,
Dispersing *qi* yet not claiming death—
Not dying, not living,
This is the meaning of the Valley Spirit.

Life and death are ever-present,
Floating and unstable, lacking substance.
Deep, feminine, and still,
Serene and unmoving—
This is the meaning of *xiānmǎn* (dark, nurturing).

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:**
*Gǔ* (Valley) is emptiness.
*Shén* (Spirit) is luminous intelligence.
Master Hé Shànggōng said:
*Gǔ* (Valley) means nourishment,
Speaking of how the common people wander through life and death
Due to their attachment to desires.
If one can guide and gather the spirit,
Like bathing in emptiness,
With a pure and unobstructed container,
Then one will no longer experience life and death.

This is called the *xiānmǎn* (dark, nurturing).

**Master Guo’s Annotation:**
*Xiān* (Profound) is the name for the unobstructed.
*Mǎn* (Taem) signifies feminine gentleness.
To clarify nourishing the spirit like the Valley,
So that it does not die,
There is nothing better than stillness, retreat, and feminine gentleness—
A pure and unobstructed container of singularity.

**Master Hé Shànggōng said:**
The Dao of not dying lies in the *xiānmǎn* (dark, nurturing).
*Xiān* (Profound) is Heaven,
In humans, it is the nose.
*Mǎn* (Taem) is Earth,
In humans, it is the [mouth].
Heaven nourishes humans with the five *qì*,
Entering through the nose and stored in the heart.
The five *qì*, pure and subtle,
Become the spirit, clarity, intelligence, sound, and harmony.
Their ghost is called *hún* (ethereal soul),
The *hún* is masculine,
Controlling entry and exit through the nose,
Communicating with Heaven,
Thus the nose is called *xiān* (profound).

*Mǎn* (Taem) is Earth,
Earth nourishes humans with the five flavors,
Entering through the mouth and processed by the stomach.
The five flavors, coarse and impure,
Become the form, flesh, bones, and the six emotions.
Their ghost is called *pò* (corporeal soul),
The *pò* is feminine,
Generated through entry and exit by the mouth,
Communicating with Earth,
Thus it is called *mǎn* (taem).

**Master Yán said:**
The *mǎn* (taem), though feminine and yielding, can generate the profound,
Like the distant and unseen yet nurturing as a mother,
Its form unseen.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:**
This continues the previous passage.
*Xiān* (Profound) is the name for the unobstructed.
*Mǎn* (Taem) signifies feminine gentleness.
To clarify nourishing the spirit like the Valley,
So that it does not die,
There is nothing better than stillness, retreat, and feminine gentleness—
A pure and unobstructed container of singularity.

The **Gate of the Profound Taem**—
This is called the **Root of Heaven and Earth**.

**Master Yu’s Annotation:**
Deep and mysterious, the empty Taem,
Capable of mothering all things—
All things arise from it,
Thus it is called the **Gate**.

Heaven and Earth have form,
Hence they rely on it as their fundamental root.

**Master Yu’s Exegesis:**
The function of the Profound Taem—
When stimulated, it responds;
Its response issues forth to all things,
Thus it is called the **Gate**.

The **Gate** signifies entry and exit.
Heaven and Earth, the greatest of formed things,
Without the function of the Profound Taem,
Would fragment and disperse.
Thus, they rely on perceiving the One as their fundamental root—
Hence it is called the **Root of Heaven and Earth**.
**Root** means **origin**.

**Master He Shang Gong said:**
The **Root** is the **Primordial**.
Speaking of the Gate of the Taem,
This is where the **Primordial Qi of Heaven and Earth** circulates.

**Master Yán said:**
The **Great Harmony** generates the One,
Unborn yet undying,
Endless yet unceasing—
Opening and guiding the spirit,
This is the **Root and Primordial** of Heaven and Earth.

**Master Róng said:**
The Dao in stillness is formless and without attributes;
When it moves, the **Earth’s and Heaven’s** phenomena emerge from it,
Thus it is named the **Gate**.
Heaven and Earth depend on it to generate,
Hence it is called the **Root**.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:**
This speaks of the profound, unobstructed Dao,
The feminine, empty, gentle, and still method,
Capable of opening and transforming all things,
Generating and transforming the Two Polarities—
Thus it is called the **Root**.

**Secondly, it clarifies the unobstructed and unceasing,**
**Endless as if existing,**
**Used without exertion.**

**Master Yu’s Annotation:**
The function of the empty Taem is subtle and profound,
Its application as if present,
Its use without intent—
Thus it does not labor.

**Master Yu’s Exegesis:**
**Endless** means subtly unceasing.
The function of the empty Taem is without self-interest.
Subtle and profound, it is called *as if existing*.
Without self-interest, its use is without exertion or fatigue.

**Master He Shang Gong said:**
Endless as if existing—
The nostrils and mouth inhale and exhale,
Should be subtle and profound,
As if existing, yet as if nonexistent.
**Used without exertion**—
The use of qi should be expansive and relaxed,
Not hurried or labored.

**Master Yán said:**
Dynamic and static, profound and mysterious,
As if nonexistent, as if existing,
Accomplishing things and completing affairs,
Without fail—
Shining yet undying,
Used without exertion,
Because its generation is non-generation,
Its form is formless.

**Master Róng said:**
**Endless** means **subtle and profound**.
The Dao of the Profound Taem
Is neither born nor destroyed,
The principle of feminine stillness
Is neither existence nor nonexistence—
Desiring to speak, yet no form is seen;
Desiring to vanish, yet all things arise.
Neither flourishing nor declining,
Neither constant nor interrupted—
Thus it is called **endless**.

**Exertion** means **toil**.
Obtaining the Dao of the Profound Taem,
Its application is boundless,
Effortless and leisurely—
Thus it does not labor.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:**
**Endless**—a subtle, unbroken appearance.
**As if**—a semblance.
**Existing**—having.

If one speaks of the spirit as empty, this is the view of annihilation;
If one speaks of the spirit as having substance, this is the view of permanence.
Earlier, the emptiness of the spirit was spoken of,
And thus immortality was attained—
Yet still, fearing that students might stagnate in this emptiness,
Now it is said: *If* it exists,
To cure the view of annihilation.

Again, fearing that students might drown in the having,
The word *as if* is appended to cure the view of permanence—
Thus, employing this practice of neither non-existence nor existence,
This mind of neither permanence nor interruption,
As the essential technique for cultivating the Dao,
It is not laborious yet truly authentic.

Thus, the *Western Ascension Scripture* says:
*"To move is to bear the burden of kalpas,
Reflecting on how wearying and toilsome it is—
My learning is in having no learning,
Only then can one illuminate the natural."*
