*Imperial Commentary and Exegesis by Tang Xuanzong, with annotations by He Shang Gong (严君平), Master Rong (李荣), and Cheng’s Exegesis (成玄英疏) by the Western Hua Monk (西华法师).*

*On the Practice of Warfare (Yongbing) #69*

This chapter follows the previous one, for the prior chapter expounded upon those who guard and uphold the Three Treasures, who can attain the Dao/Way’s ultimate fruit of antiquity. Thus, this chapter elucidates how such practitioners embody the dual transcendence of emptiness and existence, never abandoning great compassion.

Within this single chapter, four distinct teachings unfold:
1. **The application of martial power in dealing with all things**, demonstrating that all phenomena are illusory;
2. **A reiteration of prior teachings**, to reveal true emptiness;
3. **The practitioner who forsakes compassion**, who grows reckless and loses the Dao/Way;
4. **The exercise of wisdom in traversing the world**, which never strays from great compassion.

### **1. The application of martial power in dealing with all things, demonstrating that all phenomena are illusory.**
When the sage-king **Emperor Yao** ruled, he slew **Gonggong** yet lamented his wickedness; when **Great Yu** acted, he struck down **Fangfeng** yet displayed righteous resolve. **Tang** exiled **Jie** to **Wutiao**, and **Wu** slaughtered **Zhou** at **Muye**. The **Divine Lady** (Xuannü) blazed forth, and the **White Deceiver** (Bai Jian) stood tall—though they waged external war against evil men, they were ultimately inwardly shamed by the triumph of virtue.

The **Old Master** (Laojun) teaches caution: *"Retreat one foot, and my advance will be halted; press forward one inch, and I will not dare."* He feared losing his treasured virtue, lamenting the fleeting, deluded life of mortals. How could they know that when the **high black crow** (gao wu) is exhausted, the **fine bow** (liang gong) is concealed; when enemy states are diminished, the **strategists** (mou chen) perish?

Before the **military wells** (junjing) were dug, the soldiers would not thirst; before the **camp rations** (junfan) were cooked, the generals would not speak of hunger. Though **Bai Qi** was put to death in the **Qin court** and **Han Xin** was executed in the **Han prison**, why not follow the **two sages’** (Er Hao) example—hanging up one’s official hat at the **eastern gate**, emulating the **Four Worthies’** (Sihao) virtues, and letting thirst be nourished in the **Southern Hills**?

Honor the **Great Sage’s** (Dasheng) clear instruction on self-restraint: *"As long as my body remains, what need have I for further gain?"*

### **On the Practice of Warfare:**
**Imperial Commentary:** The Old Master deplored the age’s reckless slaughter in war, thus assuming antiquity to admonish it.

*"On the Practice of Warfare"* refers to the following text.

**Imperial Exegesis:** The Old Master lamented the times, where lightheartedness toward enemies brings calamity and delight in killing leads to ruin. Thus, he invoked ancient teachings to warn against such folly, and *"On the Practice of Warfare"* refers to the next sentence.

**Master He** (Heshang Gong) says: *"He expounds the Dao/Way of warfare. The Old Master deplored the age’s warfare, thus assuming his own words to set forth their meaning."*

**Master Rong** (Master Rong) says: *"He cites ancient military strategies."*

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:** *"On the Practice of Warfare"* means **martial power and wisdom** (quan zhi), the means by which one transforms and governs all beings—it is also how cultivators apply the **Six Senses** (liujing) in navigating the **phenomenal world** (chenjing). *"On the Practice of Warfare"* refers to the following text.

*"I do not dare to act as the aggressor but only as the defender,"*
**Imperial Commentary:** *"I do not dare to act as the aggressor but only as the defender"* means not daring to press forward one inch while retreating one foot. When the aggressor moves, he creates conflict and covetousness; when the defender remains passive, he relies on compassion to protect himself. To guard well is to achieve total victory; to create conflict is to court defeat. Though advancing even slightly risks stirring trouble, retreating even greatly does not lose humility. Thus, one must not dare to press forward one inch while retreating one foot.*

**Imperial Exegesis:** *"I"* refers to the practitioner of warfare. The aggressor is the first to act, the defender responds afterward. The aggressor’s advance stirs conflict and covetousness; the defender’s retreat relies on compassion to guard himself. This teaches that ancient warriors, when wielding martial power, must always restrain themselves with compassion and never act impulsively.

Thus it is said: *"I do not dare to act as the aggressor but only as the defender."*

**Master He** says: *"I do not dare to act as the aggressor"*—the aggressor is the first to raise arms. *"But only as the defender"*—the defender is one who yields without provocation, always following the **Heavenly Mandate** (tian) before acting.*

**Master Rong** says: *"To raise arms first within one’s own state is to act as the aggressor; to move first in battle is to act as the aggressor. First to raise arms or first to move invites arrogance and peril. Now, if I wish to preserve myself, I must not dare to act as the aggressor. To yield without provocation, to follow without leading, is to act as the defender."*

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:** *"Aggressor"* refers to **myself** (my body); *"defender"* refers to **the enemy** (the opposing forces). Since both **essence and matter** (genchen) are emptied and all phenomena are illusory, there is neither a self to be preserved nor an enemy to be assailed. Thus, there is no need to advance or retreat.

*"I do not dare to press forward one inch while retreating one foot."*
**Imperial Exegesis:** To retreat and defend in accordance with the Dao/Way is to achieve victory; to advance and seize by force leads to ruin. Though advancing even slightly risks the sin of greed, retreating even greatly gains the virtue of humility. Now, since I despise their strife, I say *"I do not dare to press forward one inch,"* and since I uphold compassion, I say *"I retreat one foot."*

**Master He** says: *"To invade another’s territory, to plunder their wealth and treasures, is to advance. To close the gates and defend the city is to retreat."*

**Master Rong** says: *"Not to use force to invade others, hence *"I do not dare to press forward one inch."* To rely on accumulated virtue to defend internally, hence *"I retreat one foot."*

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:** *"Advance"* means **to take**; *"retreat"* means **to release**. One inch signifies **nothingness**; one foot signifies **existence**. Since both **wisdom and the world** (jingjing) are transcended and all phenomena are illusory, one abides in the **middle** (zhongyi), detached from both **action and non-action** (liangpian). Thus, there is nothing to take, nor anything to release.

### **2. Reiterating prior teachings to reveal true emptiness.**
This is called **"action without action"** (xing wu xing),

**Imperial Commentary:** When one retreats as the defender and does not contend, though one may move to meet the enemy, it is the same as **"action without action."**

**Imperial Exegesis:** To march an army relies on halting the enemy; the key is not to contend. Now, as the defender retreating one foot, one achieves victory without contention. Though one moves to meet the enemy, it aligns with **"action without action."**

**Master He** says: *"If the enemy does not cease, he becomes a robber of the world. Though one moves to punish him, one does not act with malice."*

**Master Rong** says: *"Warfare originates from the enemy; I truly do not act first. I respond to things but do not initiate action—this is **"action without action."***

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:** Having transcended the duality of existence and non-existence, and penetrating the **forgetfulness of all perceptions** (jingguan), one thus moves in **"action without action."**

*"Though I have no arms to wield,"*
**Imperial Exegesis:** *"To wield arms"* signifies **anger**. Now, since one wages war without anger, it is as if there are no arms to wield. Hence it is said: *"Though I have no arms to wield."*

「○ Master He says: *"Not to be angry is as though there were no arms to wield."*

○ Master Yan says: *"This demonstrates not harming others."*

First to issue commands and rewards—those who submit early are rewarded, those who submit late are spared, those who surrender slightly are benefited, those who surrender greatly are prosperous, the guilty are pardoned, the capable are appointed—yet it is as though there were no arms to wield in anger.

○ Master Rong says: *"To wage war in anger is to use arms to wield them. Now, when the enemy retreats a step, no arms are needed to repel them, hence it is said: 'as though there were no arms to wield.'"*

○ Master Cheng’s Exegesis: *"Having abandoned limbs and senses, there are no arms to wield."*

**Still, there is no enemy,**
○ Imperial Exegesis: *"Still"* means "to draw in." To draw in the enemy is to desire contention while not contending, hence it is as though there were no enemy to draw in.

○ Imperial Exegesis: *"Still"* means "to draw in." The one who draws in the enemy desires contention, but now non-contention is held as virtue—thus, there is no enemy to draw in, hence it is said: *"Still, there is no enemy."*

○ Master He says: *"Even if there is a desire to draw in the enemy, it is as though there were no enemy to draw in."*

○ Master Rong says: *"To draw in that enemy is to make them return to having no enemy."*

○ Master Cheng’s Exegesis: *"All phenomena are empty illusions; there is no enemy to rely upon."*

**To grasp without weapons.**
○ Imperial Exegesis: *"To grasp weapons"* signifies killing. Now, since compassion is the principle, even if one grasps them, it is as though there were no weapons.

○ Imperial Exegesis: *"To grasp"* means "to hold." Weapons are the five weapons—spears, halberds, and the like. He who holds weapons intends to kill the enemy, but since compassion is the principle, he restrains his weapons—thus, though weapons exist, there is no intent to kill, making it as though there were no weapons.

○ Master He says: *"Even if one desires to grasp and wield them, it is as though there were no weapons to hold or use."*

Why? Because harming their people invites retribution from Heaven, encountering an unrighteous ruler brings pity and sorrow.

○ Master Rong says: *"To harm the unrighteous is to wield weapons to cease warfare. Punishments without cruelty do not lose compassion; those who yearn for the Dao return of their own accord—there are no weapons to wield."*

○ Master Cheng’s Exegesis: *"Having abandoned form and wisdom, there are no weapons to use."*

**Thirdly, it clarifies that those who abandon compassion are lighthearted, lose the Dao, and invite disaster.**
Disaster is none greater than being lighthearted toward the enemy—being lighthearted toward the enemy nearly causes the loss of my treasure.

○ Imperial Exegesis: *"The greatest disaster is being lighthearted toward the enemy. Being lighthearted toward the enemy leads to peril, and one loses the treasure of compassion."*

○ Imperial Exegesis: *"Nearly"* means "close to." *"Loss"* means "to lose." *"Treasure"* refers to compassion. The greatest disaster is being lighthearted and contemptuous toward the enemy, indulging in conflict—thus, one is close to losing the treasure of compassion.

Moreover, losing compassion means defeat and ruin in war, and dispersion in defense. Though the paths of disaster may vary, dispersion and ruin are the greatest calamities.

○ Master He says: *"Disaster is none greater than being lighthearted toward the enemy. The harm of chaos is none greater than deceiving and plundering a lighthearted enemy without cease—lighthearted warfare leads to defeat and ruin. Being lighthearted toward the enemy nearly causes the loss of my treasure—'nearly' means 'close to,' and 'treasure' means 'life.' Deceiving a lighthearted enemy nearly causes the loss of life."*

○ Master Yan says: *"Being lighthearted toward the enemy is self-indulgence. Though warfare may seem flawless, one must not lightly treat the enemy. Lightheartedness breeds deceit; when disaster strikes, one loses advantage. Fortune departs, calamity arrives—this is the loss of the natural treasure."*

○ Master Rong says: *"Warfare is rooted in killing and should not be perpetually waged in times of conflict. The Dao values stillness and quietude; thus, one governs things through non-action. The priority is to settle the people without harm. If one abandons the Way of non-action and advances with restless warfare, being lighthearted toward the enemy, the state will collapse and the people perish—this is the greatest disaster. A prosperous state with abundant people, a sage ruler and virtuous ministers—this is called possessing treasure. When the people perish and grain is exhausted, ministers are humiliated and the ruler is in peril—this is the loss of treasure."*

○ Master Cheng’s Exegesis: *"Disaster is none greater than contempt for the enemy. 'Contempt' means to lightly trample; 'enemy' refers to the frontier realm. Lightly staining oneself with dust invites the retribution of the Three Realms, thus bringing great disaster. Contempt for the enemy nearly causes the loss of my treasure—'nearly' means 'completely,' and 'treasure' refers to the Three Treasures from the previous chapter. To contain compassion while being bold is to contempt the enemy, inviting great calamity, thus completely losing the Three Treasures."*

**Fourthly, it clarifies that when engaging with circumstances and applying wisdom, nothing surpasses great compassion.**
Thus, when armies clash, the one who exhibits compassion first shall prevail.

○ Imperial Exegesis: *"Antagonize"* means "to raise." When two states raise their armies against each other, the one who is compassionate and pitiful toward others wins.

○ Imperial Exegesis: *"Antagonize"* means "to raise." When two states raise their armies against each other, it is because their rulers practice the Dao, their generals act with compassion, and they are merciful toward others—not seeking excessive slaughter—that they achieve victory.

○ Master He says: *"Thus, when armies clash—the two enemies engage in battle—compassion prevails. Compassion is mercy and benevolence; soldiers do not approach death."*

○ Master Yan says: *"The ruler is the heart and core of the state; the army is its formidable spirit. Concealed in the mysterious realm, it is only used when unavoidable. Thus, I instruct my generals to delight the soldiers, be compassionate toward people, and move with Heaven’s assistance."*

○ Master Rong says: *"When both sides raise their forces, it is called 'antagonizing armies.' Whether many or few, they are evenly matched. Being lighthearted toward the enemy, greedy for killing—this is inferior. Stillness must rely on the Dao; action must follow its laws. Never losing compassion, compassion can govern all—thus, the compassionate prevail. Internally, it clarifies that afflictions are manifold; without wisdom, they cannot be broken. To expound its method, it is said: 'Warfare has its principles.'*

*The ruler must be strong and resolute; as a guest, one must be yielding and flexible. The traveler desires to cease movement and return to stillness, knowing to be strong as a ruler and yielding as a guest—hence it is said: 'I dare not be the ruler but must be the guest.'*

*The Dao, though seemingly obscured, advances like retreat. Learning has nothing to learn; cultivation has nothing to cultivate—advancing not an inch yet retreating a foot. Recognizing that all conditions are contingent and teachings are all empty, one moves in 'action without action.'"*

The myriad realms are void and tranquil, yet one’s own body is also empty and pure—*repelling without arms*. Internally, wisdom is lost; *holding without weapons*. Externally, emotions and desires are severed, yet still there is no enemy.

If one abandons emotions and indulges in extreme desires, straying from the Dao and forfeiting one’s life, they lose their precious treasure.

Wisdom and afflictions—these two kinds always follow one in turn. *Resisting is like yielding*; if skillful means are applied to wisdom, subtle compassion is never lost. When defilements are exhausted, even the mind relaxes; solemn and unburdened, the compassionate prevail.

○ *Master Cheng’s Commentary*: If, then. Compassion, mercy. Resisting, lifting. The roots of sense and dust press upon one; lifting the eyes, the forms and colors correspond.

If one still employs the great mercy of the heart to survey the coming realm, then subject and object are both emptied, and self and other are pure. Hence, all dharmas become realms of supreme victory.

The Way of my words is most easy to know—*Chapter Seventy*.

The Way of my words follows the previous chapter, for the previous chapter expounds the proper method of dealing with people and wielding power, demonstrating the true emptiness of the Dao. Thus, this chapter follows, clarifying the teachings of the spoken word and lamenting that people cannot know them.

In this chapter, the text opens with two distinctions: first, lamenting that the profound teaching is easy to know yet common folk cannot grasp it; second, illustrating the sage’s subtle understanding, hence *outerly veiled, inwardly revealed*.

First, lamenting that the profound teaching is easy to know yet common folk cannot grasp it.

*The Book of Yu* says: The heart of the Dao is subtle, subtle then easy to perceive; the heart of people is dark, dark then difficult to see. They follow the crowd and drift with conventions, chasing fame and gain. Blessings are light as feathers, yet they do not know to bear them upon themselves; calamities are heavy as mountains, yet they do not know to avoid them from themselves.

The common folk are indeed deluded in their measure; truly, this saying holds. The Way beneath heaven is easy to practice, yet none surpass the upright. Uninvolved, unconcerned, with no attachments nor demands.

Where is the resting place of the mind? Roaming the wilds of Dongting, boundless in all directions—no hindrance. In the silent night or the celestial halls, all paths are the same, utterly pure. Shutting the eyes, one arrives at the *Pure Land of Jade*; forgetting the mind, one sits in the *Empty Palace of Jade*. Still and unobstructed by dust, what need is there for the wise to change? Yet they stubbornly persist, indulging in luxury at dawn’s table; staining themselves with sounds and colors in their attachments. Slothful and fixed in evil deeds, they sink into the *difficult-to-abandon* realm, unaware of the easy-to-practice teaching. The sage in rags is indeed worthy of pity.

My words are most easy to know, most easy to practice.

○ *Master Yu’s Annotation*: The Old Master says: My spoken words accord with principle, hence easy to know; they are simple in practice, hence easy to act.

○ *Master Yu’s Commentary*: The Old Master says: My words are such that they clarify principle. When principle is clarified, words are forgotten—hence easy to know. My affairs are such that they involve no affairs; simplicity in affairs means no action—hence easy to practice.

○ *Master He Shang Gong* says: The Old Master’s words are concise and easy to know, brief and easy to practice.

○ *Master Yan* says: The sage’s words are the unsaid words; their deeds are the *doing of the undone*. They sever the Way of words, abandon the mind and discard intentions. Their actions are the manifestation of naturalness. All beings fulfill their desires and attain eternal life. Words are easy to know; affairs are easy to practice.

○ *Master Rong* says: The sage’s teachings are concise in words yet rich in principle, clearly revealing their meaning—hence easy to know. Holding to the One, they sever the myriad delusions; embracing non-action, they cut free from burdens—hence easy to practice.

○ *Master Cheng’s Commentary*: My words are the same as the previous chapter. What is stained is not truly stained—this is easy to know. To practice without the form of practice is most easy to practice. None beneath heaven can know, none can practice.

○ *Master Yu’s Annotation*: The people of the world are entangled in words and do not awaken; they are burdened by affairs and do not simplify—hence none can know, none can practice.

○ *Master Yu’s Commentary*: This laments that the multitude cannot comprehend the *wordless word*, clinging to words and stagnating in teaching. They are bewildered by the words of instruction, hence none can know. Unable to perceive the *affairless affair*, burdened by affairs and lost in dusty matters—hence none can practice.

○ *Master He Shang Gong* says: They love the weak and soft, yet crave the strong and rigid.

○ *Master Rong* says: The common folk do not adhere to the mysterious teachings; they cling to ignorance and have not yet opened to wisdom. They do not recognize this Way—hence none can know. They are lost in desires and do not habituate in non-action; they abandon the true and follow the false—hence none can practice.

○ *Master Cheng’s Commentary*: None, that is, without. The Old Master’s words are easy to know and practice, yet the people of the world are dull and obtuse. None can know the profound and empty words; none can follow the teaching and practice.

Words have a *root*; affairs have a *master*.

○ *Master Yu’s Annotation*: Words reside in principle; when principle is attained, words are forgotten—hence the root of words is in the wordless. Affairs reside in accomplishment; when success is achieved, one does not cling to them—hence the master of affairs is in the affairless.

○ *Master Yu’s Commentary*: This reverses the explanation of easy-to-know and easy-to-practice. Root, origin. Master, lord. Words exist to clarify principle; when principle is attained, words are forgotten—hence the root of words is in the unsaid. Affairs exist to achieve success; when success is attained, one abandons affairs—hence the master of affairs is in the affairless. Is this not easy to know and practice?

○ *Master He Shang Gong* says: My words have a root and origin; affairs have lords and subjects. The world’s people, if they do not know them, are not without virtue—it is they who oppose me.

○ *Master Rong* says: Root, origin. Master, lord. Taking virtue and the Dao as the origin, this is truly easy to know. Taking non-action as the lord, this is truly easy to practice. Those who lose the origin and chase the end are many; those who do not embody the true root and abandon emotions to defy nature are numerous. How could they know that the lord and master are such that all follow and practice accordingly? Hence it is said: None beneath heaven can know or practice.

○ *Master Cheng’s Commentary*: Words, the scriptures and teachings. Master, the Son of Heaven.

The teachings, though broad, find their essence in the *Zhongyuan* (Recondite Mystery). Worldly affairs, though manifold, are governed by the Lord and Master. Seizing this essential meaning reveals what is easy to know.

It is only because of their ignorance that they fail to know me.
*御注*: It is only because the common people lack the awakened understanding that they do not know my teaching of non-speech and non-affairs.

*御疏*: "Do not know me" means they do not know my teachings. It is only because the common people are bewildered and lack awakened understanding, bound by names and forms, unable to grasp the principles. In affairs, they cling to affairs; in speech, they are entangled in words—thus they fail to grasp my teaching of non-speech and non-affairs.

Again, it is explained: The Old Master said, "Only what I know is what lies in non-knowing," yet the people of the world use knowing to seek knowing, hence they do not know me.

*Master He Shang Gong* says: It is only because the world’s people are ignorant that my Dao and virtue remain obscure, unseen externally, reaching the utmost subtlety—thus they are without knowing.

*Master Rong* says: All things are shrouded in delusion, lacking even a speck of discernment within, hence it is said they are without knowing. Lost in principle and straying from the Way, they lack the wisdom of ten thousand things externally, hence they do not know me.

*Master Cheng’s Commentary*: "Do not know me" is the same as "do not know my teachings." Only those beings who are ignorant and dull-witted cannot comprehend my profound words. Those who know me are few, hence those who follow me are noble.

*御注*: Those who truly understand my teaching of forgetting knowing are rare. The law of my speechless instruction is thus most noble.

*御疏*: "Few" means "rare." "Law" means "principle." The Old Master said that those who understand my teaching of knowing while forgetting knowing are indeed few. If one follows and practices my words as law, then they may be held in honor.

*Master He Shang Gong* says: "Few" means "rare." Only those who attain the Dao can know me, hence they are noble.

*Master Rong* says: The busy and petty value names, the petty-minded love profit. Few can embody the Dao, hence it is said those who know me are few. The weak and lost do not return; their return lies in the true path. Those who drift do not reflect; their reflection lies in the true source. The Dao is thus honored, and the law is thus noble.

*Master Cheng’s Commentary*: Those who know me are few, for the common mind is shallow and many are deluded, few truly comprehending the sacred teachings. Those who follow me are noble—"follow" means "law." Adhering to my scriptures and teachings, practicing them, and attaining the sacred fruit, this is why they are noble.

Next, it is shown that the Sage’s wisdom is profound yet externally veiled, internally illuminated. Hence the Sage wears coarse cloth while harboring jade.

*御注*: Wearing coarse cloth means concealing the external. Harboring jade means illuminating the internal. Thus, those who know me are few.

*御疏*: "Coarse cloth" refers to a rough garment, worn by the lowly. Wrapping oneself in coarse cloth conceals fine garments beneath. Jade is pure and lustrous, fitting to compare with the virtuous gentleman. This is said to reveal the Sage’s inner wisdom, outwardly appearing foolish, hence "wearing coarse cloth," and inwardly possessing wisdom, hence "harboring jade."

*Master He Shang Gong* says: Wearing coarse cloth means being thin externally; harboring jade means being rich internally. It is to hide treasure and conceal virtue, not revealing it to others.

*Master Yan* says: Wearing coarse cloth means being meager in body; harboring jade means being rich in spirit.

*Master Rong* says: Conforming to the world and blending with dust, outwardly showing coarse garments—this is wearing coarse cloth. The Recondite Virtue is unstained, pure and luminous—this is harboring jade.

*Master Cheng’s Commentary*: Knowing the Sage’s words and following the Sage’s teachings, with understanding and practice complete, one thus becomes a Sage. Coarse cloth is the garment of rustics; jade is a precious treasure. Externally blending with the world, wearing coarse cloth; internally serene and empty, harboring jade. Harboring jade means outwardly dwelling in the mundane while always true; wearing coarse cloth means inwardly empty and focused while interacting with others.

**Chapter Seventy-One: Knowing the Unknown**
This chapter follows the previous one because the previous chapter illuminated the Sage’s knowing, hence externally veiled and internally illuminated. Thus, this chapter follows, showing that even though one may know, there are many who mistake knowing for non-knowing. This chapter’s meaning is divided into two parts: first, revealing the traces of the original traces, demonstrating responses adapting to circumstances; second, revealing the stillness within responses, manifesting the Sage’s heart unburdened.

**First: Revealing the traces of the original traces, demonstrating responses adapting to circumstances.**

To shut the door and block the senses is the grand rule of the great Sage. To curb desires and be cautious of subtleties is the exemplary standard of the ancient worthies. Hence, the Duke of Zhou’s temple was restored with threefold silence from the golden mouth, and the Master’s courtyard saw twice-repeated words from the white jade tablet. Ji Bu was esteemed for a single promise, yet He Chen’s extravagance led to ruin at ten thousand coins. Austerity brings clarity and tranquility; extravagance invites reproach and calamity. Liu Kun, embodying the Dao, answered the Han Emperor with evident clarity. Yan Zi nearly attained it, dwelling in Confucius’ gate as if in ignorance. How could he compare with the clamorous thief Zhi, who died for gain at Dong Ling? The meticulous Jiang Chong perished in the Northern Prison from slander. Geng Chun was mocked in the marketplace and met with great disaster. Kong Guang did not betray the secret at Wen Shu, thus preserving his life.

Doing leads to ruin. Recently, observing the drilling of Hun Dun, one fails to grasp its subtlety. Yet, if one heeds the admonition of the enemy’s mirror, a hundred hooks will lead to ruin, while nurturing a chicken fully ensures victory. The Sage’s illness—is it for the sake of common folk?

Knowing the unknown...

「若不知而强知，则为知之病矣。知而绝知，不困於知知，故不生祸乱，而知之病息矣。
　　**知不知，上**—圣人妙契重玄，迹不乖本，洞忘虚寂，知则无知，至本虚凝，故称为上。圣人不言知，以其病病众生之强知，故不自病，怀通达之智，托於不知者，欲使天下质朴忠正，各守纯性。小人不悟此意，妄行强知之事，以自显着，终伤身损命，灭寿消年矣。

　　**不知知，病**—常俗之人强谓有知，执取着之缚，故为行之病。所照之境触境皆空，能鉴之智无智不寂，能所俱泯，境智同忘，若照如无照，知如无知，则为上德；否则，多知多失，损命伤身，是知之病也。

　　**人不畏威**—上天有龙象雷霆之威，冥司有三途五苦之罚。人若不畏破裂之苦，须臾堕地狱，遭极辛苦：隐隐搏天之羽，飞劫石而难周；皎皎日月之晖，照幽涂而莫晓；岩岩铜柱左右伤身，凛凛刀山纵横碎骨。魂魄号叫，思脱而无闻；出气成姻，吞铁丸而喉烂。前生何罪，得至於斯？良由狭其所居，不修於命，岂知唐尧化美，广辟四门，殷帝含仁，大开三面？吉祥止止，道德淳淳，其度量若大鹏举赤霄，长鲲跃沧海：举逸翮而纵凌唳，直压云天；蓄巨鳞而鼓波涛，横击淇渤。不知上下，莫辨东西，岂厌其生，以成偏狭，去彼取此者？此乃圣人之图也。」

If the people do not fear the lesser threats, then the greatest calamities shall come.

**Commentary (御注):** That which is truly a threat and worthy of fear is called *威 (Wei)*.

It is said that when one does not fear small matters, being careless of the subtle and minute, then the greatest and most fearful consequences shall arise.

**Exegesis (御疏):** That which is truly a threat and worthy of fear is called *威 (Wei)*.

The onset of misfortune and harm begins with the trivial and insignificant. Accumulated, these become burdensome afflictions—great threats. If one does not heed the small and subtle, then the great and fearful consequences shall come to pass.

**Master He Shang’s Saying (河上公曰):** *Wei* is harm. If one does not fear small harms, then great harms shall come—meaning death itself.

Those who fear should cultivate *jing* (精) and nurture *shen* (神), aligning with Heaven and Earth.

**Master Yan’s Saying (严曰):** Prosperity and decline, fortune and misfortune, all arise from oneself. If one does not fear the subtle, then greater fears shall manifest.

**Master Rong’s Saying (荣曰):** *Wei* refers to laws and punishments. If one does not fear minor transgressions, accumulating evil without restraint, violating laws and taboos, then ruin and death shall follow—great threats shall come.

Within, one does not fear the defilements of dust, indulging desires without restraint. When desires run wild, *jing* scatters; when the form is defiled, *shen* departs. When *shen* departs, the form decays; when *jing* scatters, the body weakens. Thus, one who enters the True Dao without *lǜ* (绿, vitality) becomes prey to birth and death—great threats shall come.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis (成疏):** *Wei* refers to punishments and laws, as in the scriptures and precepts. Great threats are the three evil realms and the punishments of the Northern City (地狱). It is said that those who disregard scriptures and precepts, recklessly committing evils, shall face the winds of punishment and great retribution—it shall surely come to pass.

**Second Admonition: Cultivate an Open Heart to Attain the True Source**

Do not narrow your dwelling.

**Commentary (御注):** The dwelling of the spirit is the heart.

To not narrow is to eliminate emotions and desires.

**Exegesis (御疏):** The dwelling of the spirit is the heart. One must forget emotions and desires, softening and widening the mind, allowing the spirit chambers to rest, so that the spirit may reside in the heart, and life may be preserved.

**Master He Shang’s Saying (河上公曰):** The heart, as the dwelling of the spirit, must be open and yielding, not narrow and constricted.

**Master Yan’s Saying (严曰):** No greater calamity exists than losing one’s body; no greater blessing than preserving life. The way to preserve life lies in nurturing the spirit, and the key to nurturing the spirit is in stillness and openness.

**Master Rong’s Saying (荣曰):** Do not narrow your dwelling, do not grow weary of your life. People take life as joy, cherishing birth as noble. Yet they fail to rest quietly to nurture life, cultivate virtue to ward off death, wandering like lost travelers, clinging to foreign places as vast, while despising their homeland as narrow. This is to narrow one’s dwelling.

Prolonging evil harms conduct; indulging desire harms the body. To act thus is to court death, unable to endure long. To weary of life—this is what must be avoided.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis (成疏):** Do not narrow your dwelling, do not weary of your life. *Yàn* (厌) means to abandon; *xiá* (狭) means inferior. *Jū* (居) means to dwell. Your life is the heart. It is said that those who cultivate the Dao must keep the heart unencumbered, not confining emotions to narrow or inferior states, abandoning the source of life. Why? Though the body is empty, it is the vessel for receiving the Dao. One must neither cling to it nor reject it. To cling brings attachment to action; to reject falls into the illusion of emptiness. Neither clinging nor rejecting, dwelling in the middle while forgetting the middle—this is the way of the True Scholar.

Do not weary of your life.

**Commentary (御注):** That which the body generates is the spirit. To not weary is to have few thoughts and desires, avoiding exhaustion.

**Exegesis (御疏):** That which the body generates is the spirit. *Yàn* (厌) means to despise. The spirit is what gives life, hence it is called that which the body generates. The spirit thrives in emptiness and stillness; one must purify the heart and quiet the mind, and the spirit shall return. If one indulges desires, exhausting the spirit’s purity, or engages in frivolous schemes, then *jing* and *qi* shall scatter and dissipate. When they dissipate, death follows. Thus, it is admonished to not weary of the spirit, preserving the way of enduring life.

**Master He Shang’s Saying (河上公曰):** That which sustains life is the spirit, dwelling in emptiness, favoring stillness. If one overeats, neglects the Dao, and indulges in lust, filling the mind with perversity, this is to harm the root and weary the spirit.

Only those who do not weary shall not be wearyed.

**Commentary (御注):** Only those who do not weary the spirit shall find the spirit does not weary of them in return.

**Exegesis (御疏):** The *Dao* lends itself to those who honor it daily. The form is sustained by the spirit. If one loves the Dao and preserves the spirit, it is said, "Only those who do not weary shall not be wearyed." Cleansing impurities and stilling thoughts, being singular and pure, the spirit does not weary of the person—hence, "it is so."

**Master He Shang’s Saying (河上公曰):** Only those who do not weary the spirit—cleansing the heart of filth, serene and desireless—shall find the spirit dwelling within them without weariness.

**Master Rong’s Saying (荣曰):** Life arises from the Dao, form is completed by the spirit. If one loves the Dao and preserves the spirit, it is said, "Only those who do not weary shall not be wearyed." Cleansing impurities and stilling thoughts, the mind becomes tranquil, the form pure. When the spirit attaches to the person and the Dao cherishes them, it is said, "it is so."

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis (成疏):** Only those who cultivate the realm of refinement—neither empty nor substantial—can truly cultivate it. Wisdom neither clings nor rejects; rejection aligns with wisdom, hence it is not wearying.

**Third: Illuminating the Sage’s Proof to Show Taking and Discarding**

Thus, the Sage knows himself without revealing himself,

**Commentary (御注):** Thus, the Sage knows himself without revealing himself, loves himself without arrogance. Knowing his own body, he wards off fearful matters. Loving his own body, he avoids the guilt of wearying the spirit. He does not reveal his abilities to invite misfortune, nor does he exalt himself to gather resentment. Abandon this revealing and exalting; embrace this knowing and loving.

**Exegesis (御疏):** *Zì zhī* (自知) is self-reflection and introspection, preventing harm in its subtlety, ensuring no fearful matters arise. *Bù zì xiàn* (不自见) means not to flaunt one’s talents before others, lest one deviate from reason and invite misfortune.

Thus, **Master Héshàng Gōng** said: The Sage knows himself, and thereby knows his own gains and losses. He does not reveal himself, meaning he does not display his **virtue/power** and beauty outwardly, but keeps them within.

**Róng** said: Therefore, the Sage knows himself without revealing himself, loves himself without arrogance. Thus, he abandons the latter to embrace the former. Ordinary emotions stray from the **Dao/Way**, and so they become **unaware** (無識). The Sage’s wisdom penetrates reason, so he knows himself and forgets the distinctions of self and others, obliterates sensory perceptions, and thus does not reveal himself. **Treasure the spirit and spare the qi**, firmly resolve to cultivate the **Dao/Way**, not lightly squandering this life, hence it is said: love himself without exalting himself, not holding cheap what is small nor despising what is low, acting to benefit others, and in his aspirations, harmonizing high and low. Thus, it is said: he does not exalt himself.

Those who know and love themselves have awakened to reason; those who reveal and exalt themselves are lost in delusion. The Sage speaks of self-transformation to guide all things, making them aware of their proper return. He discards the delusion of revealing and exalting to take up self-knowing and self-loving, thereby preserving his true nature.

**Chéng’s Exegesis (成疏):** His wisdom aligns with the **Dao/Way’s** realm, penetrating the true source of **dharma**. Thus, he knows himself. The four **Great Elements** (四大) are provisionally assembled; through **sitting meditation** (坐忘) and dissolution of the body (隳體), he does not reveal himself.

He loves himself without exalting himself.

**Róng’s Exegesis (御疏):** The Sage cherishes and protects his own body, abstaining from cravings and desires, so that the spirit does not weary, and he does not exalt himself—meaning he does not boast of his own worth, nor oppress others, for such behavior would only gather resentment.

**Master Héshàng Gōng** said: Love himself means to cherish his own body, thereby preserving the **qi**. Not exalt himself means not to seek high status or fame in the world.

**Chéng’s Exegesis (成疏):** Nurturing the true nature of his essence, he does not lightly indulge in sensual desires—this is loving himself. In humility and quiet retreat, he places others before himself—this is not exalting himself.

Therefore, he discards the former to embrace the latter.

**Róng’s Commentary (御注):** Discard the revealing and exalting; take up the knowing and loving.

**Róng’s Exegesis (御疏):** To discard revealing and exalting, to take up knowing and loving—this is the Sage attaining **equanimous wisdom** (平等智), comprehending the **emptiness of **dharma**-nature** (法性空). Reason holds no distinction between taking and discarding; he opens his teachings to guide the ordinary, using metaphorical language to this end.

**Master Héshàng Gōng** said: Discard revealing and exalting, take up knowing and loving.

**Chéng’s Exegesis (成疏):** Discard revealing and exalting, take up knowing and loving—to show all things a mirror of warning, hence the metaphor of taking and discarding.

**Chapter 73: "Courageous and Bold"**

This chapter follows the previous because the prior passage reveals how sentient beings, lacking wisdom, fear neither the **Dharma-net** nor the **Three Paths of Retribution**, thus sinking into suffering. Hence, this chapter emphasizes how the courageous and resolute, through their deeds, return to the cycle of birth and death.

Within this chapter, three distinct teachings unfold:
1. The differing paths of the common and the Sage, with their contrasting benefits and harms;
2. The natural consequences of virtue and licentiousness, arising from **Heavenly Principle** (*天理*);
3. The conclusion that Heaven’s net is vast, yet retribution is without fail.

**First, the differing paths of the common and the Sage, with their contrasting benefits and harms.**

The Sage’s heart, like Heaven’s application of the **Dao**, governs the realm with humility—when kings establish their states, modesty brings radiance, and gentleness yields authority. Yet boldness, when unchecked, invites calamity. Thus, the **Vermilion Emperor** flourished by yielding, while the **White Lord** perished by defiance. Boldness, when reckless, leads to slaughter—this truth is clear. Yet why do people not reflect upon it?

When **Fenglong** raises his voice, he meets the **Summer Emperor** and must sing;
When wild geese take flight, they align with the autumn mist and rise.
Even mindless things respond to the seasons—how much more so should humans, bearing hearts, act without the **Dao** as their guide?

Heaven’s net is unerring; the sun and moon maintain their constancy.
Earth’s **Principle** is without bias—mountains and rivers stand firm, never crumbling into decay,
Nor do they erupt in chaos at the **Tail Interval** (*尾间*).
When the **Way of Gentleness** is vast and **Virtue of Humility** is steadfast,
Responding without speech, arriving without summons,
Even Heaven’s net, though vast, will not fail to record accumulated **virtue and vice**.

**Boldness leads to death; courage tempered by restraint leads to life.**
**Róng’s Commentary:** *Dare* means decisive boldness—when a person acts with reckless resolve, abandoning humility and retreat, it brings ruin. Thus, it leads to death. But restraint preserves life.

**Róng’s Exegesis:** *Courage* is vigor; *dare* is decisive action. Those of rigid strength, fearing nothing, lose humility and retreat, descending into reckless defiance—this is the path of self-destruction. Hence, *"Boldness leads to death."* But when one acts with caution, restraining aggression and avoiding peril, this is the path of self-preservation. Hence, *"Courage tempered by restraint leads to life."*

**Master Héshàng Gōng** said: Boldness leads to death—bold action invites self-ruin. Courage tempered by restraint leads to life—boldness without recklessness preserves one’s life.

**Li Róng** said: Boldness is fearlessness; *dare* is resolute intent. To face blades before one, regarding death as life—that is the courage of the heroic. Yet lacking strategy, strength alone cannot prevail. If one pursues gain recklessly, disaster follows. Hence, it leads to death. But if one acts without contention, guided by **ren** and **virtue**, perhaps through **Dao** to transform others or through wisdom to subdue things—harming none, yet safeguarding oneself—this leads to life.

**Chéng’s Exegesis:** *Courage* is swift action; *dare* is decisive resolve; *death* is annihilation; *life* is longevity. When the heart rushes forward with resolute intent, clinging to worldly affairs, it leads to annihilation. But if the heart remains serene and detached, avoiding attachment, then it attains longevity. Understanding these two paths reveals their differing benefits and harms.

**Róng’s Commentary:** Knowing these two paths—whether beneficial or harmful—what does Heaven abhor? The two paths are *dare* and *not dare*. *Or* means "possessing." Those who know to refrain possess benefit; those who dare possess harm. One must therefore cultivate courage in restraint—this is the way of the truly bold. To act recklessly invites disaster, for this is what Heaven abhors. Who can fathom its intent?

**Róng’s Exegesis:** The two paths are *dare* and *not dare*. When one knows that boldness leads to harm and restraint to benefit, one must cultivate courage in restraint. Though both share the name *courage*, their applications differ—hence, *"or beneficial, or harmful."*

**Master Héshàng Gōng** said: Always knowing these two paths—*dare* and *not dare*—benefit is preserving life; harm is self-destruction.

**Li Róng** said: This refers to death and life.

**Chéng’s Exegesis:** *Or* means indeterminate. The two paths are *dare* and *not dare*. When the heart advances without attachment, it attains longevity—thus, benefit. When the body acts greedily, it returns to annihilation—thus, harm.

**Second, the consequences of virtue and licentiousness, arising from Heavenly Principle.**

What does Heaven abhor, and who can know its intent?

**Róng’s Exegesis:** *Who* means "who." *Intent* means "reason." Those who act boldly invite harm—this is what Heaven’s **Dao** abhors. Yet common folk cannot grasp its reasoning.

**Master Héshàng Gōng** said: What Heaven abhors is reckless action. Who can know its intent and avoid transgression?

**Li Róng** said: Heaven’s **Dao** cherishes life and abhors killing. Yet people often fail to seek benefit or avoid harm—this is ignorance of Heaven’s intent.

**Chéng’s Exegesis:** By nature, Heaven rewards virtue and punishes licentiousness. Examining retribution’s depths, none can fathom its sovereign. Thus, even the Sage finds it difficult.

**Róng’s Commentary:** Even the Sage finds boldness perilous.

**Róng’s Exegesis:** This example of the Sage admonishes the common. Though the Sage’s wisdom makes boldness difficult, fearing its harm, how much more so for the ordinary who would dare it?

**Master Héshàng Gōng** said: The Sage’s virtue, even so, finds boldness arduous. How much more for those without the Sage’s virtue who would attempt it?

The **Dao** of Heaven does not contend yet triumphs.

The **Dao** of Heaven does not compete with things; the four seasons wax and wane, yet none dare defy them. ○
**Róng’s Exegesis:** Since the previous passage spoke of what Heaven abhors, these four lines broadly expound Heaven’s **Dao** of humility, warning against human boldness. People harbor thoughts of victory and defeat, hence the contention; Heaven’s **Dao** is evenhanded, rewarding only the virtuous. None dare defy it, so it is said to triumph through virtue. ○
**Héshàng Gōng** said: Heaven does not contend with humans over nobility and lowliness, yet humans still revere it. ○
**Róng** said: Heaven’s **Dao** is without intent; it does not vie with things, yet naturally holds eminence and precedes all.

The **Dao** of Heaven does not speak, yet virtue responds. ○
**Róng’s Exegesis:** How could Heaven speak? It merely bestows blessings on the virtuous and retribution on the licentious, with omens of good and ill—thus it is said that virtue responds without speech. ○
**Héshàng Gōng** said: Heaven does not call, yet all things move in response to the seasons. ○
**Róng** said: Retribution for crimes and blessings is as certain as an echo; thus it is said that virtue responds. ○
**Chéng’s Exegesis:** The response of blessings and retribution is like an echo—evil and virtue must answer without need of words.

The **Dao** of Heaven does not summon yet things come of their own accord. ○
**Róng’s Exegesis:** The coming of all things is by fate’s decree, yet Heaven does not summon them to obey itself. All things come naturally and follow Heaven’s way—like the yin embracing the yang, spring arises and summer flourishes, none summoned yet they come. ○
**Héshàng Gōng** said: Heaven does not call to all things; they bear yin and turn toward yang. ○
**Róng** said: Spring blooms, winter fades; cold departs, heat arrives. Those who go are not sent away, those who come are not summoned by command. ○
**Chéng’s Exegesis:** Retribution for virtue and vice follows their deeds—no need for summoning, yet it must come.

The **Dao** of Heaven is tranquil yet ever well-planned. ○
**Róng’s Exegesis:** The note says Heaven’s **Dao** is profound and vast, silently vast, symbolically transforming—humans may take it as model, hence it is said to be well-planned. ○
**Héshàng Gōng** said: *Tán* means vast; though Heaven’s **Dao** is wide and boundless, it plans well for human affairs, rewarding virtue and punishing vice, each receiving their due. ○
**Yán** said: Silent and boundless, nothing escapes its design. ○
**Róng** said: The Great **Dao** is most level; thus it is said to be *tán* and *rán*. It weighs human gain and loss, with rewards and punishments without error; it discerns virtue and vice, with calamities and omens never failing—thus it is said to be well-planned. ○
**Chéng’s Exegesis:** *Cóng* means calculation. It speaks of the hidden principles of fate, needing no words to precisely measure deeds and misdeeds, without error.

**Third Paragraph:** Heaven’s net is vast and wide, yet retribution never falters.
Heaven’s net spreads far and wide, yet its rewards and punishments for virtue and vice are never lost, not even by a hair’s breadth. ○
**Róng’s Exegesis:** *Huīhuī*, vast and wide. This passage elucidates the previous meaning of Heaven’s **Dao**. Though Heaven’s net is vast and wide, far-reaching and sparse, its rewards for virtue and punishments for vice never fail, not even by a hair’s breadth. ○
**Héshàng Gōng** said: What Heaven’s net encompasses is vast and boundless; though sparse and distant, it oversees and judges human virtue and vice without error. ○
**Róng** said: It spreads through the boundless void and weaves among manifest forms—both vast and wide, hence *huīhuī*. Crimes are public or private, yet Heaven’s mercy knows no scale; even the slightest offense is recorded, with no oversight in its sparse or dense tracking—thus it is said to never fail.

**Chapter 74: People Do Not Fear Death**
*Chapter on People Not Fearing Death*, thus following the previous. The prior chapter showed how creatures do not fear threats or punishments, yet must face Heaven’s net; hence this chapter follows, revealing that Heaven’s net has its unseen overseers.

This chapter unfolds four themes: First, that creatures are burdened by heavy karmic obstacles and do not fear punishment; Second, that crimes, once deep, will surely invite suffering retribution; Third, that these sufferings are meted out by unseen judges; Fourth, that those who presume to act as Heaven’s judges will instead incur its blame.

**First Theme:** Creatures are burdened by heavy karmic obstacles and do not fear punishment.
Heaven’s **Dao** upholds true names; punishment is natural. Why then do rulers threaten people with death? They wear jade pendants at their belts and display them in times of crisis, clutching golden scepters and wielding them at the court’s threshold. Yī and Lǚ serve as ministers, Píng Bó plots to overthrow. The dynasty’s fate is sealed—when the age of great peace arrives, the ruler’s singular merit alone will earn him the title of *yīràng* sovereign. Then he may drum his belly in the courtyard and strike the earth in the fields, unaware of Heaven’s power, how could he bear the king’s favor?

In May, he wears his winter coat, not envying the lightly clad guest; a foot of cloth is too short, yet he keeps only the upright man. Then he understands the hundred-year fate is all by Heaven’s decree.

In life, gold and jade mark his dwelling, yet he knows the fate of the withered ram; in death, his stone tablet bears gold inscriptions, and Guō Pú foretells it first. Thus the saying: *"Death and life have fate; truly, it is so."*

Now, if one falsely executes punishment to replace Heaven’s judgment, how could such logic be erased? How could the unseen judges agree? It is like a substitute craftsman measuring with a ruler—he will surely suffer injury to his hands.

People are unaccustomed to fearing death—why then do rulers threaten them with it? ○
**Róng’s Exegesis:** If one indulges desires freely, provoking death’s reach, and grows accustomed to it without fear, how could rulers further establish punishments to strike terror through killing?

○ **Lord’s Annotation (御疏):** It speaks of how people cannot uphold the **Dao/Way** of purity and tranquility, instead indulging their passions and provoking death’s grasp. This becomes ingrained habit, and they grow so accustomed that they no longer fear it. Thus, rulers should guide them through the **Dao/Way** of purity and tranquility, yet why do they enforce punishments and killings to instill fear of death?

○ **Hé Shànggōng** said: The people do not fear death because the governance of the state is harsh, leaving them barely able to survive. Those who govern themselves are harmed by their cravings, while greed for wealth destroys their lives—yet the people do not know to fear these things. Why then do rulers threaten them with death, instead of lightening their punishments and teaching them to abandon their desires? Why set punishments and threaten death?

○ **Yán** said: Human nature, when content, finds peace; when discontented, it schemes wrongly. In destitution, one scorns death; in comfort, one cherishes life. If the people’s hearts are not satisfied and their lives are not preserved, then decrees will fail to move them. The beasts of the destitute do not shun rhinoceroses or tigers—such is their nature, and the logic of their plight.

○ **Róng** said: In an age of **Dao/Way**, all beings cherish life, and the **Dao/Way** of non-action makes them spare death. If one cannot pacify them with supreme **virtue/power**, yet restrains them with harsh punishments, the people will barely survive, hence the saying: *"People do not fear death."* The root of people not fearing death lies in cruel punishments; it is fitting to rely on pardon, using **virtue/power** to make them forget punishments. How could one still apply harsh laws to the people, desiring they fear death? This laments the failures of the times.

○ **Chéng’s Annotation (成疏):** This condemns the common delusion of passion, deeply entrenched and unrelenting. They pursue fleeting pleasures without regard for life and death, yet even with stern warnings and teachings, they remain without fear—thus the sigh of *"Why?"* is raised, profound and sorrowful.

Secondly, it clarifies that deep crimes will surely invite suffering retribution. If the people were to constantly fear death, yet one were to act deceitfully, I could seize and kill them—who would dare? **Lord’s Annotation (御注):** If all were to follow the path of purity and restraint, daring not to wallow in passion or indulge desires, and constantly feared death, yet a single deceitful one acted strangely, even if I could seize and kill them, who would dare to do so?

○ **Lord’s Annotation (御疏):** This explains how rulers guide through non-action, and the people temper their desires, each preserving their own lives, and thus fearing death. Yet if one were to act deceitfully and wickedly, and I could seize and kill them, who would dare to do so? The reason they are not killed is that there exists the **Heavenly Net** (天网) that governs retribution—thus the following text states:

○ **Hé Shànggōng** said: If the people were to constantly fear death, it would be because I had removed my own acts of cruelty and taught them to abandon greed. Yet if one were to act deceitfully, I could seize and kill them—who would dare? When **Dao/Way** is used to guide, but the people do not comply, instead acting craftily, they then fall under the **King’s Law** (王法) to be seized and killed. Who would dare to offend?

**Lǎo Zǐ** lamented the times when kings do not first guide with **Dao/Way** and **virtue/power**, but instead enforce punishments.

○ **Róng** said: The deceitful are those who disrupt the order with cunning. If the age’s ruler upholds the **Dao/Way**, all preserve their lives, and this is called fearing death. Yet those who act violently and disrupt the order grow ever more deceitful and strange in their crimes. Heaven does not endure evil, so they are seized and killed. Those who truly fear death and cultivate life—who would dare to commit wrongs?

○ **Chéng’s Annotation (成疏):** The heart of greed generates ever more deceitful schemes, firmly rooted in perversion, until it becomes their norm. The unseen judges (冥司) capture and kill them, their retribution as sharp as the wind and as evident as the scriptures. If any have insight, who would dare to create sin?

Thirdly, it clarifies that this suffering retribution comes from the unseen judges (冥司). There are always those who govern punishment.

**Lord’s Annotation (御注):** Such deceitful ones are not spared by the **Heavenly Net**—it is the unseen judges of Heaven who kill them. It states that wicked ones are killed by the unseen judges, and rulers, using their authority, seize and kill them conveniently—this is to act as substitutes for the unseen judges.

○ **Lord’s Annotation (御疏):** *Suī* (司) means "master" or "official." Heaven’s discernment is all-pervading, nothing escapes its gaze. Deceitful ones cannot escape their deaths, for it is Heaven’s unseen judges who kill them.

○ **Hé Shànggōng** said: The unseen judges are Heaven, which stands high and surveys all below, overseeing human transgressions. The **Heavenly Net** is vast yet not flawed—this is its nature.

○ **Yán** said: The unseen judges are the great ministers. The **Dao/Way** of the emperor and king is to act without action, delegating duties to those before, behind, left, and right. ○ **Róng** said: *Suī* (司) means "master." The principles of reward and punishment are constant, and the officials of life and death have their masters. One cannot act wickedly, and those who break the law must die—yet they seek to usurp the unseen judges’ role and kill at will.

Fourthly, it strengthens the argument that substituting for the unseen judges will instead bring one’s own blame. To act as a substitute for the unseen judges is to act as a substitute for the **Grand Master Carpenter** (大匠).

**Lord’s Annotation (御注):** If rulers delight in seizing and killing themselves, they will not align with Heaven’s **Dao/Way**—it is like a clumsy man substituting for the **Grand Master Carpenter** (大匠) in woodwork.

○ **Lord’s Annotation (御疏):** It speaks of how wicked ones are killed by the unseen judges, and rulers, using their authority, seize and kill them conveniently—this is the unseen judges killing people, yet they do not align with Heaven’s **Dao/Way**, just as a clumsy man substituting for the **Grand Master Carpenter** (大匠) in woodwork.

○ **Hé Shànggōng** said: Heaven’s **Dao/Way** is supremely clear, and the unseen judges have their constants, just as spring brings birth and summer growth, autumn harvest and winter concealment, the stars and Big Dipper shift in their courses to govern the seasons. ○ **Yán** said: The one who substitutes for the unseen judges is the ruler. When officials lose their proper function, governance collapses. When the sovereign takes on self-renewal, skilled laborers fold their hands idle. When the ruler takes on killing, officials lose their proper roles.

○ **Róng** said: To substitute for the unseen judges is to substitute for the **Grand Master Carpenter** in woodwork. Rewarding the virtuous and punishing the wicked is recorded in the unseen judges. Spring brings birth and summer growth, clearly manifest in the seen substitutes. Yet even so, most stubborn people are few in following transformation, and many deceitful flaws are difficult to prevent. Adjusting measures according to the times, establishing laws and ordinances, there are those in charge of punishment and officials in charge of killing. Though few may escape injury, those injured will be many.

○ **Chéng’s Annotation:** To substitute for the unseen judges is to substitute for the **Grand Master Carpenter** in woodwork. To substitute for the **Grand Master Carpenter** in woodwork, there are few who do not injure their hands. All beings create karma and reap their due retribution. Punishments and suffering belong to the unseen judges. To substitute for the **Grand Master Carpenter** in woodwork, there are few who do not injure their hands.

**Lord’s Annotation:** A clumsy man substituting for woodwork—how could he avoid injuring the village [community]? He would also injure his own hands. When a ruler assumes the role of punishment, substituting for the unseen judges, how could he avoid harming the people while also losing Heaven’s harmony?

○ **Lord’s Annotation:** The **Grand Master Carpenter** in woodwork moves in accordance with the square and round. A clumsy man substituting for him must deviate from the plumb line and level. Could one’s heart not be harmed by the village [community] while injuring their hands? Heaven’s net does not fail, and divine principles are manifest. If a ruler assumes punishment, substituting for the unseen judges, how could he avoid harming the people while losing Heaven’s harmony? Why does he act with such disregard for death?

○ **Hé Shànggōng** said: When a ruler enforces punishments, it is like a clumsy man substituting for the **Grand Master Carpenter** in woodwork—then the square and round will not align, and he will harm himself. To substitute for Heaven in killing is to lose the proper order; if the proper order is lost, he will suffer the consequences.

○ **Yán** said: When skilled laborers fold their hands idle, the great hall cannot be built. When a ruler monopolizes killing, the world loses its proper order. If the great hall cannot be built, there will be no shelter for descendants. If the world loses governance, the state cannot be secure. The chapter on people’s hunger follows the previous one, as the previous chapter clearly establishes that beings with deep karmic guilt must reap suffering. This chapter then explains why such suffering is incurred—due to attachment to worldly actions. Within this chapter, three themes unfold: first, explaining why beings lack virtue due to attachment to worldly affairs; second, why beings shorten their lives due to excessive focus on sustenance; third, demonstrating the beauty of forgetting life to guide learners.

**First, explaining why beings lack virtue due to attachment to worldly affairs:**

The **Dao/Way** and virtue are forgotten when one indulges in worldly pursuits, and thus one attains the leisure of the fish in the lake. As for the benevolent influence of Emperor Wén and Emperor Xīn, the enlightened governance of King Chéng and King Kāng—these were indeed praised as the great blessings of the Zhou. Yet during the Han, when the state was governed by law, the *lǔ* arrows came from the east, and divine forces were invoked from the west. The four classes lived in peace, the people lived without strife, and tribute included eight layers of silk. The fields yielded double harvests of rice, gentle winds blew morning and evening, sweet dew fell in the courtyards. The crown prince’s virtue was abundant in the Green Palace, and ministers assisted in the **Dao/Way** at the Red Gate. Heaven was balanced, Earth was upright, lawsuits ceased, and punishments were clear. The people of Yáo’s time could be sealed in their homes, and those of Shùn’s era thrived in their courtyards. They enjoyed the joy of proper governance—how could there be taxes from hunger? They did not die lightly, and with the sage’s teaching of non-action, they found their own ease.

The people’s hunger arises because their rulers consume too much in taxes. **Lord’s Annotation:** The reason the people of the world suffer hunger and want is that their rulers consume too much in taxes.

○ **Lord’s Annotation:** People are the foundation of the state. If governance is burdensome and taxes are heavy, the people will become impoverished, and the foundation will decay—decay leads to danger. Thus, the people’s insufficiency comes from the ruler consuming too much in taxes, causing their hunger and want.

○ **Hé Shànggōng** said: The people’s hunger arises because their rulers consume too much in taxes. The reason the people suffer hunger and cold is that their rulers consume too much in taxes, hence their hunger. Therefore, the people blame their rulers for greed, abandoning the **Dao/Way** and virtue, and thus they suffer hunger.

○ **Róng** said: When the common people are hungry and the four classes are impoverished, it is not due to other causes—taxes are heavy and levies are excessive.

○ **Chéng’s Annotation:** It says the people’s hunger arises because their rulers consume too much in taxes. Hunger refers to lacking inner virtue. "Upper" refers to the heart, which governs the five viscera and a hundred actions, hence called "upper." Taxes mean accumulation, and "food" refers to tastes. It states that practitioners ruin their virtue by indulging in sensory pleasures. Hence, they suffer hunger—connecting with the previous meaning.

The difficulty in governing the people arises because their rulers engage in worldly affairs, hence the difficulty in governing them. **Lord’s Annotation:** The reason the people of the world are difficult to govern and transform is that their rulers engage in worldly affairs, making governance difficult and deceitful schemes prevalent.

「○ **Lord’s Annotation:** The teeming masses rely on their ruler for governance, for governance is rooted in *wuwei* (無為). Thus, when I practice *wuwei*, the people naturally transform themselves.

Yet the reason people are difficult to govern today is that their rulers engage in worldly affairs. When rulers act, governance becomes burdensome and the people are disturbed; every action spawns great deceit, hence the difficulty in governing them.

○ **Master Hé Shànggōng (河上公) says:** The people are difficult to govern because their rulers engage in worldly affairs. The people cannot be governed because their rulers are consumed by desires and fond of worldly actions, hence the difficulty in governing them.

○ **Yán (严) says:** Thus, the people emulate the ruler’s worldly affairs, and their deceitful inclinations make them difficult to govern.

○ **Róng (荣) says:** Worldly actions disrupt the natural order, making governance difficult. When the ruler aligns with *wuwei* (無為), the people naturally transform.

○ **Chéng’s Annotation:** The people are difficult to govern because their ruler engages in worldly affairs, causing all actions to stray and multiply in chaotic ways. This is because the heart indulges in worldly pursuits—when the heart practices *wuwei*, all actions become easy to govern. Thus, one knows that all phenomena rest in the mind alone.

Hence, the difficulty in governing—this concludes the previous meaning.

**Secondly, it illustrates why beings shorten their lifespan: excessive attachment to life.**

The people’s disregard for death stems from their relentless pursuit of life—hence, they lightly embrace death.

○ **Lord’s Annotation:** The people of the world lightly embrace death because they violate natural limits in their excessive pursuit of life, hence they meet their end.

○ **Lord’s Annotation:** The reason people lightly court death and lose their lives is that they violate natural limits, indulging in excessive nourishment and life-preservation. They disregard the law’s penalties, recklessly pursuing their desires—hence, they lightly embrace death.

○ **Master Hé Shànggōng says:** The people’s disregard for death arises from their excessive pursuit of life. The people lightly transgress against death because they cling to ways of sustaining life, greedily seeking profit to endanger themselves—hence, they lightly embrace death.

○ **Yán says:** It is because of their excessive pursuit of life that they lightly court death.

○ **Róng says:** Those who cling to life suppress their true nature with false desires, while those who lightly embrace death are ensnared by deluded cravings, clinging to the transient body as if it were eternal. Hence, it speaks of the excessive pursuit of life. Excessive means accumulation, abundance—when affairs accumulate, the mind is disordered; when tastes multiply, vitality wanes. Unable to cherish life with caution, they squander themselves through indulgence and lightly court death.

○ **Chéng’s Annotation:** The people’s disregard for death stems from their excessive attachment to life. Practitioners who do not fulfill their natural lifespan and lightly court death are those who remain entangled in delusion, failing to awaken. They do not comprehend that all phenomena, including life, are illusory—life is but the absence of death. Yet they burden themselves with excessive demands on the six senses and overindulge in the four elements—hence, they lightly embrace death.

This concludes the previous meaning.

**Thirdly, it demonstrates the beauty of forgetting life, urging scholars to reflect.**

Indeed, those who do not excessively cling to life are wiser than those who prize it.

○ **Lord’s Annotation:** When natural sustenance is sufficient, life is preserved. If one overnourishes beyond natural limits, life is lost. Thus, those who do not excessively cling to life are wiser than those who prize it.

○ **Lord’s Annotation:** Life has its bounds—contentment is enough, yet one must neither defy nor overreach them. If one pursues life beyond its proper measure, confusion follows. Thus, not clinging to life preserves it, while excessive pursuit destroys it. Hence, one knows that those who do not make life their concern are wiser than those who vainly prize it.

○ **Master Hé Shànggōng says:** Only those who do not make life their primary concern—who remain untouched by rank and wealth, who do not covet profit or power—can be said to be wiser than those who prize life.

○ **Yán says:** The natural Dao always opposes artificiality. The lifeless attain life, while the living cling to life and meet death. ○ **Róng says:** Heaven grants life as a finite reality, yet excessive nurturing beyond its measure harms it—this is failing to truly cherish life. Those who grasp the supreme Dao perceive the body as illusory, understanding that governance is lifeless. They do not cling to false forms, naturally releasing the burdens of attachment. They align with emptiness and coldness, harmonizing with virtue, sharing in the Dao’s root. Though they do not nourish life, life nourishes itself—this is truly cherishing life.

Wise (*xián*, 賢) means virtuous; prizing (*guì*, 貴) means valuing.

○ **Chéng’s Annotation:** Wise (*xián*, 賢) means good. Those who attain profound insight do not extinguish sensory existence but instead practice *zuòwàng* (坐忘), realizing life’s formless nature. Hence, those who are repelled by vulgarity and disdain worldly pleasures—who alone do not make life their primary concern—are truly virtuous in safeguarding and valuing life.

**Chapter on the Lifespan of Human Beings**

This chapter follows the previous because the prior illustrates how those who cling to life ultimately court death, while those who forget life achieve longevity. Thus, this chapter explains that gentle and weak beings naturally attain longevity, while the rigid and strong perish early. To distinguish excellence from mediocrity, this is why it follows.

This chapter’s meaning is divided into three parts: first, it presents two paired analogies to contrast life and death in the strong and weak; second, it unites the analogies to argue their superiority and inferiority; third, it uses the analogies and further elaboration to reinforce the meaning.

**First, it presents two paired analogies to contrast life and death in the strong and weak.**

The *Nánchāng* (南昌) adjusts its course, bestowing life on the weak and frail. The *Běidì* (北帝) of *Āngdū* (酆都) holds the register of death, seizing the strong and mighty. The heavens favor the light and yielding, long preserving the moistness of clouds and winds, while the earth’s terrain is solid and enduring—only the sound of metal and stone is heard. Solidity can be shattered, while yielding never stagnates. When the supreme Dao governs, the weak naturally dwell in the lower currents, while the strong suffer mutilation as an omen of misfortune, eye-gouging as a fate of rebellion. Jié Lì (截离) deceived them—why did he kill his own son for another? Dào Zhì (盗婿) was foolish—why did he defy his father and brother, boasting of his valor? Do they not know that all phenomena are transient, and humility and yielding prevail? Without relying on divination, they naturally follow the Dao like Sūn Zhū (孙叔). The waters swirl in the hollows, and withered leaves scatter like wind. The *Jìn Bì* (晋鄙) was buried with an iron hammer, and *Jì Lún* (季伦) met his end with a golden axe. Regret comes too late—whose fault is this?

Better to preserve true purity in tranquil stillness,
where fame and gain are utterly severed—

wealth and nobility like passing clouds—

are the warnings of life and death.
