「**Master’s Annotation:**
To place one’s body last means others gladly advance it,
Thus one’s body is first.
To set one’s body aside means the heart forgets self-interest,
Thus one’s body is preserved.

**Master’s Commentary:**
Therefore, the Sage follows the Heaven and Earth’s nurturing,
Ensuring equitable nourishment without favoritism,
Thus advancing his body first for all to rely upon,
The people joyfully depend on him,
As the foundation for those below,
So his body is first.
He does not exalt himself,
Nor does he neglect his own body,
When the world returns to *rén* (benevolence),
He fears no harm,
Thus his body is preserved.

**Master Héshàng Gōng says:**
Therefore, the Sage places his body last yet his body is first,
Advances others before himself.
Yet his body is first, for the world respects him,
Advancing him to positions of authority.
To set his body aside is to treat himself lightly while enriching others.
Yet his body is preserved, for the people love him as their parents,
And the *shénmíng* (divine luminaries) protect him like a cherished child,
Thus his body remains eternally preserved.

**Master Yán says:**
The Sage’s awe commands the eight directions,
His keen insight permeates the four quarters—
Yet his wisdom lies beyond desire,
His plans beyond action.
He humbles himself to honor Heaven,
Sets himself aside to bring peace to the people,
Thus without action he achieves,
Without words he is trusted,
All wish to serve him as their lord,
So he advances others.
He reverses his own inclinations to follow the Dao,
Sets aside his own interests to bring peace to the people—
His merit is boundless, yet unseen,
His virtue towering, yet unheard.
His transformation flows with the divine luminaries,
His lifespan aligns with the mountains and rivers,
Thus his body is preserved.

**Harmony with the Dao.**
**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
Therefore, the Sage—
Few forget their emotions and still their *jī* (mechanisms),
Many pursue song and deviate from truth—
Only the Sage can enact this.
Practicing humility to dwell behind all things,
His exalted virtue thus dwells first.
Preserving the Dao, he sets his body aside yet his body remains,
His own essence ascends to merge with the analogy.
The Sage is he who aligns with Heaven and Earth’s virtue,
Setting forth his lofty conduct as a model for all.
To place his body last is to first grant others passage.
Yet his body is first, transcending the *sānjiè* (Three Realms).
To set his body aside is to fortify his limbs.
Yet his body is preserved, attaining *long life*.
**Third section concludes with praise for the Sage’s unique and noble virtue.**
Is it not because he has no private interests?
Thus he fulfills his own private essence.»

chunks.original_text: 御注：天地忘生养之功，是无私。 而能长且久，是成其私。 圣人后外其身，是无私，而能先能存，是成其私也。 ○御疏：天地所以长久，圣人所以先存者，非以其无自私之心，故能成此长久先存之私乎？ ○河上公曰：非以其无私耶，圣人为人所爱，神明所佑，非以其公正无私所致乎，故能成其私。 人以为私者，欲以厚己，圣人无私而己自厚，故能成其私也。 ○荣曰：凡情幽滞，灵识不通，无至公之心，有偏私之行，尊己而加物，厚身而薄人，欲先而不能超物，须存而报体已亡。 圣人无心，欲居物先，自然在先，无情，欲得存固，自然存固，故曰成其私也。 ○成疏：此其无尸，故能成其尸。 尸，主也，言圣人观物我虚幻，名实俱空，故能后己先人，忘我济物，故无主也。 而言成其尸者，结叹圣人也。 只为德合二仪，刍狗百姓，故独居三界之尊，成天人之化主也。 上善若水章第八 上善章所以次前者，前章略明忘我之行，未显功能，故次此章广举忘我之人，有殊能妙用。 就此一章，义开三别。 第一正标上善，法喻两陈。 第二泛举三能，广明七德。 第三结叹柔弱，所以无疵。 第一正标上善，法喻两陈。 夫至德幽玄，真宗秘赜，鉴万象於虚室，产三才於自然，众妙之门，群生并入，恬忘之户，蠢动滋生，何以喻之，其将若水滥觞之缢，成大海之滔天，尾闾之山，括洪河而泄地，虽浩汗莫测，而澄恬至柔，荡垢浊於人间，守清泠於性表，道之为用，斯可近乎。 上善若水。 御注：将明至人上善之功，故举水性几道之喻。 ○御疏：上善者，标人也。 若水者，举喻也。 至人虚怀，於法无住，忘善而善，是善之上。 上善之行，如水之能，其在下文，皆合法喻。 ○河上公曰：上善之人，如水之性。 ○荣曰：上善若水，水善利万物又不争，处众人之所恶，故几於道。 理本深远，难可测知，善人修道，行亦微妙，故借於水以为喻焉。 水能润物，道能济人，故言善利。 水则壅次任人，道则大顺平等，故言不争。 物多恶下，人多爱上，今水流趣下，道行谦退，故言处恶。 几者近也，水性与道相近，故取以为譬焉。 ○成疏：水有二种，一执二忘，此是忘善，故称为上。 水有多种利用，故偕况之。 利用功能，具列於下。 ○节解曰：善者谓p 中津液也，以口漱之则甘泉出，含而咽之，下利万神，子欲行之，常以晨朝，漱华池令津液满口，即昂头咽之，以利万神而益精熙。 第二泛举三能，广明七德。 水善利万物又不争，处众人之所恶，故几於道。 御注：几，近也。 ○御疏：水善利万物又不争，处众人之所恶，水性甘凉，散洒一切，被其润泽，蒙利则长，故云善利，此一能也。 天下柔弱，莫过於水，平可取法，清能鉴人，乘流遇坎，与之委顺，在人所引，尝不竞争，此二能也。 恶居下流，众生恒趣，水则就卑受浊，处恶不辞，此三能也。 故几於道，几，近也。 利物明其弘益，不争表其柔弱，处恶示其含垢，此水性之三能也，唯至人之一贯，其行如此，去道不远，故云近尔。 ○河上公曰：水善利万物，水在天为雾露，在地为泉源也。 又不争，处众人之所恶，众人恶卑湿垢浊，水独静流居之。 故几於道，水性几与道同也。

The **Commentary** states:
Heaven and Earth forget their nurturing function—this is *wu si* (no private interest).
Yet they endure long and vast—this is fulfilling their own private essence.
The Sage sets aside and transcends his body—this is *wu si*,
Yet he is first and preserved—this is fulfilling his own private essence.

**Commentary on the Commentary** says:
Heaven and Earth endure long, the Sage is first and preserved—
Is it not because they have no selfish intent,
Yet achieve this enduring, first-preserved private essence?

**Master He Shang Gong** says:
Is it not because of their *wu si*?
The Sage is loved by people, favored by the numinous—
Is it not because of his impartiality and *wu si*?
Thus he fulfills his own private essence.

What others call *si* (private),
Is to enrich oneself in desire.
The Sage, without *si*, yet himself is enriched—
Thus he fulfills his own private essence.

**Master Rong** says:
Ordinary beings are mired in desires, their spirit obscured,
Lacking absolute impartiality, harboring partiality.
They exalt themselves while burdening others,
Hoard for their own bodies while neglecting people,
Desire to lead yet cannot transcend others,
Seek preservation yet their bodies perish.

The Sage, without intent, desires to dwell first—
Naturally he is first.
Without desires, seeks firm preservation—
Naturally he is preserved.
Thus it is said: he fulfills his own private essence.

**Master Cheng’s Commentary** says:
This is his *wu shī* (no selfhood),
Thus he fulfills his *shī* (selfhood).
*Shī* is the master—
The Sage, observing all things, sees emptiness in self and name,
Both void—
Thus he can set himself aside and lead others,
Forget self to aid others—
Thus he has no master.
Yet it is said he fulfills his *shī*—
In praise of the Sage’s virtue harmonizing with Heaven and Earth,
Like a straw dog for the people,
Thus alone he dwells in the Three Realms’ exalted position,
Fulfilling the transformation of Heaven and humanity.

---
**Chapter Eight: The Chapter on Supreme Virtue**
This chapter follows the previous one,
For the prior chapter briefly illuminated the conduct of forgetting self,
Yet did not reveal its efficacy—
Thus this chapter expounds further,
Extolling the person of forgetting self,
Who possesses extraordinary abilities and wondrous functions.

Within this chapter, three distinct meanings unfold:
First, it establishes *shàngshàn* (supreme virtue) with two analogies—law and metaphor.
Second, it broadly enumerates three abilities, elaborating seven virtues.
Third, it concludes with praise for gentleness and weakness,
Thus free from blemish.

**First: Establishing Supreme Virtue with Two Analogies**
Supreme virtue is profound and mysterious,
The true essence, its secrets hidden.
It mirrors all phenomena in emptiness,
Gives birth to the Three Powers in spontaneity.
The gateway to all wonders,
Where all life converges,
The threshold of tranquil forgetting,
Where inert beings proliferate.
How shall we liken it?
Like water filling a vessel to its brim,
Becoming the boundless sea’s surging tide,
Like the *Wèilú* Mountains containing the Yellow River’s flood,
Draining the earth—
Though vast and unfathomable,
Yet serene and supremely yielding,
Cleansing filth from the world,
Preserving clarity within its nature.
Thus the Way’s function may be approached:
**Supreme virtue is like water.**

**Commentary** says:
To illuminate the Sage’s supreme virtue,
Water’s nature is taken as an analogy to the Dao.

**Commentary on the Commentary** says:
*Shàngshàn* (supreme virtue) marks the person.
*Ruò shuǐ* (like water) is the metaphor.
The Sage’s emptiness embraces all—
Without clinging to the law, yet virtue arises—
This is virtue’s summit.

The Sage’s conduct, like water’s function,
In the following text, all align with law and metaphor.

**Master He Shang Gong** says:
The person of supreme virtue is like water’s nature.

**Master Rong** says:
Supreme virtue is like water—
Water benefits all things yet does not contend,
Dwells where people revile,
Thus it nears the Dao.
Its principles are profound and distant,
Hard to fathom—
The virtuous cultivating the Way,
Their actions are subtle and wondrous,
Thus water is borrowed as metaphor.

Water nourishes things, the Dao aids people—
Thus it is said to benefit.
Water yields to obstacles, the Dao is vast and equal—
Thus it is said not to contend.
People often revile what is low, yet water flows downward,
The Dao practices humility—
Thus it is said to dwell where others revile.
*Jì* (near)—water’s nature nears the Dao,
Thus it is taken as analogy.

**Master Cheng’s Commentary** says:
Water has two kinds—
One clings, one forgets—
This is forgetting virtue, thus called supreme.
Water has many uses,
Thus it is paired as analogy.
Its functions and virtues are listed below.

**Master Jié’s Explanation** says:
*Shàn* (virtue) refers to the *jīn* (saliva).
Rinsing with it yields sweet dew,
Swallowing it benefits all spirits.
If you wish to practice this,
Morning and evening, rinse the *Huá Chí* (Jade Pool),
Filling your mouth with saliva,
Then tilt your head to swallow,
Benefiting all spirits and enriching your essence.

---
**Second: Broadly Enumerating Three Abilities, Elaborating Seven Virtues**
Water benefits all things yet does not contend,
Dwells where people revile—
Thus it nears the Dao.

**Commentary** says:
*Jì* (near) means close.

**Commentary on the Commentary** says:
Water benefits all things yet does not contend,
Dwells where people revile—
Water’s nature is sweet and cool,
Scattering everywhere, its dew nourishes all.
Those it benefits grow—
Thus it is said to benefit—this is its first ability.
Under Heaven, none are softer than water,
Yet it can be modeled—
Its clarity reflects others,
Flowing, it submits to obstacles,
Following its course—
It never contends—this is its second ability.
It reviles low places, yet people flock there—
Water accepts filth, dwells in evil without complaint—this is its third ability.
Thus it nears the Dao—*jì* (near) means close.
Benefiting others shows its vast efficacy,
Not contending reveals its gentleness,
Dwelling in evil demonstrates its tolerance of defilement—
These are water’s three abilities,
Which the Sage embodies as one.
His conduct is not far from the Dao—
Thus it is said he is near.

**Master He Shang Gong** says:
Water benefits all things—
In Heaven, it is mist and dew;
On Earth, it is springs and rivers.
Yet it does not contend,
Dwelling where people revile—
People revile what is low, damp, and filthy,
Yet water alone flows quietly there.
Thus it nears the Dao—
Water’s nature nearly aligns with the Dao.

chunks.original_text: ○成疏：水善利万物，言水在天为雾露，在地为泉源，津润沾洽，利物处多，以此功能，故况圣德。 圣德应感，善功机权，方便开化，其义如水，故以为喻也。 又不争，水性柔和，不与物争，方圆任器，壅次随人，上善之行，应物亦尔。 处众人之所恶，所恶者卑下之地，卑下之地，水则居之，言众人皆拾下趣高，憍慢陵物，上善独去高取下，柔和静退。 故几於道，几，近也，言行此三能，故近於道，三能已了，次明七德。 居善地， 御注：上善之人，处身柔弱，亦如水之居地，润益一切，地以卑用，水好下流也。 ○御疏：至人所居，善能弘益。 如水在地，利物则多。 又地道用卑，水好流下，同至人之谦顺，几道性之柔弱，故云居善地。 ○河上公曰：水性善於地，在草木之上，即流而下，有似於化，动而下人也。 ○荣曰：水不择地，随处俱流，行道之人，所居皆善也。 ○成疏：水性趣下，以下为安，上善好谦，以谦为吉，故用卑下，而为善地，所谓处乎不竞之地。 心善渊， 御注：用心深静，亦如水之渊停也。 ○御疏：至人之心，善於安静，如水之性，湛尔泉源，水静则清明，心闲则了悟。 渊，深静也，故云心善渊。 ○河上公曰：水心空虚，渊深清明。 ○荣曰：水心静而明，人心虚而鉴也。 ○成疏：渊，止水也。 言止水清洁泓澄，渊深难测，上善心源虚远，静照亦然，故渊静则鉴人，心虚则照物。 匀善仁， 御注：施与合乎至仁，亦如水之滋润品物矣。 ○御疏：至人弘济，常以与人。 善施之坊，合乎仁行，如水滋润，无心爱憎，故云与善仁。 ○河上公曰：万物得水以生，与虚不与盈也。 ○荣曰：水洽於物，人惠於俗。 ○成疏：仁，恩也。 言水性沾濡，惠润於物，圣德慈救，恩被苍生，慈救则不隔怨亲，沾濡则岂拣冷秽。 言善信， 御注：发言信实，亦如水之行险，不失其信矣。 ○御疏：上善之言，言必真实，引化凡庶，善信不欺。 如彼流泉，岂殊坎险？ 故云言善信。 注云行险而不失其信者，《周易》坎之词也。 ○河上公曰：水内影照形，不失其清。 ○荣曰：水之影物，妍丑不失其形。 仁者为言，终始不乖其实。 ○成疏：信，实也。 水能澄鉴仪貌，妍丑不欺，圣言证理，信如符契，亦言海水三潮，不失时候。 况圣智逗机，不遗三品。 ○节解：谓神炁既行，形中万神合会，故口中甘泉自出，漱咽无已，人既不知，安能行也。 故圣人淡泊行一，则何华不先也。 政善治， 御注：从政善理，亦如水之洗涤群物，令其清冷矣。 ○御疏：政，正也。 至人於事，动合无心，正容悟物，物自从正。 正则自治，非善而何？ 如彼水性，洗涤群物，令其清净，故云善理。 ○河上公曰：无有不洗，清且平也。 ○荣曰：太平莫盛於停水，无偏不越於善人。 ○成疏：水性平而无僻，圣心正而治邪，《庄》云：平中准，大匠取则焉。 事善能， 御注：於事善能任用，亦如水性方圆随器，不滞於物矣。 ○御疏：至人圆明，於物无碍，凡有运动，在事皆通。 通则善能，是明照了。 如彼水性，次之为川，壅之为池，浮舟涵虚，无所不为，是善能也。 ○河上公曰：能方能圆，曲直随形。 ○荣曰：水之无用不成，君子何为不可。 ○成疏：水性多能，随事利益，圣智虚察，顺物成功。
chunks.translated_text:
「○ Cheng Shu [Master Cheng’s commentary] says:
Water excels in benefiting all things—
It is mist and dew in Heaven,
Springs and rivers on Earth,
Moistening and nourishing all,
Its efficacy widespread.
Thus it is likened to the Sage’s virtue.

The Sage’s virtue responds to all things,
His benevolent deeds are flexible and expedient,
His skillful means open and transform—
Their meaning aligns with water’s nature,
Hence the comparison.

Again, water does not contend—
Its nature is gentle and yielding,
It does not vie with others,
Adapting to square or round vessels,
Filling or receding as people will.
The Sage’s highest conduct,
In responding to all things, is likewise.

It dwells in what people revile—
What they revile are lowly places,
And water alone resides there.
People all seek the high and despise the low,
Their arrogance tramples others,
Yet the Sage alone forsakes the high to embrace the low,
Gentle, yielding, and still.

Thus it nears the Dao—*jì* (near) means close—
His conduct embodies these three abilities,
Hence it is near the Dao.
With the three abilities now explained,
Next, the seven virtues are revealed.

**Residing in the Virtuous Land**—
*御注* [Master He Shang Gong’s annotation]:
The Sage’s highest virtue,
In his gentle and yielding conduct,
Is like water dwelling in low places,
Nourishing all things.
The land is humble in its use,
Water favors flowing downward—
Thus it is said the Sage resides in the virtuous land.
*御疏* [Master He’s commentary]:
The Sage’s dwelling,
Exemplifies vast beneficence.
Like water on Earth,
It brings abundant benefit to all.
Again, the land’s virtue lies in its humility,
Water flows downward naturally,
Matching the Sage’s meekness and compliance,
Nearly aligning with the Dao’s gentle nature—
Thus it is said he resides in the virtuous land.

**Master He Shang Gong says:**
Water’s nature harmonizes with the land—
Above grass and trees, it flows downward,
Like transformation, its movement subjugates all.

**Rong says:**
Water does not discriminate in its flow,
It moves wherever it is placed—
The Sage’s path is always virtuous.

**Master Cheng’s commentary:**
Water’s nature favors the low,
Finding peace in downward flow.
The Sage’s highest virtue lies in humility,
For humility is auspicious—
Thus he dwells in low places,
Called the land of *non-contention*.

**The Heart is Virtuous in Depth**—
*御注* [Master He Shang Gong’s annotation]:
A virtuous heart is deep and still,
Like water’s settled clarity.

*御疏* [Master He’s commentary]:
The Sage’s heart,
Exemplifies profound tranquility—
Like water’s nature,
Resting as a pure spring.
Water’s stillness reveals its clarity,
A quiet heart attains insight.

Thus it is said the heart is virtuous in depth.
*御注* [Master He Shang Gong’s annotation]:
Water’s heart is empty and profound,
Its depths clear and bright.

*Rong says:*
Water’s heart is still yet clear,
A human heart is empty yet reflective.

**Master Cheng’s commentary:**
Depth means still water—
Water’s settled purity is clean and bright,
Its depths unfathomable.
The Sage’s heart is like a boundless spring,
Still yet illuminating—
Thus still water reflects all things,
An empty heart perceives all objects.

**Generosity is Virtuous in Benevolence**—
*御注* [Master He Shang Gong’s annotation]:
Generosity in giving aligns with the utmost benevolence,
Like water’s nourishment of all things.

*御疏* [Master He’s commentary]:
The Sage’s vast compassion,
Always extends to others.
Generosity’s essence harmonizes with benevolent conduct,
Like water’s nourishment—
It bestows without favor or aversion,
Thus it is said generosity is virtuous in benevolence.

*御注* [Master He Shang Gong’s annotation]:
All things rely on water to thrive,
It gives to the empty, not the full.

*Rong says:*
Water harmonizes with all things,
Humans benefit the common folk.

**Master Cheng’s commentary:**
Benevolence means grace—
Water’s nature clings and moistens,
Its grace nourishes all things.
The Sage’s virtue is compassionate and saving,
His grace extends to all beings—
Compassion knows no bounds of enmity or kinship,
Moistening does not discriminate between cold or foul.

**Speech is Virtuous in Faithfulness**—
*御注* [Master He Shang Gong’s annotation]:
Words spoken are true and real,
Like water’s flow through perilous paths,
Never failing in its truth.

*御疏* [Master He’s commentary]:
The Sage’s highest speech,
Words must be true and real,
Guiding the common folk toward transformation,
His faithfulness never deceives.

Like flowing springs,
Do they differ from treacherous ravines?
Thus it is said speech is virtuous in faithfulness.
The annotation states: *Water flows through perilous paths yet never loses its truth*—
This is the language of the *Zhou Yi* [Book of Changes] on *Kǎn* [the hexagram of danger].

*御注* [Master He Shang Gong’s annotation]:
Water’s inner reflection mirrors all forms,
Its clarity never falters.

*Rong says:*
Water’s reflection of things,
Beauty or ugliness, never distorts their form.
The benevolent in speech,
Their words never diverge from their truth.

**Master Cheng’s commentary:**
Faithfulness means reality—
Water can purify and reveal all appearances,
Beauty or ugliness, without deception.
The Sage’s words validate truth,
Their faithfulness is like a seal’s verification—
Even the tides of the sea,
Three times daily, never fail their appointed hour.
Much more so the Sage’s wisdom,
Which discerns all things,
Never neglecting the three categories of beings.

**Governance is Virtuous in Rectification**—
*御注* [Master He Shang Gong’s annotation]:
Governance excels in proper ordering,
Like water’s cleansing of all things,
Making them pure and cold.

*御疏* [Master He’s commentary]:
Governance means uprightness—
The Sage in his affairs,
Acts without contrivance,
His uprightness guides all things,
And all things follow naturally.
Uprightness brings self-ordering,
What else could be called virtuous?
Like water’s nature,
It cleanses all things,
Making them pure and serene—
Thus it is said governance is virtuous in rectification.

*御注* [Master He Shang Gong’s annotation]:
There is nothing water does not cleanse,
Its purity is vast and even.

*Rong says:*
Great peace is none greater than still water,
No partiality exceeds the Sage’s virtue.

**Master Cheng’s commentary:**
Water’s nature is level and without bias,
The Sage’s heart is upright and rectifies all evil.
As *Zhuangzi* says:
*In the midst of balance, the standard is set—
The great artisan takes his measure from it.*

**Capability is Virtuous in Skillfulness**—
*御注* [Master He Shang Gong’s annotation]:
In all affairs, his capability is skillful,
Like water’s nature—
Square or round, it adapts to the vessel,
Neither hindered nor obstructed by things.

*御疏* [Master He’s commentary]:
The Sage’s clarity and insight,
In all things, are without hindrance.
Whatever there is to move or act,
In all affairs, he is proficient.
Proficiency is skillfulness,
This is his illuminated understanding.
Like water’s nature,
It becomes a river when flowing,
A pond when obstructed—
Supporting boats, embracing emptiness,
It accomplishes all things—
This is its skillfulness.

*御注* [Master He Shang Gong’s annotation]:
It can be square or round,
Curved or straight, as form demands.

*Rong says:*
Water’s lack of use makes it unformed,
Yet the Sage’s purpose is never incomplete.

**Master Cheng’s commentary:**
Water’s nature is multifaceted in its capabilities,
Adapting to all affairs for benefit.
The Sage’s wisdom is insightful yet yielding,
His success comes from aligning with things.

**The Way’s Seven Virtues**—
Thus water’s three abilities,
And the Sage’s seven virtues,
Are nearly one in essence.
His conduct is not far from the Dao—
Thus it is said he is near.»

chunks.original_text: 动善时。 御注：物感而应，其不失其时，亦如水之春伴冬凝也。 ○御疏：至人之心，喻彼虚谷，方之镜像，物感斯应，如彼水性，春浮冬凝，与时消息，故云动善时。 ○河上公曰：夏散冬凝，应感而动，不失天时。 ○荣曰：水冬凝夏液，不差其节，君子相时而动，未失其宜也。 ○成疏：水冬凝夏释，流结随时，况圣智虚忘，感来则应，观机动寂，不失事宜，出处默语，不二而一。 ○节解：谓圣人事道以治身，去却邪伪，特为后贤而作轨范。 夫此七善者，皆因一行，形中万神自善也。 第三结柔弱，所以无疵。 夫唯不争，故无尤。 御注：上善之人，虚心顺物，如彼水性，壅止决流，既不违逆於物，故无尤过之地也。 ○御疏：尤，过也。 至人善行，与物无伤，虚心曲全，未尝争竞，波流颓靡，委顺若斯，既不违逆於物，故无尤过之地矣。 ○河上公曰：夫唯不争，壅之则止，次之则流，听从人也。 故无尤，水性如是，故天下无有怨尤水也。 ○严曰：人者体柔守弱，去高处下，受辱如地，含垢如海，言顺人心，身在人后，人之所恶，常独处之，恬若无心，荡若无已，变动无常，与道流止，去己任因，莫过於水。 帝王体之，用之为治，其德微妙，有何尤矣。 ○荣曰：水本无心，人能虚己，不与物同，前释唯水与圣独以不争，为能争，自然之道也。 ○成疏：夫唯义虚柔顺，故无尤过也。 道德真经玄德慕疏卷之二竟 道德真经玄德纂疏卷之三
chunks.translated_text:
**The Way’s Virtues in Motion**

**Timely Action**
*Master He Shang Gong’s annotation:*
Things respond and react—
when it does not fail its season,
it is like water:
spring it flows, winter it congeals.

*Master He’s Exegesis:*
The Perfect One’s heart
is like the hollow valley,
like a mirror’s reflection—
when things stimulate it, it responds.
Like water’s nature:
spring it rises, winter it congeals,
ebbing and flowing with the seasons.
Thus it is said: *Timely Action.*

*Master He Shang Gong:*
Summer it scatters, winter it congeals—
responding to stimuli, never missing the cosmic time.

*Rong says:*
Water congeals in winter, flows in summer,
never erring in its rhythms.
The Sage acts in accord with the seasons—
never failing what is proper.

*Master Cheng’s Exegesis:*
Water congeals in winter, releases in summer,
flowing and solidifying with the times.
How much more so the Sage’s insightful, empty wisdom—
responding as things arise,
observing the moment, acting or stilling,
never failing in what is fitting.
Emerging or retiring, speaking or silent—
dual yet one.

*The Seven Virtues’ Conclusion:*
This is how the Sage practices the Dao to govern himself,
discarding deceit and falsehood,
establishing norms for later sages.
These seven virtues
all arise from a single action—
within form, the myriad spirits act of their own accord.

**Third Virtue: Gentle Weakness**
Thus without blemish.

**The Virtue of Non-Contention**
*Master He Shang Gong’s annotation:*
The highest virtue is empty-hearted,
yielding to things—
like water’s nature:
obstructed, it stops; unobstructed, it flows.
It neither resists nor opposes things,
so there is no fault or blame.

*Master He’s Exegesis:*
*Fault* means *transgression*.
The Perfect One’s conduct is flawless,
harmonizing with things without injury,
empty-hearted yet complete,
never competing or contending.
Its currents ebb and flow,
submissive and yielding—
never resisting things,
so there is no fault or blame.

*Master He Shang Gong:*
Only by not contending
does it stop when obstructed, flow when unobstructed—
yielding to others.
Thus there is no fault.
Water’s nature is such—
the world has no grievance against water.

*Yan says:*
Human nature is gentle, weak in defense,
descending from high to low,
bearing insult like the earth,
containing filth like the sea.
Its words conform to others’ hearts,
its body follows behind.
What others detest,
it alone endures—
serene as if without thought,
drifted upon as if without end.
Its transformations are ever-changing,
flowing and stilling with the Dao,
abandoning self, following things—
nothing surpasses water.
If the Sage-King embodies this,
using it to govern,
his virtue is subtle and profound—
what fault could there be?

*Rong says:*
Water has no will of its own.
If one empties oneself,
not aligning with things,
as previously explained—
only water and the Sage, by not contending,
are capable of contending.
This is the natural Way.

*Master Cheng’s Exegesis:*
Only by righteousness, emptiness, gentleness, and yielding
is there no fault or transgression.

*End of Volume Two of the *Dao De Jing’s* Profound Virtue and Its Revered Commentary*
*Beginning of Volume Three of the *Dao De Jing’s* Profound Virtue and Its Compiled Commentary*

「Emperor Xuanzong’s Imperial Commentary and Exegesis
—Master He Shanggong’s *Strict* Commentary, Lord Yan Junping’s *Righteous* Commentary, Master Li Rong’s *Illuminating* Commentary,
—Master Xi Hua’s *Exegesis by Cheng Xuaning*, Master Mengyang Qiangsi’s *Compiled Commentary*

**Chapter Nine: *Hold Yet Overflow***

This chapter follows the previous one, for the prior expounded on the supreme excellence of *wuwei* (non-action) and the Way’s highest virtue—emptying oneself to benefit others. Thus, this chapter reveals the perils of worldly desires and self-inflicted blame, the reasons for which it follows. Here, one chapter unfolds three distinct teachings:

1. **The dangers of clinging to desires with a fixed heart—prone to ruin.**
2. **Wealth and honor breed arrogance, inviting calamity.**
3. **Only humility, gentleness, and quiet retreat align with the Dao.**

**1. The dangers of clinging to desires with a fixed heart—prone to ruin.**
The heavens and earth are vast crucibles of divine transformation, yet even their luminous forms—moon and sun—abide by the measure of waxing and waning, lest they falter. Mountains and rivers stand deep and firm, yet they endure the fate of collapse and exhaustion. How much more so we, mere mortals, who dare to grasp at fullness? We stamp our feet in the realm of sound and color, indulging our hearts in the duality of self and other. Our minds teem with wicked seeds, yet we remain blind to their absence of clarity; our hearts bristle with malevolent intent, yet we persist in delusion, secure and undisturbed. Like infants wailing in their cradles, we rise from the Three Palaces to lodge our complaints; like bones exposed to the elements, we drift through the Nine Abysses, unrecognized. The folly of a mortal’s life is thus inverted—truly blind, yet unseeing, and how deeply pitiable!

**To hold yet overflow is not as good as simply ceasing.**
*Imperial Commentary:* Grasping at fullness and overflow, preventing their loss, only burdens one with wealth—regret and stinginess arise thereafter. Thus, it is better to cease.
Cease means *to stop*.

*Imperial Exegesis:* **Hold** is *to grasp*; **overflow** is *fullness*; **cease** is *to stop*.
The human heart, greedy and loving desires, endlessly seeks and takes, grasping and preserving to ensure fullness. Yet wealth becomes a burden, and regret and stinginess fester anew. Therefore, the Sage warns: *Better to rest than to persist*.

*He Shanggong says:* Overflow is fullness; cease is to stop. To grasp at fullness guarantees its loss—better to stop.

*Yan Junping says:* When one pollutes the paths of all beings with political schemes and the accumulation of wealth, the heavier the riches, the more one’s spirit and clarity are depleted. Wealth and gain, piling up, only breed the guilt of life and death—far better to cease before fullness is reached.

*Li Rong says:* A tilted vessel, filled to the brim, must topple; excess and indulgence, once overflowing, must fail. If one wishes to avoid ruin and defeat, only humility and restraint suffice.

*Exegesis by Cheng Xuaning:* **Hold** is *to grasp*; **overflow** is *fullness*; **cease** is *to stop*.
Those who cannot retreat in quietude nor embrace humility, who persist in grasping and seeking fullness, who boast of their greatness and scheme to overpower others—such folly will surely invite ruin. Better to stop than to act.

Thus, the *Zhuangzi* states: *"Fill to the brim, and it will topple and perish."* And the *Book of Documents* says: *"Fullness invites loss; humility invites benefit."*

**To probe yet sharpen is not long-enduring.**
*Imperial Commentary:* To measure and sharpen one’s ambitions, pursuing honor and fame, will inevitably breed arrogance—sitting thus invites misfortune and blame. Hence, it cannot endure long.

*Imperial Exegesis:* **Probe** is *to measure*; **sharpen** is *to whet*.
When mundane emotions are sluggish and drowned, one clings to the pursuit of honor and gain. Thus, one measures past events, whets the heart’s desires, and invites the resentment of ghosts and men—sitting in such folly will surely bring misfortune and blame. Hence, it cannot endure long.

*He Shanggong says:* **Probe** is *to govern*; one first governs by probing, yet later must abandon it.

*Yan Junping says:* To whet one’s heart and sharpen one’s resolve, to strategize with cunning—when one’s wisdom grows sharp and one’s rank and reputation swell, one’s vitality wanes while the body advances. How can such a state endure long?

*Li Rong says:* Honor invites censure; prosperity invites weariness. A sharp mind that stands out among others will be scorned by men—how can it endure long?

*Exegesis by Cheng Xuaning:* **Probe** is *to polish*; **sharpen** is *to refine*.
To polish a blade or whet a tool—though refined, they must surely wear. How much more so when one polishes and sharpens one’s own heart, demanding only of others, whose harm is greater than that of weapons? All things are my inferior, yet I persist—how can such folly endure long?

*Commentary by Mengyang Qiangsi:* The upper **probe** refers to reckless speech; the lower **probe** refers to scattered spirit. Reckless speech invites war and strife; scattered spirit invites decay and loss—teeth falling, hair turning white.

**2. Wealth and honor breed arrogance, inviting calamity.**
Gold and jade fill the halls—yet none can guard them.

*Imperial Commentary:* This reveals that overflow cannot be long preserved.

*Imperial Exegesis:* Even if one ceaselessly demands and takes, filling halls with gold and jade—like the sun with teeth yet burning its own body, or the rooster with fear yet having its tail cut—one will lose the very treasures one sought to hoard, inviting the woes of bandits. How can such folly be guarded? This reverses the meaning of *holding yet overflowing*.

*Commentary by Mengyang Qiangsi:* Without blood, there is no gold; without essence, there is no jade. If one can cultivate the *One*, the upper and lower will flow freely—rumbling within the belly like thunder, limbs and joints supported, eyes bright and responsive, in harmony with the *One*.

*He Shanggong says:* Lustful desires weary the spirit; wealth burdens the body.

*Yan Junping says:* Wealth and honor, like ice and coal—both cannot coexist. Honor and power are defilements of the spirit; gain and wealth are harms to the body. To nourish the spirit’s defilements and accumulate the body’s harms is to diminish the means of one’s flourishing while fostering the causes of one’s ruin. The more one gains in wealth, the more one’s *qi* is exhausted—how can it be guarded?

*Li Rong says:* Gold and jade have no feet, yet they scatter of their own accord. Fire and water’s disasters cannot be repelled; bandits and thieves cannot be warded off. Thus, it is known: to hoard and gather is to lose the Way; to disperse and give is to conform with the Dao.

*Exegesis by Cheng Xuaning:* Desires excessive, the spirit grows weary; wealth accumulated, the body labors. When both body and mind are thus strained, none can guard them. Moreover, if one hoards without dispersing, great thieves will surely come. Within, one harbors grief and sorrow; without, one’s grasp weakens. When the body perishes, the wealth remains—thus, none can guard it.»

---

Wealth and honor yet proud—one invites one’s own calamity.
*Imperial Commentary:* This reveals the sharpness that cannot be measured.
Pride arises from the heart, hence the retribution comes not from others.

*Imperial Exegesis:* *Heru* (遗), to bestow. Wealth invites others’ pursuit, hence one easily deceives things.
Honor invites subservience, hence one takes to domineering others.
When arrogance and excess reach their height, misfortune comes—who can blame?
Because of pride, retribution arises; pride stems from the heart—thus it is said, "one invites it oneself."
This is the reversal of measuring sharpness.

*River Above Master* says: When wealthy, one should relieve the poor; when honored, one should pity the lowly. Yet to indulge in pride and licentiousness is to invite disaster.

*Yan* says: To be wealthy and honored yet not proud is easy to speak but hard to practice. The higher one’s station, the loftier one’s aspirations—yet to be proud in wealth and honor is like a torch meeting fire: the brighter the door, the faster the flame consumes. How can one not be cautious?

*Li Rong* says: Accumulated wealth, if not dispersed, and riding honor to oppress others—retribution arises from within, not from without.

*Cheng Exegesis:* *Jiu* (咎), an omen. *Heru* (遗), to bestow. Those in wealth and honor ought to aid others, yet failing to be modest, they grow ever more arrogant and swollen, bringing ruin upon themselves—how could it concern others?

*Concise Explanation:* It speaks of those in wealth and honor who covet fame, riches, and bribes, unwilling to cultivate the Dao, until death comes. Even if one hoards money to the heavens, what use is it to the body? When the body dies, the name perishes. Only through humility, gentleness, and retreat does one align with the Dao of Heaven.

When achievements are complete and reputation fulfilled, retreat is the Way of Heaven.
*Imperial Commentary:* Those whose achievements are complete and reputation fulfilled should withdraw to decline prominence—this is not yet the Dao of Heaven. Only by observing the ebb and flow of fullness and emptiness can one be free from worry and rest.

*Imperial Exegesis:* This is a warning. Fullness invites loss; humility invites benefit. Even Heaven does not remain perpetually full, so those whose achievements are complete meet ruin, and those whose reputation is fulfilled suffer decline. To seek enduring preservation—no such words have been heard. One must forget merit and step back, withdrawing from prominence like the Dao of Heaven, never losing the balance of fullness and emptiness, thus free from blame and worry.

*River Above Master* says: When a person’s deeds are accomplished and reputation established, if they do not withdraw and avoid their position, they will surely meet disaster—this is the constant Dao of Heaven. Like the sun at its zenith moving on, the moon at fullness waning, things at their peak declining, and extreme joy turning to sorrow.

*Li Rong* says: Yin and yang succeed one another; cold and heat shift in turn—this is the constant principle of things, the eternal Dao of Heaven. If one clings to honor without retreat, disaster follows. The exegeses thus perceive the signs; the Four Worthies departed in understanding, aligning with the principles of things and the Dao of Heaven.

*Cheng Exegesis:* Heaven is the natural order. The sun at its zenith declines; the moon at fullness wanes—waning and fullness alternate, extremes reverse—this is their constant nature. Thus, those whose worldly achievements are complete and whose reputation is fulfilled must guard their station, know contentment, practice humility, gentleness, and retreat, dwelling in uncompetitive places, avoiding harm, and preserving life. Only thus do they deeply align with the true Dao of Heaven. Those whose achievements are complete and reputation fulfilled must withdraw and refine their conduct, acting naturally.

---
**Chapter Eleven: Nurturing the Vital Essence (载营魄)**

This chapter follows the previous, which broadly expounded the faults of arrogance and the virtue of humility and retreat. Yet regarding the practice of the Dao’s path, its methods were still incomplete. Thus, this chapter elaborates on the inner and outer practices, detailing their functions step by step. Its meaning is divided into three parts: first, it clarifies restraining the spirit and subduing the vital essence, focusing on inner cultivation; second, it broadly displays the conduct of governing the state and benefiting others; third, it reveals the beauty of attaining the Dao and forgetting merit.

**First: Restraining the Spirit and Subduing the Vital Essence, Guarding Oneness in Inner Cultivation**

Just as rare trees flourish with fragrance and forest flowers bloom with charm, it is because their roots are deep and their stems firm, drawing nourishment from the dew. So too for humanity: the spirit and vital essence must be nourished, preserving harmonious *qi* to self-moisten, guarding humility and gentleness to achieve completion.

When snow falls thickly, one must endure the toil of coming and going;
When the rooster crows, one must add to the diligence of night and day.
One must ensure the vital essence and spirit are harmonious and at peace,
Lest the mind and spirit scatter and stray.
Know that Ziji controlled the white crane to part the clouds,
Only then did he realize the Master’s lute, riding the red carp, soared to the Han.
If one abandons true essence for mundane affairs,
The Dao’s sorrow is profound—how dark the common folk’s ignorance!

Nurturing the vital essence and embracing oneness—how could it ever depart?

*Imperial Commentary:* At the beginning of life, the vital essence is called *po* (魄); once born, the *po* becomes *hun* (魂) with the rise of yang. The *po* is yin and empty, the *hun* is yang and full. It speaks of the initial bearing of empty *po*, which must constantly be nurtured and protected to restore yang. When yang *qi* fills the *po*, it becomes *hun*; if the *hun* can move, life is complete. *One* means "unrestrained." To restore yang and preserve life, one must not be contaminated—thus, one must embrace and guard pure oneness, lest it depart from the body.

*Imperial Exegesis:* *Zai* (载), initial. *Ying* (营), to protect. It says that at the start of life, one is but an empty form; once the *po* is born, yang *qi* fills the empty *po*. If the *po* can move, it is called *hun*—like the moon’s reflection illuminating the sun, generating light. Thus, as recorded in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Zichan said: "At the beginning of life, the vital essence is called *po*; once the *po* is born, yang becomes *hun."* It speaks of the initial bearing of empty *po*, which must be nurtured and protected, constantly ensuring yang *qi* fills it, thus preserving life. If movement is irregular and yang *qi* is dissipated, it reverts to empty *po* and perishes. *Zhuangzi* says: "The mind near death must not restore yang." Thus, one must nurture and protect the empty *po*, restoring yang to preserve life, embracing and guarding pure oneness, lest it be contaminated—then life is complete. This teaches the nourishment of the spirit.

*River Above Master* says: *Zai ying po* (载营魄), *ying* is *hun* (魂).

chunks.original_text: 人载魂魄之上得以生，当爱养之。 喜怒伤魂，卒惊伤魄，魂在肝，魄在肺，美酒甘者，腐人肝肺，故魂静则志道不乱，魄安则得寿延年。 抱一能无离乎，言人能抱一，使不离於身则长存。 一者，道始所生，太和之精，故曰一。 布名於天下，天得一以清，地得一以宁，侯王得一以为正。 入为心，出为行，布则为施，总名为一。 一之为言，志一无二也。 ○荣曰：载，运也。 营，护也。 魄，身神也。 一，道也。 人者神之车，故言载。 身清则魂魄安，心浊则真神远，染虑以守神，故言营。 灰心无有二，故言一。 智将道合，神与形同，故曰无离。 ○成疏：载营魄，载，运也，营魂是阳神，欲人之善。 魄是阴神，欲人之恶。 故魂营营然而好生，魄，泊也，欲人之泊着生死。 又魂性雄健，好受喜怒，魄性雌柔，好受惊怖，惊怖喜怒，皆损精神。 故修道之初，先须拘魂制魄，使不驰动也。 抱一能无离，抱，守也，一，三一也。 离，散也。 既能拘魂制魄，次须守三一之神，虚夷凝静，令不离散也。 专气致柔，能如婴儿乎？ 御注：专一冲气，使致和柔如婴儿，无所分别乎。 ○御疏：专，专一也。 气，冲和妙气也。 人之受生，冲气为本，若染杂尘境，则冲气离散，神不固身，故戒令专一冲和，使致柔弱，能如婴儿，无所耽着乎，此教养气也。 ○河上公曰：专气致柔，专精其气使不乱，则形体能应之而柔顺也。 能如婴儿乎，能如婴儿，内无思虑，外无故事，则精神不去也。 ○荣曰：一身心则纯和不散，专气也。 得长生之道，致柔也。 未识阴阳之合，无复是非之情，能如婴儿也。 ○成疏：专，精专也。 炁，道也。 致，得也。 柔，和也。 只为专精道炁，致得柔和之理，故如婴儿之无欲。 涤除玄览，能无疵乎？ 御注：玄览，心照也。 疵，病也。 涤除心照，使令清净，能无疵病乎。 ○御疏：涤，洗也。 除，理也。 玄览，心照也。 疵，病也。 人之耽染，为起欲心，当须洗涤除理，使心照清净，情欲不起，能令无疵病乎。 此教修心也。 ○河上公曰：涤除玄览，当洗其心，使洁清也。 心居玄冥之处，览知万事，故谓之玄览也。 能无疵乎，不淫邪也。 ○荣曰：浴玄流以洗心，涤也。 荡灵风以遣累，除也。 内外圆净，同水镜之清凝，表里贞明，绝珠玉之瑕类也。 ○成疏：涤，洗也。 除，遣也。 览，察也。 疵，病也。 涤荡六府，除遣五情，神炁虚玄，故能览察妙理，内外清夷，而无疵病者。 第二明广显治国利佗之行。 爱民治国，能无为乎？ 御注：爱养万人，临理国政，能无为乎，当自化矣。 自上营魄，皆放修身。 身修则德全，故可为之君也。 ○御疏：爱民者，使之不暴卒，役之不伤性。 理国者，务农而重谷，事简而不烦，则人安其生，不言而化。 此无为也，能为之乎。 ○河上公曰：爱民治国，治身者爱气则身全，治国者爱民则国安。 能无知乎，治身者，呼吸精气，无令耳闻。 治国者，布德施惠，无令下知。 ○荣曰君上不能自化，必藉於人化，物理人事资安静，但有为而躁动者，伤物也，无为而安静者，爱人也。 ○成疏：前既自利道圆，此下应须接物，行之莫先治国爱民。 知，分别智也。 慈悲覆养，是曰爱民，布政行化，名为治国。

「The human being bears *hun* and *po* above, and thereby sustains life—this must be cherished and nourished.
Joy and anger harm the *hun*; sudden fright harms the *po*.
The *hun* resides in the liver, the *po* in the lungs.
Rich wine and sweetness corrupt the liver and lungs,
so when the *hun* is tranquil, one’s resolve in the Dao remains undisturbed,
and when the *po* is secure, longevity and extended years are attained.
Can one not depart from *oneness*?
It is said that if one can embrace *oneness*,
keeping it ever-present within oneself, then one may endure forever.
*Oneness* is the Dao’s initial manifestation,
the essence of *Great Harmony* (太和),
hence it is called *oneness*.

It is proclaimed throughout the world:
the heavens attain *oneness* and thereby become clear,
the earth attains *oneness* and thereby becomes settled,
and sovereigns attain *oneness* to establish righteousness.
Within, it becomes the heart;
without, it becomes conduct.
When it is dispersed, it is called *application* (施);
in totality, it is called *oneness*.
The term *oneness* means
a singular resolve with no duplicity.

**Honor** says:
*Load* (载) means *circulate*.
*Camp* (营) means *protect*.
*Po* (魄) is the vital spirit of the body.
*Oneness* is the Dao.
The human being is the Dao’s vehicle,
hence it is said to *load*.
A pure body ensures *hun* and *po* are secure;
a turbid heart drives away the true spirit.
With contemplation and vigilance, one guards the spirit,
hence it is said to *camp*.
The mind must not be divided,
hence it is said to be *one*.
When wisdom aligns with the Dao,
the spirit harmonizes with the form,
hence it is said that there is no *departure*.

**Master Cheng’s Commentary** says:
*Load hun and po* (载营魄):
*Load* (载) means *circulate*.
*Camp hun* (营魂) is the yang spirit, urging one toward goodness.
*Po* (魄) is the yin spirit, urging one toward vice.
Thus, the *hun* is restless yet inclined toward life,
while the *po* is tranquil, desiring detachment from birth and death.
Moreover, the *hun*’s nature is bold and vigorous,
prone to receiving joy and anger,
while the *po*’s nature is yielding and passive,
prone to receiving fright and terror.
Fright, terror, joy, and anger
all diminish the vital spirit.
Hence, at the outset of cultivating the Dao,
one must first restrain the *hun* and subdue the *po*,
preventing their unrestrained movement.
If one can embrace *oneness* without departing,
*embrace* (抱) means *guard*,
*oneness* refers to the *three-in-one* (三一),
*departure* (离) means *scatter*.
Having restrained the *hun* and subdued the *po*,
one must next guard the *three-in-one* spirit,
keeping it empty, tranquil, and concentrated,
so that it does not scatter.
Can one focus the *qi* to attain softness,
as with an infant?
**Master Cheng’s Annotation** says:
To focus the *succinct qi* (冲气),
making it harmonious and soft like an infant,
without discrimination—
this is the teaching of nourishing *qi*.

**Master Cheng’s Commentary** says:
*Focus* (专) means *concentrated focus*.
*Qi* (气) is the Dao.
*Attain* (致) means *obtain*.
*Softness* (柔) is *harmony*.
It is merely to concentrate on the Dao’s *qi*,
obtaining the principle of harmonious softness,
hence like an infant’s lack of desire.
Can one purify and clarify *mystic vision* (玄览),
and thereby be free of flaws?
**Master Cheng’s Annotation** says:
*Purify* (涤) means *wash*.
*Clarify* (除) means *order*.
*Mystic vision* (玄览) is the heart’s illumination.
*Flaws* (疵) are *illnesses*.
To wash and order the heart’s illumination,
making it pure and clear,
so that desires do not arise,
and one may be free of illness—
this is the teaching of refining the heart.

**River Above Master** says:
*Purify and clarify mystic vision* (涤除玄览),
one must wash the heart,
making it pristine and pure.
The heart dwells in the *mystic void* (玄冥),
perceiving all things,
hence it is called *mystic vision*.
Can one be free of flaws?
It means not indulging in licentiousness.
**Honor** says:
To bathe in the *mystic flow* (玄流) and wash the heart—*purify* (涤).
To sway the *numinous breeze* (灵风) and dispel burdens—*clarify* (除).
Within and without, perfectly pure,
like the clarity of a mirror in water,
and in integrity, without blemish,
cutting off the defects of jade and pearl.
**Master Cheng’s Commentary** says:
*Purify* (涤) means *wash*.
*Clarify* (除) means *dispel*.
*Mystic vision* (玄览) is *perception*.
*Flaws* (疵) are *illnesses*.
To purify and dispel the *six palaces* (六府),
and clarify the *five emotions* (五情),
the spirit and *qi* become empty and mystic,
hence one may perceive subtle principles,
and within and without, be serene,
free of illness.

**The Second Section Illuminates the Broad and Manifest Practices of Governing and Benefiting the People.**
To cherish the people and govern the realm,
can one act without *action* (為)?
**Master Cheng’s Annotation** says:
To cherish and nourish the myriad people,
to oversee state affairs,
can one act without *action*?
It should be natural and self-transforming.
From above, one circulates and protects *po*—
all are released to cultivate the self.
When the self is cultivated, *virtue* is complete,
hence one may be their sovereign.

**Master Cheng’s Commentary** says:
*Cherishing the people* (爱民)
means ensuring they do not suffer sudden violence,
and laboring without harming their nature.
*Governing the realm* (治国)
means prioritizing agriculture and valuing grain,
simplifying affairs and avoiding excess,
so that the people find ease in life,
and order is achieved without words.
This is *non-action* (无为).
Can one attain it?

**River Above Master** says:
*Cherishing the people and governing the realm* (爱民治国):
One who governs the self cherishes *qi* and thereby preserves the body;
one who governs the realm cherishes the people and thereby secures the state.
Can one act without *knowledge*?
In governing the self, one breathes in the refined *qi*,
without letting it be heard by the ears.
In governing the realm, one dispenses *virtue* and bestows benevolence,
without letting the subjects know of it.

**Honor** says:
The sovereign cannot self-transform,
and must rely on others to transform.
The principles of things and human affairs depend on tranquility—
only those who act with *action* (有為) are restless and harm things;
those who act without *action* (無為) are tranquil and cherish the people.

**Master Cheng’s Commentary** says:
Having already perfected the Dao for self-benefit,
one must now apply it to others.
The most urgent practice is to govern the realm and cherish the people.
*Knowledge* (知) is discriminative wisdom.
Compassionate and merciful nurturing is called *cherishing the people*,
and implementing policies to transform is called *governing the realm».*

chunks.original_text: 夫治国者必须示其淳朴，教以无为，杜彼邪奸，塞兹分别，如此则击壤之风斯返，结绳之政可追。 故下文云以智治国国之贼，不以智治国国之德。 天门开阖，能为雌乎？ 御注：天门，历数所从出。 开阖，谓理乱。 言人君应期#2受命，能守雌静，则可以永终天禄矣。 又解云：《易》曰：常不以雄成，守雌牝，亦如天门开阖，亏而益谦。 ○御疏：修德可以为君，为君须承历数，即天门者，帝王历数所从出也。 开谓受命，阖为废黜，天降宝命，以祚有道，能守雌柔，可享元吉。 故云能为雌乎。 又解云：《易》曰：一阖一辟谓之变，言圣人设教，应变无常，不以雄成，而守雌牝，亦如天门开阖，亏盈而益谦也。 ○河上公曰：天门开阖，天门，谓北极紫官。 开阖，谓终始五际。 治身，天门谓鼻孔，开谓喘息，阖谓呼吸也。 能为雌乎，治身当如雌牝，安静柔弱。 治国应变和而不唱也。 ○荣曰：天有四时之门，青门开而暄，赤门开而热，白门开而冷，黑门开而寒，今之细人暑雨祁寒，皆生怨嗟，此不能静也。 阖，闭也，一门开三门闭。 雌，静也，圣人神凝於太漠，智寂於虚玄，死生否泰不能惊，水火寒热不能动。 ○成疏：阖，闭也。 雌，静也。 天地闭阖，谓劫运成坏也。 言圣人混述二仪之中，不为三灾所及，虽劫有废兴，而心恒虚静，故《庄子》云：大浸稽天而不溺，大旱金石流，土山焦，而不热。 明白四达，能无知乎？ 御注：人君能为雌静，则万姓乐推其德，明白如日四照，犹须忘功不宰，故云能无知乎？ ○御疏：帝王既受历数，临御万方，若能守雌静，则其德明白，如日之照，四达天下，功被於物，不以为功，所谓忘功若无知者，故云能无知乎？ ○河上公曰：明白四达，言道明白如日月，四通满天下，八极之外，故曰视之不见，听之不闻，彰布之於十方，焕焕煌煌。 能无知乎，无有能知道满於天下者。 ○荣曰：圣人智周万物，明斋两曜，四方皆照，为四达也。 照而常寂，光而不曜，遗识混心，能无知也。 ○成疏：明以能照得名白，以洁素受称。 四者四方，达者无碍，言圣人空惠明白，妙达玄理，智无不照，境无不通，故略举四，足明八极。 且寂而能应，所以四达，应不乖寂，恒自无为也。 ○又解云：四达者，达三界及道境。 生之畜之，生而不有，为而不恃，长而不宰，是谓玄德。 御注：令物各遂其生而畜养之，遂生而不以为有，修为而不恃其功，居长而不为主宰。 人君能如此，是谓深玄之德矣。 ○御疏：生之畜之，下经云：道生之，德畜之，此云生之畜之者，谓人君治道清净，令物得遂其生理，效德弘济，令物各尽其畜养，故云生之畜之。 生而不有，为而不恃，长而不宰，是谓玄德。 物得遂生，圣忘功用。 遂生则生理自足，忘功则功用常全，斯乃无私而成私，不宰而为宰也。 故生而不有者，令物各遂其生，君不以为己有也。 为而不恃者，令各得动为，而不自负恃为己功也。 居万民之上，故云长，不恃其功，故云不宰也。 如是是谓深玄之德矣。 ○河上公曰：生之畜之，道生万物而畜养。 生而不有，道生万物无有取也。 为而不恃，道所施为，不恃望其报。 长而不宰，道长养万物，长大不宰割，以为其器用之。
chunks.translated_text:
「Thus, in governing the realm, one must display one’s sincerity and simplicity,
and teach *non-action* (無為).
One must extinguish their deceitful and perverse ways,
and block all discriminative distinctions.
In doing so, the *striking the earth* custom shall return,
and the *tying knots* governance may be emulated.

Therefore, the following passage states:
To govern the realm with *knowledge* (知) is to be the realm’s thief,
but not to govern the realm with *knowledge* is to be the realm’s *virtue* (德).

Can one act as the *feminine* (雌)?
**Imperial Commentary** says:
*Heaven’s Gate* (天門) is where the *cosmic cycles* (歷數) emerge.
*Opening and closing* (開闢) refers to the rise and fall of order.
It means that when the sovereign receives the *Mandate of Heaven* (受命),
can they maintain *feminine tranquility* (雌靜),
then they may endure and enjoy the *Heavenly Blessings* (天祿) forever.

Another interpretation says:
*The Classic of Changes* (《易》) states:
*"The constant does not rely on the masculine to complete itself,
but guards the feminine principle—
just as Heaven’s Gate opens and closes,
retreating to yield more humility."*

**Imperial Commentary** further explains:
To rule as a sovereign, one must cultivate *virtue* (德).
A sovereign must uphold the *cosmic cycles* (歷數),
for *Heaven’s Gate* (天門) is where the *imperial succession* (帝王歷數) originates.
*Opening* (開) signifies receiving the *Mandate of Heaven* (受命),
while *closing* (闢) signifies abdication (廢黜).
When Heaven bestows its *precious Mandate* (寶命),
it grants prosperity to those with the *Way* (道).
If one can maintain *feminine tranquility* (雌柔),
they may attain the ultimate *auspiciousness* (元吉).
Thus it says: Can one act as the *feminine* (雌)?

Another interpretation says:
*The Classic of Changes* (《易》) states:
*"The alternation of opening and closing is called *change* (變).*
It means the Sage establishes teachings
to adapt to ever-shifting circumstances,
never relying on the masculine alone,
but guarding the *feminine principle*—
just as Heaven’s Gate opens and closes,
receding to further humility and balance."

**River Above Master** (河上公) says:
*Heaven’s Gate* (天門) refers to the *Purple Office* (紫官) of the *Northern Pole* (北極).
*Opening and closing* (開闢) signifies the *five cosmic junctures* (五際) of beginning and end.
In *governing the body* (治身),
*Heaven’s Gate* (天門) refers to the nostrils—
*opening* (開) is breathing in,
*closing* (闢) is breathing out.
To *act as the feminine* (為雌) means
to govern the body with *tranquility and softness* (安靜柔弱),
and to govern the realm by harmonizing responses without excess.

**Honor** says:
Heaven has *four seasonal gates* (四時之門):
the *Blue Gate* (青門) opens and brings warmth,
the *Red Gate* (赤門) opens and brings heat,
the *White Gate* (白門) opens and brings cold,
the *Black Gate* (黑門) opens and brings chill.
Nowadays, the common people suffer oppressive summer rains and bitter cold,
all because they cannot maintain *tranquility*.
*Closing* (闢) means shutting—
when one gate opens, the other three close.
*Feminine* (雌) is *tranquility*.
The Sage’s spirit is concentrated in the *Great Void* (太漠),
their wisdom is still in the *Empty Mysterious* (虚玄),
and neither life nor death, nor calamity or fortune,
can disturb them.
Nor can fire, water, cold, or heat move them.

**Master Cheng’s Commentary** (成疏) says:
*Closing* (闢) means shutting,
*feminine* (雌) is *tranquility*.
When Heaven and Earth *close and open* (閉闢),
it refers to the *formation and destruction of kalpas* (劫運).
It means the Sage dwells harmoniously within the *Two Principles* (二儀),
unaffected by the *Three Calamities* (三災).
Though the kalpas may rise or fall,
the Sage’s heart remains ever *Empty and Tranquil* (虚靜),
thus *Zhuangzi* says:
*"The Great Flood submerged Heaven yet did not drown me,
the Great Drought made metal and stone flow,
earth-mountains withered and cracked,
yet I did not feel the heat."*

*Fourfold illumination* (明白四達) means
the Sage’s *virtue* (德) is clear and boundless,
like the radiance of the sun and moon.
*Four* (四) signifies the four directions,
*illumination* (照) means unobstructed,
*illumination* (達) means without hindrance.
It means the Sage’s *Empty and Clear Virtue* (空惠明白)
penetrates the *Mystic Principles* (玄理),
their wisdom illuminates all things,
and their perception reaches every domain—
thus mentioning *four* suffices to encompass the *Eight Extremes* (八極).
Yet they remain ever still,
and respond without contradiction,
so their *fourfold illumination* persists.
Their responses never disrupt their stillness—
they remain in *non-action* (無為) always.

Another interpretation says:
*Fourfold illumination* (四達) means
penetrating the *Three Realms* (三界) and the *Dao* (道).
To *generate and nurture* (生之畜之)
is to *generate without possession* (生而不有),
*act without reliance* (為而不恃),
and *endure without domination* (長而不宰)—
this is called *Mystic Virtue* (玄德).

**Imperial Commentary** says:
The sovereign *generates and nurtures* (生之畜之),
letting all things fulfill their natural growth and sustenance.
They fulfill life without claiming it as their own,
act without relying on their deeds,
and endure without ruling over others.
If a sovereign can do this,
it is called *Mystic Virtue* (深玄之德).

**Imperial Commentary** further explains:
*Generate and nurture* (生之畜之)
is elaborated in the lower scripture:
*"The Dao generates all things,
and *virtue* (德) nurtures them."*
Here, it means the sovereign upholds the *Pure Way* (清净之道),
allowing all things to fulfill their natural essence (*生理*).
They embody *virtue* (德) to broadly aid and sustain,
letting all things attain their full sustenance (*畜養*).
Thus it says: *generate and nurture* (生之畜之).
To *generate without possession* (生而不有),
*act without reliance* (為而不恃),
and *endure without domination* (長而不宰)
is called *Mystic Virtue* (玄德).
Things fulfill their natural growth,
while the Sage forgets their own deeds.
When things fulfill their growth,
their natural essence is complete,
and when deeds are forgotten,
their efficacy remains constant—
this is *selfless yet all-encompassing*,
*non-domination yet rule*.
Thus, *to generate without possession* (生而不有)
means the sovereign lets all things fulfill their natural growth,
yet does not claim it as their own.
*To act without reliance* (為而不恃)
means they allow all to act as they will,
yet do not credit the deeds as their own achievements.
As the sovereign over all people,
it is said they *endure* (長),
yet do not rely on their deeds—
thus *not to dominate* (不宰).
Such is called *Mystic Virtue* (深玄之德).

**River Above Master** (河上公) says:
*Generate and nurture* (生之畜之)
refers to the Dao generating all things and nurturing them.
To *generate without possession* (生而不有)
means the Dao generates all things yet takes nothing for itself.
To *act without reliance* (為而不恃)
means the Dao’s actions are not done in expectation of reward.
To *endure without domination* (長而不宰)
means the Dao endures and nurtures all things,
growing vast yet never seizing or controlling—
it merely provides them as instruments for use.»

chunks.original_text: 是谓玄德，言道德玄冥，不可得见，欲使人如道也。 ○严曰：不有不恃不以不宰，变化冥冥，天地自理，去为譬，以况理教，教其文字为有也，理绝名言为无也，教之行也，因理而明，理之诠焉，由教而显，理因教显，无教理无所寄，教籍理明，无理教何所说。 既知理教之相由，是体有无之为用。 ○成疏：《周礼·考工记》云：三十辐象三十日，以成一月也。 当其无者，箱毂内空也，只为空能容物，故有车用。 况学人心空，故能运载苍生也。 又车是假名，诸缘和合而成，此车细析推寻，遍体虚幻，况一切诸法，亦复如是。 埏埴以为器，当其无，有器之用。 御注：埏，和也。 坛，牯土也。 陶匠和土，为瓦缶之器也。 ○御疏：埏埴，粘土也。 注云陶匠者，《尚书》云：范土曰陶。 此言陶匠范和粘土，烧成瓦器，亦取其中空虚，以用盛受物也。 ○河上公曰：埏埴以为器，埏，和也。 坛，土也。 和土以为食饮之器也。 当其无，有器之用，器中空虚，故得有所盛受也。 ○荣曰：作器必须和泥，泥调则器可用。 修身理宜炼行，行洁则道可成。 埏，和也。 埴，土也。 ○成疏：《考工记》云：埏，和也。 值，粘土也。 和粘水土，烧以成器，器中空无，故得盛受。 以况学人心空，故能容物。 凿户牖以为室，当其无，有室之用。 御注：古者陶穴以为室宇，亦开户牖，故云凿耳。 ○御疏：凿，穿也。 门旁窗谓之牖。 古者穴居，故《诗》云：陶复陶穴，谓穿凿穴中之土以复覆其上，故云凿耳。 后代圣人易之以官室，取其室中空虚，所以人得居处。 《庄子》曰：室无空虚，则妇姑勃蹊，勃蹊谓争路也。 《尔雅》云：官谓之室。 故有之以为利，无之以为用。 有之所利，利铃资无，故有以无为利也。 无之所用，用於体，体必资有，故无以有为用也。 注云：形而上者曰道，形而下者曰器，《易·系辞》文也。 自无则称道，涉有则称器，欲明道用，必约形器以彰，虽借喻於三翻，终用无於一政耳。 ○河上公曰：凿户牖以为室，谓作室屋。 当其无，有室之用，言户牖室虚，人得以出入。 观视室中空虚，人得居处，是其用也。 ○荣曰：为室内不空虚，外无户牖，其为用不以难乎。 为道内既暗昧，外复聋瞽，以此求道，理非易乎。 室开户牖，有用也。 人生慧解，道成之。 ○成疏：穿凿户牖，以为屋室，室中空无，故得居处。 况学人心空，故能覆物。 又穿凿户牖，通人往来，况根窍虚通，故能用而无染。 车等三物，其义相类，所以重出者，车则动而不静，室则静而不动，器则亦动亦静，有此三异，故重出之。 第二的辨有无，显明资导。 故有之以为利，无之以为用。 御注：有体利无，以无为利。 无用体者，以有为用。 且形而上者曰道，形而下者曰器，将明至道之用，约形质以彰，故借粗有之利无，以明妙无之用有耳。 ○河上公曰：故有之以为利，物利於形，器中有物，室中有人，恐其屋破坏。 腹中有神，畏其形之消亡也。 无之以为用，言虚空中者，乃可用盛受物，故曰虚无制有形。 道者空无也。 ○荣曰：单有而无无，有不得为利，单无而无有，无不得为用，明有因无以为利，无因有以为用。 既识有无之相因，自知粗妙之相籍也。
chunks.translated_text:
「This is called *Mystic Virtue* (玄德), for the Dao/Way’s virtue is profound and unfathomable (玄冥), beyond direct perception, yet it seeks to guide people toward its nature.

○ **Yan** (严) says:
*Not possessing, not relying, not taking credit, not dominating* (不有不恃不以不宰),
the transformations are unfathomable (变化冥冥).
The heavens and earth regulate themselves naturally (天地自理).
*Going without* (去为) is an analogy to illustrate the principle of teaching (譬以况理教).
The teaching’s words are said to be *possession* (有),
yet the principle transcends all names and speech—*emptiness* (无).
The teaching’s practice is to clarify through the principle (因理而明),
and the principle is elucidated through teaching (理之诠焉).
By teaching, the principle becomes manifest (由教而显),
and the principle relies on teaching to reveal itself (理因教显).
Without teaching, the principle has no means of expression (无教理无所寄),
and without the principle, teaching has no foundation (教籍理明).
Without the principle, what is teaching’s purpose (无理教何所说)?

Having understood the interdependence of principle and teaching (理教之相由),
one grasps how *possession* and *emptiness* serve as its essence (是体有无之为用).

○ **Cheng’s Commentary** (成疏) cites *The Rites of Zhou – The Record of Craftsmen* (《周礼·考工记》):
*"Thirty spokes resemble the thirty days,
to complete one month."* (三十辐象三十日，以成一月也)

When it is *emptiness* (当其无),
the hub’s interior is hollow (箱毂内空),
yet this very hollowness allows it to contain things—
thus the wheel’s utility (只为空能容物，故有车用).
Consider the scholar’s mind as emptiness (況学人心空),
so it can bear the weight of all sentient beings (故能运载苍生也).
Moreover, the wheel is but a *conventional name* (假名),
arising from the harmonious convergence of all conditions (诸缘和合而成).
Analyzing its nature thoroughly,
one finds its entirety is void and illusory (此车细析推寻，遍体虚幻).
How much more so for all dharmas (诸法),
which are likewise in their entirety.

*Molding clay to make vessels* (埏埴以为器),
when it is *emptiness* (当其无),
the vessel’s utility is realized (有器之用).
**Yu’s Annotation** (御注):
*埏* (Cultivating) means *harmonizing* (和).
*坛* (Tamped earth) refers to *clay* (土).
The potter harmonizes the clay,
forging it into jars and pots (陶匠和土，为瓦缶之器也).

**Yu’s Commentary** (御疏):
*埏埴* (Molding clay) refers to *adhesive clay* (粘土).
The annotation says *potter* (陶匠),
yet *The Book of Documents* (《尚书》) states:
*"To knead the earth is called pottery."* (范土曰陶)
Here, the potter kneads and molds the clay,
fires it into ceramic vessels,
and takes advantage of their emptiness
to hold and receive things (烧以成器，器中空虚，以用盛受物也).

○ **River Above Master** (河上公) says:
*Molding clay to make vessels* (埏埴以为器),
*埏* (Cultivating) means *harmonizing* (和),
*坛* (Tamped earth) refers to *clay* (土).
The potter harmonizes the clay
to create vessels for food and drink (和土以为食饮之器也).
When it is *emptiness* (当其无),
the vessel’s utility is realized—
its hollowness allows it to contain and receive (器中空虚，故得有所盛受也).

○ **Rong** (荣) says:
To *make vessels*, one must first harmonize the clay (作器必须和泥),
and only when the clay is refined does the vessel serve its purpose (泥调则器可用).
To *cultivate the self*, one must purify conduct (修身理宜炼行),
and only when conduct is pure does the Dao/Way manifest (行洁则道可成).
*埏* (Cultivating) means *harmonizing* (和),
*埴* (Clay) refers to *earth* (土).

○ **Cheng’s Commentary** (成疏) again cites *The Record of Craftsmen* (《考工记》):
*"埏* (Cultivating) means *harmonizing* (和).
*値* (Clay) refers to *adhesive clay* (粘土).
Harmonizing adhesive clay with water and earth,
firing it to form vessels—
though the vessel’s interior is empty,
it is capable of containing and receiving (和粘水土，烧以成器，器中空无，故得盛受).
This illustrates how the scholar’s mind, being emptiness,
can embrace all things (況学人心空，故能容物).

*Carving doors and windows to make a dwelling* (凿户牖以为室),
when it is *emptiness* (当其无),
the dwelling’s utility is realized (有室之用).
**Yu’s Annotation** (御注):
In ancient times, people dug caves to dwell in (古者陶穴以为室宇),
and even these were furnished with doors and windows (亦开户牖),
hence the term *carving* (故云凿耳).

**Yu’s Commentary** (御疏):
*凿* (Carving) means *piercing* or *hollowing* (穿).
*牖* (Windows) refers to openings beside doors (门旁窗).
In ancient times, people lived in caves (穴居),
so *The Book of Odes* (《诗》) says:
*"To dig and cover the cave"* (陶复陶穴),
meaning they hollowed out the earth within the cave
and covered it above—
hence the term *carving* (穿凿穴中之土以复覆其上，故云凿耳).
Later sages replaced this with official dwellings (官室),
yet the principle remains:
the dwelling’s emptiness allows people to reside (取其室中空虚，所以人得居处).
*Zhuangzi* says:
*"If a dwelling has no emptiness,
even wives and mothers-in-law will jostle for passage"* (室无空虚，则妇姑勃蹊),
meaning they will *contend for the path* (勃蹊谓争路也).
*The Er Ya* (《尔雅》) states:
*"Official halls are called dwellings"* (官谓之室).
Thus, *possession* (有) is for *advantage* (利),
while *emptiness* (无) is for *utility* (用).
The advantage of *possession* (有体利无)
is that it relies on *emptiness* (以无为利),
yet the advantage of *emptiness* (利铃资无)
is that it depends on *possession*—
hence *emptiness* is advantageous through *possession* (故有以无为利也).
The utility of *emptiness* (无之所用)
is rooted in its form (用於体),
yet its form requires *possession*—
hence *emptiness* derives utility from *possession* (体必资有，故无以有为用也).
The annotation says:
*"That which transcends form is called Dao/Way* (形而上者曰道),
*that which is beneath form is called vessel* (形而下者曰器),
as written in *The Systematic Words of the Yi* (《易·系辞》).
When it is purely *emptiness*, it is called Dao/Way (自无则称道),
and when it involves *possession*, it is called vessel (涉有则称器).
To clarify the Dao/Way’s utility,
one must use form and vessel as analogies (欲明道用，必约形器以彰).
Though these analogies employ the three illustrations,
the ultimate aim remains to emphasize *emptiness* in all governance (终用无於一政耳).

○ **River Above Master** (河上公) says:
*Carving doors and windows to make a dwelling* (凿户牖以为室)
refers to constructing houses (谓作室屋).
When it is *emptiness* (当其无),
the dwelling’s utility is realized—
doors and windows are hollow,
allowing people to enter and exit (户牖室虚，人得以出入).
Observing the dwelling’s emptiness,
people can reside within—
this is its utility (观视室中空虚，人得居处，是其用也).

○ **Rong** (荣) says:
If a dwelling is not hollow within,
and lacks doors and windows without,
its utility is not difficult to grasp (其为用不以难乎).
Yet the Dao/Way is inwardly obscure and dark (内既暗昧),
externally deaf and blind (外复聋瞽),
and seeking it thus is no easy matter (以此求道，理非易乎).
A dwelling with doors and windows is useful (室开户牖，有用也).
So too, when a person’s wisdom is enlightened,
the Dao/Way is accomplished (人生慧解，道成之).

○ **Cheng’s Commentary** (成疏):
To pierce and hollow doors and windows,
to construct houses—
though the interior is empty,
it allows people to reside (穿凿户牖，以为屋室，室中空无，故得居处).
Consider the scholar’s mind as emptiness,
so it can embrace all things (況学人心空，故能覆物).
Moreover, piercing and hollowing doors and windows
allows passage for people,
yet emptiness in the roots and orifices
permits use without attachment (況根窍虚通，故能用而无染).
The three analogies—wheel, vessel, and dwelling—
share similar meaning,
yet they are repeated for emphasis:
the wheel is for motion but not stillness (车则动而不静),
the dwelling is for stillness but not motion (室则静而不动),
the vessel is both motion and stillness (器则亦动亦静).
These three distinctions
are why they are restated (有此三异，故重出之).
The second purpose is to distinguish *possession* and *emptiness*,
and to clarify their interdependence (显明资导).
Thus, *possession* is for *advantage*,
and *emptiness* is for *utility* (故有之以为利，无之以为用).

**Yu’s Annotation** (御注):
*Possession* relies on *emptiness* for advantage (有体利无),
and *emptiness* is advantageous through *possession* (以无为利).
*Emptiness* derives utility from *possession* (无用体者),
and *possession* is the means of *emptiness’* utility (以有为用).
Moreover, that which transcends form is called Dao/Way (形而上者曰道),
and that which is beneath form is called vessel (形而下者曰器).
To elucidate the supreme Dao/Way’s utility,
one must use form and substance as analogies (将明至道之用，约形质以彰).
Thus, one borrows the coarse advantage of *possession* over *emptiness*
to clarify the subtle utility of *emptiness* in *possession* (故借粗有之利无，以明妙无之用有耳).

○ **River Above Master** (河上公) says:
Thus, *possession* is for *advantage* (故有之以为利),
for things benefit from their form (物利於形),
and vessels contain things while dwellings shelter people—
yet one fears the house may collapse (器中有物，室中有人，恐其屋破坏).
The stomach contains the spirit (腹中有神),
yet one fears the body’s decay (畏其形之消亡也).
*Emptiness* is for *utility* (无之以为用),
for only within the void can one contain and receive (虚空中者，乃可用盛受物),
hence it is said: *"The void governs the form of possession"* (故曰虚无制有形).
The Dao/Way is emptiness itself (道者空无也).

○ **Rong** (荣) says:
If there is only *possession* and no *emptiness*,
*possession* alone cannot be advantageous (有不得为利).
If there is only *emptiness* and no *possession*,
*emptiness* alone cannot serve its purpose (无不得为用).
This makes clear that *possession* depends on *emptiness* for advantage (明有因无以为利),
and *emptiness* depends on *possession* for utility (无因有以为用).
Having recognized how *possession* and *emptiness* interdependently arise (既识有无之相因),
one naturally understands the coarse and subtle as mutually reliant (自知粗妙之相籍也).」

chunks.original_text: ○成疏：无赖有为利，有籍无为用，二法相假，故成车等也。 言学人叉须以有资空，以空导有，有无资导，心不偏溺，故成．学人之利用。 五色令人目盲章第十二 五色章所以次前者，前章泛举车器，欲显假法不真，故次此章，正辨色声，以明实法，虚幻相对，所以次之。 就此一章，义开二别。 第一显尘能败根，应须厌离。 第二明根染尘境，劝令静息。 第三举圣戒凡，示其取舍。 第一显尘能败相，应须厌离。 夫至道恬忘，理相俱寂，一气生贷，遂成于人。 圆首戴天，方足履地，四肢象於四气，五脏法於五行，故得目耳彻明，心情洞晓。 须掩有为之色，来归真净之源。 岂趋驰放之心一以结聋盲之业，不能割却诬妄，行诸大方，驰彩凤於丹台，控玄虹於碧落，去彼取此，长为真人哉。 五色令人目盲，五音令人耳聋，五味今人口爽。 御注：目悦青黄之观，耳耽官征之令形骸盲聋也。 ○御疏：色谓青黄赤白黑，音谓官商角征羽味谓酸咸甘苦辛。 爽，差也。 目视色，耳听声，口察味，伤当过分，则不能无损。 故坐令形骸聋盲爽差尔。 又况耽滞代间诸法，不悟声色性空，岂惟形骸之有聋盲，此亦智之聋盲者也。 ○河上公曰：五色令人目盲，贪淫好色，则伤精失明也。 五音令人耳聋好听五音，则和气去心，不能听无声之声。 五味令人口爽，妄也，人嗜於五味则口爽，言失於道也。 ○严曰：淫於五色之视不见祸福之形，色者陷目之锥也。 佚於五音之变者，听不闻吉凶之声者，塞耳之椎也。 美於五味之变者，口不中是非之之情味者，斩舌之器也。 ○荣曰：目虽能见，耽色不已，丧其明。 耳虽能闻，淫声无倦失其听。 能尝，察味莫穷，乖其养。 爽也。 然盲以不见为义，聋以不闻为义，有目而不见真人大圣，盲也。 有耳不闻希声之广乐，微妙之灵音，聋也。 口以知味为用，若贪俗味，失於道味，故言爽也。 ○成疏：五色令人目盲，五色者，谓青黄赤白黑也。 人不能内照真源，而外逐尘境，虽见异空之色，乃曰非盲，不视即色是空与盲何别。 五音令人耳聋五音者，官商角征羽也。 心耽丝竹耳滞宫商，不能返听希声，故曰聋也。 《庄子》云：非唯形骸有聋盲，夫智亦有之。 五味令人口爽，五味者，甘苦辛酸咸。 差失也。 耽贪醪醴，咀嚼膻腥，不能味道谈玄，故曰口爽。 第二明根染尘境，劝令静息。 驰骋田猎，令人心发狂。 御注：驰骋代务，耽着有为如彼田猎，唯求杀获。 《庄子》云：日以心斗，逐境奔驰，静而思之，是发狂病也。 ○御疏：此言耽声滞色之人驰骋欲心，亦如田猎，但求杀获，欲心奔盛，逐境如驰，静而观之，是以发狂病也。 ○河上公曰：人精神好安静，驰聘呼吸，精神散亡，故发狂也。 ○严曰：乐於田猎之变者，思不免於狂惑。 田猎者，狂惑之师也。 ○荣曰：纵之於田渔，太康失业，猎之於名声，张毅发病。 身亡国失，狂之大也。 ○成疏：驰骋犹奔骤也，言田猎之夫，贪逐禽兽，快心放荡，有类狂人。 倒置之徒，欲心逐境，速如驰骋，狂如田猎。 《庄子》云：失性有五，一曰五色乱目，使目不明等是也。 难得之货，令人行妨。 御注：性分所无，求亦不得。 妄求难得，故令道行有所妨伤。 ○御疏：难得之货者，言人身以村器为货，难得之货者，即性分所无，求不可得。

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
*Possession* relies on *emptiness* for advantage,
*emptiness* depends on *possession* for utility—
these two principles mutually support each other,
thus forming the Dao/Way of vehicles and such.

It is said that the student must use *possession* to nourish *emptiness*,
and *emptiness* to guide *possession*—
when *possession* and *emptiness* mutually nourish and guide,
the mind does not become one-sided or immersed,
thus achieving the student’s utility.

**Chapter XII: The Five Colors Blind the Eyes**

The discussion of the five colors follows the preceding chapter,
for the earlier chapter broadly cited vehicles and instruments
to demonstrate that dependent principles are not inherent.
Thus, this chapter directly examines colors and sounds
to clarify the true *dharma* and the opposition of emptiness and illusion,
hence its placement here.

Within this chapter, three teachings unfold:
1. **The dust defiles the faculties—one must cultivate aversion.**
2. **The faculties are stained by dusty realms—one must be urged to stillness.**
3. **The distinction between sages and commoners—demonstrating their choices.**

**1. The dust defiles the faculties—one must cultivate aversion.**

The supreme Dao/Way is tranquil and forgetful,
its nature and essence both quiescent.
From a single breath of *qi*, humanity is formed.
The rounded head upholds Heaven,
the square feet tread Earth.
The four limbs mirror the four seasons,
the five viscera follow the five phases—
thus the eyes and ears attain clarity,
the mind and emotions become luminous.

One must veil the artificial hues of *possession*,
returning to the pristine source of truth.
How could the restless, roving heart
bind itself to the deeds of blindness and deafness,
unable to sever deceit and illusion,
pursuing the Great Dao/Way?
It rides the vermilion phoenix to the Red Terrace,
commands the dark rainbow in the Azure Abyss—
abandoning that to take this,
eternally becoming a True Person.

The five colors blind the eyes,
the five sounds deafen the ears,
the five flavors dull the palate.

**Master Cheng’s Annotation:**
The eyes delight in the sights of blue, yellow, red, white, and black;
the ears indulge in the melodies of *gong*, *shang*, *jiao*, *zhi*, and *yu*—
thus the form and body become blind and deaf.

**Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
Colors refer to blue, yellow, red, white, and black;
sounds refer to *gong*, *shang*, *jiao*, *zhi*, and *yu*;
flavors refer to sour, bitter, spicy, sweet, and salty.
*"Dull"* means "erroneous."
The eyes see colors, the ears hear sounds, the mouth tastes flavors—
if indulged to excess, harm inevitably follows.
Thus, one’s form and body become blind, deaf, and dulled.

Moreover, if one is infatuated with the transient laws of the world,
unaware that colors and sounds are empty in nature,
how could it be only the form and body that are blind and deaf?
This is also the blindness and deafness of wisdom.

**Master He Shang Gong says:**
The five colors blind the eyes—
greed and lust for colors drain the essence, causing blindness.
The five sounds deafen the ears—
indulgence in the five tones disperses the harmonious *qi* of the heart,
rendering one unable to hear the soundless sound.
The five flavors dull the palate—
deceitful craving for the five flavors makes the mouth dull,
speaking of deviation from the Dao/Way.

**Master Yan says:**
Those who indulge in the five colors’ sights
see neither the forms of blessings nor calamities—
colors are the spear that pierces the eyes.
Those who abandon themselves to the variations of the five sounds
cannot hear the voices of auspiciousness or misfortune—
they are the mallet that seals the ears.
Those who delight in the five flavors’ changes
cannot discern the true emotions of right and wrong—
they are the instrument that severs the tongue.

**Master Rong says:**
Though the eyes can see, if one is infatuated with colors without restraint,
they lose their clarity.
Though the ears can hear, if one indulges in sounds without fatigue,
they lose their acuity.
Though the mouth can taste, if one exhausts itself in flavors without end,
it perverts its nourishment—
thus, it becomes dulled.
Yet "blindness" is defined by not seeing,
"deafness" by not hearing.
To have eyes yet not see the True Person and Great Sage—this is blindness.
To have ears yet not hear the vast music of the subtle
or the subtle, wondrous spiritual sounds—this is deafness.
The mouth’s purpose is to discern flavors,
but if one craves mundane tastes and loses the flavor of the Dao/Way,
thus it is said to be dulled.

**Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
The five colors blind the eyes—
the five colors are blue, yellow, red, white, and black.
If one cannot internally illuminate the true source
but instead chases external dusty realms,
though they see the colors of empty space,
they say it is not blindness—
what difference is there between not seeing and blindness?

The five sounds deafen the ears—
the five sounds are *gong*, *shang*, *jiao*, *zhi*, and *yu*.
If the heart is entangled in strings and bamboo,
the ears are clogged by *gong* and *shang*,
unable to return and hear the subtle sounds—
thus, it is called deafness.
As *Zhuangzi* says:
Not only does the form and body have blindness and deafness—
wisdom also has them.

The five flavors dull the palate—
the five flavors are sweet, bitter, spicy, sour, and salty.
*"Dull"* means "erroneous."
If one indulges in wine and strong drinks,
chews on rancid and gamey meats,
unable to savor the Dao/Way or discuss the mysterious,
thus it is said the mouth is dulled.

**2. The faculties are stained by dusty realms—one must be urged to stillness.**

Galloping and hunting drive the mind to madness.

**Master Cheng’s Annotation:**
Galloping and hunting are worldly pursuits—
like hunting, one is obsessed with killing and capturing.
As *Zhuangzi* says:
Daily, the heart wages battle,
chasing realms and galloping—
if one reflects in stillness, it is the disease of madness.

**Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
This speaks of those entangled in sounds and colors,
their desires galloping like hunters—
only seeking to kill and capture,
their desires raging, chasing realms like a gallop.
If one observes them in stillness, it is the disease of madness.

**Master He Shang Gong says:**
Human spirit naturally seeks tranquility,
but galloping and panting disperse the spirit,
thus madness arises.

**Master Yan says:**
Those who delight in the variations of hunting
cannot escape confusion and delusion—
hunting is the teacher of madness.

**Master Rong says:**
To indulge in fishing and hunting is to lose the business of Great Peace,
to hunt for fame and reputation is to incur the illness of Zhang Yi.
The loss of life and state—this is the greatest madness.

**Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
"Galloping" means "racing."
Those who hunt are greedy for beasts,
their hearts delighted and unrestrained—
like madmen.
Those who invert principles, their desires chasing realms,
move swiftly like galloping,
mad as hunters.
As *Zhuangzi* says:
There are five ways to lose one’s nature—
the first is that the five colors confuse the eyes,
causing them to lose their clarity, and so on.

Hard-to-obtain treasures obstruct one’s path.

**Master Cheng’s Annotation:**
These are things beyond one’s natural endowment—
though sought, they cannot be obtained.
Foolishly pursuing what is unattainable
thus obstructs the path of the Dao/Way.

**Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
"Hard-to-obtain treasures" refers to those who
regard vulgar possessions as treasures.
What is hard to obtain is what lies beyond one’s natural endowment—
though sought, it cannot be attained.

chunks.original_text: 夫不安本分，矫性妄求，既其乖失天倪，所以妨伤道行。 ○河上公曰：妨，伤也。 难得之货，谓金银珠玉。 心贪意欲，不知厌足，则一行伤身辱。 ○严曰：贪於货财之变，虑不免於邪倾。 财货者，害本之物矣。 ○荣曰：美色重宝，难得也。 以此乱心伤行也。 ○成疏：难得之货，谓赵璧隋珠，珍贵佳丽之物也。 贪着爱玩，为生死之因，於修道行中，大为妨碍。 第三举圣戒凡，示其取舍。 是以圣人为腹不为目，故去彼取此。 御疏：腹者，含受而无分别。 目者，妄视滞於色尘。 无分别则全和，故为之。 滞色尘则伤性，故不为也。 故去彼取此，彼目妄视，故去之。 此腹含受，故取之。 ○河上公曰：是以圣人为腹，守五性，去六情，节志气，养神明。 不为目，目不妄视，妄视泄精於外矣。 故去彼取此，去彼目之妄视，取此腹之养性也。 ○严曰：夫圣人者，服无色之色，听无声之声，味无味之味，驰骋无境之域，经历无界之方，发无形之网，获道德之心矣。 ○荣曰：虚心而内实，为腹也。 反听而不盲，不为目也。 有累之业，遣去也。 无为之道，来取也。 ○成疏：是以圣人为腹不为目，是以，仍上之圣人即举圣戒凡也。 腹，内也，目，外也，怀道抱德，充满於内，故为腹也。 内视无色，返听无声，诸根空净，不染尘境，故不为目也。 故去彼取此，去彼为目之盲聋，取此为腹之实智。 道德真经玄德慕疏卷之三竟 #1遇：原作『过』，据文义改。 #2期：原作『斯』，据文义改。 道德真经玄德纂疏卷之四 唐玄宗御注并疏　河上公严君平李荣注　西华法师成玄英疏　蒙阳强思齐纂 宠辱若惊章第十三 宠辱章所以次前者，前章正辩根尘等法，举体不真，故以此章明身反荣华，适为患本。 就此一章，分为三别。 第一总言宠辱贵患不殊，第二假设疑问，辩其所以。 第三校量贵爱，显其得失。 第一总言宠辱贵患不殊。 夫代上尊荣，无过九五，人之死地，唯十有三，开宠辱之两途，明众生之不悟。 家门赫赫，大冠长剑之雄，禄爵巍巍，佩剑垂缨之盛，岂知夫玄勋一秩，赤族便来，故霍光以芒刺生忧，杨惮以豆其成祸。 老君大戒宠辱须惊，念我凡夫心情不鉴，入朝廷而不赏，出当宠而恒安，田宝所以相倾，为执当之要。 宠辱若惊， 御注：操之则栗，拾之则悲，未忘宠辱，故皆惊也。 ○御疏：若，如也。 言宠辱之惊相如也。 夫操之则宠，拾之则辱，言人不能心齐荣辱，矜徇功名，执权既以为光宠，失势自伤於卑辱。 光宠则矜恃，卑辱则惊嗟，故陈戒使若惊，欲令齐其宠辱。 ○河上公曰：身宠亦惊，身辱亦惊。 ○荣曰：官高而虑危，贱极而多耻，皆惧也。 ○成疏：宠为荣爱之名，辱是戮耻之称，若，如也，惊，恐也，言人得宠则逸豫喜欢，遭辱则怵惕忧患，故得宠心惊喜，遭辱心惊怖。 喜怖虽异，为惊即同，故言若也。 然喜怖之情皆非真性者也，是以达者譬穷通於寒暑，比荣辱於傥来，生死不挠其神，何#l贵贱之能惊也。 贵大患若身。 御注：身为息本，故矜贵其身，即如贵大息矣。 此合云贵身如贵大息，而乃云贵大息如身者，欲明起心责身，即是大息。 有贵即身是大息，故云贵大息如身。 若，如也。 此上两句正标也。
