「Just as one holds water to let it flow where it is poured,
or uses a concave mirror to draw fire—
the fire comes naturally.

Thus it is said: Those who align with the Dao, the Dao attains them.
**Master He Shang** said:
Those who align with the Dao, the Dao attains them—
those who harmonize with the Dao, the Dao joyfully attains them.
Those who align with virtue, virtue attains them—
those who harmonize with virtue, virtue joyfully attains them.
Those who align with error, error attains them—
those who harmonize with error, error joyfully attains them.

**Yan** said:
When affairs follow the Dao, the Dao follows affairs.
When affairs follow virtue, virtue follows affairs.
When affairs follow error, error follows affairs.
When faith is insufficient, there arises doubt.

**御 Commentary:**
Clinging to words and being obstructed by teachings,
one cannot awaken to true understanding—
this is the insufficiency of faith.
If one aligns with error, error joyfully comes—
this is the presence of doubt.

**御 Citation:**
It speaks of why people cannot embody and verify the truth,
forgetting words in the process—
when faith and understanding are insufficient, confusion and obstruction arise.
Once confusion and obstruction arise,
one clings to words and seeks understanding.
Clinging to words to seek understanding,
one only creates further bewilderment and stumbling—
this is the presence of doubt’s response.
Thus it is said: *There arises doubt.*

**Master He Shang** said:
When faith is insufficient, the ruler lacks faith in his subjects.
When there arises doubt, the subjects respond with doubt to the ruler.
This illustrates how things of the same kind gather,
and voices of the same kind resonate—
clouds follow the dragon, winds follow the tiger,
water flows to the damp, fire turns to the dry.

**Yan** said:
Insufficient faith refers to the self;
doubt arises refers to both humankind and the cosmos.

**Rong** said:
Those who align with the Dao, the Dao attains them—
when one has faith in the Dao, the Dao attains that person.
Those who align with error, the Dao abandons them—
when faith is insufficient, doubt arises.

**Cheng’s Citation:**
Unable to forget words,
yet clinging to words to seek truth—
though one claims to have faith in the Dao,
one’s understanding is still insufficient,
and thus one clings obstinately to teachings and doctrines,
failing to reach the true source.
This is the heart of doubt.

Therefore, in the realm of Supreme Mystery,
there are those who **stand on tiptoe**—
*Chapter Twenty-Four: The Chapter of Those Who Stand on Tiptoe,*
explaining why this chapter follows the last—
the last chapter criticized the restless and competitive,
those who clung to erroneous teachings,
so this chapter further clarifies its meaning.
Within this chapter alone,
there are three distinct teachings:
First, it illustrates the two confusions of **tiptoeing and striding**,
closely following the chapter on sudden rains;
Second, it reiterates the four bewilderments,
contrasting with the four virtues of *curved fullness* and *complete harmony*;
Third, it uses analogies to encourage one to abandon such tendencies.

**First: Illustrating the two confusions of tiptoeing and striding, closely following the chapter on sudden rains.**
Within the Three Realms,
only the sages who adhere to the **Mysterious Origin** are revered.
Within the Eightfold Heaven,
all honor the **authentic teachings of Huang-Lao**.
They humble themselves and yield gently,
neither tiptoeing nor striding,
borrowing the **mother-qi** to give birth to things,
and presenting the **father of learning** to teach the ignorant.
Their **effortless effort** is grand and pure,
their **clear brightness** is pristine and white—
like a well that never runs dry,
or the boundless sky above.
Gazing upward, it only grows higher—
how can it compare to the vast blue?
In **nirvana**, they remain unstained,
congealing the **pure emptiness** beyond thought,
yet in the world of dust, they can blend harmoniously,
dwelling in the **sand realm** while ever serene.

They lament the **pride in excess** like leftover food,
and sigh at the **flaunting of clarity** like superfluous adornments.
Steadfast and unmoving,
their **purple qi** radiates from the **West Pass**,
tranquil and effortless,
their **white light** is heard in the **Southern Calendar**.

To know their subtlety,
this is what is meant.

Those who **stand on tiptoe** cannot endure,
those who **stride arrogantly** cannot proceed.

**御 Commentary:**
**Standing on tiptoe** means lifting one’s heels to gaze afar.
**Striding** means clinging to things to surpass others.
What analogy better illustrates
those who vainly seek enlightenment—
their clarity never obtained—
than the one who stands on tiptoe, unable to endure long,
or strides, yet cannot move forward?
For **tiptoeing** makes one unstable,
and **striding** obstructs one’s path—
just as in the following lines,
*self-perception leads to blindness*,
*self-righteousness obscures truth*.

Thus it is clear:
**Tiptoeing** cannot endure,
**striding** cannot proceed,
**self-perception** cannot bring clarity,
**self-righteousness** cannot reveal truth.

**Master He Shang** said:
Those who **tiptoe** cannot endure—
**tiptoeing** means advancing.
It refers to those who covet power and fame,
pursuing功名 (*official status and glory*)—
such advancement cannot last in body or Dao.

Those who **stride arrogantly** cannot proceed—
they consider themselves noble,
yet **stride over others**,
and the crowd scorns them,
preventing their progress.

**Rong** said:
**Striding** means surpassing.
Slow and measured steps endure long,
but **tiptoeing and striding** over others—
such progress cannot last.
This illustrates that those who practice humility, modesty, and yielding
can endure and flourish,
while those who **tiptoe and stride in pride**
invite their own ruin.

**Cheng’s Citation:**
Those who **tiptoe** cannot endure long—
**tiptoeing** means coveting and emulating.
The restless and competitive,
their hearts not harboring the Dao,
cannot uphold authenticity or preserve simplicity,
yet they covet external desires.
But things have their inherent nature,
and such desires cannot be attained by **tiptoeing**.
Having abandoned their Dao,
how can they endure long?

Those who **stride arrogantly** cannot proceed—
**striding** means prideful arrogance.
Practitioners of the Dao must be humble and modest,
yet if they **stride over others in pride**,
taking this as their aspiration,
they cannot proceed on the Dao.
Thus *Zhuangzi* says:
*"The eagle and the falcon rest while the carp and the kite tire themselves out in striding,"*
and again:
*"Power and influence are short-lived,
so the boastful will weep."*

chunks.original_text: ○荣曰：自见不明，自是不彰，自伐无功，自矜不长，此非君子之行，岂是忘怀之士哉。 ○成疏：不能忘我，自见有身，此乃昏愚，非明智也。 自是者不彰， 御注：是己非人，直为怨府，故不彰也。 ○御疏：言人不能曲全而自以为是，且欲大夸诸己，而以出众为心，求彰名迹，以自光大，直为怨府，人所不堪，众毁日闻，故难彰着。 故云自是不彰。 ○河上公曰：自以为是而非於人，众人共弊之，使不得彰明也。 ○成疏：心恒自是，口每非他，物共蔽之，故其德不显。 自伐者无功， 御注：专固伐取，物所以不与，故无功。 ○御疏：夫谦者德之柄，让者礼之文，苟失斯道，无从而可，况自专固伐取以求功，不让则争，功斯滥矣。 故云自伐者无功。 ○河上公曰：所以辄自伐取其功美，自失有功於人。 ○严曰：万人未动，天下未应，为之起兵，失君之道。 为兵之道，失君之机，万民怨恨，天心不平，宗庙危殆，终身无功也。 ○成疏：凡有所为，辄自伐取，物皆不免，故无功绩。 自矜者不长。 御注：矜街行能，人所鄙薄，故不长也。 ○御疏：盛德若愚，昔贤通议。 矜卫名器丑行，则多人所鄙薄，坐招嗤诮，自矜虽欲求益，胥怨物不推长，故云自矜者不长。 ○河上公曰：好自矜大者，不可以长久也。 ○成疏：矜夸自高，骄慢陵物，此乃愚短，其德岂长乎。 第三举譬喻，劝令厌舍。 其於道也，日余食赘行，物或恶之，故有道者不处。 御注：自见等行，於道而论，是日残余之食，疣赘之行。 凡物尚或恶之，故有道之人，不处斯事矣。 ○御疏：其在道也，曰余食赘行，余食者，残余之食也。 赘行者，疣赘之行也。 残余，食之秽，疣赘，身之病。 以此自见自是等行，其於道而论之，如残余赘疣，人所共恶也。 谓为赘行者，为自见自是等为德行之疣赘，故云赘行。 《春秋》曰：人将不食吾余。 《庄子》云：附赘悬疣，出乎形哉而侈於性，物或恶之，故有道者不处，此自见自是等，既如余食赘行，凡物尚或恶之而不为，故有道之君子不处身於此事矣。 ○河上公曰：其於道也，日余食赘行，赘，责也。 使此自矜伐之人在治国之道，日日赋敛余禄为贪行。 物或恶之，此人在位，动欲伤害，故物无有不畏恶之者。 故有道者不处，言有道之人，不居其国者也。 ○荣曰：残余之食，不可以荐飨，夸趺之行，不可以进道。 昏乱者爱斯行之为是，乃安之，达理者恶此道之为非，故不爱也。 ○成疏：其在道，日余食赘行，余食，犹残食也。 赘，附生之害也。 《庄》云：附赘悬疣也。 言矜夸自是之人，其在道行，实犹残食赘病，甚可厌贱也。 物或恶之，故有道者不处。 赘是无用之肉，跨是无用之行，世间人物咸恶见之，故怀道之士岂处心於矜夸赘行乎。 道德真经玄德慕疏卷之六竟 道德真经玄德纂疏卷之七

「○ *Rong* says: Those who seek self-clarity are blind,
those who insist on their own right are not illuminated,
those who boast of their own merit achieve nothing,
those who vaunt their own virtue do not endure long.
This is not the conduct of a true gentleman—
how can it be the way of one who forgets himself?

○ *Cheng*’s commentary: Unable to forget oneself,
one sees only one’s own body,
which is the mark of stupidity, not wisdom.
Those who insist on their own right are not illuminated.

○ *Yu*’s annotation: To stubbornly uphold one’s own views while rejecting others,
and to boast of one’s superiority as if seeking fame,
is to invite universal censure.
Thus, one’s virtue remains obscured,
and one cannot shine.

○ *He Shang Gong* says: When one insists on one’s own appearance as good,
and on one’s own actions as conforming to the Dao,
one fails to recognize that one’s appearance is actually ugly,
and one’s conduct is base.

○ *Rong* says: Those who boast of their own merit achieve nothing,
for they lack the virtue of humility and the practice of yielding.
If one abandons this Way,
there is no path to success—
how much more so when one arrogantly claims merit and strives for glory,
only to invite contention and squander one’s achievements?
Thus it is said: those who boast of their own merit achieve nothing.

○ *He Shang Gong* says: Those who habitually claim their own right
and constantly speak ill of others
will find their virtue obscured by all.

○ *Cheng*’s commentary: Those who vaunt their own grandeur,
overbearing and arrogant toward all,
are short-sighted and foolish—
how can their virtue endure long?

○ *Yan* says: Before the masses have stirred,
before the realm has responded,
to raise arms in war is to lose the Way of the ruler.
The Way of wielding arms is to lose the ruler’s timing—
the people’s resentment grows,
the celestial order is disturbed,
the ancestral temples face peril,
and one’s life ends with no merit.

○ *Cheng*’s commentary: Whenever one acts,
one boasts of one’s own merit,
and all things recoil in aversion—
thus one achieves no lasting glory.

○ *Rong* says: Residual leftovers are unfit for ancestral offerings,
boastful conduct is unfit for advancing the Dao.
The confused love such conduct as correct,
while the enlightened despise it as false—
thus they do not cherish it.

○ *Cheng*’s commentary: In the Dao, one speaks of residual leftovers and parasitic growths—
residual leftovers are like spoiled food,
parasitic growths are like harmful excrescences.
*Zhuangzi* says: *"Hanging warts and parasitic growths—
they protrude from the body and exceed its nature,
and all things may detest them,
so those who follow the Dao do not dwell upon them."*
This refers to those who seek self-clarity and insist on their own right—
their conduct in the Dao is like spoiled food and parasitic growths,
which all things detest.
Parasitic growths are useless flesh,
boastful conduct is useless action—
all beings in the world abhor their sight.
Thus, those who cherish the Dao
would never fix their minds on such parasitic, boastful ways.

---
*End of Volume Six of the *Dao De Zheng Jing* (True Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue) – Commentary by Master *Cheng*
*Beginning of Volume Seven of the *Dao De Zheng Jing* (True Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue) – Compiled Commentary*」

Having abandoned their Dao,
how can they endure long?

Those who **stride arrogantly** cannot proceed—
**striding** means prideful arrogance.
Practitioners of the Dao must be humble and modest,
yet if they **stride over others in pride**,
taking this as their aspiration,
they cannot proceed on the Dao.
Thus *Zhuangzi* says:
*"The eagle and the falcon rest while the carp and the kite tire themselves out in striding,"*
and again:
*"Power and influence are short-lived,
so the boastful will weep."*

chunks.original_text: 唐玄宗御注并疏　河上公严君平李荣注　西华法师成玄英疏　蒙阳强思齐纂 有物混成章第二十五 有物章所以次前者，前章泛举矜夸，劝其厌好，故次此章。 显道之体状，令物起修，夫设教处方，必先病后药，药病相对，所以次之。 今就此章，义开为五，第一显道之体状，妙绝形声，第二明本无称谓，降迹立名，第三明引物向方，归根反本，第四举域中四大，令物依修，第五示自浅之深，渐阶圆极。 第一显道之体状，妙绝形声。 夫有物混成，先天地而作，始气含庶品，超造化而为功，理性湛然，寂寞独立，见其善贷，强与之名，物得以生，字之日道，瑶池暂会，或闻黄竹之歌，峒岭斯逢，即见白茅之味。 其为逝也远，其为精也真，十二帝称无名之君，五千言作有物之母，自然之道，天何言哉。 有物混成，先天地生。 御注：将欲明道立名之由，故云有物。 言有物混然而成，含孕一切，寻其生化，乃在天地之先也。 ○御疏：有物者，妙物也，即虚极妙本也。 将欲申明强名所由，不可即称道，故云有此妙物。 混然而成，含孕众象，寻其生化，乃在乎天地之先，故云先天地生尔。 ○河上公曰：谓道无形混沌，而成万物，乃在天地之前。 ○荣曰：有物者，道也。 名之日道，故言有物。 然道之为物，唯恍唯惚，不可以有无议，不可以阴阳辨，混沌无形，自然而成，故日混成。 自然之理，运之以变化，无形之内，阐之以气象，原其本者，先天地生也。 ○成疏：有物者，道也。 明道非有而有，非物而物，混沌不分，而能生成庶品，亦明不混而混，虽混而成，不成而成，虽成而混，即此混成之道，在天地先生，还是不先先不生生义也。 故《庄子》云：神鬼神帝，生天生地，又云：在天地之先而不为老。 寂兮寥兮，独立而不改，周行而不殆，可以为天下母。 御注：有物之体，寂寥虚静，妙本湛然常寂，故独立而不改。 应用遍於群有，故周行而不危殆。 而万物资以生成，被其茂养之德，故可以为天下母。 ○○御疏：寂兮寥兮，独立而不改，周行而不殆，寂寥者，叹有物之体寂寥虚静，妙本湛然，故独立而不移改，物感必应，应用无心，遍於群有，故周行而不危殆。 可以为天下母，妙本生化，遍於群有，群有之物，无非匠成，万物被其茂养之德，故可以为天下母尔。 母以茂养为义也。 ○河上公曰：寂兮寥兮，独立而不改，寂者无音声，寥者空无形。 独立者无匹双，不改者化有常。 ○荣日：混成之道，先天地生，听之不闻，则寂寥无响，搏之不得，则澹漠无形，丧偶而无对，故言独立。 湛然而常存，故言不改。 无处不在，周行也。 用之不动，不殆也。 覆载生畜，母之义也。 ○○成疏：寂寥独立不改，寂无声也，寥无形也。 独立，无待对也。 不改，无迁变也。 言道体窈冥，形声斯绝，既无因待，亦不改变。 此乃－独独非待独也。 道无不在，名日周行。 所在皆通故无危殆。 开化阴阳，安立天地，亭毒群品，子育含灵，生之畜之故可为母。 第二明本无称谓，降迹立名。 吾不知其名，字之日道，强为之名日大。 御注：吾见其物生成，隐无名氏，故以通生表其德，字之日道，以包含目其体，故强名日大。 ○御疏：字者表其德，名者定其体。

**Chapter Twenty-Five: *The Chapter of the Undifferentiated Essence***

*This chapter follows the previous one,*
*for the prior spoke broadly of boastful pride,*
*urging one to shun such tastes.*
*Thus, this chapter is placed next,*
*revealing the true nature of the Dao,*
*to inspire beings to cultivate.*

*Teaching and prescribing methods*
*must first diagnose the ailment,*
*then offer the remedy.*
*The remedy confronts the disease—*
*this is why the chapter follows.*

*Now, this chapter unfolds in five themes:*
*First, revealing the Dao’s true nature,*
*transcending all form and sound;*
*Second, clarifying its original namelessness,*
*then establishing names through its manifestations;*
*Third, guiding beings toward its path,*
*returning them to their root and origin;*
*Fourth, citing the Four Great Elements within the realm,*
*to show beings how to align their cultivation;*
*Fifth, illustrating the shallow’s path to depth,*
*gradually ascending to the ultimate perfection.*

---

**First: Revealing the Dao’s True Nature, Transcending All Form and Sound.**

*There is an Essence that coalesces without distinction,*
*existing before Heaven and Earth arise,*
*the primordial *qi* that enfolds all things,*
*exceeding the workings of *造化* (Creation and Transformation) in its function.*
*Its essence is profound and still,*
*quiet and solitary, standing alone.*
*Though its goodness is vast,*
*we force upon it a name—*
*thus things are born,*
*and we call it *Dao/Way*.*
*At the Jade Pool’s fleeting gathering,*
*some hear the *Huangzhu* (Yellow Bamboo) hymn,*
*while in the *dongling* (caverns and peaks) others encounter*
*the scent of white *mao* (grass).*

*Its passing is distant,*
*its essence is true.*
*The Twelve Sovereigns honor the Nameless Lord,*
*and the Five Thousand Words proclaim it as the Mother of All Things.*
*The Dao of Nature—*
*what need has Heaven of speech?*

*There is an Essence that coalesces without distinction,*
*existing before Heaven and Earth arise.*
*[Emperor’s Annotation]:*
*To explain why the Dao is named,*
*it speaks of "an Essence."*
*The Essence coalesces without distinction,*
*encompassing all things.*
*Tracing its transformation,*
*one finds it precedes Heaven and Earth.*
*[Emperor’s Commentary]:*
*"An Essence" refers to the wondrous Essence,*
*the very *虚极* (Ultimate Void) and *妙本* (Profound Origin).*
*To further clarify why names are imposed,*
*yet the Dao cannot be directly called,*
*it says, "There is this wondrous Essence."*
*Coalescing without distinction,*
*it enfolds all phenomena.*
*Tracing its transformation,*
*one finds it precedes Heaven and Earth—*
*thus, it is said to exist before Heaven and Earth arise.*

*[Master He Shang Gong] said:*
*The Dao is formless, like the undifferentiated *混沌* (Chaos),*
*yet it gives birth to all things,*
*existing before Heaven and Earth.*

*[Master Li Rong] said:*
*"An Essence" is the Dao.*
*Though named *Dao/Way*,*
*the Dao as Essence*
*is but a fleeting glimpse,*
*a hazy vision—*
*it cannot be discussed in terms of presence or absence,*
*nor distinguished by yin and yang.*
*Coalescing without distinction,*
*it forms all things naturally.*
*Thus, it is called *混成* (Undifferentiated Coalescence).*
*The Dao’s natural principle*
*operates through transformation and change,*
*its formless depths*
*unfold through the *qi* of phenomena.*
*Its origin precedes Heaven and Earth—*
*thus, it is said to exist before their birth.*

*[Master Cheng’s Commentary]:*
*"An Essence" is the Dao.*
*It clarifies that the Dao, though called "having,"*
*is not truly a thing,*
*and though called "an Essence,"*
*it is not truly material.*
*Undifferentiated yet capable of giving birth to all things,*
*it is also said to be not mixed yet mixed,*
*though mixed, it coalesces,*
*though coalesced, it remains undifferentiated.*
*Though undifferentiated, it coalesces,*
*though coalesced, it remains undifferentiated—*
*this is the Dao of Undifferentiated Coalescence,*
*existing before Heaven and Earth,*
*yet neither prior nor posterior,*
*neither giving birth nor being born.*
*Thus, the *Zhuangzi* says:*
*"The Spirit Sovereign, the Ghost Sovereign,*
*give birth to Heaven and Earth,"*
*and also:*
*"It exists before Heaven and Earth,*
*yet is not called the Old One."*

*Silent and vast, it stands alone unchanging,*
*circulates endlessly without exhaustion,*
*and may be called the Mother of all things.*

*[Emperor’s Annotation]:*
*The nature of "An Essence" is silent and vast,*
*its profound origin ever still and tranquil.*
*Thus, it stands alone unchanging.*
*Its influence permeates all beings,*
*so it circulates endlessly without peril.*
*All things draw from it to be born and formed,*
*receiving its nurturing and flourishing virtue—*
*thus, it may be called the Mother of all things.*

*[Emperor’s Commentary]:*
*"Silent and vast, it stands alone unchanging,"*
*—this sighs at the nature of "An Essence,"*
*silent and vast, its profound origin ever still and tranquil,*
*thus standing alone without alteration.*
*All things respond to it inevitably,*
*yet its response is without intent,*
*permeating all beings—*
*thus, it circulates endlessly without peril.*

*"It may be called the Mother of all things,"*
*—its profound origin gives birth and transforms,*
*permeating all beings.*
*All things under Heaven*
*are none but its crafted forms,*
*and all creatures receive its flourishing nurturing virtue—*
*thus, it may rightly be called the Mother of all things.*
*The Mother’s meaning lies in its nurturing virtue.*

*[Master He Shang Gong] said:*
*"Silent and vast, it stands alone unchanging—*
*Silent means without sound,*
*Vast means formless emptiness.*
*Standing alone means without pair or equal,*
*Unchanging means transformation has constancy."*

*[Master Li Rong] said:*
*The Dao of Undifferentiated Coalescence,*
*existing before Heaven and Earth,*
*when listened to, is inaudible—*
*thus, it is silent and vast without echo.*
*When grasped, it cannot be held—*
*thus, it is formless and boundless.*
*It lacks a counterpart,*
*so it is said to stand alone.*
*Ever profound and unceasing,*
*thus, it is said to be unchanging.*
*It is nowhere absent,*
*thus, it circulates endlessly.*
*Its application is without effort,*
*thus, it is without peril.*
*It nurtures and shelters all living things—*
*this is the meaning of "Mother."*

*[Master Cheng’s Commentary]:*
*"Silent and vast, standing alone unchanging—*
*Silent means without sound,*
*Vast means formless.*
*Standing alone means without reliance on another.*
*Unchanging means without alteration or drift.*
*The Dao’s nature is deep and mysterious,*
*its form and sound utterly transcended.*
*Since it lacks dependence,*
*it neither alters nor is altered.*
*This is the meaning of*
*—**独独非待独* (Truly solitary, without reliance, truly alone).*
*The Dao is nowhere absent,*
*thus its circulation is endless.*
*Wherever it is, all is penetrated—*
*thus, it is without peril.*
*It opens yin and yang,*
*stabilizes Heaven and Earth,*
*nurtures all phenomena,*
*and nurtures sentient beings,*
*giving birth and sheltering them—*
*thus, it may be called the Mother.*

---

**Second: Clarifying the Original Namelessness, Then Establishing Names Through Its Manifestations.**

*I do not know its name;*
*it is called *Dao/Way*.*
*We force upon it the name *Great*.*

*[Emperor’s Annotation]:*
*I see its Essence giving birth to all things,*
*hidden without a name,*
*so I use "universal birth" to mark its virtue,*
*and call it *Dao/Way*.*
*To encompass its entirety,*
*I force upon it the name *Great*.*

*[Emperor’s Commentary]:*
*By "calling it," we mark its virtue,*
*by "naming it," we define its essence.*

chunks.original_text: 老君云妙本生化，冲用莫穷，寂寥虚静，不可定其形状。 先天地生，难以言其族氏。 故吾不知其名，但见其大通，欲表其通生之德，故字之日道。 见其包含无外，将欲定其至无之体，故强名日大。 凡物先名而后字者，以其自小而成大，而道先字而后名者，以其从本而降迹尔。 ○河上公曰：吾不知其名，字之曰道，我不见道之形容，不知当何以名之，见万物皆从道所生，故字之日道也。 强为之名曰大，不知而名日强。 大者，高而无上，罗而无外，无不包容，日大。 ○荣曰：夫有形者称，无像者绝，名约通生而为用，字之日道，无一法而不包，名之日大。 理本无名，无名而名，谓之强也。 ○成疏：吾不知其名，字之日道，道本无名，不可智知，道名即初章云无名天地始也。 取其有通生之德，故字之日道。 即初章云有名万物母也。 强为之名日大，体无涯际，故名为大，故称为强名。 以名体字，道即是用，大即是体，故名大而字道也。 人皆先名后字，今乃先字后名者，欲表道与俗反也。 故不同而同，有右有字，同而不同，先字后名也。 第三明引物向方，归根反本。 大日逝，逝日远，远日返。 御注：妙用无方，强名不得，故自大而求之，则逝而往矣。 自往而求之，则远不及矣。 若能了悟，则返在於身心而证之。 ○御疏：夫滞於一方者，非天下之至通也。 故天职生覆而不能形载，地职形载而不能生覆，唯妙本之用，用无定方，虽则强名日大，而复不继於大。 自大而求之，则逝而往矣。 自往而求之，则远不及矣。

The Venerable Lord Lao says:
*"The wondrous origin gives birth and transforms,*
*its boundless application knows no end,*
*silent, empty, and tranquil—*
*its form cannot be fixed.*

*It precedes Heaven and Earth in birth,*
*its lineage is beyond speech.*

*Thus, I do not know its name,*
*but seeing its boundless penetration,*
*I mark its virtue of universal birth*
*and call it **Dao/Way**.*

*Seeing it encompass all without limit,*
*I seek to define its ultimate, boundless essence,*
*and thus force upon it the name **Great**.*

*All things first receive a name, then a character,*
*for they grow from small to great.*
*But **Dao/Way** first receives a character, then a name,*
*for it descends from its origin to its traces.*

---
*The Master of the Yellow River says:*
*"I do not know its name,*
*so I call it **Dao/Way**.*
*I do not see the form of **Dao/Way**,*
*and do not know how to name it.*
*Seeing all things arise from **Dao/Way**,*
*I call it **Dao/Way**.*

*I force upon it the name **Great**—*
*unknown yet named, thus called *strong naming*.*

*Greatness is high and without surpass,*
*expansive and without boundary,*
*encompassing all without exclusion—*
*thus, it is called **Great**."*

---
*Honor says:*
*"That which has form is named,*
*that which has no likeness is transcended.*
*The name **Dao/Way** is marked by its virtue of universal birth and function,*
*encompassing all without exception—*
*thus, it is named **Great**.*

*Its principle is originally nameless,*
*yet named—*
*this is called *strong naming*."*

---
*The Commentary of Cheng says:*
*"I do not know its name,*
*so I call it **Dao/Way**.*
***Dao/Way** is originally nameless,*
*incapable of being grasped by intellect.*
*The name **Dao/Way** is as in the first chapter: *‘The nameless is the origin of Heaven and Earth.’*

*Taking its virtue of universal birth,*
*I call it **Dao/Way**—*
*as in the first chapter: *‘The named is the Mother of all things.’*

*I force upon it the name **Great**,*
*for its body knows no bounds—*
*thus, it is called *strong naming*.*

*By naming the body and marking with the character,*
***Dao/Way** is its function,*
***Great** is its essence—*
*thus, it is named **Great** and marked **Dao/Way**.*

*All others name first, then mark,*
*but here, marking comes before naming—*
*to invert **Dao/Way** from the common.*

*Thus, different yet the same,*
*having both right and mark,*
*same yet different,*
*marking before naming."*

---
**Third: Guiding Things to Their Directions, Returning to the Root and Origin.**

*The **Great** departs,*
*The departing is distant,*
*The distant returns.*

*The Emperor’s Annotation:*
*"Its wondrous function knows no fixed direction,*
*and forced naming cannot contain it.*
*Seeking it from **Great**, it departs and goes.*
*Seeking it from its going, it is distant and unattained.*
*If one can awaken to this, then its return lies within the body and mind to be verified."*

---
*The Emperor’s Commentary:*
*"To be fixed in one direction*
*is not the ultimate penetration of the world.*

*Thus, Heaven’s role is to cover and nurture,*
*yet it cannot bear form,*
*Earth’s role is to bear form,*
*yet it cannot cover and nurture.*
*Only the wondrous origin’s function*
*has no fixed direction—*
*though named **Great**, it cannot be sustained by **Greatness**.*

*Seeking it from **Great**, it departs and goes.*
*Seeking it from its going, it is distant and unattained."*

chunks.original_text: 自远而求之，则复返在人身心矣，故日远日返。 《庄子》曰：夫道於大不终，於细不遗。 ○河上公曰：大曰逝，其为大，非若天常在上，非若地常在下，乃复逝去无常处所也。 逝日远，言远者穷於无穷，布炁天地，无所不通也。 远日返，言其远不超然绝远，乃复返在人身也。 ○荣曰：逝，往也。 即大求之而不得往也，就往追之不及远也，体之近在於身，故谓之返也。 ○成疏：大日逝，逝，往也。 有大力，用能运致众生，往至圣境也。 逝曰远，超陵三界，远适三清也。 远曰返，返，还也。 既自利道圆，远之圣境，故能返还界内，慈救苍生。 又解：迷时以三清为三界，悟则三界是三清，故返在尘俗之中，即是大罗之上。 第四举域中四大，令物依修。 故道大，天大，地大，王亦大。 御注：因其所大而明之，得一者天地王。 天大能覆，地大能载，王大能法地则天行道，故云亦大也。 ○御疏：因强名道日大，而举所次大者，放天能颠玄在上，垂覆万物，地能凝静於下，厚载万物，王能清静无为而化万物，此三大也，吾道一以贯之。 ○河上公曰：道大者，无所不容，包罗诸天地也。 天大者，无不盖。 地大者，无不载。 王大者，无不制也。 ○荣曰：道尊德贵，弥罗无外，天能广覆，无隔於贵贱，地能厚载，不择於妍蚩，帝王控制，通贯於远近，字育普均於贫富，用各有主，历言大也。 ○成疏：道大无不包也，天大无不覆也，地大无不载也，王大无不制也。 域中有四大，而王居其一焉。 御注：王者，人灵之主，万物系其兴亡，将欲伸其鉴诫，故云而王居其一，欲警王令有所法，谓下之文也。 ○御疏：域者，限域也。 今云域中之大，则道不只在域中，若云约所见而言，则天地自为限域，亦不秖在域中矣。 夫遗语以伸玄理，不必曲生异义，存文以防疑难，众说皆未尽通。 今明域者，名也，名为体域，物无名外之体，故日域中。 若举道名则道在其中矣，举天名则天无遗体矣，故云域中。 即有名之中，有此四大云，而居一者，王为人灵之首，有道即万物被其德，无道则天地蒙其害，故特标而王居一，欲令法道自然。 ○河上公曰：八极之内有四大，王居其一焉。 严曰：功德同也。 ○荣曰：寰宇之表自可绝言，形象之中理当称谓，罗之虽具，万品究之，唯有四大。 大名既一，用义难殊，欲劝帝王抱式於道德，取则於天地也。 ○成疏：境域之中有此四大，王有化被之德，故继二仪而居一数也。 《庄》云：夫道未始有封而此言域中者，欲明不域而域，虽域不域，不域而域，义说域中，虽域不域，包罗无外也。 第五示自浅之深，渐阶圆极。 人法地，地法天，天法道，道法自然。 御注：人谓王也，为主者先当法地安静。 既尔又当法天，运用生成。 既生成已，又当法道，清静无为，令物自化。 人君能尔者，即合道法自然。 ○御疏：人谓王也，所以云人者，谓人能法天地生成，法道清静，则天下归往，是以为王。 王若不然则物无所归往，故称人以戒尔。 为王者当法地安静，因其安静，又当法天生化，功被物矣。 又当法道清静无为，忘功於物，令物自化。 人君能尔，则合道法自然，言道之为法自然，非复仿法自然也。 若如惑者，难以道法效於自然，是则域中有五大，非四大也。

「Seeking it from the distant,
then it returns within the human body and mind—
thus it is called *far* and *return*.

*The Zhuangzi* states:
*"The Dao/Way does not terminate at the **Great**,
nor does it neglect the **small**."*

*River Upper Master* says:
*"When called **Great**, it passes.
Its greatness is not like Heaven’s constant presence above,
nor like Earth’s constant presence below—
rather, it passes away to places without constancy.
When it passes, it is distant—
the distant extends to the boundless,
its *qi* permeating Heaven and Earth,
reaching everywhere without obstruction.
When distant, it returns—
this means its distance does not sever itself utterly,
but rather returns within the human body and mind."*

*Rong* says:
*"Passing" means "going."
If one seeks it from the **Great** but cannot attain its going,
or follows its going but cannot catch up to its distance,
then its essence is near within the body—
thus it is called *return*."*

*Master Cheng’s commentary* states:
*"When called **Great**, it passes—
passing means going.
With great power, its function can guide all beings,
leading them to the realm of the Sage.
When it passes, it is distant—
ascending beyond the Three Realms,
distant in its attainment of the Three Pure Ones.
When distant, it returns—
returning means returning.
Having perfected the Dao/Way of self-benefit,
it returns to the realm of the Sage,
mercifully rescuing all sentient beings.
Alternatively interpreted:
When lost in delusion, the Three Pure Ones are seen as the Three Realms,
but upon awakening, the Three Realms are the Three Pure Ones—
thus its return lies within the mundane dust,
which is the Great Void above.

The fourth illustration presents the Four Great Elements within the domain,
ordering things to conform to their nature.
Thus, the Dao/Way is **Great**, Heaven is **Great**, Earth is **Great**,
and the Sovereign too is **Great**.

*The Emperor’s Commentary* states:
*"By clarifying what each **Great** refers to,
one attains the unity of Heaven, Earth, and the Sovereign.
Heaven’s **Greatness** lies in its covering,
Earth’s **Greatness** lies in its bearing,
The Sovereign’s **Greatness** lies in its ability to emulate Earth and Heaven,
thus following the Dao/Way—
hence it is also called **Great**."*

*The Emperor’s Expanded Commentary* states:
*"Though the Dao/Way is named **Great** by force,
it illustrates the next **Great** things in order:
Heaven can invert the mysterious and abide above,
hanging its cover over all things;
Earth can solidify and remain below,
thickly bearing all things;
The Sovereign can maintain clarity and stillness, doing nothing,
yet transforming all things—
these are the Three **Great** ones.
My Dao/Way unifies them all."*

*River Upper Master* says:
*"The **Greatness** of the Dao/Way is that it contains all things,
encompassing all the Heavens and the Earth.
Heaven’s **Greatness** is that it covers all without exception.
Earth’s **Greatness** is that it bears all without exception.
The Sovereign’s **Greatness** is that it governs all without exception."*

*Rong* says:
*"The Dao/Way is noble and virtue/power is precious,
its net extends without limit.
Heaven can broadly cover,
without distinction between high and low;
Earth can thickly bear,
without preference for beauty or ugliness;
The Sovereign can control,
penetrating far and near,
nurturing all equally among the poor and rich—
each has its own function,
thus it is called **Great**."*

*Master Cheng’s commentary* states:
*"The Dao/Way’s **Greatness** is that it encompasses all;
Heaven’s **Greatness** is that it covers all;
Earth’s **Greatness** is that it bears all;
The Sovereign’s **Greatness** is that it governs all.
Within the domain are the Four **Great** ones,
while the Sovereign occupies one among them.

*The Emperor’s Commentary* states:
*"The Sovereign is the master of human spirit,
all things depend on his rise and fall.
To extend his warnings and admonitions,
it is said that the Sovereign resides among the Four **Great** ones—
this is to urge the Sovereign to follow the Dao/Way naturally."*

*The Emperor’s Expanded Commentary* states:
*"Domain" refers to limitation.
Now when it speaks of the **Great** within the domain,
the Dao/Way is not confined solely within the domain.
If one speaks of it in terms of what is visible,
then Heaven and Earth themselves form a domain,
yet they are not solely within the domain either.

The ancient words are used to expound profound principles,
not necessarily to force strange interpretations.
The text is preserved to prevent doubts and difficulties,
yet all interpretations fail to fully grasp it.

Now, when clarifying "domain," it is a name—
a name for a limited realm.
Things have no form beyond their names,
thus it is called *domain*.
If one speaks of the Dao/Way’s name,
then the Dao/Way is within it;
if one speaks of Heaven’s name,
then Heaven’s form is not neglected—
thus it is called *domain*.
Within the realm of names,
these Four **Great** ones are spoken of,
and the Sovereign, as the chief of human spirit,
resides among them.
With the Dao/Way, all beings receive its virtue/power;
without the Dao/Way, Heaven and Earth suffer its harm—
thus it is especially noted that the Sovereign resides among them,
to urge the Sovereign to follow the Dao/Way naturally."*

*River Upper Master* says:
*"Within the Eight Extremes there are the Four Great Elements,
and the Sovereign occupies one among them.
Yan* says: "Their functions and virtues/powers are the same."*

*Rong* says:
*"Beyond the world’s circumference,
words may cease,
but within its forms,
names should be applied.
Though the net is complete,
when examining all phenomena,
only the Four Great Elements exist.
The name **Great** being unified,
its functions are difficult to distinguish—
it exhorts the Emperor to embrace the model of Daoist virtue/power,
and take Heaven and Earth as his standard."*

*Master Cheng’s commentary* states:
*"Within the realm of phenomena,
these Four **Great** ones exist.
The Sovereign possesses the virtue/power of transformation and influence,
thus it follows the Two Principles and occupies one among them.
The Zhuangzi says:
*The Dao/Way has never been confined by boundaries*—
yet this text speaks of *domain*—
it means that though confined by domain,
the Dao/Way is not confined by domain,
and though not confined by domain,
it is confined by domain—
this is the meaning of *domain*.
Though confined by domain,
it encompasses all without limit.

The fifth illustration shows how the shallow becomes deep,
gradually ascending to the Perfect Dao/Way.

Humans follow Earth,
Earth follows Heaven,
Heaven follows the Dao/Way,
The Dao/Way follows Nature.

*The Emperor’s Commentary* states:
*"Humans" refers to the Sovereign,
who as ruler must first follow Earth’s stillness.
Having done so, he must then follow Heaven’s movement and transformation.
Having transformed and created,
he must then follow the Dao/Way’s clarity and stillness,
doing nothing to let things transform of themselves.
If the human ruler can do this,
then he unites with the Dao/Way’s following of Nature.*

*The Emperor’s Expanded Commentary* states:
*"Humans" refers to the Sovereign,
and it is said "humans" because humans can follow Heaven and Earth’s creation,
follow the Dao/Way’s clarity and stillness,
and thus all under Heaven will turn toward him—
this is why he is called the Sovereign.
If the Sovereign does not act thus,
then things have nowhere to turn—
thus "humans" is mentioned to warn him.

As a Sovereign, he must first follow Earth’s stillness,
and from that stillness,
he must then follow Heaven’s transformation and influence,
and his virtue/power will extend to all things.
Again, he must follow the Dao/Way’s clarity and stillness,
doing nothing,
forgetting his own influence over things,
and letting them transform of themselves.
If the human ruler can do this,
then he unites with the Dao/Way’s following of Nature.
It is said that the Dao/Way’s following of Nature is not merely imitating Nature’s following of itself.

If one is confused and cannot follow the Dao/Way’s example in Nature,
then there are Five **Great** ones within the domain,
not Four.*"*

---
*Annotations:*
*Yan: Likely refers to a figure named Yan, possibly Yan Hui (顏回), a famous disciple of Confucius, or another commentator in the Daoist tradition.
*This text is from the *Taoist Canon* (道藏), specifically the *Zhouyi Cantong Qi* (周易参同契), a Daoist alchemical text.

chunks.original_text: 又引《西升经》：虚无生自然，自然生道，道则以为虚无之孙，自然之子。 妄生先后之义，以定尊卑之自，塞源拔本，倒置何深？ 且尝试论曰：虚无者，妙本之体，体非有物，故日虚无。 自然者，妙本之性，性非造作，故日自然。 道者，妙本之功用，所谓强右，无非通生，故谓之道。 约体用名，即谓之虚无，自然之道尔。 寻其所以，即一妙本，复何所相仿法乎？ 则知惑者之难，不诣夫玄键矣。 ○河上公曰：人法地，人当法地安静和柔。 种得五谷，掘得甘泉，劳而不怨，有功而不置之也。 地法天，天澹泊不动，施而不求报，生长万物，无所收取也。 天法道，道法清静，不言阴阳，运行精气，万物自成也。 道法自然，道性自然，无所法也。 ○荣曰：夫为人主者，静与阴同德，其载无私，法地也。 动与阳同波，其覆公正，法天也。 清虚无为，运行不滞，动皆合理，法道也。 圣人无欲，非存於有事，虚己理绝於经营，任物义归於独化，法自然也。 此是法於天地，非天地以相法也。 ○成疏：人，主也，王必须法地安静，而静为行先，定能生惠。 故下章云躁则失君，既静如地，次须法天清虚，覆育无私也。 天有三光，喻人有惠照，地是定门，天是惠门也。 既能如天，次须法道虚通，包容万物也。 既能如道，次须法自然之妙理，所谓重玄之域也。 道是进，自然是本，以本收之迹，故义言法也。 又解：道性自然，更无所法，体绝修学，故言法自然也。 重为轻根章第二十六 重为章所以次前者，前章明人法於地，表学道以静为先，故次此章； 即校量静躁。 就此章内，文有三重，第一正辨轻躁之劣，重静之胜，第二明重静之人动不乖寂，第三明轻躁之者，亡国丧身。 第一正辨轻躁之劣，重静之胜。 夫天地之大德日生，圣人之大宝日位，静以制动，三十辐之循环，重为轻根，九五君之端委。 登太山者宏大，归众阜之高，佩玉宸者为君，握庶人之纪。 是知六爻将设，上一制之於群象，八有初分，下五镇之於众位。 则知玄鉴妙远，唯静与清，黄屋尊凝，唯高唯大，圣开厥理，详而可知。 重为轻根，静为躁君。 御注：重者制轻，故重为轻根。 静者持躁，故静为躁君。 ○御疏：根，本也。 草木根蒂重，花叶轻，花叶禀根蒂而生，则根蒂为花叶之本，故曰：重为轻根。 夫重则静，轻则躁，既重为轻者根，则静为躁者君矣。 是知重有制轻之功，静有持躁之力，故权重则是属鼻之绩斯举，心静则朵颐之求自息。 ○河上公曰：重为轻根，人君不重则不尊，治身不重则失神，草木之花叶轻故零落，根重故能长存也。 静为躁君，人君不静则失威，治身不静则身危，龙静故能变，虎躁故夭亏。 ○荣曰：大小俱轻，不能为於根本，上下皆躁，岂可为於君主，是以一轻一重，轻者以重为根，一躁一静，躁者以静为主。 故无为重静者君之德也，有为轻躁者臣之事也。 上下各司其业，为君又须重静。 ○成疏：重为轻根，譬重为树根，轻为花叶，轻者凋落，重者长存。 此戒学人勿得轻躁，故《书》云：君子不重则不威。 静为躁君，静则无为，躁则有欲，有欲生死，无为长存，静能制动，故为君也。 第二明重静之人，动不乖寂。 是以君子终日行，不离辎重。

「Again, it cites the *Xisheng Jing* (《西升经》): The **Voidlessness** (虚无) gives rise to **Nature** (自然), **Nature** (自然) generates the **Dao/Way** (道), and the **Dao/Way** (道) is thus called the **Voidlessness’s** (虚无) grandchild and **Nature’s** (自然) son.
To falsely establish precedence and hierarchy,
to block the source and uproot the root,
to invert the order—how profound the error!
Let me attempt to explain:
**Voidlessness** (虚无) is the **Mystic Root’s** (妙本) essence,
an essence that is not a tangible thing—hence **Voidlessness** (虚无).
**Nature** (自然) is the **Mystic Root’s** (妙本) inherent disposition,
a disposition without contrivance—hence **Nature** (自然).
The **Dao/Way** (道) is the **Mystic Root’s** (妙本) function and manifestation,
so-called **"Strengthening the Right"** (强右),
yet nothing but universal generation—hence it is called the **Dao/Way** (道).
In brief, by naming essence and manifestation,
it is called the **Dao/Way** (道) of **Voidlessness** (虚无) and **Nature** (自然).
Seeking its origin,
it is but the **One Mystic Root** (一妙本),
so what else could one imitate or follow?
Thus, the difficulty of those who are confused
lies in their failure to grasp the **Profound Key** (玄键).

○ **Master He Shang Gong** (河上公) says:
Humans should follow the Earth (地),
and humans ought to follow the Earth’s stillness and yielding softness (安静和柔).
They reap the Five Grains (五谷) and dig sweet springs (甘泉),
laboring without complaint,
acting with purpose yet not claiming the merit.

The Earth follows the Heaven (天),
as Heaven is vast and tranquil, unmoving (澹泊不动),
bestowing without seeking recompense,
nurturing all things,
yet taking nothing in return.

Heaven follows the **Dao/Way** (道),
as the **Dao/Way** (道) follows clarity and stillness (清静),
not speaking of yin and yang (阴阳),
yet circulating the **Refined Qi** (精气) to let all things form of themselves.

The **Dao/Way** (道) follows **Nature** (自然),
as the **Dao/Way’s** (道) inherent disposition is **Nature** (自然),
and it follows nothing else.

○ **Rong** (荣) says:
For the ruler of men (人主),
stillness (静) shares the **virtue/power** (德) of yin (阴),
its burden is without partiality (无私),
following the Earth (地).

Action (动) aligns with the **virtue/power** (波) of yang (阳),
its **covering** (覆) is impartial and just (公正),
following Heaven (天).

Clarity and **Voidlessness** (虚) with **non-action** (无为),
circulating without obstruction (不滞),
all movement in accordance with principle (合理),
following the **Dao/Way** (道).

The **Sage** (圣人) has no desires (无欲),
not dwelling in affairs (有事),
emptying himself to sever all **scheming** (经营),
entrusting things to their **spontaneous transformation** (独化),
following **Nature** (自然).

This is following the **virtue/power** (德) of Heaven and Earth (天地),
not Heaven and Earth following one another.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary** (成疏):
Humans (人) are rulers (主),
so the **Sage** (王) must follow the Earth’s stillness (安静),
and stillness is the first step in conduct (静为行先),
fixed resolve can generate benevolence (定能生惠).
Hence the next chapter states: *"Agitation leads to loss of rule"* (躁则失君).
Once still like the Earth (地),
one must next follow Heaven’s clarity and **Voidlessness** (清虚),
nurturing all without partiality (无私).

Heaven has the Three Lights (三光),
symbolizing how humans have benevolent illumination (惠照),
Earth is the gateway to **stillness** (定门),
Heaven is the gateway to benevolence (惠门).

Once one can emulate Heaven (天),
one must next follow the **Dao/Way’s** (道) clarity and **Voidlessness** (虚通),
encompassing all things.

Once one can emulate the **Dao/Way** (道),
one must next follow the **profound principles** (妙理) of **Nature** (自然),
the realm of the **Double Mystery** (重玄).

The **Dao/Way** (道) is the **advancement** (进),
**Nature** (自然) is the **Root** (本),
and by the **Root** (本) absorbing the **advancement** (迹),
thus the meaning of "following" (法).
Again, it is explained:
The **Dao/Way’s** (道) inherent disposition is **Nature** (自然),
and it follows nothing else—
its essence transcends all cultivation and learning (体绝修学),
hence it is said to follow **Nature** (自然).

**Double Mystery** (重玄) is the **root of the light** (轻根) in Chapter Twenty-Six.
**Double Mystery** (重) is the reason this chapter follows the previous one:
the previous chapter expounds how humans should follow the Earth (地),
and demonstrates that for those who seek the **Dao/Way** (道),
stillness is the first principle (静为先).
Hence this chapter follows,
to weigh and measure stillness against agitation (校量静躁).

Within this chapter, there are three layers of meaning:
First, it correctly distinguishes the inferiority of **lightness and agitation** (轻躁)
and the superiority of **stillness** (静).
Second, it explains that one who upholds **stillness** (重静) will not act contrary to **tranquility** (寂).
Third, it reveals that those who are **light and agitated** (轻躁) will meet ruin in state and person (亡国丧身).

First, it correctly distinguishes the inferiority of **lightness and agitation** (轻躁) and the superiority of **stillness** (静).
The great **virtue/power** (德) of Heaven and Earth is **generation** (日生),
the great treasure of the **Sage** (圣人) is **proper rule** (日位).
Stillness governs movement (静以制动),
as the thirty spokes revolve around the hub (三十辐之循环),
**Double Mystery** (重) is the **root of the light** (轻根),
and the **Nine-Five Sovereign** (九五君) embodies its perfect manifestation (端委).

Ascending the **Great Peak** (太山) is vast and grand,
returning to the myriad hills (众阜) is high,
wearing the **Jade of Perfection** (玉宸) is for rule (为君),
grasping the common people’s reins (握庶人之纪).

Thus, it is known:
when the six lines are set,
the upper one governs the myriad forms (上一制之於群象),
and the initial division of the eight lines (八有初分),
the lower five stabilize the myriad positions (下五镇之於众位).

Hence, the **Profound Mirror** (玄鉴) is distant and wondrous,
only stillness and clarity (唯静与清) can reveal it.
The **Yellow Palace** (黄屋) holds its august dignity,
only the high and the great (唯高唯大) can embody it.
The **Sage** (圣人) opens his principles,
which can be discerned in detail.

**Double Mystery** (重) is the **root of the light** (轻根),
and **stillness** (静) is the **lord of agitation** (躁君).

○ **Master He Shang Gong’s Commentary** (河上公曰):
**Double Mystery** (重) is the **root of the light** (轻根),
so if the human ruler does not uphold **Double Mystery** (重),
he will not be revered (不尊).
If one does not uphold **Double Mystery** (重) in governing his body (治身),
he will lose his **spirit** (神).
Grasses and trees have **light** (轻) flowers and leaves,
so they wither and fall,
but their **roots** (重) are heavy (重),
so they endure and persist (长存).

**Stillness** (静) is the **lord of agitation** (躁君),
so if the human ruler is not still (不静),
he will lose his **awe** (威).
If one does not uphold **stillness** (静) in governing his body (治身),
his body will be in danger (身危).
The **Dragon** (龙) is still, so it can transform (变),
the **Tiger** (虎) is agitated, so it meets early demise (夭亏).

○ **Rong** (荣) says:
Both great and small are **light** (轻),
yet they cannot serve as **roots** (根本).
Both high and low are agitated (躁),
yet how can they serve as **lords** (君主)?
Thus, one **light** (轻) and one **heavy** (重),
the **light** (轻) takes the **heavy** (重) as its **root** (根).
One agitated (躁) and one still (静),
the agitated takes the still as its **master** (主).

Hence, those who uphold **non-action** (无为) and **heavy stillness** (重静) embody the **virtue/power** (德) of rule (为君),
and those who uphold **action** (有为) and **light agitation** (轻躁) fulfill the duties of subjects (臣之事).

The high and low each attend to their own affairs (各司其业),
and for the ruler (为君),
**heavy stillness** (重静) is essential.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary** (成疏):
**Double Mystery** (重) is the **root of the light** (轻根),
an analogy like a tree’s **root** (根) being **heavy** (重),
and its flowers and leaves **light** (轻).
The **light** (轻) withers and falls,
while the **heavy** (重) endures and persists (长存).

This warns learners not to be **light and agitated** (轻躁),
hence the *Book of Documents* (《书》) states:
*"A gentleman who is not **heavy** (重) will not command **awe** (威)."*

**Stillness** (静) is the **lord of agitation** (躁君),
as stillness is **non-action** (无为),
and agitation is **desire** (有欲).
**Desire** (有欲) brings death (生死),
**non-action** (无为) brings endurance (长存).
Stillness can govern movement (静能制动),
hence it is for rule (为君).

Second, it explains that one who upholds **heavy stillness** (重静)
will not act contrary to **tranquility** (寂).
Thus, the **gentleman** (君子) moves all day,
yet never departs from his **burden** (辎重).»

chunks.original_text: 御注：辎，车也。 重者，所载之物也。 轻躁者贵重静，亦由行者之守辎重，故失辎重则遭冻馁； 好轻躁则生祸乱也。 ○御疏：君子者，谓人主也，言其德可以君子人物，故云君子。 辎，屏车也，重者所载之物也，此举喻也。 言人君常守重静，犹如行者之不离辎重，行者若失辎重，则无所取给，必遭冻馁。 人君若好轻躁，则臣必离散，必生息祸，故云终日行不离辎重也。 ○河上公曰：辎，静也。 圣人终日行道，不离静与重。 ○荣曰：有道之主，君人子物，务於重静，不为轻躁，举不失道，动不离静，是以行必辎重，居必摄卫，不至危亡，由重静也。 ○成疏：是以仍前生后文也。 辎，静也。 言君子达人终日行化，同尘处世，而不离重静，此即动而寂者也。 虽有荣观，燕处超然。 御注：人君者，守重静，故虽有荣观，当须燕尔安处，超然不顾。 ○御疏：夫人君好重静，则百姓不烦劳，若高台深池，撞钟舞女，以为荣观，则人力凋尽，乱亡斯作。 故戒云虽有荣观，当须燕尔安处，超然远离而不顾。 ○河上公曰：荣观为官阙燕舍，后妃所居。 超然，远避而不处也。 ○荣曰：圣人所贵者大道，所宝者重静，虽有瑶台琼室之丽馆，身之所托者虚寂，孋姬飞燕之美御，心之所游者无为，情欲不足以累真．’华屋未能以惑己，物无累者，故日超然。 ○成疏：重言重静之人，虽有荣华之官观，燕寝之处所，以游心虚澹，超然物外，不以为娱，处染不染也。 第三明轻躁之者亡国丧身。 奈何万乘之主，而以身轻天下？ 御注：奈何者，伤叹之词也。 天下者，大宝之位也。 言人君奈何以身从欲，轻用其身，令亡其位乎。 ○御疏：天子提封百万井，定出赋税六十四万，并出戎马百万匹，兵车万乘，故云万乘之主。 奈何者，伤叹之词也。 天下者，大宝之位也。 夫万乘之主，四海必同，当令子孙千亿，本枝百代。 善建则无为偃化，善抱则有截归仁，奈何承此重器，耽乐是从，以身充欲，沦胥以败？ 是以一身之欲，而轻大宝之位，甚可伤叹，故云奈何。 ○河上公曰：奈何万乘之主，奈何者，疾时王伤痛之也。 万乘之主，谓王者。 而以身轻天下，王者至尊，而以其身行轻躁乎？ 疾时奢恣轻淫也。 ○荣曰：千金之子，坐不垂堂，万乘之君，岂宜妄动。 ○成疏：如何，奈何也。 王畿千里，戎车万乘之君，应须重静，乃恣情淫勃，厚赋繁徭，禽荒色荒，轻忽宇内，哀叹之甚，故云奈何。 轻则失臣，躁则失君。 御注：君轻易，则人离散，故失臣。 臣躁求，则主不齿，故云失君。 ○御疏：夫君多轻易则必烦扰，烦扰则人散，谁与为臣？ 故云轻则失臣，此戒君也。 为人臣者，当量能受爵，无速官谤。 若矫迹干禄，饰诈析荣，躁求若斯，祸败寻至，坐招窜拯，焉得事君？ 故云躁则失君，此伸戒人臣也。 ○河上公曰：轻则失臣，王者轻淫则失臣，治身轻淫则失其精。 躁则失君，王者行躁疾则失其君位，治身躁疾，则失其精神也。 ○严曰：失臣作失本，言君好轻躁，如树之根本而摇动，根摇动则技木桔而槁矣。 人主不静则百姓摇荡，宗庙倾危，则失其国君之位也。 ○荣曰：前明重静，则超然无累，今明轻躁则必致有损，无累则上下俱安，有损则君臣皆失也。

**Commentary of the Master (御注):**
*"Zhī"* (辎) means "chariot" (车).
*"Zhòng"* (重) refers to the things it carries.
Those who are **light and agitated** (轻躁) must uphold **heavy stillness** (重静),
just as travelers must guard their **burden** (辎重).
Thus, losing the **burden** (辎重) leads to cold and hunger (冻馁),
while indulging in **lightness and agitation** (轻躁) brings disaster (祸乱).

**Commentary of the Master (御疏):**
*"Jūnzǐ"* (君子) refers to the sovereign (人主),
speaking of how his **virtue** (德) can govern the people (人物),
hence it is called *"jūnzǐ"* (君子).
*"Zhī"* (辎) means "screened carriage" (屏车),
*"zhòng"* (重) refers to the things it carries—this is a metaphor.
It says the sovereign must always uphold **heavy stillness** (重静),
just as travelers never abandon their **burden** (辎重).
If travelers lose their **burden** (辎重),
they will have nothing to sustain them,
and they must suffer cold and hunger (冻馁).
If the sovereign indulges in **lightness and agitation** (轻躁),
his ministers will scatter,
he will breed calamities (息祸),
and his state will fall—
hence it is said that the sovereign moves all day yet never abandons his **burden** (辎重).

**Master Hé Shànggōng (河上公) says:**
*"Zhī"* (辎) means **stillness** (静).
The **sage** (圣人) moves through the **Dao/Way** (道) all day,
yet never abandons **stillness** (静) and **heavy stillness** (重).

**Master Róng (荣) says:**
A sovereign who upholds the **Dao/Way** (道),
governing the people (物),
must strive for **heavy stillness** (重静)
and not indulge in **lightness and agitation** (轻躁).
Every action must not stray from the **Dao/Way** (道),
every movement must not abandon **stillness** (静).
Thus, when he travels, he must carry his **burden** (辎重),
and when he resides, he must maintain his **defenses** (摄卫).
This prevents ruin (危亡),
all from **heavy stillness** (重静).

**Commentary of the Master (成疏):**
Hence, it continues the earlier warning and adds new meaning.
*"Zhī"* (辎) means **stillness** (静).
It says the sovereign, who understands humanity (达人),
moves through the world all day (终日行化),
yet never abandons **heavy stillness** (重静).
This is the meaning of "moving yet tranquil" (动而寂).
Even amid splendor (荣观),
he remains detached (超然).

**Commentary of the Master (御注):**
The sovereign must uphold **heavy stillness** (重静),
so even amid splendor (荣观),
he must rest content (燕尔安处),
detached (超然) and unmoved.

**Commentary of the Master (御疏):**
If the sovereign upholds **heavy stillness** (重静),
the people will not be burdened with labor (烦劳).
If he indulges in high platforms (高台),
deep pools (深池),
tolling bells (撞钟),
and dancing women (舞女),
taking such displays as splendor (荣观),
then the people’s strength will be exhausted,
and chaos and ruin will follow (乱亡斯作).
Thus the warning says:
Even amid splendor (荣观),
he must rest content (燕尔安处),
detached (超然) and far removed from such distractions (远离而不顾).

**Master Hé Shànggōng (河上公) says:**
*"Hóngguān"* (荣观) refers to the palaces (官阙) and resting halls (燕舍)
where the queen and concubines reside (后妃所居).
*"Chāorán"* (超然) means to stand far away and not dwell there.

**Master Róng (荣) says:**
What the **sage** (圣人) values is the **Great Dao/Way** (大道),
what he treasures is **heavy stillness** (重静).
Even with the most splendid halls (瑶台琼室),
his dwelling is empty and tranquil (虚寂).
Even with the most beautiful consorts (孋姬飞燕),
his heart remains in **non-action** (无为).
Passions and desires cannot weigh down the true—
*"Hua wū"* (华屋), though grand, cannot deceive him,
and material things cannot burden him,
hence it is said that he is detached (超然).

**Commentary of the Master (成疏):**
For those who uphold **heavy stillness** (重静),
even amid the splendor of palaces (荣华之官观)
and comfortable lodgings (燕寝之处所),
they keep their hearts in emptiness (虚澹),
detached from the world (超然物外),
not taking pleasure in such things,
and though immersed, they are not stained (处染不染).

**Third, it explains that those who indulge in lightness and agitation (轻躁) will lose their kingdom and their life (亡国丧身).**
How can a sovereign of ten thousand chariots (万乘之主)
lightly abandon his body (以身轻) for the sake of the world (天下)?

**Commentary of the Master (御注):**
*"Nàihé"* (奈何) is a word of lamentation (伤叹).
*"Tiānxià"* (天下) refers to the supreme position (大宝之位).
It says: How can the sovereign abandon his body to desire (从欲),
lightly use his life (轻用其身),
and thus forfeit his position (令亡其位)?

**Commentary of the Master (御疏):**
The Son of Heaven (天子) controls vast lands (封),
taxes from a million households (百万井),
and levies tribute of sixty-four thousand (六十四万).
He commands a hundred thousand warhorses (戎马百万匹)
and ten thousand chariots (万乘).
Hence it is called "sovereign of ten thousand chariots" (万乘之主).
*"Nàihé"* (奈何) is a word of lamentation (伤叹).
*"Tiānxià"* (天下) refers to the supreme position (大宝之位).
The sovereign of ten thousand chariots must unite the four seas (四海必同),
and ensure his descendants number in the billions (子孙千亿),
his lineage endure for a hundred generations (本枝百代).
If he governs well, he will achieve **non-action** (无为) and universal transformation (偃化).
If he embraces virtue, he will cut off evil and return to **ren** (仁).
How can he, bearing this heavy responsibility (重器),
indulge in pleasures and follow desires (耽乐是从),
abandon his life to gratify his passions (以身充欲),
and thus sink into ruin (沦胥以败)?
Hence, abandoning his body to desire (一身之欲)
while lightly discarding his supreme position (轻大宝之位),
is deeply lamentable—
thus it is said: *"Nàihé"* (奈何).

**Master Hé Shànggōng (河上公) says:**
*"Nàihé"* (奈何), the sovereign of ten thousand chariots (万乘之主),
*"Nàihé"* (奈何) is a reproach against the ruler (疾时王伤痛).
The sovereign of ten thousand chariots refers to the king (王者).
And yet, he lightly indulges in licentiousness (轻淫)?
It reproaches the ruler’s extravagance (奢恣) and **lightness and agitation** (轻淫).

**Master Róng (荣) says:**
The son of a thousand gold pieces (千金之子)
does not sit idly in his hall (坐不垂堂),
how much more so the sovereign of ten thousand chariots (万乘之君),
who must not lightly move without purpose (岂宜妄动).

**Commentary of the Master (成疏):**
*"Rúhé"* (如何) is the same as *"Nàihé"* (奈何).
The king’s domain (王畿) is a thousand *lǐ* wide,
and the sovereign of ten thousand chariots (万乘之君)
should uphold **heavy stillness** (重静).
Yet he indulges in licentiousness (轻躁),
imposes heavy taxes (厚赋),
and multiplies labor services (繁徭).
He plunders the land for its beauty (禽荒),
and indulges in excess (色荒).
He neglects the world (轻忽宇内),
and his lamentation is great—
hence it is said: *"Nàihé"* (奈何).
**Lightness** (轻) causes him to lose his ministers (失臣),
**agitation** (躁) causes him to lose his sovereignty (失君).

**Commentary of the Master (御注):**
If the sovereign is **light and careless** (轻易),
people will scatter (离散),
hence he loses his ministers (失臣).
If ministers are **agitated and greedy** (躁求),
the sovereign will be disgraced (不齿),
hence it is said that he loses his sovereignty (失君).

**Commentary of the Master (御疏):**
If the sovereign is often **light and careless** (轻易),
he will surely bring trouble (烦扰),
and trouble will cause people to scatter (人散).
Who will remain to serve as his ministers?
Thus it is said: **Lightness** (轻) causes him to lose his ministers (失臣)—
this is a warning to the sovereign.
As a minister, one should measure his abilities before accepting office (量能受爵),
and not hasten to seek promotion (速官).
If he falsifies his path to gain wealth (矫迹干禄),
or deceives to secure honor (饰诈析荣),
and is as **agitated and greedy** (躁求) as this,
disaster will follow (祸败寻至),
and he will be banished (坐招窜拯).
How can he serve the sovereign?
Thus it is said: **Agitation** (躁) causes him to lose his sovereignty (失君)—
this extends the warning to ministers.

**Master Hé Shànggōng (河上公) says:**
**Lightness** (轻) causes him to lose his ministers (失臣),
the sovereign’s **lightness and licentiousness** (轻淫) cause him to lose his ministers,
and **lightness** (轻) in self-cultivation causes him to lose his vitality (失其精).
**Agitation** (躁) causes him to lose his sovereignty (失君),
the sovereign’s **agitation and haste** (躁疾) cause him to lose his position (失其君位),
and **agitation** (躁) in self-cultivation causes him to lose his spirit (失其精神).

**Master Yán (严) says:**
*"Shī chén zuò shī běn"* (失臣作失本),
speaking of how the sovereign’s indulgence in **lightness and agitation** (轻躁)
is like a tree’s roots being shaken (根本而摇动).
If the roots shake, the branches will wither (技木枯),
and the trunk will dry up (桔而槁).
If the sovereign is not **still** (静),
the people will be unsettled (摇荡),
the ancestral temples will be endangered (倾危),
and he will lose his position as king (失其国君之位).

**Master Róng (荣) says:**
Earlier, it was explained that **heavy stillness** (重静)
leads to detachment (超然) and no burden (无累).
Now, it is explained that **lightness and agitation** (轻躁)
will surely bring harm (致有损).
No burden means both sovereign and ministers are at ease (上下俱安),
while harm means both sovereign and ministers are lost (君臣皆失).

chunks.original_text: ○成疏：恣情放欲，轻躁日甚，外则亡国，内则危身。 忠良窜匿，失臣也。 宗庙倾覆，失君也。 善行无辙迩章第二十七 善行章所以次前者，前章正明重静圣人动不乖寂，故次此章，广显此人行能功用。 就此章内，文有四重，第一明重静之人，三业清净，第二明重静之人，结显坚固，六根解脱，第三明降迹激救，应物无遗，第四示师资之道，修学之妙，而言之也。 第一明重静之人，三业清净。 夫圣应圆界夏心湛寂，不行而去，远游昆阆之中，不出而知，瑕践瑶京之上。 寂而能动，处暗常明，欲我苍生，永苦於九幽之内。 叹彼邪秽，长昏於五欲之中。 如嗔蛇头，贤圣於焉不敢，如醉象首，达人所以弃之。 衰彼凡迷，从何得悟，故善行无迹！ 将欲救之。 师资之道一齐，凡圣之心双泯也。 善行无辙述， 御注：於诸法中，体了真性，行无行相，故云善行。 如此则心与道冥，故无辙迹可寻求也。 ○御疏：此明法性清净也。 行谓修行也。 法性清净，是曰重玄。 虽藉勤行，必须无着，次来次灭，行无行相，心与道合，故云善行。 能如此，则空有一齐，境心俱净，欲求辙进，不亦难乎？ ○河上公曰：善行道者，求之於身，不下堂，不出门，故无辙述也。 ○荣曰：七香流水之车，动之者有辙，千里浮云之马，跃之者有述。 不疾而速，云耕不辗地，不行而至，凤鸟本无迹。 言圣人垂拱庙堂，不偏周王之辙，贤士销声丘壑，不削孔丘之迹也。 ○成疏：以无行为行，行无行相，故云善行妙契所修，境智冥会，故无辙迹之可见，此明身业净。 善言无瑕谪， 御注：能了言教，不为滞执，遗象求意，理证言忘，故於言教中无瑕疵谪过也。 ○御疏：此明学人不滞言教也。 瑕，病也。 谪，责也。 言谓言教也。 夫善行无迹，则能了言教，不为执滞，於言忘言，是善言也。 能如此，遗象导意，理照言忘，於彼言教，一无病责，故云善言无瑕谪。 ○河上公曰：善言谓择言而出之，则无瑕疵谪过於天下。 ○荣曰：言铃有中，千里应之，非法不言，有何过也。 ○成疏：不言之言，言而不言，终日言未尝言，亦未尝不言，故谓之善言也。 《庄子》云：言而足则终日言而尽道也。 瑕，疵病也。 谪，过责也。 默语不异，故无口过之责也。 本文作的字，谓圣人之言，既无的当，故无所之谓，此明口业净。 善计无筹算。 御注：能了诸法，本无二门，一以贯之，不生他见，故无劳筹算，自然照了。 计无计相，非善而何也。 ○御疏：此明言教无滞，则不计异门也。 夫执言滞行，辨是与非，适令巧历亦不能计。 若能了诸法皆方便门，究竟清净，不生他见，则无劳筹策算数，自能深入一乘。 善计若斯，何劳筹算？ 故云善计不用筹算。 ○河上公曰：善以道计事者，守一不移，所计不多，不用筹策而可知者也。 ○荣曰：筹策者，以算物数，以道观之，物无不尽，道非於数，宁用筹策也。 ○成疏：妙悟诸法同一虚假，不设虚假，即假体真，无劳算计，划然明了，此明意业净。 第二明结愿坚固，六根解脱。 善闭无关梃而不可开， 御注：兼忘言行，不入异门，心无逐境之迷，境无起心之累，虽无关楗，其可开乎？ ○御疏：此明不计异门，则欲心自闭也。 横日关，竖日楗。

「○ **Master Chéng’s Commentary** (成疏):
To indulge emotions and abandon **Daoist restraint** (恣情放欲),
to grow ever **light and agitated** (轻躁日甚),
externally leads to the loss of the realm (亡国),
internally endangers one’s own body (危身).
When loyal ministers are exiled and hidden (忠良窜匿),
this is the loss of **ministers** (失臣).
When ancestral temples are toppled (宗庙倾覆),
this is the loss of **sovereignty** (失君).

**Chapter Twenty-Seven: *The Chapter of **Daoist Virtue** (善行)***
This chapter follows the previous one,
for the earlier chapter expounds on the **sages** (圣人)
practicing **heavy stillness** (重静),
whose actions do not stray from **Daoist quiescence** (寂).
Thus, this chapter elaborates on the **Daoist adept’s** (此人) **virtuous conduct** (行能功用).
Within this chapter, the text unfolds in **four layers** (文有四重):
1. It first elucidates the **Daoist adept of heavy stillness** (重静之人),
   whose **Three Businesses** (三业) are pure and **Daoist stillness** (清净).
2. It then reveals the **Daoist adept of heavy stillness** (重静之人)
   as **firm and unshakable** (结显坚固),
   with the **Six Roots** (六根) **liberated** (解脱).
3. It next demonstrates **transcending traces and urgent rescue** (降迹激救),
   responding to all things without omission (应物无遗).
4. Finally, it illustrates the **Dao of teacher and disciple** (师资之道),
   the **marvels of cultivation** (修学之妙),
   and its **eloquence** (而言之).

1. **The Daoist adept of heavy stillness** (重静之人) **whose Three Businesses are pure** (三业清净).
The **sage** (圣) **responds to the vast Dao** (应圆界),
his **heart** (心) **settled in primordial stillness** (夏心湛寂),
yet **does not act** (不行) while **transcending** (去).
He wanders through the **Midst of Kunlun** (远游昆阆之中),
yet **does not depart** (不出) while **knowing** (知).
He treads upon **Jiaozhen** (瑕践瑶京之上),
the **Daode Palace** (瑶京).

In **stillness**, yet able to **move** (寂而能动),
dwelling in darkness yet ever **illuminated** (处暗常明),
he **pities** (欲) the **myriad living beings** (我苍生),
enduring their eternal suffering in the **Nine Abysses** (九幽).
He **lament**s (叹) those ensnared in **evil and filth** (彼邪秽),
lost in the **Five Desires** (五欲) **for endless ages** (长昏).

Like the **venomous serpent’s head** (嗔蛇头),
even the **wise and virtuous** (贤圣) **dare not approach**.
Like the **drunken elephant’s trunk** (醉象首),
the **enlightened** (达人) **abandon it**.
The **common and deluded** (凡迷) **how can awaken** (从何得悟)?
Thus, **Daoist virtue** (善行) **leaves no trace** (无迹)!
When **rescue** (救) is sought,
the **Dao of teacher and disciple** (师资之道) **is unified** (一齐),
and the **hearts of all beings** (凡圣之心) **are extinguished** (双泯).

**Daoist virtue** (善行) **leaves no trace** (无辙述).
**The Imperial Commentary** (御注) **says:**
Within all **dharma** (诸法),
realizing the **true nature** (体了真性),
actions manifest **no action** (行无行相),
thus it is called **Daoist virtue** (善行).

So, the **heart unites with the Dao** (心与道冥),
and **no trace or path** (辙迹) **can be sought**.

**The Imperial Commentary** (御疏) **says:**
This reveals the **pure nature of dharma** (法性清净).
**Actions** (行) refer to **cultivation** (修行).
When the **nature of dharma** (法性) is pure,
this is called **Triple Primordial** (重玄).
Though one relies on **diligent practice** (勤行),
one must **avoid attachment** (无着),
**gradually extinguishing** (次来次灭)
until **actions manifest no form** (行无行相).
The **heart unites with the Dao** (心与道合),
thus it is called **Daoist virtue** (善行).
To achieve this is to **equalize emptiness and unity** (空有一齐),
where **phenomena and mind are both pure** (境心俱净).
If one seeks **traces or paths** (辙进),
is it not **difficult** (难)?

**Master Héshàng** (河上公) **says:**
The **Daoist adept of virtue** (善行道者)
seeks it **within oneself** (於身),
never descending from the **hall** (不下堂),
nor stepping outside the **door** (不出门),
thus **leaving no trace** (故无辙述).

**Master Róng** (荣) **says:**
The **Seven-Scented Fragrance Chariot** (七香流水之车),
when **moved** (动), has **traces** (有辙).
The **Thousand-Li Cloud-Steed** (千里浮云之马),
when **leaping** (跃), has **pathways** (有述).
Yet **not hasty yet swift** (不疾而速),
**cloud-plowing** (云耕) **does not trample the earth** (不辗地).
**Not acting yet arriving** (不行而至),
the **Phoenix Bird** (凤鸟) **has no trace** (本无迹).
This speaks of the **sage** (圣人) **resting in the hall** (垂拱庙堂),
yet **not following the tracks of Zhou’s kings** (不偏周王之辙),
and the **virtuous scholar** (贤士) **fading into seclusion** (销声丘壑),
**not diminishing the footsteps of Confucius** (不削孔丘之迹).

**Master Chéng’s Commentary** (成疏) **says:**
To **act without action** (以无行为行),
actions manifest **no form** (行无行相),
thus it is called **Daoist virtue** (善行).
When **cultivation is profound** (妙契所修),
**phenomena and wisdom merge** (境智冥会),
no **traces or paths** (辙迹) **are visible** (之可见),
this reveals the **purity of bodily conduct** (身业净).

**Daoist virtue in speech** (善言) **leaves no blemish or censure** (无瑕谪).
**The Imperial Commentary** (御注) **says:**
One who **comprehends the teachings** (能了言教),
yet **does not cling rigidly** (不为滞执),
**discards the form to seek the meaning** (遗象求意),
**realizes the truth beyond words** (理证言忘),
thus **speech is free from flaw or blame** (於言教中无瑕疵谪过).

**The Imperial Commentary** (御疏) **says:**
This reveals the **learned not clinging to words** (学人不滞言教).
**Blemish** (瑕) means **defect or illness** (病).
**Censure** (谪) means **blame** (责).
**Speech** (言) refers to **teachings** (言教).
When **Daoist virtue leaves no trace** (善行无迹),
one **comprehends the teachings** (能了言教),
yet **does not cling rigidly** (不为执滞),
**forgetting speech while in speech** (於言忘言),
this is **Daoist virtue in speech** (善言).
Thus, **discarding forms to guide meaning** (遗象导意),
**truth illuminates speech-forgetting** (理照言忘),
in all **teachings** (言教),
**there is no defect or blame** (一无病责),
thus it is called **Daoist virtue in speech** (善言无瑕谪).

**Master Héshàng** (河上公) **says:**
**Daoist virtue in speech** (善言) **is to choose words wisely** (择言而出之),
thus **no flaw or blame exists in the world** (无瑕疵谪过於天下).

**Master Róng** (荣) **says:**
When **words strike the bell** (言铃有中),
**a thousand li respond** (千里应之),
yet **speak only of the Dao** (非法不言),
what **blame** (过) **could there be**?

**Master Chéng’s Commentary** (成疏) **says:**
**Speech without speech** (不言之言),
**speaking yet not speaking** (言而不言),
**all day speaking yet never truly speaking** (终日言未尝言),
**nor truly not speaking** (亦未尝不言),
thus it is called **Daoist virtue in speech** (善言).
As the *Zhuangzi* says:
*"Words sufficient to convey the Dao
are spoken all day yet exhaust the Dao."* (言而足则终日言而尽道也).
**Blemish** (瑕) means **defect or illness** (疵病).
**Censure** (谪) means **blame** (过责).
**Silence and speech are alike** (默语不异),
thus **no blame for words** (无口过之责).
The original text uses the character **de** (的),
referring to the **sage’s speech** (圣人之言),
which **lacks any target** (既无的当),
thus **no blame for any direction** (故无所之谓).
This reveals the **purity of verbal conduct** (口业净).

**Daoist virtue in thought** (善计) **requires no scheming** (无筹算).
**The Imperial Commentary** (御注) **says:**
One who **comprehends all dharma** (能了诸法),
**has no dual paths** (本无二门),
**unifies all with one principle** (一以贯之),
**does not generate other views** (不生他见),
thus **no need for scheming or calculation** (故无劳筹算),
**naturally illuminated and comprehended** (自然照了).
When **thoughts manifest no thought-form** (计无计相),
what is more **virtuous** (善) than this?

**The Imperial Commentary** (御疏) **says:**
This reveals **teachings not clinging** (言教无滞),
thus **no duality in thought** (则不计异门).
When one **clings to words and stagnates in actions** (执言滞行),
**distinguishing right from wrong** (辨是与非),
even **clever strategists** (巧历) **cannot compute**.
Yet if one **comprehends all dharma as expedient means** (能了诸法皆方便门),
**ultimately pure and unadulterated** (究竟清净),
**not generating other views** (不生他见),
then **no need for scheming or calculation** (则无劳筹策算数),
**one can naturally penetrate the One Vehicle** (自能深入一乘).
When **thoughts are thus virtuous** (善计若斯),
why **labor in scheming or calculation**?
Thus it is said: **Daoist virtue in thought requires no scheming** (善计不用筹算).

**Master Héshàng** (河上公) **says:**
The **virtuous in thought** (善以道计事者)
**holds to one principle without deviation** (守一不移),
**thoughts are few** (所计不多),
**no scheming is needed yet all is known** (不用筹策而可知者).

**Master Róng** (荣) **says:**
**Scheming and calculation** (筹策) **are for counting things** (算物数),
but **the Dao observes all** (以道观之),
**nothing is left unexamined** (物无不尽),
**the Dao transcends numbers** (道非於数),
so why use **scheming and calculation**?

**Master Chéng’s Commentary** (成疏) **says:**
**Mysterious comprehension** (妙悟) **of all dharma as one** (诸法同一虚假),
**not setting up falsehoods** (不设虚假),
**falsehoods reveal truth** (即假体真),
**no need for calculation** (无劳算计),
**suddenly illuminated and clear** (划然明了),
this reveals the **purity of mental conduct** (意业净).

2. **Revealing the firm and unshakable vow** (结愿坚固), **and the liberation of the Six Roots** (六根解脱).
**Daoist virtue in closing** (善闭) **has no bolts or bars** (无关梃) **yet cannot be opened** (而不可开).
**The Imperial Commentary** (御注) **says:**
**Both speech and action are forgotten** (兼忘言行),
**not entering false paths** (不入异门),
**the heart does not wander in phenomena** (心无逐境之迷),
**phenomena do not burden the heart** (境无起心之累),
though **no bolts or bars** (虽无关楗),
how could it be **opened**? (其可开乎?)

**The Imperial Commentary** (御疏) **says:**
This reveals **not clinging to false paths** (不计异门),
thus **the desire-heart naturally closes** (则欲心自闭).
**Horizontal bars are called "guān"** (横日关),
**vertical bars are called "jiàn"** (竖日楗).」

chunks.original_text: 夫善行善言，不耽不滞，则心照清净，境尘不起，故云善闭虽无关梃，其可开乎？ 故云善闭无关梃而不可开。 ○河上公曰：善以道闭情欲守精者，不如门户有关楗不可得开之。 ○荣日：门以关梃，有闭有开，若能以道制之，无开无闭，是以理国者以道纂弒，无以窥仑，修身者以道声色，无由开凿。 ○成疏：外无可欲之境，内无能· 欲之心，恣根起用，用而无染，斯则不闭而闭，虽闭不闭，无劳关梃，故不可开也。 此明六根解脱。 善结无绳约而不可解。 御注：体了真性，本以虚忘，若能虚忘，则心与道合，虽无绳索约束，其可解而散乎？ ○御疏：此明善闭之人，心与道合。 结，系也。 绳，索也。 约，束也。 解，散也。 夫坐忘遗照，深契道源於诸法中，尽能不滞系心於此，故云善结。 夫用绳约者，绳散则约解，以道结者，心静则道冥，适使万绿尽兴，终能一无所染，虽无绳索约束，岂可解而散乎？ 故云善结无绳约而不可解。 ○河上公曰：善以道结事者，乃结其心，不如绳索可得解之。 ○荣曰：用绳之者，有缚有解，以道控制於四方，善结也。 万国共戴於一人，不解也。 修身者心契於道，故言善结。 抱一无离，不可解。 ○成疏：上士达人，先物后己，发大弘愿，化度众生，誓心坚固，结契无爽，既非世之绳索约束，故不可解也。 然誓心多端，要不过五：一者发心，二者伏心，三者知真心，四者出离心，五者无上心。 第一发心者，谓发自然道意，入於法门也。 第二伏心者，谓伏诸障惑也。 就伏心有文，文尸三解，解有三品，物增成九品，通前发心，为十转行也。 第三知真心，有九品，即生彼九官也。 第四出离心，有三品，即生彼三清，所谓仙、真、圣也。 第五无上心，谓直登道果，至大罗也。 善结者，结此五种心，终始无替也。 此明结愿坚固。 第三明降迹慈救，应物无遗者也。 是以圣人常善救人，故无弃人。 常善救物，故无弃物。 御注：是以圣人常用此五善之教以成之，故无弃者。 ○御疏：是以圣人常善救人，故无弃人。 是以者，引下以明上也。 言圣人心虽凝寂，教则流通，故常用五善以救人，令必释然而达解，大慈平等，无所偏隔，凡是於人，尽皆善诱，故云常善救人，故无弃人。 常善救物，故无弃物。 物者通有识无识也。 救人善教，故不弃人，救物善心，亦无弃物，使令动植咸遂，无残伤者，故云常善救物，故无弃物。 ○河上公曰：是以圣人常善救人，圣人所以教人忠正者，欲以救人之性命也。 故无弃人，使贵贱各得其所也。 常善救物，圣人所以教民顺四时，以救万物之残伤。 故无弃物，圣人不贱石而贵玉，视之如一。 ○荣曰：是以圣人常善救人，而无弃人，一物失所，虑轸纳隍，视人如子，宁有弃乎。 真圣阐经以开化，赴感以遵凡，以道济之，曾无遗弃。 常善救物，而无弃物，始终用道，故言常。 惠及万方，故言善。 德能广济，故言救。 通言一切，故言物。 ○成疏：是以圣人常善救人，故无弃人。 圣人即是前三业清净六根解脱之人也。 为能发弘誓愿，救度众生，故常在世间，有感斯应，慈善平等，终不遗弃也。 常善救物，而无弃物。 先举人者，表恩被有情，后举物者，示仁覃无识。

「夫善行善言，不耽不滞，则心照清净，境尘不起，故云善闭虽无关梃，其可开乎？ 故云善闭无关梃而不可开。
The **virtuous Daoist** (善) in **conduct and speech** (行言) who neither **lingers nor stagnates** (耽滞),
then **illuminates the heart with clarity and purity** (心照清净),
and **no dust of phenomena** (境尘) arises—
thus it is said: **"Virtuous closure** (善闭) **though lacking bolts and bars** (无关梃), **how could it be opened**? (其可开乎？)
Therefore it is said: **"Virtuous closure** (善闭) **though lacking bolts and bars** (无关梃), **cannot be opened**." (而不可开)

**Master He Shang Gong** (河上公) **says:**
The **virtuous Daoist** who **closes emotions and guards essence** (闭情欲守精) with the **Dao/Way** (道),
is **not inferior to a door with bolts and bars** (不如门户有关梃) that **cannot be opened** (不可得开).

**Rong** (荣) **says:**
A **door is closed with bolts and bars** (关梃),
**having both closure and opening** (有闭有开).
If one **can control it with the Dao/Way** (以道制之),
there is **neither opening nor closure** (无开无闭).
Thus, **those who govern by principle** (理国者) **use the Dao/Way to bind and restrain** (纂弒),
**so that none may spy upon the realm** (无以窥仑).
**Those who cultivate the self** (修身者) **use the Dao/Way to master speech and color** (声色),
**so that there is no means of opening or breaching** (无由开凿).

**The Imperial Commentary** (成疏) **says:**
Externally, there are **no desired phenomena** (无可欲之境),
internally, there is **no capacity for desire** (无能欲之心).
**The Six Roots** (恣根) **arise and function** (起用),
yet **no defilement occurs** (用而无染).
Thus, it is **closure without closure** (不闭而闭),
**though closed, it is not closed** (虽闭不闭),
requiring **no labor of bolts and bars** (无劳关梃),
hence **it cannot be opened** (故不可开).
This reveals **the liberation of the Six Roots** (六根解脱).

**善结无绳约而不可解。**
**Virtuous bonds** (善结) **lack cords and restraints** (无绳约) **yet cannot be undone** (而不可解).

**The Imperial Commentary** (御注) **says:**
One who **fully comprehends the true nature** (体了真性),
**fundamentally forgets in emptiness** (本以虚忘),
if **able to forget in emptiness** (能虚忘),
then **the heart unites with the Dao/Way** (心与道合).
Though **no cords or restraints** (虽无绳索约束),
**how could it be undone and scattered**? (其可解而散乎？)

**The Imperial Commentary** (御疏) **says:**
This reveals **the virtuous Daoist** (善闭之人) whose **heart unites with the Dao/Way** (心与道合).
**Bonding** (结) is **tying** (系),
**cords** (绳) are **ropes** (索),
**restraints** (约) are **bindings** (束),
**undoing** (解) is **scattering** (散).
**Sitting in forgetfulness and abandoning illumination** (坐忘遗照),
**deeply resonating with the Dao’s source** (深契道源) amidst all **dharma/phenomena** (诸法),
**completely able to not be hindered or bound** (尽能不滞系心於此),
thus it is said: **"Virtuous bonding"** (善结).
**One who uses cords and restraints** (用绳约者),
when **the cords are scattered** (绳散), **the restraints are undone** (则约解).
But **one who bonds with the Dao/Way** (以道结者),
when **the heart is tranquil** (心静), **the Dao/Way is profound** (则道冥),
**allowing all things to flourish naturally** (适使万绿尽兴),
**yet never defiled** (终能一无所染).
Though **no cords or restraints** (虽无绳索约束),
**how could it be undone and scattered**? (岂可解而散乎？)
Therefore it is said: **"Virtuous bonds** (善结) **lack cords and restraints** (无绳约) **yet cannot be undone**." (而不可解)

**Master He Shang Gong** (河上公) **says:**
The **virtuous Daoist** who **bonds with the Dao/Way** (善以道结事者),
**merely bonds the heart** (乃结其心),
**not inferior to cords and restraints** (不如绳索可得解之).

**Rong** (荣) **says:**
**One who uses cords** (用绳之者),
**has both binding and undoing** (有缚有解).
**The Dao/Way controls all four directions** (以道控制於四方),
thus it is **virtuous bonding** (善结).
**All under Heaven unite beneath one** (万国共戴於一人),
**never undone** (不解).
**The cultivator’s heart resonates with the Dao/Way** (修身者心契於道),
thus it is said: **"Virtuous bonds"** (故言善结).
**Embracing the One without separation** (抱一无离),
**it cannot be undone** (不可解).

**The Imperial Commentary** (成疏) **says:**
The **exalted sage** (上士达人),
**prioritizes phenomena over self** (先物后己),
**takes the great vow** (发大弘愿),
**transforms and liberates all beings** (化度众生).
Their **vow-heart is firm and unshaken** (誓心坚固),
**bonding without flaw** (结契无爽).
Since it is **not worldly cords or restraints** (既非世之绳索约束),
thus **it cannot be undone** (故不可解).
However, **vows of the heart are manifold** (誓心多端),
yet **they do not exceed five**:
1. **The vow of awakening** (发心者),
   which is **awakening to the natural Dao/Way** (发自然道意) and **entering the dharma-gate** (入於法门).
2. **The vow of subduing** (伏心者),
   which is **subduing all obstacles and delusions** (伏诸障惑).
   Within **subduing the heart** (就伏心), there are **scriptures** (有文),
   and **these scriptures** (文) **are threefold in their liberation** (尸三解),
   **liberation** (解) **having three grades** (有三品),
   **phenomena** (物) **increasing to nine grades** (增成九品),
   **uniting with the prior vow of awakening** (通前发心), **forming the Ten Transgressions of conduct** (为十转行).
3. **The vow of knowing the true heart** (知真心),
   which **has nine grades** (有九品), **generating the Nine Officials** (即生彼九官).
4. **The vow of emancipated heart** (出离心),
   which **has three grades** (有三品), **generating the Three Pure Ones** (即生彼三清)—
   the **Immortal, True One, and Sage** (所谓仙、真、圣).
5. **The vow of the peerless heart** (无上心),
   which is **directly ascending to the Dao’s fruit** (直登道果), **reaching the Great Luo** (至大罗).

The **virtuous bond** (善结者) is **bonding these five kinds of hearts** (结此五种心),
**without ever wavering in beginning or end** (终始无替).
This reveals **the firm and unshakable vow** (结愿坚固).

**第三明降迹慈救，应物无遗者也。**
**Thirdly, it reveals the Sage’s descent in compassion and salvation** (降迹慈救),
**responding to all things without omission** (应物无遗).

Thus, the **Sage** (圣人) **constantly saves beings** (常善救人),
hence **there is no abandonment of beings** (故无弃人).
The **Sage constantly saves phenomena** (常善救物),
hence **there is no abandonment of phenomena** (故无弃物).

**The Imperial Commentary** (御注) **says:**
Thus, the **Sage** (圣人) **constantly employs these five virtues of teaching** (常用此五善之教以成之),
hence **there are no abandoned ones** (故无弃者).

**The Imperial Commentary** (御疏) **says:**
Thus, the **Sage constantly saves beings** (是以圣人常善救人), hence **there is no abandonment of beings** (故无弃人).
**"Thus"** (是以) is **to elucidate the lower with the higher** (引下以明上).
Though the **Sage’s heart is concentrated and still** (圣人心虽凝寂),
**teaching flows freely** (教则流通),
thus **constantly employing the Five Virtues** (常用五善) to **save beings** (救人),
**so that all may be liberated and enlightened** (令必释然而达解),
**with great compassion and equality** (大慈平等),
**without partiality or exclusion** (无所偏隔).
**All beings are universally guided with virtue** (凡是於人，尽皆善诱),
hence it is said: **"The Sage constantly saves beings, hence there is no abandonment of beings"** (故云常善救人，故无弃人).

**The Sage constantly saves phenomena** (常善救物), hence **there is no abandonment of phenomena** (故无弃物).
**"Phenomena"** (物) **encompass both sentient and insentient beings** (通有识无识).
**Saving beings through virtuous teaching** (救人善教), hence **there is no abandonment of beings** (故不弃人).
**Saving phenomena through a virtuous heart** (救物善心), **there is also no abandonment of phenomena** (亦无弃物),
**allowing all movement and growth to flourish** (使令动植咸遂),
**without any harm or injury** (无残伤者),
hence it is said: **"The Sage constantly saves phenomena, hence there is no abandonment of phenomena"** (故云常善救物，故无弃物).

**Master He Shang Gong** (河上公) **says:**
Thus, the **Sage constantly saves beings** (是以圣人常善救人),
**the Sage’s teaching of loyalty and rectitude** (圣人所以教人忠正者),
is **to save the lives of beings** (欲以救人之性命).
Hence **there is no abandonment of beings** (故无弃人),
**allowing the noble and base to each attain their place** (使贵贱各得其所).

**The Sage constantly saves phenomena** (常善救物),
**the Sage’s teaching to follow the Four Seasons** (圣人所以教民顺四时),
is **to save all phenomena from harm and injury** (以救万物之残伤).
Hence **there is no abandonment of phenomena** (故无弃物),
**the Sage does not demean stone while esteeming jade** (圣人不贱石而贵玉),
**viewing them as one** (视之如一).

**Rong** (荣) **says:**
Thus, the **Sage constantly saves beings** (是以圣人常善救人),
**yet there is no abandonment of beings** (而无弃人).
**If one thing loses its place** (一物失所), **it is mourned and taken into consideration** (虑轸纳隍),
**viewing beings as one’s children** (视人如子),
**how could there be abandonment**? (宁有弃乎).
The **True Sage expounds scriptures** (真圣阐经) **to open enlightenment** (以开化),
**responding to their karmic resonance** (赴感),
**to guide the common** (以遵凡),
**using the Dao/Way to deliver them** (以道济之),
**never omitting or abandoning any** (曾无遗弃).

**The Sage constantly saves phenomena** (常善救物),
**yet there is no abandonment of phenomena** (而无弃物).
**Beginning and end, the Sage employs the Dao/Way** (始终用道),
hence it is said: **"constantly"** (故言常).
**Grace extends to all directions** (惠及万方),
hence it is said: **"virtuous"** (故言善).
**Virtue can broadly deliver** (德能广济),
hence it is said: **"salvation"** (故言救).
**"Phenomena"** (物) **speaks universally of all things** (通言一切),
hence it is said: **"phenomena"** (故言物).

**The Imperial Commentary** (成疏) **says:**
Thus, the **Sage constantly saves beings** (是以圣人常善救人), hence **there is no abandonment of beings** (故无弃人).
The **Sage** (圣人) is **the same as the prior one** (即是前三业清净六根解脱之人也),
**able to take the great vow** (为能发弘誓愿),
**and save all beings** (救度众生),
thus **constantly remaining in the world** (故常在世间),
**responding to all karmic resonances** (有感斯应),
**with compassion and virtue, equal and unceasing** (慈善平等),
**never omitting or abandoning any** (终不遗弃).
**The Sage constantly saves phenomena** (常善救物), yet **there is no abandonment of phenomena** (而无弃物).
**First mentioning beings** (先举人者) **demonstrates the恩 being extended to sentient beings** (恩被有情),
**then mentioning phenomena** (后举物者) **shows the virtue permeating insentient beings** (示仁覃无识).」
