「○ Master Cheng’s Commentary:
If one finds beauty in victory,
they will delight in killing.
If one finds beauty in fine arms,
then they love to wield the sword and spear.

To delight in killing—
this is what all under heaven detest.
With many slain in battle,
they cannot achieve their true ambitions.

The fourth passage broadly cites military laws
to illustrate the Daoist principle of **real wisdom’s victory**—
auspicious matters are placed on the left,
inauspicious matters on the right.
The **Viceroy-General** stands on the left,
the **Supreme-General** on the right.

○ **Imperial Commentary:**
The Viceroy-General is of lower rank,
placed on the left because they do not hold sole authority over killing.
The Supreme-General’s exalted status
places them on the right, as they command military strategy.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
Auspicious matters are placed on the left,
inaspicious matters on the right—
the left embodies the **Yang Principle**, the source of life, hence auspicious.
The right embodies the **Yin Principle**, the path of killing, hence inauspicious.
*The Record of Rites (Liji) – Tan Gong* states:
When the Master stood with his disciples,
he bowed and took the rightmost position.
The disciples also took the rightmost position.
The Master said:
“My disciples’ zeal for learning
is but as my sorrow for my sister’s death.”
The disciples then took the leftmost position.

The Viceroy-General stands on the left,
the Supreme-General on the right—
this is to liken military command to funeral rites.
The Supreme-General, placed on the right,
holds sole authority over killing,
while the Viceroy-General, as deputy,
does not command life and death,
thus standing on the left.

Now, the left is exalted,
the right is lowly—
the Supreme-General, though now placed on the right,
is likened to the funeral rites’ position,
for though they command killing,
they are treated with the solemnity of death.
○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
The left is the auspicious position,
the right is the funeral position.
Now, the Viceroy-General, of lesser rank,
stands on the left,
while the Supreme-General,
of greater rank, stands on the right—
this is to clarify that even if they command killing,
they are placed with the rites of death and mourning.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
The funeral rites place the position on the right,
and now the Supreme-General stands on the right—
this is to liken them to the rites of death.
The departed are honored with **Yin**,
and killing many in battle
is met with tears of sorrow and lamentation.
○ **Imperial Commentary:**
Because life is precious yet must be sacrificed in war,
there is a compassionate and benevolent heart
that mourns the loss,
and this is fitting.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
To wage war and seek victory
must inevitably bring many deaths.
Victory is not beautiful,
so the Supreme-General mourns in sorrow and lamentation.
The people are the foundation of the state—
if they are secure, the state is at peace.
Now, in battle, many are slain,
so the benevolent heart feels sorrow and pity,
and this is indeed appropriate.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
This reflects the fear that one’s own **virtue/power** is thin,
unable to transform the people through the Dao,
and thus harming the innocent.

○ **Master Rong’s Commentary:**
The purpose of arms is to uphold justice
and rescue the people.
To mourn is to lament their straying from the Dao,
to sorrow is to regret the harm done.
In ancient times, the use of arms was guided by **compassion (慈)**,
and military affairs were valued by **virtue/power (德)**,
not by weapons alone.
After defeating the enemy,
the Supreme-General wore plain attire
and took charge of the funeral rites,
accepting condolences as part of the ceremony.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
Wherever arms are used,
slaughter and harm abound.
Thus the Supreme-General mourns,
pitying the loss of life,
fearing that the Dao was not followed
and that the innocent may be harmed.

Victory in battle is treated with funeral rites—
the Supreme-General, though placed on the right,
is likened to the rites of death.
The right is exalted for the living,
yet now the Supreme-General stands on the right—
this is because war is an **unauspicious instrument**,
so they are honored with mourning attire,
though it is not truly a funeral rite.
○ **Imperial Commentary:**
When a warrior gains victory in battle,
they receive their title and stand on the right—
a position not auspicious,
hence it is likened to funeral rites.
But war is merely an **unauspicious instrument**,
so why must they don mourning robes
and use a staff of office
before it can be called funeral rites?
All commentaries on this meaning
claim that such a custom existed in antiquity,
but upon examining the ancient texts,
there is no evidence to support it.
The present interpretation is unsettling,
so it is omitted.

Again, citing the case of Qin Bo weeping before his defeated teacher—
this was lamentation for defeat,
not for victory in battle.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
In ancient times,
when victory was achieved,
the Supreme-General would take the funeral master’s position,
wearing plain attire and mourning,
to show that the **gentleman values virtue/power (德) over arms (兵)**,
and killing is only done when unavoidable.
Their reluctance toward killing
is likened to the sorrow of mourning.

Knowing that later ages would not cease from using arms,
they mourned in sorrow and grief.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
The **gentleman** and the **good person** value the use of the Dao.
When forced to resort to arms,
they do so only out of necessity.
Though they may defeat the enemy,
they do not take it as a good thing,
so they wear plain attire and mourn,
and still observe funeral rites in burial.

Though their martial prowess surpasses their literary skill,
this shows that **strategic expedience (权)** is inferior to **true wisdom (实)**.
In governing the state,
one must resort to arms when necessary,
and to **strategic expedience** when unavoidable.
By this measure,
it is clear that **strategic expedience is weaker than true wisdom**,
and that **martial force is lesser than virtue/power**.

**End of the *Zhuangzi* – *Xuan De* (玄德) Commentary, Volume Eight.**

「Emperor Xuanzong’s Imperial Commentary and Exegesis
*Commentaries by Master He Shang, Lord Yan Junping, and Li Rong*
*Exegesis by Master Xihua, Fa Xuan Ying, and Master Qiang Si of Mengyang*

**Chapter Thirty-Two: Dao Constantly Without Name**

The reason this chapter follows the previous is that the prior chapter illustrates that "good arms are not auspicious," hence one with the Dao does not dwell in them. This chapter demonstrates that if a sovereign and king upholds the Dao, then all things will naturally submit to them.

This chapter is divided into four parts within itself:
The first marks the "Nameless One" to elucidate the Dao,
the second cites the sovereign who upholds the Dao and thereby attracts blessings,
the third introduces the creation of named things and expands their applications,
and the fourth concludes with the Dao descending to the "Nameless One."

**First: Marking the "Nameless One" to Elucidate the Dao.**

The most profound Dao, the true essence of the Way,
is the precious *Zhenjing* of the Supreme Official.
Its source is unfathomable, its nature serene and undisturbed—
length and brevity are equalized,
so that the morning mushroom and the ancient tree share the same lifespan;
foolishness and wisdom are unified,
so that the mythical *Tao* and *Liang* creatures merge into the dual *Zhuang* and *Yuan*.

From the root to the branches, all distinctions dissolve,
unified in speech yet divided in form,
encompassing all phenomena yet returning to the True.
Across the three lives, purity is complete—
names vanish, dust and hues dissolve,
and the transformation manifests:
the white deer appears at *Ren’an*,
the purple cakes descend to *Yinzǔ*.
Its application is present,
yet its name remains ever without—
when sovereigns and kings uphold it,
the *Xianzhang* trees flourish like sweet dew,
and the *Lieshi* naturally incline toward it,
their ears cooled by the breeze of *Chengfeng*,
the Great Harmony without name—
truly, there is good reason for this.

**Dao Constantly Without Name,**
though *Pu* is small,
the world dares not treat it as a subject.

*Imperial Commentary*: The Dao is constant in its application;
this constancy can respond to all things,
and its responses are not singular,
hence "constant without name."

*Imperial Exegesis*: Its application is inexhaustible,
adapting only to what is sensed—
this is the Dao’s constancy.
The constancy lies in its application,
yet its responses are not singular,
hence "constant without name,"
and thus it is said: *Dao Constantly Without Name*.

*Master He Shang* says: The Great Dao can be both yin and yang,
can contract and expand,
can be vast or minute,
can preserve or vanish—
hence it has no constant name.

*Pu* is the wondrous origin.

When speaking of its universal generation, it is called *Dao Yi* (One Dao);
when discussing its refined unity, it is called *Pu*.
The wondrous origin, refined and singular,
thus remains tranquil yet responsive in application.

The craftsman completes all universal generation—
this is the utmost greatness.
Hence, none dare treat the Dao as a subject.

*Lord Rong* says: All named things are universally without constancy;
yet now it is said to return to the constant Dao.
*Pu* is the origin; *chén* (subject) is the lowly.
The constant Dao is the wondrous origin—
neither great nor small,
though great, it cannot be prized,
though small, it cannot be belittled.
If sovereigns and kings uphold it,
all things will naturally submit.

*Imperial Commentary*: If sovereigns and kings uphold the Dao,
refined and singular,
acting without action,
then all things will naturally submit and serve them.

*Imperial Exegesis*: It speaks that if sovereigns and kings embrace and uphold
the wondrous origin, refined and singular,
acting without action or affairs,
then the eight extremes will look upward in transformation,
the four seas will return to virtue,
and all will bathe in virtue and drink in harmony,
naturally submitting and serving.

**Second: Citing the Upholding of the Dao and the Attraction of Auspicious Blessings.**

When Heaven and Earth unite,
they descend sweet dew—
none commands it, yet it naturally equalizes.

*Imperial Exegesis*: When sovereigns and kings uphold the Dao,
bringing about harmony,
there will be no calamities of drought or sandstorms,
the earth will be level and Heaven complete,
the two *qi* blending in equilibrium,
uniting to descend sweet dew—
auspicious blessings will naturally manifest for the sovereigns and kings.

*Master He Shang* says: *Fa Tong* also says:
When Heaven and Earth unite,
it refers to the ruler upholding *Dao De*,
uniting with Heaven and Earth,
harmonizing *qi* so that it flows smoothly,
auspicious blessings naturally descending—
none commands, yet transformation naturally equalizes.

Sweet dew is the fluid of harmonized *qi*.

chunks.original_text: 御注：人君以道政平，始能制御有名之物，故有名之物，亦尽为侯王所有矣。 既，尽也。 ○御疏：制，御也。 有名者，天下有名之物也。 既，尽也。 言侯王抱守精一，则天降善瑞，惠化无心，均平若一。 如此始能制御有名之物，物归有道，故有名之物亦尽为侯王所有矣。 ○河上公曰：始，道也，有名，万物也。 道无名能制於有名，无形能制於有形。 夫将知止。 知止不殆。 御注：若侯王能制有名之物，则夫有名之物，亦将知依止於侯王，知依止有道之君，所以无危殆之事。 ○御疏：殆，危殆也。 侯王若以道而化，万物自宾服，则夫有名之物，亦依止於侯王。 能依止有道之君，所以无危贻之事矣。 故云知止所以不殆。 ○河上公曰：有名之法，尽有情欲，叛道离德，故身致毁辱，经云知止所以不殆。 ○成疏：筌蹄既忘，妙理斯得，止名会实，故无危殆。 ○荣曰：子依母铃无伤害，人依道故无危殆也。 第四譬道下将以结成。 譬道在天下，犹川谷之与江海。 御注：天降甘露以瑞，有道之君在宥天下，天则应之，犹川谷与江海通流耳。 ○御疏：此结侯王守道，则天必应之，故云譬有道之君在理天下，陶以仁德，则自致太平。 和气感天，天瑞必应，犹川谷之水，而与江海通流耳。 王弼曰：此举谕言道不居一天下，今将在天下法。 譬之犹川谷之与江海，川谷为末，以喻於有名，江海是本，以喻於无名。 川谷从何而来，从江海而来，今日欲归何处，还复归於江海。 有名从何而来，从无名而来，今日摄化众生，欲归何处，还归於无名。 河海若无川谷，则无以满，川谷若无江海，则无以流。 无名若无有名，则无以显。 有名若无无名，则无以出。 江海犹川谷，故所以满。 无名由有名，故以显也。 知人者智章第三十三 知人章所以次前者，前者明君王守道则万物自宾，此章明所宾服有道之君。 此一章内，物有三句具一意，连次而来，遂分为四。 第一明自知，自知则明了，第二明自胜，自胜则全强，第三明知足强行，明安贫而乐道，第四结其死而不知，善其不违天理。 第一明自知，自知则明了。 夫明镜以净莹形，幽谷以虚纳物，大冶陶铸，先忌於镇邹，造化分形，必不言於人耳。 则知用智迷道，失所者亡，故七圣驰车，问襄城而不得，一子凝观，坐河阳而冥然。 尧舜以禅让大全，燕秦以争权失国。 是知息智自胜，道洽於谁耶。 知人者智，自知者明。 御注：知者役用以知物，明者融照以鉴微，智则无所不知，明则无所不照。 ○御疏：知，识察也。 夫心与境合，是以生知。 生知之心识察前事，是名知法。 ○成曰：谓照达前境，鉴人机性，大小深浅，无不悉知。 为智自知己身宿命善恶，三代报应，无不明也。 ○河上公曰：能知人好恶，是智。 人能自知贤与不肖，是为反听无声，内视无形，故为明也。 ○荣曰：闻而知之谓之圣，见而知之谓之智，然则外难知者人也，内难知者己也。 鉴人而知善恶者，智也。 照己而知得失者，明也。 知善就君子，如染芳兰，知恶远小人，如去鲍肆。 智得尽之以忠贞，知失除之以悔怀，此乃明智也。 若乃清重玄之路，照虚寂之门，知人者识万境之皆空，自知者体一身之非有，一身非有，内岂食於名利。

「**御注**: The ruler, through *Dao De* governance and equilibrium,
begins to regulate and govern named things—
thus, all named things are entirely under the sway of sovereigns and kings.
*既 (jì)*, here means *exhaustive/all*.

**御疏**: *制 (zhì)*, meaning *to govern/regulate*.
The *有名 (yǒumíng)* are the named things of the world.
*既 (jì)*, here also means *exhaustive/all*.
When sovereigns and kings embrace and uphold the *精一 (jīngyī)* of the Dao,
Heaven descends auspicious blessings,
and benevolent transformations occur without intent—
uniform and balanced as one.

Thus, they begin to govern all named things,
and things return to those who uphold the Dao—
so all named things are entirely under the sway of sovereigns and kings.

**河上公曰**: *始 (shǐ)*, the Dao.
*有名 (yǒumíng)*, all things.
The Dao, though nameless, can regulate the named;
the formless can regulate the formed.
He who knows *止 (zhǐ)* knows cessation.
Knowing cessation brings no peril.

**御注**: If sovereigns and kings can govern named things,
then all named things will also know to depend upon the sovereigns and kings—
to depend upon the ruler who upholds the Dao,
and thus avoid perilous affairs.

**御疏**: *殆 (dài)*, meaning *danger/peril*.
If sovereigns and kings transform through the Dao,
all things naturally submit and serve—
thus, all named things will know to depend upon the sovereigns and kings.
To depend upon the ruler who upholds the Dao,
is to avoid affairs that bring ruin and peril.
Hence, it is said: *Knowing cessation brings no peril*.

**河上公曰**: The laws of the named are all bound by desires,
rebelling against the Dao and departing from *德 (virtue/power)*—
thus, the body incurs destruction and dishonor.
The *经 (sutra/classic)* says: *Knowing cessation brings no peril*.

**成疏**: When the *筌蹄 (quán tí)*—the snares and traps—are forgotten,
the wondrous logic is attained.
*止 (zhǐ)* unites name with reality—
thus, there is no peril.

**荣曰**: The child depends upon the mother’s bell without harm,
just as people depend upon the Dao—
thus, there is no peril.

**Fourth: The Dao/Way in the World, Illustrated by Its Completion.**

The Dao/Way in the world
is like streams and valleys to rivers and seas.

**御注**: Heaven descends sweet dew as an auspicious blessing,
and the ruler who upholds the Dao nurtures the world—
Heaven responds accordingly,
just as streams and valleys flow into rivers and seas.

**御疏**: Here, it illustrates that when sovereigns and kings uphold the Dao,
Heaven must respond to it—
hence, it is said: *The ruler who upholds the Dao governs the world with benevolent virtue*,
and thus brings about universal peace.
Harmonized *qi* moves Heaven,
and Heaven’s auspicious blessings must respond—
like the waters of streams and valleys
flowing into the rivers and seas.

**王弼曰**: This passage clarifies that the Dao does not dwell within the world,
yet today we speak of its laws in the world.
It is likened to streams and valleys flowing into rivers and seas—
streams and valleys are the lesser,
used to illustrate the *有名 (yǒumíng)*—the named;
rivers and seas are the origin,
used to illustrate the *无名 (wúmíng)*—the nameless.

From whence do streams and valleys come?
From rivers and seas.
Where do they return today?
Back to rivers and seas.
From whence do named things come?
From the nameless.
Today, governing all beings,
where do they return?
Back to the nameless.

If rivers and seas lacked streams and valleys,
they would not be full.
If streams and valleys lacked rivers and seas,
they would not flow.
If the nameless lacked the named,
it would not be manifest.
If the named lacked the nameless,
it would not arise.
Rivers and seas are like streams and valleys,
hence they are full.
The named arises from the nameless,
hence it is manifest.

**知人者智 (Chapter Thirty-Three: Knowing People)**

This chapter follows the previous,
for the previous clarifies that when the ruler upholds the Dao,
all things naturally submit and serve—
this chapter elucidates the nature of those who submit and serve the ruler who upholds the Dao.

Within this chapter,
three statements about things convey one meaning,
sequentially linked,
therefore divided into four sections.

**First: Knowing Oneself**
Knowing oneself brings clarity.
The bright mirror reflects shapes with purity,
the deep valley receives things with emptiness,
the great artisan molds and refines—
first, he must be cautious of his *镇邹 (zhèn zōu)*—the balance and measure.
Creation differentiates forms,
yet never speaks to mortals.

Thus, knowing that *智 (zhi)* used in confusion with the Dao
leads to loss,
the seven sages drove their chariots in haste,
questioned Shàngchéng but found no answer—
one child sat in contemplation,
gazing at Héyáng while lost in thought.
Yáo and Shùn achieved greatness through *禅让 (chán ràng)*—the Dao’s transmission.
Yān and Qín lost their kingdoms through *争权 (zhēng quán)*—the struggle for power.

Thus, knowing to still *智 (zhi)* and conquer oneself—
who would not find the Dao harmonized?

Knowing others is *智 (zhi)*,
knowing oneself is *明 (míng)*.

**御注**: *智 (zhi)* discerns through effort to comprehend things,
*明 (míng)* illuminates through unity to perceive subtleties—
*智 (zhi)* knows nothing unknown,
*明 (míng)* reveals nothing unseen.

**御疏**: *知 (zhi)*, to recognize and perceive.
When the heart unites with its object,
it is called *生知 (shēng zhī)*—innate knowledge.
The heart of innate knowledge recognizes and perceives past events—
this is called *知法 (zhī fǎ)*—knowing the law.

**成曰**: To perceive past events clearly,
to discern the nature of others—
great or small, profound or shallow—
nothing remains unknown.
To know one’s own past karma and present virtues and vices,
the retributions of the *三代 (sāndài)*—the Three Dynasties—
nothing remains unclear.

**河上公曰**: To know people’s likes and dislikes—
this is *智 (zhi)*.
People can know their own worth and unworthiness—
this is *反听无声 (fǎn tīng wú shēng)*—listening inwardly without sound,
*内视无形 (nèi shì wú xíng)*—gazing inwardly without form—
thus, it is *明 (míng)*.

**荣曰**: To hear and know is called *圣 (shèng)*—sagehood,
to see and know is called *智 (zhi)*—wisdom.
Then, it is difficult to know others externally,
and difficult to know oneself internally.

To discern others and know their virtues and vices—
this is *智 (zhi)*.
To perceive oneself and know one’s gains and losses—
this is *明 (míng)*.

To know virtue is to associate with the virtuous,
like dyeing in fragrant orchids—
to know vice is to distance oneself from the petty,
like avoiding the fishmonger’s stall.
*智 (zhi)* exhaustively obtains loyalty and integrity,
knowing loss removes it through repentance—
this is the true *明智 (míng zhì)*—wisdom and clarity.

If one follows the path of *清重玄 (qīng zhòng xuán)*—pure, weighty, and profound,
and enters the gate of *虚寂 (xū jì)*—emptiness and tranquility—
those who know others recognize that all phenomena are empty,
those who know themselves understand that the self is not permanent—
the self is not permanent,
how then could one internally feed upon name and gain?
»

chunks.original_text: 万境皆空，外何染於声色。 内外清静，故曰明哉。 物我皆通，故日智也。 按《南华经》曰：黄帝游乎赤水之北，登乎昆仑之丘，而南望还归，遗其玄珠，使智索之而不得，使离朱索之而不得，使契诟索之而不得，乃使象罔。 象罔得之，黄帝曰：异哉，象罔乃可得之乎。 若用人间之巧智辨是与非，欲求道原，未闻斯旨。 惟当灭智，可契真诠。 故经云：非以明民，将与愚之，即其义也。 第二明自胜，自胜则全强。 胜人者有力，自胜者强。 御注：能制胜人者，适可谓有力。 能自胜其心使柔弱者，方可以全其强矣。 ○御疏：胜人者，谓以权智制胜於人，如此之人，适可谓之有力尔。 自胜者，谓自能制胜其心，使心柔弱，柔弱之道，物不能加，故可全其强尔。 故下经云：守柔日强。 又曰：柔胜刚，弱胜强，故云自胜者强。 ○河上公曰：才干胜人，不过有力。 有力之人，叉有其敌。 有其敌者，则强弱未定。 今以性制情，谓之自胜。 自胜之人，无敌於外。 无敌於外者，可谓强矣。 ○荣曰：夫用力者，力大则胜人。 用德者，德高则伏物。 进道修业，自强不息，不溺於非，斯自胜也。 修道者忘怀，则外物无害，故日胜人。 虚心而弱骨日强，故言自胜。 第三明知足强行，明安贫而乐道。 知足者富，强行者有志。 御注：知止足者无贪求，可为富矣。 强力行者不懈怠，可谓有志节矣。 ○御疏：知足在心，心若知足，则无贪求，虽草食瓢饮，傲然自足，可谓富矣。 强勉力行，曾不懈怠，自知自胜，终久不渝，可谓有志节矣。 ○河上公曰：强由动也，人能勤力行道，道亦有意於人。 ○荣曰：知分之人，虽一瓢而为富，贪利之者，积百万而为贫。 饰躬励己为强行，信道弥笃为有志，按《南华经》云：曾子居卫缢抱无表，颜色肿脍，手足胼胝，三日不举火，十年不制衣，正冠而缨绝，捉拎而肘见，纳屦而踵次，曳展而歌商，颂声满天地，若出金石者，天子不得臣，诸侯不得友，故养志者忘形，养形者忘利，盖谓知足也。 第四结其死而不忘，善其不违天理。 不失其所者久，死而不亡者寿。 御注：知足强力，不失其所恒，则是久於其道。 又注：死者分理之终，亡者夭枉之数，寿者一期之尽。 夫知人胜人，必招殃咎，知足强力，乃得天常。 得天常者，死而不亡。 一期之尽，可谓寿矣。 ○御疏：知足强力等行，人所常行，若不失其所恒，即是久能行道者矣。 又解云：同不失所者，则可以长久。 又疏：死者，分理之终。 亡者，夭枉之数。 寿者，一期之尽。 言委顺得常，不失天和，颓然任化，而去者得一期之尽，可谓寿矣。 若不鞭其后，生理不全，虽单豹有婴儿之色，张毅有丰高之贵，不终天理，焉得为之寿乎？ 故《庄子》曰：天下莫寿於殇子，而彭祖为夭。 ○河上公曰：人能自节养，不失其所，爱天之精气，则可以长久。 大道泛兮章第三十四 大道章所以次前者，前章明宾服有道之君，由能自知自胜，此章明能成光大之业，皆为法道忘功。 就此门中，分为三别，第一标大道泛兮，示左右略无封吵，第二功成不有，明小大难与为名，第三举圣人不贵其身，以全光大之业。 第一标大道泛兮，示左右略无封畛。 夫四大居尊，一人为首，明者为之视，智者为之谋，端坐紫宫，无为自得，况大道广泛，具物资生，河上真人腾青云於百丈，淮山仙客，嚼丹桂於三秋，昊主谒葛玄於水中，汉武接上元於云路，则知可左可右，其斯之谓欤。
chunks.translated_text:
The myriad phenomena are empty—
what external defilement could cling to sounds and colors?
Inner and outer purity and stillness—
thus it is called *明 (míng)*.

All things and self are unified—
thus it is called *智 (zhi)*.

According to the *Nanhua Jing* [Southern Flower Scripture]:
The Yellow Emperor wandered in the north of the Red River,
ascended Kunlun’s heights,
and gazing southward, returned—
he lost his *玄珠 (xuán zhū)* [Mysterious Pearl].
He sent *智 (Zhì)* to seek it, but he could not find it;
he sent *离朱 (Lí Zhū)* to seek it, but he could not find it;
he sent *契诟 (Qì Gòu)* to seek it, but he could not find it—
then he sent *象罔 (Xiàng Wǎng)*.

*象罔 (Xiàng Wǎng)* obtained it,
and the Yellow Emperor said:
“Strange! *象罔* alone could retrieve it.”
If one employs worldly cleverness and discrimination,
seeking to distinguish right from wrong,
and desires to trace the origin of the Dao—
this has never been heard of.
Only by extinguishing *智 (zhi)* can one grasp the true meaning.

Thus the Scripture says:
*“Not to enlighten the people,
but to let them remain in their simplicity*—
this is its intent.”

---

**Second: Clarity in Self-Mastery**
Self-mastery preserves one’s strength.
He who overcomes others has force,
he who overcomes himself is strong.

**御注 (Yù Zhù):**
One who can subdue others may be called strong in force.
But one who subdues his own heart, rendering it gentle and weak,
can alone preserve his true strength.

**御疏 (Yù Shū):**
He who overcomes others relies on cunning and intelligence to prevail—
such a man may be called strong in force.
He who overcomes himself masters his own heart,
making it gentle and weak—
nothing external can overcome him,
thus he preserves his strength.

Hence the Scripture below says:
*“Guard the gentle, and strength will endure.”*
And again:
*“The gentle overcomes the rigid,
the weak overcomes the strong.”*
Thus, self-mastery is true strength.

**河上公 (Hé Shàng Gōng) says:**
One who excels in talent and skill may merely be strong in force.
But a strong man has his rival.
If he has a rival, his strength and weakness remain undetermined.
Now, to govern emotions with innate nature—
this is self-mastery.
The self-mastered have no external rival.
Without external rivals, they are truly strong.

**荣 (Róng) says:**
He who exerts force—
the greater his strength, the more he overcomes others.
He who cultivates *德 (virtue/power)*—
the higher his virtue, the more he subdues all things.
Advancing the Dao and refining one’s practice,
strengthening oneself without ceasing,
not sinking into error—
this is self-mastery.
The Daoist, forgetting all concerns,
is unharmed by external things—
thus he overcomes others.
With a vacant heart and weak bones, strength endures—
hence the saying: *self-mastery is strength.*

---

**Third: Clarity in Contentment and Resolute Action**
Know contentment to be rich,
strengthen resolve to have purpose.
He who knows sufficiency is wealthy,
he who perseveres has resolve.

**御注 (Yù Zhù):**
He who knows to be content lacks greed—
this is true wealth.
He who strives with unflagging effort is resolute—
this is true purpose.

**御疏 (Yù Shū):**
Contentment lies in the heart.
If the heart knows sufficiency,
there is no greed—
even with coarse food and gourd-drinking,
he stands proud and self-sufficient—
this is wealth.
With unremitting effort and perseverance,
self-aware and self-mastered,
his resolve never wavers—
this is true purpose.

**河上公 (Hé Shàng Gōng) says:**
Strength comes from action.
If a man diligently pursues the Dao,
the Dao responds to him.

**荣 (Róng) says:**
He who knows his place—
though he drinks from a gourd, he is rich.
He who covets gain—
though he hoards a hundred fortunes, he is poor.
Adorning oneself and striving with vigor—
this is resolute action.
Firm faith in the Dao, ever deepening—
this is true purpose.

According to the *Nanhua Jing* [Southern Flower Scripture]:
*Zengzi*, dwelling in Wei, wrapped himself in rags,
his face swollen and emaciated,
his hands and feet calloused,
he went three days without fire,
a decade without new clothes.
His crown’s ribbon frayed,
his sleeves torn to the elbow,
his sandals worn to the heel,
he dragged his feet while singing *Shang* hymns—
his voice filled heaven and earth,
as if struck from metal and stone.
The Son of Heaven could not make him a subject,
the feudal lords could not make him a friend.
Thus, he who nourishes his purpose forgets his form,
he who nourishes his form forgets gain—
this is the meaning of *contentment.*

---

**Fourth: Clarity in Accepting Death with Integrity**
To accept death without forgetting,
to act in accordance with Heaven’s principle—
he who does not lose his place endures,
he who dies without perishing attains longevity.

**御注 (Yù Zhù):**
Knowing contentment and persevering,
never losing one’s place—
this is to endure in the Dao.
Again:
Death is the end of one’s appointed fate,
perishing is the measure of untimely ruin,
longevity is the completion of one’s allotted span.
He who knows others and overcomes them
inevitably invites calamity.
He who knows contentment and perseveres
attains Heaven’s constant way.
He who attains Heaven’s constant way
dies without perishing.
The completion of one’s span—
this is longevity.

**御疏 (Yù Shū):**
Knowing contentment and resolute action—
these are common practices.
If one does not lose his constant way,
he is one who endures in the Dao.
Again:
He who does not lose his place
can endure long.
Again:
Death is the end of one’s appointed fate,
perishing is the measure of untimely ruin,
longevity is the completion of one’s allotted span.
If one submits to Heaven’s harmony,
does not lose the natural flow,
and departs in tranquility,
he completes his allotted span—
this is longevity.
If one is not driven onward,
his vital essence is incomplete—
though *Dan Bao* may have the complexion of an infant,
though *Zhang Yi* may boast noble stature,
if they do not fulfill Heaven’s principle,
how can they be called long-lived?
Thus *Zhuangzi* says:
*“None are longer-lived than the stillborn child,
while Pengzu is counted as untimely.”*

**河上公 (Hé Shàng Gōng) says:**
If a man regulates himself,
does not lose his place,
and cherishes Heaven’s vital essence,
he can endure long.

---

**Chapter Thirty-Four: The Chapter on the Great Dao**
This chapter follows the previous one,
for the earlier text illuminated the sovereign who serves the Dao—
one who knows himself and masters himself.
This chapter reveals how to accomplish and magnify great deeds,
all for the sake of the Dao, forgetting merit.

Within this gate, it is divided into three sections:
First, it marks *“The Great Dao is vast”*—
showing that left and right have no boundaries.
Second, *“Merit accomplished, not possessed”*—
illustrating that great and small cannot be named.
Third, *“The Sage does not prize his body”*—
to preserve the brilliance of great deeds.

**First: Marking *“The Great Dao is vast”*—
showing that left and right have no constraints.**

The Four Sovereigns reside in eminence,
one as their leader.
The enlightened guide their vision,
the wise devise their plans.
Seated in majesty at the Purple Palace,
they act without action and find fulfillment.
How much more so the Great Dao—
vast and boundless,
providing for all things and nurturing life.
The River Above True Person soars on the hundred-zhang clouds,
the Huai Mountain Immortal chews the autumn *dan* osmanthus,
the Celestial Lord pays homage to *Ge Xuan* in the waters,
and the Han Emperor meets the Celestial Official on the cloud path—
thus it is known:
It can be to the left or to the right—
this is what is meant.

chunks.original_text: 大道泛兮，其可左右。 御注：大道泛兮，无系而能应物，左右无所偏名。 ○御疏：泛兮者，无系之貌也。 言道之为物，非阴非阳，非柔非刚，泛然无系，能应众象，可左可右，无所偏名。 故《庄子》曰：夫道未始有封。 ○河上公曰：泛是无滞言道，泛泛若浮，若有若无，视之不见，说之殊离，罄无不宜，在人所用，故用周内外，左右咸得，故云其可左右，不可左右也。 万物侍之以生而不辞。 御疏：言天地万物皆恃赖大道通生之功，以全其生理，而大道生化，妙本无心，虽则物恃以生，而道不辞以为劳倦。 又解云：物不辞谢於道尔。 ○河上公曰：恃，待也，辞，惮也。 物实资待至道而得生成，道能生成而不辞惮也。 第二功成不有，明小大难与为名。 功成而不名有。 御注：言万物恃赖冲用之道而生化，而道不辞惮以为劳，功用备成，不名己有。 ○御疏：功者生成之功也，言大道生物之功备成，而不以其物为己之有。 又解：道之生物虽则功成，其功虽成，曾不名有，言忘功也。 ○成疏：生化群品，至功潜被，而归功於物，故不有功名。 爱养万物而不为主，常无欲可名於小。 御注：爱养群材，而不宰於物，於物无欲，则可名於小，言不可名小也。 ○御疏：此声解义也。 云可名小者，是不可名小尔。 夫道生#2万物，爱养熟成而不为主宰，衣被万物，常无欲心，岂是道之狭小耶。 故云可名於小者，言不可名於小。 ○成疏：衣被者，覆育也。 虽覆育万物而匿德藏名，泊然无形，故不为主，似若微小，以是声义，言不小也。 万物归之而不为主，可名於大。 御注：爱养之，故万物归之，有万物不同，而不为主，则可名为大。 言不可名大，非小非大，故以难名矣。 ○御疏：万物归之者，归道生成之功也。 言万物归道，道不为主，有此万物弃而不收，岂是道不广大。 故云可名於大尔。 既云可左可右，所以非小非大。 非小非大，固难与为名。 注云：有万物不同者，《庄子》文也。 ○成疏：道能生长为物所归，譬彼大海，方兹虚谷，虽物所归，不为物主，既不为物主，可名大耶。 言不可名大。 第三举圣人不贵其身，以全光大之业。 是以圣人终不为大，故能成其大。 御注：是以圣人法道忘功，终不自为光大，故能成其光大之业。 ○御疏：言理天下之圣人，布德施惠，淳风偃化，物遂生成，法道忘功，不自为尊大，故能成其光大之业也。 ○成疏：明体道圣人，忘我存物，静退谦柔，终不为大，只为先物后己，忘功忘大，故为众圣之长，独居三界之尊，而成其大也。 道德真经玄德慕疏卷之九竟 #1弛：原作『施』，据文义改。 #2生：原无生字，据文义补。 宗御注并疏　河上公严君平李荣注　西华法师成玄英疏　蒙阳强思齐纂 执大象章第三十五 大象章所以次前者，前章无方之用，利物忘功，故次此章，显忘功之人，为物之所归往，就此章内，文有三重，第一明物之归依，皆获利益，第二举乐饵为譬，表理教虚玄，第三示非色非声，而妙用无尽。 第一明物之归依，皆获利益。 夫五岳分形，泰山为长，三才肇位，圣主居尊，举纲则众目自至，握枢则群方。 是执大象也，天下归焉，虚忘之德既弘，坐进之言可大，岂比阳春白雪，郢曲奏而成虚，芳饵红鳞，过客止而无实，则知玄言味澹，俗士抱之而无知，金格理清，愚夫求之而罕得，非执大象者，孰能体之乎。
chunks.translated_text:
**The Great Dao is boundless—
it can be to the left or to the right.**
*Commentary (御注):*
The Great Dao is boundless—
unconstrained yet responsive to all things,
left and right without partiality.

*Explanatory Commentary (御疏):*
"Boundless" describes its unconstrained nature.
The Dao is neither yin nor yang,
neither soft nor hard—
boundless and unrestrained,
responding to all phenomena,
capable of left or right,
without partiality.
Thus *Zhuangzi* says:
*"The Dao has never had boundaries."*

*River Master (河上公) says:*
"Boundless" speaks of the Dao’s unfettered flow—
vast and floating, like presence and absence,
visible yet elusive, spoken yet divergent,
exhausting all yet never inadequate,
lying in human use—
thus it encompasses all within and without,
left and right alike,
so it is said: *It can be to the left or to the right—
yet cannot be confined to left or right.*

All things rely on it for life without complaint.
*Explanatory Commentary:*
All things under Heaven depend on the Great Dao’s generative power
to fulfill their nature,
yet the Dao’s transformation is wondrous and heartless—
though things rely on it for life,
the Dao does not weary of the labor.

*Alternative Explanation:*
Things do not reject the Dao.

*River Master says:*
"Rely" means "depend upon,"
"complaint" means "avoidance."
Things truly depend on the Perfect Dao for their formation,
yet the Dao forms them without avoidance.

---
**Second: When deeds are complete, one does not claim them—
illuminating the difficulty of naming small or great.**

Deeds are complete yet not claimed as one’s own.
*Commentary:*
Things rely on the Dao’s spontaneous action for their transformation,
yet the Dao does not weary of the labor,
its functions fully realized—
it does not claim them as its own.

*Explanatory Commentary:*
"Deeds" refers to the generative function.
The Great Dao’s work of nurturing life is complete,
yet it does not regard the things it creates as its own.

*Alternative Explanation:*
Though the Dao’s creation is complete,
its deeds, though complete, are never claimed—
this is the forgetting of deeds.

*Further Explanation:*
It transforms all beings,
its subtle work silently accomplished,
yet the merit is attributed to the things themselves—
thus it does not claim deeds or names.

---
It cherishes all things yet does not rule them,
constantly without desire—
this is what makes it *not* small.
*Commentary:*
It nurtures all things yet does not dominate them;
toward things, it has no desire—
thus it can be called *not* small.

*Explanatory Commentary:*
This is a rhetorical inversion.
To say "it can be called small"
is to say it *cannot* be called small.
The Dao generates and nurtures all things to maturity
without ruling over them,
clothing and covering all things,
yet without desire—
how could this be the Dao’s narrowness?
Thus, to say "it can be called small"
is to say it *cannot* be called small.

*Further Explanation:*
"Clothing and covering" means nurturing.
Though it nurtures all things,
it conceals its virtue and hides its name,
serene and formless,
thus not ruling—
though it seems minute,
by this reasoning, it is *not* small.

---
All things return to it yet it does not rule—
this is what makes it *not* great.
*Commentary:*
It cherishes them, so all things return to it;
though there are myriad differences among things,
it does not rule—
thus it can be called *not* great.
To say it cannot be called great
is neither small nor great—
thus it is difficult to name.

*Explanatory Commentary:*
"All things return to it" refers to the Dao’s generative function.
Though all things return to the Dao,
the Dao does not rule—
how could this not be vast and great?
Thus it is said: *It can be called great.*

---
Since it can be to the left or to the right,
it is neither small nor great—
thus it is difficult to name.

*Commentary:*
There are myriad differences among things—
this is from *Zhuangzi*.

*Further Explanation:*
The Dao can grow and nurture things,
like the great sea or vast valleys—
though things return to it,
it does not rule over them.
Since it does not rule,
can it be called great?
Thus it cannot be called great.

---
**Third: The Sage does not prize his body—
to preserve the brilliance of great deeds.**

Thus the Sage never claims greatness,
and so achieves greatness.

*Commentary:*
Therefore, the Sage follows the Dao and forgets deeds,
never seeking his own brilliance,
and so accomplishes his great deeds.

*Explanatory Commentary:*
The Sage who governs the world
spreads virtue and bestows benefits,
establishing pure winds and transforming customs,
things thus flourishing—
following the Dao and forgetting deeds,
not exalting himself,
and so accomplishes his great deeds.

*Further Explanation:*
The Sage embodies the Dao,
forgets self to cherish others,
quiet and retiring, humble and yielding,
never claiming greatness—
only prioritizing others over self,
forgetting deeds and greatness,
thus becoming the leader of all sages,
solely honored in the Three Realms,
and accomplishing greatness.

---
**End of Volume Nine of the *True Virtue Commentary* on the *Dao De Jing***
*#1 "Prestige" (弛): Original text had "施" (bestow), corrected for meaning.*
*#2 "Generates" (生): Missing in original, supplied for meaning.*

*Compiled from:
Commentaries of Lord River Master (河上公严君平),
Li Rong’s Notes (李荣注),
Master Xihua’s Explanations (西华法师成玄英疏),
and Master Qiang Sisi’s Compilation (蒙阳强思齐纂).*

---
**Chapter Thirty-Five: The Great Symbol**
*Why this chapter follows:*
The previous chapter spoke of boundless, benefit-giving action,
forgetting deeds—
thus this chapter follows,
revealing that those who forget deeds
are where all things turn.
Within this chapter, the text has three layers:
First, it clarifies that all things return to it for benefit,
Second, it uses the analogy of bait to illustrate
the subtle, ineffable principle of teaching,
Third, it shows that it is neither form nor sound,
yet its wondrous use is inexhaustible.

---
**First: Clarifying that all things return for benefit.**

The Five Peaks manifest their forms,
with Tai Mountain as the longest.
The Three Powers establish their ranks,
with the Sage Ruler in eminence.
When the halter is held, all eyes follow;
when the pivot is grasped, all directions align—
this is *holding the Great Symbol*.
Under Heaven, all return to it.
Its virtue of emptiness and forgetting is vast,
its seated teachings are great—
how could it compare to
Yang Spring’s White Snow,
or *Ying* melodies performed in vain,
or red bait luring fish without substance?
Thus it is known:
The flavor of profound speech is subtle,
yet common scholars embrace it without understanding;
the resonance of the golden bell is pure,
yet fools seek it and rarely find it.
If not for those who hold the Great Symbol,
who else could embody it?

chunks.original_text: 执大象，天下往。 御注：大象，道也。 帝王执持大道，以理天下，万物归往矣。 ○御疏：执，持也。 大象，道也。 此言人君执持大道，以理天下，无为无事，物遂其生，候日观风，皆归有道，故云天下往。 ○河上公曰：执，守也。 象，道也。 圣人守大道，则天下万民移心归往之。 治身则天降神明，往来於己也。 ○荣曰：大象无形，无形者虚无之大道。 执，专也，持也，能持身於玄德之境，专心於幽寂之门，有道则物归，故言天下往也。 ○成疏：执，持也，此不执而执，执无所执。 大象，犹大道之法象也，即前章忘成大之圣人，持无形之象，常善救物，故为天下之所归往也。 《庄子》云：王驰立不教，坐不议，虚而往，实而归，宣尼将引天下归之是也。 往而不害，安平泰。 御注：物往而不伤害，则安於泰平矣。 ○御疏：言天下四方之人，慕化而往，帝王以道绥抚，而不伤害之，则安於太平者矣。 平者，言政教之和平也。 大者，言功业之光大也。 ○河上公曰：万民归往而不伤害，则国安家宁而太平矣。 治身不害神明，则身体安而大寿也。 ○荣曰：油云布而万物润，膏雨降而百草滋，但以被微物而有益，是知归大道而无害，无害之理，其政云何，身神不动日安，死生泯然日平，彼此玄通日泰也。 ○○成疏：太，大也。 言苍生往至圣所，皆获利益而无损害，所获之利，即是安和等大乘之法。 不害则明其技苦，安平则语其与乐。 第二举乐饵为譬，表理教虚玄。 乐与饵，过客止。 御注：乐以声聚，饵以味聚，过客少留，非久长也。 ○御疏：乐，音乐也。 饵，饮食也。 此举喻也。 言人君执大象，而天下之人则归往，亦如人家有音乐饮食，则行过之客，皆为之留止尔。 ○河上公曰：饵，美也。 过客一也，人能乐美於道，则一留止。 一者去盈而处虚，忽忽如过客。 ○荣曰：五音之声，乐也。 八珍之味，饵也。 百年寄身，过客也。 止，留也，依也。 归往於道，可以平泰，物情不悟，少能依止，乃留心於丝竹，以此畅情，依身於兰桂，用兹适己，不能执象，欲泰难乎。 ○成疏：乐，丝竹官商也，饵，饮食滋味也。 乐有声可悦，饵有味可玩，故暂过之客，逢必止住耽爱也。 道之出口，澹乎其无味。 御注：人君以道德清净为教，初出於口，澹乎其无味，不似俗中言教，有亲誉畏侮等也。 ○御疏：道之出口者，言人君约道德清净之法，以为不言无为之教者，初出於口，澹然无味，岂如俗中有亲誉畏侮等，以为滋味乎。 ○河上公曰：道出入於口澹澹，非如五味有酸咸甘苦辛也。 ○荣曰：繁华者物情之所悦，虚寂者人性不能安，情悦谓之为美，不安谓之为澹也。 ○成疏：至道虚寂，其体希夷，所以出口澹然无味，非如乐饵可骯可悦，故音乐有声，行者为之止住，道言无味，学者罕见惠能。 嗟乎世人迷妄之甚，但能淫听有声之声，诅能咀嚼无味之味耶。 深叹愚徒，故有斯譬。 第三示非色非声，而妙用无尽。 视之不足见，听之不足闻，用之不可既。 御注：以道镇静，初无言教，故视不足见，听不足闻，而淳风大行，万物和泰，岁计有余，故用不可既。 既，尽也。 ○御疏：既，尽也。 道化无为，澹然平正，既不为察察之苛急，亦无滋彰之法令，故视不足见，听不足闻，而岁计有余，淳风和畅，动植咸遂，具物光亨，故用不可尽也。

「Holding the Great Symbol, all under Heaven come forth.  *[The Great Symbol] is the Dao/Way.  When the Sage Ruler upholds the Great Dao, to govern all under Heaven, all things return and follow.*

*[The Great Symbol] is the Dao/Way.  This speaks of the ruler holding the Great Dao to govern all under Heaven—without action or affairs, things flourish in their natural order.  Observing the sun and winds, all return to the Dao, thus it is said that all under Heaven come forth.*

*River Master said:  "Holding" means guarding.  "Symbol" is the Dao/Way.  The Sage guards the Great Dao, and thus all people under Heaven turn their hearts and follow.*

*Rong said:  The Great Symbol is formless, the formless being the vast and empty Dao.  "Holding" means to focus and uphold oneself within the realm of profound virtue, to concentrate one’s heart at the gate of quiet seclusion.  When one follows the Dao, all things return, hence it is said that all under Heaven come forth.*

*[Master] Cheng’s commentary:  "Holding" means upholding, yet this is not holding while holding—it is upholding without upholding anything.  The Great Symbol is like the great Dao’s law and image, that is, the Sage from the previous chapter who upholds the formless Symbol, always skillfully rescuing all things.  Thus, all under Heaven come forth and follow.  The *Zhuangzi* says:  "The Sage stands without instruction, sits without discussion, emptiness brings forth, fullness returns—Confucius would lead all under Heaven to follow him."  This is the same.  When all come forth without harm, peace and tranquility prevail.*

*[The Great Symbol] is the Dao/Way.  When the Sage Ruler upholds the Great Dao, all under Heaven come forth and follow, just as when a household has music and food, passing travelers will stop and stay.  This is a metaphor.*

*River Master said:  "Bait" is beauty.  The passing traveler is one and the same—if one can find beauty and joy in the Dao, then they will stop and stay.  "One" means to depart from excess and dwell in emptiness, drifting like a passing traveler.*

*Rong said:  The five tones of music are the "bait" of joy.  The eight delicacies of food are the "bait" of taste.  A hundred years of life is but a passing traveler.  "Stop" means to linger, to depend.  To return and follow the Dao, one may attain peace and tranquility.  But if beings do not awaken, few will remain—only those who fix their hearts on strings and pipes, using them to indulge their emotions, or who cling to orchids and cassia, relying on these for comfort, cannot uphold the Symbol.  To seek tranquility is difficult indeed.*

*[Master] Cheng’s commentary:  Music is the tones of strings and pipes, the five notes of *guan, shang, jiao, zhi, yu*.  Bait is the savor of food and drink.  Music has pleasing sounds, bait has flavors to delight in—thus even transient travelers, upon encountering them, will stop and linger in love.  The Dao’s utterance is subtle, without taste—*

*[The Great Symbol] is the Dao/Way.  When the Sage Ruler upholds the Great Dao, to govern all under Heaven, all things return and follow.  The governance is without form, yet its efficacy is boundless.*

*[The Great Symbol] is the Dao/Way.  The Sage upholds the Great Dao, and thus all under Heaven’s people turn their hearts and follow.  Governing oneself without harming clarity, then the body is at peace and longevity is assured.*

*Rong said:  When the misty clouds spread and all things are nourished, when the fragrant rains descend and every plant thrives—this is but the benefit of the Dao’s embrace, without harm.  The principle of non-harm: how does it manifest in governance?  When body and spirit remain undisturbed, there is ease; when life and death are indistinct, there is tranquility; when all is harmoniously interconnected, there is great peace.*

*[Master] Cheng’s commentary:  "Tranquility" is greatness.  When the common folk come to the Sage’s dwelling, all gain benefit without harm.  The benefit they gain is the peace and greatness of the teachings of the Mahayana.  Non-harm reveals the skillful means of suffering; peace and tranquility speak of harmony and delight.*

*[The Great Symbol] is the Dao/Way.  The Dao’s transformation is without action, subtle and balanced—neither the scrutiny of harsh laws nor the display of ostentatious decrees.  Thus, it is not seen or heard, yet its pure influence prevails, and each year there is abundance.  The governance is harmonious and flourishing, all things grow and thrive, the myriad beings radiant and complete.  Hence its efficacy cannot be exhausted.*

Thus, it is invisible when gazed upon, inaudible when listened to.  Yet each year there is abundance, the pure winds harmonious and unrestrained.  All that moves and grows flourishes, the myriad beings radiant and complete—hence its efficacy cannot be exhausted.*

The Master of the Yellow River said:
*"To gaze upon it is not to see"*—*"see"* means *to obtain*. The Dao is formless; unlike the five colors—blue, red, white, black, and yellow—it cannot be grasped by sight. *"To listen to it is not to hear"*—the Dao is unlike the five tones—*gong*, *shang*, *jiao*, *zhi*, and *yu*—which can be heard by the ear. *"Its use cannot be exhausted"*—when the Dao is applied to govern a state, the nation grows wealthy and the people flourish; when applied to cultivate the self, life is prolonged without end.

Honor said: *"Exhausted"* means *complete*. What is visible to the eye is dazzled by hues of green and yellow; what the ear hears is deceived by tones of *gong* and *zhi*; what the heart covets is blinded by treasures and riches. Though treasures serve utility, their use is finite. Though sounds may please, the deaf remain distant. Though colors may charm, the blind are near. Thus, one who knows to cease indulging in pleasures finds rest.

Yet the Dao of tranquility and non-action—though unseen by the eye—governs with penetrating clarity, though unheard by the ear—discerns with profound acuity. Though the mind cannot fathom it, those attuned to it act without depletion. The common and the Daoist differ thus; those bound by gain and harm are as such.

Master Cheng’s commentary:
*"To gaze upon it is not to see"*—the Supreme Dao is profound and mysterious, transcending form and color, unlike food and drink, which cannot be sought through mere visual perception. *"To listen to it is not to hear"*—the Great Sound is subtle beyond tone, its essence not like *gong* or *jiao*; it is not grasped by the ears as bells and drums are. The words of the Sage, though spoken, are but examples of their meaning. *"Its use cannot be exhausted"*—*"exhausted"* means *complete*. The words of the Supreme Dao are serene and boundless, neither sound nor color, transcending sight and hearing. Like a mirror’s heart, it reflects all that comes; like a valley’s echo, it responds as it is stirred. Thus, the use of the Dao, though seemingly without action, is inexhaustible.

**Chapter Thirty-Six: "When One Would Contract It"**
This chapter follows the previous one, which expounds on the Great Sage’s forgetfulness of merit as the refuge of all things. It now reveals the Sage’s use of expedient means in forgetfulness of merit.

The Sage adapts to myriad paths; the responses are not singular. Sometimes, following the circumstances, they teach lesser doctrines; sometimes, arousing aspiration, they expound the Great Vehicle. Thus, there are true and expedient bodies, real and expedient wisdom. They employ expedient means to honor inferior disciples and uphold the real to guide superior ones. Within expedient and real, there are distinctions of superiority and inferiority. This chapter briefly elucidates this meaning.

Within this chapter, three distinctions unfold:
1. The expedient Dao benefits beings, expanding the paths of governance.
2. Measuring the two wisdoms, it clarifies that expedient does not surpass the real.
3. It demonstrates that the expedient Dao cannot be revealed to all.

**First: The expedient Dao benefits beings, expanding the paths of governance.**
The Great Dao governs all actions, yet the foolish calculate in vain—like one drinking from the river on the verge of death, wearying in futile pursuit of the sun. To absorb dew and preserve life, one rejoices in the hope of ascending to the clouds. Spring’s fragrance and summer’s lushness unfold in their seasons; rain disperses, clouds gather, and the seven celestial officials align. Sometimes, reversal brings harmony, illustrating the sage’s clear laws. Sometimes, transformation renews, teaching the virtuous to retreat quietly.

What of the blind? Though ignorant, they linger in the gates of affection and desire, inevitably losing the realm of stillness. Like a fish escaping water or a sharp blade shown to all, such common beings—how can their lamentations be exhausted?

When one would contract it, they must first fully expand it.

chunks.original_text: 将欲弱之，必固强之。 将欲废之，必固兴之。 将欲夺之，必固与之。 是谓微明。 御注：经云：正言若反，《易》云：异以行权。 权，反经而合义者也。 故君子行权贵於合义，小人用之则为砟谲。 孔子曰：可与立，未可与权，信矣。 故老君前章云执大象，斯谓之实。 此章继以歙敛，是谓之权。 砍量众生根性，故以权实覆却相服，令必致於性命之域。 而惑者乃云非道德之意．何其迷而不悟哉。 故将欲歙敌众生情欲，则先开张，极其侈心，令自困於爱欲，则当歙敛矣。 强弱等义，略与此同。 此道甚微，而效则明着，故云是谓微明。 ○御疏：翕，敌也。 此明圣人用权道以摄化众生也。 夫人既有钝根利根，教亦有权有实。 圣人欲量众生根性，故以权实覆却相明，利根众生见善则迁，有过则玫，略示方便，则深达根源。 钝根众生，惑滞滋久，自非以权摄化，不可令其归往，故将歌翕敛其情欲者，则先开张，极其侈心，令自困於爱欲，即当自歙敛矣。 强弱等义，亦复如是，推而行之，无不信者。 乍闻斯语，以为非道之意，深达玄极，然后明权实之由。 故注云君子行权贵於合义，小人用之以为砟谲。 下文又云不可示人者，正以权道之难故尔。 ○河上公曰：将欲歙之，必固张之，先开张之者，欲极其奢淫也。 将欲弱之，必固强之，先强大之者，欲使通祸也。 将歌废之，铃固兴之，先兴之者，欲使其骄危也。 将欲夺之，铃固与之，先与之者，歌使极其贪心也。 是谓微明，此四者其道微，其效明也。 ○严曰：此四者明绝圣而德自起，废智而化自行，翕天下之心而使自张，弱天下之志而使自强矣。 ○荣曰：将欲歙之，必固张之，将欲塞兑而闭门，愚夫不服，纵其开兑而济事，困而后已。 将欲弱之，必固强之，将欲息其雄猛之心，纵其刚强之志，柔弱生之徒，刚强死之徒，苦至当止也。 将欲废之，必固兴之，欲衰而更盛，物极而自反。 将欲夺之，必固与之，欲夺其恶，恶行不除，恶积灭身，临时自悟。 是谓微明，上之权道，观之则未似施教，究理则极有潜资，甚自微妙分明，历然有益，故谓微明。 八十一章，广陈化导，而凡情有系，所执不同，以实示之而不从，将权化之令知返。 玄教深远，左右宜之，权释辨於前，实解彰於后，欲歙敛之，开经化之，欲弱俗情，强其仙骨，欲废邪志，与之正道，欲夺恶行，与之善业。 ○成疏：将欲歙之，必固张之，歙，合也，敛也。 将欲行权，摄化群品，歙敛不为食染者，必先开张纵任，极其奢淫，然后歙之。 昔老君西入罽宾化胡之日，初恣其凶悖，后化之以道是也。 其委曲逗留具在文始内传。 将欲弱之，必固强之，欲令归道柔弱，必先极其强大然后示以雌柔。 将欲废之，必固兴之，欲废其残犷者，必固恣其凶暴，凶暴既极可以废之。 即胡王肆其猛毒，烧溺老君水火既不为灾然后为其说法是也。 将欲夺之。 必固与之，先恣其恶，名日与之，后令归善，名日夺之。 故老君先示凡迹，所以恣其刚戾，后见神通，於是胡人降伏，方得夺其凶恶，令归善道。 此四对义势相似，只言初浅后深耳。 上机之人，闻实即悟，下根之者，要假於权，此则增法除妄。 是谓微明，上来权道虽复微密，而甚有明验也。

The Way that would contract must first fully expand it.
The Way that would weaken must first fully strengthen it.
The Way that would abandon must first fully elevate it.
The Way that would take must first fully give it.
This is called **subtle luminosity**.

**Commentary:** The Classic says: *"Upright speech seems contrary."* The *Yijing* says: *"Diverge to exercise authority."* Authority is that which, though contrary to the Way, aligns with principle.

Thus, the sage exercises authority while valuing alignment with principle, while the petty man uses it for deceit and guile. Confucius said: *"One may stand with him, but not yet exercise authority with him—truly so."* Therefore, the Old Master in the previous chapter spoke of holding the Great Image—this is called **substance**. This chapter follows with contraction—this is called **authority**.

Measuring the roots of sentient beings, he thus covers and reverses with substance and authority, compelling them to reach the realm of nature and life. Yet the deluded claim this is not the Dao’s intent—how deeply they err and fail to awaken!

When one would contract the emotions of sentient beings, first expand them, exhausting their extravagant desires, so that they become ensnared in love and lust—then contraction follows. The meanings of strength and weakness are similarly applied.

This Dao is most subtle, yet its effects are clearly manifest—hence, it is called **subtle luminosity**.

**Exegesis:** *Teru* (合) means to contract. This reveals the Sage’s use of authority to transform and guide sentient beings.

Since people have dull and sharp roots, and teaching has both authority and substance, the Sage measures the roots of sentient beings. Thus, with authority and substance, he covers and reverses, revealing the truth: sharp-rooted beings, seeing virtue, turn toward it; having faults, they contract. A slight demonstration suffices to reach their depths. Dull-rooted beings, long mired in delusion, unless transformed through authority, cannot be led to return. Therefore, when contracting the emotions of those who would expand them, first expand them, exhausting their extravagant desires—then they will naturally contract.

The meanings of strength and weakness are likewise so. Extend this principle, and none will fail.

At first hearing, one may take this as contrary to the Dao, but upon deep understanding, the purpose of authority and substance becomes clear. Hence the commentary: *"The sage exercises authority while valuing alignment with principle; the petty man uses it for deceit and guile."* The following text further states that it should not be shown to others—precisely because authority is so difficult to wield.

**Master He Shang Gong** said:
The Way that would contract must first fully expand it—first expanding it is to exhaust their licentiousness.
The Way that would weaken must first fully strengthen it—first strengthening them is to make them suffer calamity.
The Way that would abandon must first fully elevate it—first elevating them is to make them proud and perilous.
The Way that would take must first fully give it—first giving it is to exhaust their greedy hearts.
This is called **subtle luminosity**—these four methods are subtle in their Dao, yet their effects are clearly manifest.

**Yan** said:
These four methods show that when the Sage is extinguished, virtue naturally arises; when wisdom is abandoned, transformation naturally proceeds; contracting the hearts of all under Heaven while making them expand; weakening the resolve of all under Heaven while making them strong.

**Rong** said:
The Way that would contract must first fully expand it—when one would close the *Gui* (兑) and shut the door, the foolish do not comply. Thus, one opens the *Gui* and accomplishes the matter, exhausting them until they cease.
The Way that would weaken must first fully strengthen it—when one would still their fierce and mighty hearts, one indulges their rigid resolve. The weak perish, the strong endure—suffering reaches its limit and must stop.
The Way that would abandon must first fully elevate it—when one would decay, it instead flourishes; things reach their extreme and naturally reverse.
The Way that would take must first fully give it—when one would take away evil, if evil deeds are not removed, evil accumulates and destroys the self. Only then do they awaken in the moment.

This is called **subtle luminosity**—though the Sage’s authority seems at first unlike teaching, upon examining its principle, it holds profound potential, most subtly luminous and clearly beneficial. Hence, it is called **subtle luminosity**.

In eighty-one chapters, the transformations and guidance are broadly expounded, yet common emotions cling, and their grasp differs. When substance is demonstrated and they do not comply, authority is used to transform them, compelling them to return.

The Mysterious Teaching is profound and far-reaching, fitting for all. Authority is explained first, substance clarified afterward. To contract, one opens the Way’s transformation; to weaken worldly emotions, one strengthens their immortal essence; to abandon evil intent, one offers the true path; to take away evil deeds, one gives them virtuous conduct.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:**
The Way that would contract must first fully expand it—*teru* (歙) means to gather, to contract. When exercising authority to transform all classes of beings, those who would not be contracted by substance must first be expanded and indulged, their licentiousness exhausted—then they may be contracted.

In the past, when the Old Master entered the west to transform the barbarians of *Jibin*, he first indulged their savagery, then transformed them with the Dao—this is the case. The intricate details are fully recorded in the *Wen Shi Nei Zhuan*.

The Way that would weaken must first fully strengthen it—when one would lead them to the Dao’s gentle weakness, one must first exhaust their strength, then demonstrate the yielding and soft.

The Way that would abandon must first fully elevate it—when one would abandon their brutal and untamed nature, one must first indulge their ferocity and violence. Once their violence is exhausted, it can be abandoned. This is as when the barbarian king unleashed his poisonous wrath, burning and drowning the Old Master—yet water and fire did not harm him—only then did he teach him the Dao.

The Way that would take must first fully give it—first indulging their evil, calling it "giving," then leading them to goodness, calling it "taking." Thus, the Old Master first displayed his mundane form to indulge their rigidity, then revealed his divine powers—only then did the barbarians submit, allowing their ferocity to be taken away and leading them to the virtuous path.

These four paired meanings are similarly structured, differing only in shallow and deep layers. Those of superior capacity hear substance and immediately awaken; those of inferior roots require authority. This is the method of increasing the law and eliminating delusion.

This is called **subtle luminosity**—though the Sage’s authority is subtle and profound, its effects are clearly verified.

「Again it is said: *微隐* means subtle and hidden; *明*, wisdom. This is the subtle and hidden Way of wisdom.

**The Second Section** explains the comparison of two kinds of wisdom: the wisdom of the Way is not inferior to that of authority. The gentle overcomes the rigid.

**御注** states: The *巽* (compliant) can wield authority, and when authority is wielded, it can control all things. Hence, it is known that the gentle and compliant can indeed overcome the rigid and strong.

**御疏** elaborates: The *易* (Classic of Changes) says: *"巽以行权"* (The compliant can wield authority). If one desires to clarify that *巽* (compliant) is humble and yielding, then one can practice the Way of authority. Therefore, to make something *翕* (converge), one must first give it *张* (expansion); to make it *弱* (weak), one must first give it *强* (strength). Ultimately, when one leads it to *翕弱* (convergence and weakness), it is the Way of gentleness triumphing over rigidity and strength. Hence, it is said: *The gentle overcomes the rigid.*

**河上公** states: *The gentle endure long, while the rigid perish first.*

**荣** says: The Way of authority follows without resistance, hence it is called *gentle*. Yet it must ultimately control the rigid, hence it is said to *overcome*.

**成疏** explains: *Gentle* refers to the true Way; *rigid*, to the wisdom of authority. To teach those difficult to convert, one must rely on the wisdom of authority. When comparing the two wisdoms, the true wisdom of the Way surpasses that of authority.

**The Third Section** illustrates through analogies that the Way of authority cannot be revealed to all.

*A fish cannot be removed from its depths; the state’s sharpest tools should not be displayed to the people.*
**御注** clarifies: *脱* (removed) means *lost*. The *利器* (sharpest tools) refers to the Way of authority. This states that the Way of authority cannot be revealed to those unworthy of it, hence the analogy: *If a fish loses its pool, it will be captured by men. If the Way of authority is revealed to those unworthy, they will seize it and use it for deception.*

**御疏** further elucidates: *脱* (removed) means *lost*. The *利器* (sharpest tools) refers to the Way of authority. A fish in water is like a ruler wielding authority; a fish losing its water is like a ruler losing his authority, and then he will be captured. If the Way of authority is falsely revealed to those unworthy, they will misuse it and practice deception.*

**河上公** says: *A fish cannot be removed from its depths*—if a fish is removed from its depths, it is like losing rigidity and gaining gentleness, and thus can no longer control. *The state’s sharpest tools should not be displayed to the people*—the sharpest tools refer to the Way of authority. Those who wield authority in governing the state should not reveal it to their ministers, nor should those who practice the Way reveal it to those unworthy of it.*

**荣** says: *脱* (removed) means *lost*. A fish swims in the river and lake, relying on them for its livelihood. The Sage’s greatest treasure depends on the subtle and hidden Way of authority. A fish cannot lose its water, for losing it means the fish perishes. The sharpest tools should not be displayed to the people, for revealing them brings peril. Hence it is said: *One can lead people by the Way, but not make them know it*—this shows that the Way of authority must not be entrusted to the wrong hands.

**成疏** concludes: *脱* (removed) means *lost*. The *利器* (sharpest tools) refers to authority. A fish hides in water, and authority hides in the heart, so nothing can harm it. A fish loses its water and is captured by others; authority revealed to the people is controlled by them. Hence, it cannot be done.

**Chapter Thirty-Seven: The Way is Ever Without Action**

This chapter marks the third section of the text, clarifying the ultimate convergence.

Within this chapter, the text opens two distinct themes: the first converges the essence of the Way, revealing its tranquil stillness while ever in motion; the second converges the essence of the student, displaying the profound mystery of the highest subtlety.

**The First Convergence: The Essence of the Way—Revealing Tranquility While Ever in Motion**

The wondrous Way of non-action is exalted and detached from worldly affairs, not enduring forever, yet dwelling in obscurity is not dim. The radiant virtue encompasses all life, working unceasingly yet unperceived. The profound roots remain silent, yet all things resonate with it—who can discern? Unlocking the hidden depths of the jade-like treasury, the celestial scriptures ascend to the *上清* (Upper Purity) and *太清* (Supreme Purity). Manifesting the teachings of the jade cabinet, the realms of *罪福* (guilt and fortune) span the *三涂* (Three Stygian Realms) and *九夜* (Nine Nights of Torment). The lonely spirits wail along the *泉路* (path to the underworld), while the stagnant *魄* (ethereal souls) languish in the *苦庭* (court of suffering). Without the great Way to deliver them, who can rescue the lost and bring forth clarity? Though called profound and silent, yet nothing is left undone—teaching the common folk, the power of the Way is now revealed.

The Way is ever without action, yet nothing remains undone. If rulers could uphold it, all things would transform naturally.

**御注** states: The wondrous origin is pure and tranquil, hence it is ever without action. All things depend on it for existence, yet nothing is left undone—thus all things transform naturally. The ruler’s non-action leads to the people’s simplicity and purity.

**御疏** elaborates: The Way is ever without action, yet nothing remains undone. The nature of the Way is pure and tranquil, its wondrous origin serene and still—hence it is ever without action. All things rely on it for creation, responding with sensation when moved—hence nothing is left undone. Those who act will inevitably have things they cannot do; those who do not act will have nothing they cannot accomplish. If rulers uphold it, all things will transform naturally. Rulers who guard the pure and tranquil Way, without action or affairs, will see all things naturally respond and transform. The people will then become simple and virtuous through their ruler’s good teaching.

**河上公** says: The Way is ever without action, yet nothing remains undone. The Way’s constancy lies in its non-action. If rulers uphold it, all things will transform naturally. This means that if rulers guard the Way, all things will transform in accordance with it.

**成疏** explains: The Way is ever without action, yet nothing remains undone. The Way of constancy is silent and tranquil, yet its application arises spontaneously to respond to all things. The earlier sentence is the origin; the later, its manifestation. This reveals that though the Way’s origin is profound and silent, its motion is tranquil and responsive—clarifying the interplay of motion and stillness.

If rulers uphold it, all things will transform naturally. The sovereigns of the *万乘* (ten-thousand chariots) and the five ranks of rulers, if they uphold this Way, will see the *八荒* (eight remote regions) and all nations naturally follow and transform. Students are the same. The reason for emphasizing rulers is that their transformation benefits many and spreads widely.

**The Second Convergence: The Essence of the Student—Displaying the Profound Mystery of the Highest Subtlety**

When one seeks to act after transformation, I will restrain them with the nameless simplicity.

**御注** states: This speaks of those who, having followed their ruler’s transformation through the Way of non-action, now wish to act with worldly deeds. I will restrain them with the nameless simplicity.

chunks.original_text: 无名之朴者，道也。 ○御疏：无名之朴，道也。 欲作者，欲动作有为也。 吾者，侯王自称也。 言人禀承善教以化，君德无为清净，而复欲动作有为者； 吾则将以无名之朴而镇之，令其清净不欲作也。 ○河上公曰：吾，身也，无名之朴，谓道也。 万物已化，而后欲作巧伪者，王侯当镇抚以道德也。 ○成疏：作，起修也，朴，道也。 言众生初从化起修者，必有心欲於果报也。 既起斯欲，即须以无名朴素之道安镇其心，令不染有，此以空遣有也。 无名之朴，亦将不欲。 不欲以静，天下将自正。 ○御注：言人君既以无名之朴镇静苍生，不可执此无名而令有迹，将恐寻迹丧本，复入有为，故於此无名之朴，亦将兼忘，不欲於欲，无欲亦忘，泊然清净，而天下自正矣。 ○御疏：无名之朴，亦将不欲，上言凡人欲动作有为者，人君则将无名之朴而镇静之，今言於彼无名之朴，亦将不欲者，所以镇无名之朴，为众生兴动欲心，若复执滞无名，还将有迹，令此众生寻迹丧本，复入有为，则兴彼欲心，等无差别。 故初用无名之朴以镇静苍生欲心，苍生欲心既除，圣人无名亦拾。 喻如药以理病，病愈而忘药； 舟以济水，济而遗舟。 若水已济而仍守舟，病已除而复尝药，岂唯不达彼岸，亦复更生患累矣。 不欲以静，天下将自正，夫无名之朴既将不欲，不欲之欲於此亦忘，则泊然清净，是名了出。 君无为而上理，人遂性而化下，不烦教令，而天下平正，故日天下将自正。 河上公曰：无名之朴，亦将不欲，不欲以静，言王侯镇抚以道德，於民亦将不欲，故当以清净道化之者也。 天下自正，能如是者，天下将自正安定也。 ○成疏：无名之朴，亦将不欲，非但不得欲於有法，亦不得欲此无名之朴也。 前以无遣有，此以有遣无。 有无双离，一中道也。 不欲以静，天下自正，静，息也。 前以无名遣有，次以不欲遣无，有无还息，不欲既除，一中斯泯，此则遣之又遣，玄之又玄，所谓探幽索隐，穷理尽性者也。 既而一切诸法无非正真，梯牌瓦号，悉皆至道，故云天下将自正，此句结众妙之门者也。 道德真经玄德慕疏卷之十竟 道德真经玄德纂疏卷之十一

**The Second Convergence: The Essence of the Student—Displaying the Profound Mystery of the Highest Subtlety (Continued)**

The nameless simplicity is the Dao.

**御疏** states: The nameless simplicity is the Dao. Those who wish to act are those who desire to engage in worldly deeds. *吾* refers to the rulers themselves. It means that once people have received the benevolent teachings and been transformed, the ruler’s virtue of non-action brings purity and stillness. Yet if they still wish to act and engage in worldly deeds, I will restrain them with the nameless simplicity, so that their hearts remain pure and undisturbed by such desires.

**河上公** says: *吾* means the self. The nameless simplicity refers to the Dao. After all things have been transformed, if one then seeks to engage in clever artifices, the rulers must govern and pacify them with virtue and the Dao.

**成疏** states: *作* means to begin cultivation. *朴* is the Dao. It speaks of those who, having first followed the transformation and begun cultivation, inevitably harbor desires for fruition and rewards. Once these desires arise, one must use the nameless, simple Dao to calm their hearts, so that they do not cling to worldly attachments. This is the way of dispelling the worldly with emptiness.

The nameless simplicity will also not desire. Without desire, there is stillness, and the world will naturally align in harmony.

**御注** states: Once the ruler has restrained the people with the nameless simplicity, one must not cling to this nameless simplicity and leave traces behind. Otherwise, people may seek these traces and lose their original nature, falling back into worldly action. Thus, even this nameless simplicity must be forgotten—without desire, one forgets desire. In tranquil purity, the world will naturally align in harmony.

**御疏** states: The nameless simplicity will also not desire. Earlier, it was said that even if common people desire to engage in worldly deeds, the ruler will restrain them with the nameless simplicity. Now, it is said that even this nameless simplicity should not desire. This is to prevent the ruler from clinging to the nameless simplicity, lest they awaken desires in the people, leading them to seek traces and lose their original nature, thereby returning to worldly action. Such desires would be equal and indistinguishable.

Thus, initially, the nameless simplicity is used to restrain the desires of the people. Once the people’s desires are eliminated, the sage’s own nameless simplicity is also abandoned. It is like medicine used to treat an illness—once the sickness is cured, the medicine is forgotten; or a boat used to cross water—once the crossing is complete, the boat is left behind. If one guards the boat after crossing the water or continues to take medicine after the illness is gone, not only will they fail to reach the other shore, but they may also incur new suffering. Without desire, there is stillness, and the world will naturally align in harmony. When the nameless simplicity no longer desires, the desire for it is also forgotten, leading to tranquil purity—this is called *了出* (realization and transcendence).

The ruler governs through non-action, and the people follow their nature and transform from below. Without the need for teaching or commands, the world becomes peaceful and harmonious. Hence, it is said that the world will naturally align in harmony.

**河上公** says: The nameless simplicity will also not desire. The ruler governs and pacifies with virtue and the Dao, and yet the ruler should also not desire. Therefore, one must transform them with the pure Dao.

The world will naturally align in harmony for those who can do this.

**成疏** states: The nameless simplicity will also not desire, not merely refraining from desire for worldly laws but also from desire for this nameless simplicity itself. Earlier, it was said to dispel worldly attachments with emptiness; now, it is said to dispel the emptiness with worldly existence. With both worldly and emptiness forgotten, one attains the Dao.

Without desire, there is stillness, and the world will naturally align in harmony. Stillness is cessation. Earlier, worldly attachments were dispelled with the nameless simplicity; now, the desire for it is dispelled with non-desire. When worldly attachments and emptiness are both forgotten, desire is eliminated, and one attains the Dao. This is the process of dispelling again and again, the profound within the profound—what is called *探幽索隐，穷理尽性* (probing the depths and seeking the hidden, exhausting principle and attaining nature).

Since all dharmas are ultimately true and real, ladders, scaffolding, and all contrivances are none other than the highest Dao. Therefore, it is said that the world will naturally align in harmony. This sentence seals the gate of all profound mysteries.

**End of Volume Ten of the *Moral and Mysterious Classic*—Commentary on the *Profound Virtue***

chunks.original_text: 唐玄宗御注并疏   河上公严君平李荣注  西华法师成玄英疏   蒙阳强思齐纂 上德不德章第三十八 上经明道，下经辨德，上经亦具明道德，但以道为正，以德为傍，下经亦具明道德，然以道为傍，以德为正。 据傍正为论，故有道德经上下。 此经一卷凡四十四章，一经大分，义开三别，第一一章正开德宗，第二四十二章广明德义，第三一章总结前旨也。 第一正开德宗。 就此章中，又开四别。 第一显上下二德，妄执不同，第二辨仁义礼之德，明浇淳世异，第三明去本之末，劝令息末崇本，第四斥礼为浮伪之始，示其取舍向方。 第一显上下二德，妄执不同。 夫义顼道尊，唐虞化美，皆处无为之事，同乐自得之场，不矜名声，无善夸伐，合天地之清，镇齐日月之贞明。 在物能知，行身不费，可谓上德不德。 玄之又玄，谦卑而光，道合三皇之首，动而能寂，爰标陆栗之时，则知行礼行仁，洎乎浇浮渐兴，故宪法斯执，正卯诛两馆之间，贤圣不明，姬昌致七年之祸，不能忘义在道，遂乃处薄居华，失妙於大全，皇愚夫之弗鉴。 上德不德，是以有德。 御注：上德不德，是以有德，下德不失德，是以无德。 德者道之用也，《庄子》曰：物得以生谓之德，时有淳酿，故德有上下。 上古淳朴，德用不彰，无德可称，故云不德。 而淳德不散，无为化清，故云是以有德。 逮德下衰，功用稍着，心虽体道，迹涉有为，执德可称，故云不失。 迹涉矜有，比上为粗，故云是以无德尔。 ○御疏：上者，举时也。 德者，辫用也。 谓上古淳朴，无为而理，体道之主，任物自然，是上古之淳德，故云上德。 至德潜运，人无能名，故云不德，而淳风和畅，物遂生成，德用常全，故云有德。 注云：物得以生谓之德者，此《庄子》杂篇之文。 ○河上公曰：上德不德，上德谓太古无名号之君，德大强名，故言上德。 不德者，言其不以德教民，因循#1自然，养人性命，其德不见，故言不德。 是以有德，言其德合於天地，和气流行，民得以全也。 ○荣曰：明古之皇道，宅太虚以为心，凝至一而为体，不言均天地之化，无事成万物之功，未规揖让之名，岂有干戈之争，虽复处宗极，而乃非争非名，无为自然，故云上德。 为而不恃，成功不居，故云不德。 畜养万物，物得以成，故云有德。 内明德与道合，厥义可尊，故云上德。 道既无象，德亦虚玄，韬光藏用，故云不得。 虽藏於用，无用之用用矣，乃韬於光，不耀之光光矣。 有用有光，济人济物，故云是以有德。 ○成疏：上者高胜，是超出之名，德者得也，以克获为义。 言上德之人，妙契道境，境智冥会，得失兼忘。 得失兼忘，故言不德。 境智冥会，故言有德。 有德则遣其失，不德则遣其得也。 下德不失德，是以无德。 御疏：此言淳风渐散，德亦下衰。 故圣人美无为之风，而百姓尚无为之迹，尚述为劣，故云下德。 迹着则有德可称，故云不失。 德称不失，迹涉矜有。 矜有之弊，淳朴不全，故云是以无德。 ○河上公曰：下德不失德，下德谓号镒之君，德不及上德，故言下德。 不失德者，其德可见，其功可称。 是以无德，盖以有名号及其身故也。 ○荣曰：道德之风，几乎将失，仁义之化，殆欲斯兴。

**Commentary on the *Profound Virtue* – Chapter Thirty-Eight: *Upper Virtue Does Not Virtue***

**Imperial Commentary and Exegesis of the Tang Xuanzong**
**Commentary by Lord Yan Junping of He Shang, Li Rong**
**Exegesis by Master Cheng Xuan of Xihua**
**Compiled by Qiang Sici of Mengyang**

The *Dao De Jing* is divided into two volumes: the upper text elucidates the *Dao*, the lower text expounds on *virtue*. Yet the upper text also encompasses both *Dao* and *virtue*, though it prioritizes *Dao* as the primary and *virtue* as secondary. Similarly, the lower text also encompasses both, but here *virtue* takes precedence while *Dao* becomes secondary. Thus, the text is structured as *Dao De Jing* (Classic of the *Dao* and *Virtue*), with *Dao* and *virtue* as its twin pillars.

This single scroll comprises forty-two chapters, its meaning branching into three distinct divisions:
The first chapter establishes the foundation of *virtue*,
Chapters two through forty-two expound extensively on the principles of *virtue*,
The final chapter synthesizes the preceding teachings.

**First Division: Establishing the Foundation of *Virtue***

Within this chapter, four further distinctions unfold:
1. Distinguishing the *virtue* of the upper and lower realms, dispelling erroneous fixation,
2. Clarifying the *virtue* of *ren* (benevolence), *yi* (righteousness), and *li* (rites), illustrating the shift from purity to corruption across ages,
3. Exposing the superficiality of later developments, urging a return to the root,
4. Denouncing *li* (rites) as the origin of hollow pretense, guiding proper discernment and alignment.

**1. Distinguishing the *Virtue* of the Upper and Lower Realms, Dispelling Erroneous Fixation**

Indeed, *yi* (righteousness) is subordinate to *Dao*, while *Dao* holds supreme dignity. The transformations of Tang and Yu were pure and beautiful, their governance rooted in *wuwei* (non-action), their realm a field of spontaneous harmony where none boasted of virtue or sought praise. They harmonized with the purity of Heaven and Earth, steadied the rectitude of sun and moon. In their midst, things flourished without effort, their actions costing nothing—truly, *upper virtue does not virtue*.

Mysterious beyond measure, yet humble and radiant, their *Dao* aligned with the first of the Three Sovereigns. Though they acted, they remained still. When the age of Lu Lu (the legendary era of simplicity) faded, the practice of *li* (rites) and *ren* (benevolence) emerged. As corruption spread, laws became rigid, and the *Dao* of the two *Zhuans* (ancient officials) was abandoned. The wise and sagely grew obscured, and Ji Chang (King Wen of Zhou) suffered seven years of misfortune—yet he never forgot that *yi* (righteousness) was subordinate to *Dao*. Thus, he endured poverty while dwelling in splendor, losing the subtlety of the whole. Even the foolish failed to discern this.

**Upper virtue does not virtue, and thus it possesses virtue.**
**Imperial Commentary:**
*Upper virtue does not virtue, and thus it possesses virtue.*
*Lower virtue does not lose virtue, and thus it lacks virtue.*
*Virtue* is the manifestation of the *Dao*.
As *Zhuangzi* says: *"When things attain their natural state, it is called virtue."*
In ancient times, the pure and unadorned *virtue* was not yet manifest, and thus there was no *virtue* to be named—hence, *"does not virtue."* Yet the pure *virtue* did not disperse; through *wuwei*, its influence remained clear—hence, *"and thus it possesses virtue."*

When *virtue* declined, its functions became more pronounced. Though the heart still embodied the *Dao*, its actions leaned toward *wei* (action). *Virtue* could now be named—hence, *"does not lose virtue."* Yet because its traces leaned toward ostentation, it was coarser than the upper—hence, *"and thus it lacks virtue."*

**Imperial Exegesis:**
*Upper* refers to the ancient age.
*Virtue* is the manifestation of *Dao*.
In the upper antiquity, pure and unadorned, *wuwei* governed all. The essence of the *Dao* was its foundation, and all things flourished naturally—this was the pure *virtue* of antiquity, hence *"upper virtue."* Yet its *virtue* was so profound that none could name it—hence, *"does not virtue."* Yet the harmonious winds prevailed, and all things thrived—*virtue* remained complete—hence, *"and thus it possesses virtue."*

**Commentary by Lord He Shang:**
*Upper virtue does not virtue*—*upper virtue* refers to the sovereigns of the most ancient era, whose *virtue* was so vast that names could not contain it. *"Does not virtue"* means they did not govern through *virtue* but followed nature spontaneously, nurturing life—thus their *virtue* was unseen, hence *"does not virtue."* *"And thus it possesses virtue"* signifies that their *virtue* aligned with Heaven and Earth, and the harmonious *qi* flowed, allowing the people to thrive.

**Commentary by Li Rong:**
The ancient *Dao* was established in the boundless void as its heart, its essence condensed into unity. It required no effort to transform all things, nor did it seek the names of courtesy—how could there be conflict with arms? Though it resided at the pinnacle, it was neither contentious nor named. *Wuwei* was its nature—hence, *"upper virtue."* It acted without reliance, achieved without claiming—hence, *"does not virtue."* It nourished all things, allowing them to flourish—hence, *"and thus it possesses virtue."* Internally, it illuminated *virtue* in harmony with the *Dao*, its meaning thus worthy of reverence—hence, *"upper virtue."* The *Dao* was formless, *virtue* was subtle—its light was concealed, its use was hidden—hence, *"does not virtue."* Though concealed in use, its use was indeed use; though hidden in light, its light was indeed light. With use and light manifest, it benefited all—hence, *"and thus it possesses virtue."*

**Exegesis by Master Cheng Xuan:**
*Upper* signifies transcendence and excellence—it is the name for what surpasses. *Virtue* means attainment, its meaning rooted in mastery. Those of *upper virtue* subtly align with the *Dao*, their wisdom merging with reality, transcending gain and loss. Thus, *"does not virtue."* Their wisdom merges with reality—thus, *"and thus it possesses virtue."* When *virtue* is present, loss is dispelled; when *virtue* is absent, gain is dispelled.

**Lower virtue does not lose virtue, and thus it lacks virtue.**
**Imperial Exegesis:**
This speaks of the decline of pure winds and the waning of *virtue*. Thus, the Sage praised the spirit of *wuwei*, yet the people clung to its traces. To cling to traces is inferior—hence, *"lower virtue."* When traces became manifest, *virtue* could be named—hence, *"does not lose virtue."* Though *virtue* was named, its traces leaned toward ostentation. The flaw of ostentation disrupted the purity—hence, *"and thus it lacks virtue."*

**Commentary by Lord He Shang:**

The winds of *Dao* and *virtue* were nearly lost, and the transformations of *ren* (benevolence) and *yi* (righteousness) were about to arise.
