「The *Rong*’s Commentary said:
To eat sweetly is to eat in moderation—moderation makes all food sweet.
To dress beautifully is to wear appropriately—appropriateness makes all clothing beautiful.
If not moderate and fitting, even jade-like delicacies and brocade garments
cannot truly be called sweet and beautiful.

**He Shang Gong** said:
*"Sweet their food"* means sweet their coarse meals,
not plundering the people for fine cuisine.
*"Beautiful their clothing"* means beautiful their rough garments,
not prizing the five colors.

**Rong** said:
Sweet their food, beautiful their clothing,
settle their dwellings, delight in their customs—
when people’s desires are unfulfilled,
even jade food and silk brocade are not deemed beautiful.
But when the heart finds contentment,
plain rice and coarse hemp robes suffice as sweetness.
Let **Tao Sheng** and **Da Jun** transform the world,
and all shall eat sweetly without distinction of rank.
Clothing shall have no preference for good or ill,
all garments worn shall be deemed beautiful.
Homes shall know no poverty or wealth,
all dwellings shall be deemed settled.
Villages shall know no excess or want,
all abodes shall be filled with joy.
Since none seek distant migration,
the weak and bereaved shall find no need to wander.

**Cheng’s Commentary** said:
*"Sweet their food"*—flavor attains the Dao.
*"Beautiful their clothing"*—virtue/power shines in the body.
*"Settle their dwellings"*—delight in their customs.
The *Rong*’s Commentary said:
Without desire, their dwellings are settled.
With simplicity transformed, their customs are joyful.
If one pursues desires without restraint,
how could they settle in their dwellings?
Harsh governance and burdens bring only trouble—
how could they then delight in their customs?

**He Shang Gong** said:
*"Settle their dwellings"*—settle in thatched huts,
not favoring ornate houses.
*"Delight in their customs"*—delight in simple and unadorned ways,
not shifting to foreign norms.

**Cheng’s Commentary** said:
*"Settle their dwellings"*—all places are settled,
stillness within motion.
*"Delight in their customs"*—harmonizing with the world’s light,
motion within stillness.

**Fourthly, it illustrates attaining true Dao/Way and harmonizing with its flow,
exceeding all coming and going.**
Neighboring lands face one another,
the sounds of roosters and dogs reach across them—
yet the people, until death, never visit one another.

The *Rong*’s Commentary said:
Neighboring lands face one another—
the sounds of roosters and dogs are heard—
this speaks of their closeness.
That the people, until death, never visit one another,
is because each has their own sufficiency,
and nothing more to seek or give.

**He Shang Gong** said:
Neighboring lands face one another,
the sounds of roosters and dogs are heard—
this marks proximity.
The people, until death, never visit one another—
this is their lack of emotional attachments.

**Rong** said:
Two lands as neighbors, visible to the eye,
roosters crow and dogs bark, heard by the ear—
from beginning to end, in youth and age,
they never visit one another.
Each person is self-sufficient,
each home holds the Dao.
Thus it is said:
*"People forget the Dao as it spreads,*
*fish forget the rivers and lakes they dwell in."*

**Cheng’s Commentary** said:
Neighboring lands face one another—
*neighbor* means near,
*lands* refers to the realms of life and death,
and the Dao’s domain.
This says that these two realms lie close within the heart,
so they are said to face one another.
The sounds of roosters and dogs are heard—
roosters watch for dawn,
dogs guard through the night—
these teachings serve as warnings against the long night of ignorance,
and calls to the morning of wisdom.
Thus, these teachings are near in expounding the unity of mind,
so they are said to be heard.
That the people, until death, never visit one another—
when one attains true understanding and harmony,
this is the Dao.
The Dao is neither born from life and death,
nor does it depart through any path—
when these two realms merge as one,
there is no coming or going,
no distinction between beginnings and ends.

---
**Chapter Eighty-One of *Sincere Speech Not Beautiful***

*Sincere Speech*—this chapter is the third section,
its text summarizing earlier themes.
Within this chapter, the meaning is divided into three:
**Firstly, it shows the virtuous/powerful person,
whose wisdom transcends all speech and argument.**
Good medicine tastes bitter,
sincere speech is not beautiful,
great eloquence seems dull,
the learned do not know all.
The Sage scatters Dao/Way to teach the common and foolish,
yet does not hoard it.
He laments the long night of ignorance,
while the foolish and dull remain unaware—
I, like grass, am but one of these common folk,
standing at the edge of the boundless sea of desire,
yet unable to unfurl my ragged robes.
Before the mountain of error, who dares lift a foot?
The owl that neither cries nor flies—
when it rises, it soars to the heavens.
The man who is both foolish and dull—
how could he awaken in a hundred years?

The Sage labors to point out the Great Dao/Way,
but distorts the natural transformations of life.
In darkness, they do not know—
what more can be said?

I have privately observed the utmost sincerity,
refining the self and governing the realm—
above, it ascends to the brilliance of the sun,
soaring through the clouds like a bird.
Below, it cleanses the intestines and washes the heart,
leading many to follow in its path.
To act without effort is the Dao’s honor—
dwelling in the source of harmony and balance,
virtue/power can nourish all things.
The child of a skilled craftsman
must first learn to make his own leather coat—
my disciples embrace the True,
so why do they not gather?

My spirit is weary from yellowed scrolls and shallow learning,
my Dao is impoverished by clear streams.
Day and night, I strive in fear,
never ceasing in sleep or waking.
I regret not attaining the likeness of the Sage,
nor the colors of his teachings.
My wasted bones and tattered soul—
how could my sighs ever end?
Those who share my resolve—
do not forget this heart’s intent.

*Sincere speech is not beautiful—*
The *Rong*’s Commentary said:
*Sincere speech*—this refers to the Sage’s teachings,
truthful and real.
Laozi wished to clarify his established teachings,
to transform and guide all beings,
and truly, these are words of utmost sincerity—
yet they conflict with common ways,
so people deem them not beautiful.

**He Shang Gong** said:
*Sincere speech*—speech that matches reality.
*Not beautiful*—simple and unadorned.

**Rong** said:
Sincere speech is not beautiful,
beautiful speech is not sincere—
speech reveals the heart,
not a matter of idle fabrication.
It seeks true principles,
not flashy words.
Thus it is said: *sincere speech is not beautiful,*
*sweet words lose truth,*
*light promises lack substance.*

**Cheng’s Commentary** said:
*Sincere speech is not beautiful,*
*beautiful speech is not sincere*—
*sincere* means real,
*beautiful* means superficial and gaudy.
The virtuous/powerful person, obscured yet in accord with the Dao,
speaks teachings that are real without ornamentation.
Superficial and gaudy speech—
mere tales from the common world—
deviates from ultimate truth,
so it is not believed.»

chunks.original_text: 故《庄子》云：犬不以善吠为良，人不以善言为贤也。 美言不信。 御疏：美言，谓代教甘美之言也。 言多浮华，动合於俗，既非信实，不可化人。 信言所以不美，正以代教美言不信故尔。 ○河上公曰：滋美之言者，孳孳华辞。 不信者，饰伪多空虚也。 善者不辩， 御疏：悟教之善，在於修行，行而忘之，曾不执滞，故不辩说也。 ○河上公曰：善者以道修身，不采文也。 ○严曰：容疏者讷，谓之不辩，挽挽而成，默默而信，故能成善何也，动得天心，静得地意，君子之本，为百行之长矣。 ○荣曰：善者不辩，辩者不善，大辩若讷，无劳词费，善者不辩也。 偏词过当，多言数穷，辩者不善也。 ○成疏：辫，别也。 善体至道之人，指马天地以一为喻，故无可分别也。 儒墨是非，坚执人我分别者，良由未证善道故也。 第二明上德之人，财德两施。 辩者不善。 御疏：但能辫说者言教，曾不悟了  修行，惑滞既多，故为不善。 ○河上  公曰：辩者谓巧言，不善者，舌致息  也。 山有玉，掘其山，水有珠，竭其  渊，辫口多言亡其身也。 ○严曰：  散朴浇淳，诬天诬地，变化文辞，以  倾家国，故不善也。 知者不博， 御疏：知，了悟也。 博，多闻也。 言体道了悟之人，在乎精一，不在多闻，故《庄子》云：博溺心。 ○河上公日：知者谓知道之士，不博者，守一元。 ○严曰：趋被务本，多识万端，目窥人事，无所穷极，为道之博，万物离散，是不知於道者也。 ○荣曰：子能知一，万事毕，知者不博也。 文灭质，博溺心，迷至理，不知也。 ○成疏：知道之人，忘言绝学，所以不博。 博学之士，耽滞名教，所以不知。 故《西升经》云：人能图知有天地万物，不知己之所由生，是大不知。 又云：子能知一，万事毕。 《庄子》云：文灭质，博溺心。 博者不知。 御疏：夫多闻者则滞於言教，滞教则终日言而尽物，既非了悟，故曰不知。 ○河上公曰：博者多见闻，不知者失要真也。 重明上德之人，财德两施。 圣人不积。 御疏：积，滞聚也。 圣人妙达理源，深明法性，悟文字虚假，了言教空无，所说之理既明，能说之言亦遣，则於彼言教，一无滞积，故云圣人不积尔。 ○河上公曰：圣人积德不积财，有德以教愚，有财以与贫也。 ○严曰：圣人去博与辫，如彼虚空，无所贮积，与物俱变尔。 ○荣曰：圣人不积，既以与人己愈有，既以与人己愈多，不积者，虚怀也，犹如日月流辉，照临方妈，物得已见，转益光华，犹圣人智彻於物，法施无穷也。 江海洒润，善利万物，物得以生，而源流不竭，亦犹圣人财施不尽也。 ○成疏：积，聚也。 圣人有财惠物，有德教人，故不积也。 既以为人己愈有，既以与人己愈多。 御疏：既，尽也。 言圣人虽不积滞言教，然众生发明慧心，必资圣人诱导，故圣人以清净理性，尽与凡愚而教导之。 於圣人慧解之性，曾不喊耗，故云愈多。 注云有明自性，多明外益者，悟理之性，既非他有，故云自性。 因教之益，不自中来，故云外益。 明圣人教导凡愚，心弥慧解，故云愈有。 惟教学者，理益精畅，故云愈多尔。 ○河上公曰：既以与人己愈有，既以为人施设德化，己愈有德化，己愈有德也。

「Thus *Zhuangzi* states: *"A dog is not considered good merely because it barks well; a person is not deemed virtuous/powerful merely because of eloquent speech."* **Beautiful speech lacks sincerity.**

**Yu’s Commentary** said:
**Beautiful speech** refers to teachings that are sweet and adorned.
Speech that is excessive in superficiality and conforms to worldly tastes—
though it lacks sincerity and substance—
it cannot transform others.
Thus, *sincere speech is not beautiful*
because **beautiful speech lacks sincerity.**

**Master Gong of the He River** said:
Those who speak in **honeyed beauty**—
their words are **nailed and polished** with ornate phrases.
Those who lack sincerity—
their speech is **decorated with falsehoods**, full of emptiness.

The **good** do not **argue**—
**Yu’s Commentary** said:
The **good** in understanding teachings
lie in **cultivation and practice**—
acting without clinging,
never fixating or obstructing,
thus they do not **argue** for their views.

**Master Gong of the He River** said:
The **good** cultivate themselves in the **Dao/Way**,
without embellishing with **literary refinement**.

**Yan** said:
Those who appear **naive and slow** in speech
are called **not argumentative**—
yet their words are **drawn out and true**,
their silence **deep and trustworthy**,
thus they can **achieve goodness**—
how so?
Their actions **move the heart of Heaven**,
their stillness **aligns with the will of Earth**—
the foundation of the **virtuous/powerful person**,
the longest-lasting of all **conducts**.

**Rong** said:
The **good** do not **argue**,
those who **argue** are not **good**—
**great argumentation seems naive**,
without **labored words or empty rhetoric**—
thus the **good** do not **argue**.
Excessive **partial phrasing**,
overly **prolific speech**,
**argumentative words exhaust truth**—
thus those who **argue** are not **good**.

**Cheng’s Commentary** said:
**Argumentation** means **distinction and separation**.
Those who **grasp the ultimate Dao/Way**,
point to the **horse of Heaven and Earth** with the **unity of One**,
thus have nothing to **distinguish or separate**.
The **Confucian and Mohist debates** on right and wrong—
those who rigidly cling to **self/other duality**—
are indeed those who have not yet **attained the good Dao/Way**.

**Secondly**, it clarifies that the **virtuous/powerful person of highest virtue** engages in **twofold giving**—
**of wealth and of virtue**.

The **good** do not **accumulate**—
**Yu’s Commentary** said:
**Accumulation** means **obstruction and stagnation**.
The **sage** **penetrates the subtle source of principles**,
**deeply understands the nature of dharma**,
**discerns the emptiness of words and teachings**,
and **realizes the void of verbal instruction**.
Since their **understood principles are clear**,
their **spoken teachings are also abandoned**,
thus they **do not accumulate** in those teachings—
hence it is said: *"The sage does not accumulate."*

**Master Gong of the He River** said:
The **sage accumulates virtue, not wealth**,
using **wealth to aid the poor**,
using **virtue to guide the ignorant**.

**Yan** said:
The **sage** **discards argumentation and literary refinement**,
like **void and emptiness**,
holding nothing in **stagnation or accumulation**,
adapting with all things—
thus it is said.

**Rong** said:
The **sage does not accumulate**—
when they give to others, their own **virtue/power grows**,
when they give to others, their own **virtue/power becomes more abundant**—
**not accumulating** means **an empty heart**,
like the **radiance of the sun and moon**,
shining upon all **regions and lands**,
things **obtain their own illumination**,
yet their **light becomes ever more brilliant**—
just as the **sage’s wisdom permeates all things**,
their **dharma-giving is boundless**.

The **rivers and seas** **nourish and moisten**,
**benefiting all creatures**—
things **gain life through them**,
yet their **source never runs dry**—
also like the **sage’s wealth-giving**, which is **never exhausted**.

**Cheng’s Commentary** said:
**Accumulation** means **gathering**.
The **sage** has **wealth to benefit others**,
has **virtue to teach others**,
thus they do not **accumulate**.

When they give to others, their own **virtue/power grows**,
when they give to others, their own **virtue/power becomes more abundant**—
**Yu’s Commentary** said:
**Exhaust** means **complete**.
Though the **sage** does not **stagnate or accumulate** in teachings,
yet **sentient beings** **awaken their wisdom**,
must rely on the **sage’s guidance**.
Thus the **sage** uses **pure and clear rational insight**,
**fully imparting** to the **common and ignorant** for instruction.

In the **sage’s nature of wisdom and penetration**,
there is **no depletion or waste**,
hence it is said: *"The more they give, the more they possess."*
The **annotation** states:
**Self-illumination** refers to **inherent clarity**,
**external illumination** refers to **wisdom gained from teaching**—
the **nature of insight**,
though not **originating from others**,
is said to be **self-illumination**.
The **benefit from teaching**,
not arising **from within themselves**,
is said to be **external illumination**.
Thus, the **sage’s instruction** of the **common and ignorant**,
**their wisdom grows ever clearer and more fluent**,
hence it is said: *"The more they teach, the more abundant their wisdom."*

**Master Gong of the He River** said:
When they give to others, their own **virtue/power grows**,
when they **impart virtue/power and dharma-transformations** to others,
their own **virtue/power and dharma-transformations** grow ever more abundant—
thus they **possess ever more virtue/power**.»

chunks.original_text: 既以与人己愈多，既以财贿布施与人，己财益多，如日月之光，无有尽时也。 ○严曰：无为之旨，尽以与人己益明，尽以与人己益寿矣。 ○成疏：既以与人己愈有，既，尽也。 为，施化也。 言己所有道德，尽特教人，而无鄙吝，德弥高远，故言愈有，此德施。 既以与人己愈多，所有财宝，尽特施散，而果报弥广，故云愈多。 此财施也。 第三总结上德，利物忘功。 天之道，利而不害。 御疏：天道施生，长养万物，利也。 无所宰割，不害也。 举喻欲明圣人之道弘益尔。 ○河上公曰：天生万物爱育之，令长大无所伤害也。 ○荣曰：天道施生利也，常善救人而不害也，争由心起，为因事生，圣人无心，自然无事，事既无事，为亦无为。 ○成疏：天然之道，生成万物，利益弘多，有何损害。 圣人之道，为而不争。 御疏：圣人之道，凡所作为，而与物不争者，圣人无所积滞，与人愈有，是以不争尔。 ○河上公曰：圣人法天，无所施为，化成事就，不与人争功名，故能全其圣功也。 ○成疏：圣人上德，法道虚通，施为至教，化被群品，谦以自牧，成功不居，推功於物，故言不争也。 道德真经玄德慕疏卷之二十竟
chunks.translated_text:
The **Dao** thus declares:
*"When one gives to others, one’s own abundance grows ever greater—
when one distributes wealth and treasures in alms,
one’s own wealth grows ever more abundant,
like the light of sun and moon,
endless without cessation."*

**Master Yan** said:
*"The principle of *wuwei* [non-action] is this:
The more one gives to others, the brighter one’s own virtue/power becomes,
the more one gives to others, the longer one’s own life endures."*

**Master Cheng’s commentary** said:
*"When one gives to others, one’s own virtue/power grows ever greater—
*ji*, meaning ‘exhaustively.’
*Wei*, meaning ‘to transform and bestow.’
It speaks of one’s inherent virtue/power and moral cultivation,
exhaustively imparted to teach others,
without miserliness or pettiness,
thus one’s virtue becomes ever more profound and vast—
this is *virtue-giving*.
When one gives to others, one’s own abundance grows ever greater—
all one’s wealth and treasures,
exhaustively dispersed in alms,
the fruit of one’s merit becomes ever broader—
this is *wealth-giving*."*

**A summary of the highest virtue:**
*"Benefiting others while forgetting one’s own deeds.*
The **Dao of Heaven** benefits without harming."*

**The Imperial Commentary** said:
*"The **Dao of Heaven** nourishes and sustains all things—
this is benefiting.
It takes nothing in return—
this is without harming.
This analogy illustrates how the **Sage’s Way** is vast and beneficial."*

**Master Gong of the He River** said:
*"Heaven nurtures and cherishes all things,
letting them grow great without injury."*

**Master Rong** said:
*"The **Dao of Heaven** benefits by giving life—
it constantly aids others without harm.
Strife arises from the mind,
and from actions born of desire.
The Sage has no mind,
thus naturally no affairs.
When affairs are without affairs,
action is *wuwei*."*

**Master Cheng’s commentary** said:
*"The natural **Dao** generates and nurtures all things,
its benefits vast and boundless—
what harm could there be?
The **Sage’s Way** acts without contention."*

**The Imperial Commentary** said:
*"The **Sage’s Way**—
whatever is done,
does not contend with others.
The Sage holds nothing back,
gives ever more to others—
thus, no contention."*

**Master Gong of the He River** said:
*"The Sage follows Heaven’s **Dao**,
takes no action of his own.
Transformation complete, deeds accomplished,
he does not contend for fame or merit—
thus his sagehood remains whole."*

**Master Cheng’s commentary** said:
*"The Sage’s highest virtue
follows the **Dao**, open and unobstructed,
his actions reaching even the lowest,
his transformation encompassing all ranks.
He guards himself with humility,
achieves success without claiming it,
attributing merit to others—
thus it is said, ‘without contention.’"*

*Thus concludes the twenty-second scroll of the* **Mysterious Virtue Commentary on the* Dao De Jing*.*
